The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

figure.p: CHIRURGERY According to the Moderne Practice Written by PAULE BARBETTE DOCTOR of Phyick & Practitioner at AMSTERDAM.

div.p: THESARS CHIRRGIAE: THE CHIRURGICAL and ANATOMICAL WORKS OF PAL BARBETTE, M. D. Practitioner at Amterdam. Compoed according to the Doctrine of the Circulation of the Blood, and other new Inventions of the Moderns.
Together with a Treatie of the PLAGUE, Illutrated with Obervations.
Tranlated out of Low-Dutch into Englih,
THE FOURTH EDITION.

To which is added the Surgeon's Chet, Furnihed both with Intruments and Medicines, all ueful: Illutrated with everal Copper-Plates: And to make it more compleat, is adioyned a Treatie of Dieaes that for the mot part attend Camps and Fleets.
Written in High-Dutch by Raymundus Minderius.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Rhodes, next door to the Swan-Tavern, near Bride-Lane, in Fleet-Street, 1687.

div.head: THE AUTHOR'S PREFACE TO THE JUDICIOUS READER.
div.p:
WHat hould be the cope of putting forth this my not ufficient Polihed Treatie, after o many Excellent and Learned Writings of Phyicians, the Title before will declare unto thee, viz. That my Deign was both out of the Ancient and Modern, to extract the very Marrow, and plainly to hew the bet way of Curing Dieaes belonging to Chirurgery: Therefore I have purpoed not to obtrude upon thee this or that Man's Fancy,
or Conceit, for Modern Practice: For who ever was o mad as to Embrace the Opinion of any one Region, City, or Man? Who ever, though mot ingenious and judicious, equally excelled in all the Parts of his Profeion? Seeing it hath not pleaed the Giver of all Arts to grant this perfectnes to Men: But I reolve to et down that Practice which Reaon and Experience, after a diligent Reading of the bet Authors, and an exact obervation of everal Operations, have Taught me to be the afet, convenientet and eaiet, for prolixity I have purpoely avoided, and ued not more words than only to expres the thing it elf. Nevertheles I have tudied to conprehend the Foundation of the Art in few Chapters. Read over all diligently, and let not what I purpoely
omitted trouble thee: Great Volumns eaily affright the Reader, as thoe that are too little betrays him: I have carefully endeavoured, what is hardly found, a mean; and therefore, I have rather in few words inerted my Obervations, in the very decriptions of the Dieaes, then to wate thy time with a prolix dicoure: To this end, that I might not repeat in particular Dieaes, what I had once et down in generals.

Tumors, Wounds, and lcers, which neither in Caue nor Cure differ, I have reduced under one Head, contrary to what mot Writers ue to do, who only from the difference of the Part and Member affected, difference the Dieaes, which aftewards giving them new names, they without any benefit multiply, and o
they render that Art which is difficult enough of it elf, much more difficult. The mot diligent of Students can carce ditinguih them, who unprofitably pend much labour and time, in the Controveries of the Ancients concerning the Name, whoe Opinions they uppoe they ought to follow to a Tittle, if they will arrive at the degree of Doctor. We are the Miniters of Nature, not the Slaves of thoe Men that decribe it: We account neither them Prophets, nor their Writings acred, neither unlawful to add, or diminih to them without the name Heretick.

I have et down both few, and many Medicaments; for thoe that I have produced, although few in number, yet of great vertue, which by vat pains, and no les charges I have found out, and which dayly
Practice hath confirmed to me, as the afet of all. Other Medicines eek for amongt others.

Farewel kind Reader, and whil't I am imployed about other, and better (if I can poible) Writings, receive thee with a grateful mind; and as I tudy to be profitable to thee, o alo do thou endeavour always by thee to help others..

div.head: BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Firt Part.
CHAP. I. Of Manual Operations in general.
div.p: ALthough the word Chirurgery ignifies all Manual Operations in general; yet, by reaon of its pre-eminence above all the ret, it is now only given to that Art, which endeavours to remove the Dieaes of the Body, by the aitance of the Hands.

'Tis true, that External Accidents require not only the help of the Hands, but alo Internal Means; therefore it is no wonder for a Part of Phyick to require the whole: Chirurgery being a Part, which depends upon the Body of Phyick: But thee internal Medicines we impart to you, not as Chirurgeons, but as Phyicians.
The General Operations of this Art, to which all the particular ones may be reduced, are of four orts:
1. Syntheis, which teacheth how to unite parts disjointed.
2. Diaereis, To eparate parts unnaturally joyned.
3. Exaereis, To remove what is uperfluous.
4. Anaplerois, To upply thoe that are wanting.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Syntheis or nition.
div.p: UNition is of two orts; one regards the Hard and Boney; the other the Soft and Flehy parts of the Body.
The Unition of Bones is again twofold; the one, etting Bones broken; the other, reducing Bones wrenched or dijointed. We will begin with Fractures.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Nature, Difference, Signs, Prognoticks and Cure of Fractures in general.
div.p: A Fracture is a Solution of Continuity in the hard parts of the Body, caued by an hard Intrument externally forced upon the part.

The Differences are taken, 1. From the Manner; there being ome tranvere, which are properly called Fractures; others that are made according to the length of the Bone, called Fiures: and others are Comminutions, when the Bone is
broken into many mall parts. 2. From the Part, it being ome times in the Head, ometimes in the Shoulders, Ribs, Arms, Legs, &c. 3. From the Accidents; there being ometimes a Wound accompanying it; at other times, a Dilocation, Inflamation, Gangrene, &c.
Caue] is, Whatever is able to break, bruie, or cut: Sometimes alo a Bone corrupted by the Pox, Gout, or otherwie, hath been broken without any external force.

Signs.] A Bone being tranverly or obliquely broke, by handling it, you perceive an inequality; the Patient is carce able to move the Part affected, and ometimes that Part is horter than the other; the Thigh, Leg or Foot being broken, the Patient cannot tand at all; but he may omewhat, though with pain, in a Dilocation: And this is the uret difference between a Fracture and a Dilocation. A Fiure is dicerned by the thicknes, pain and unevennes of the Part, and requireth the judgment of a skilful Chirurgion. A Comminution is eaie to be perceived, the Bone being very unequal, and here and there yielding to the Fingers.

Prognoticks] A Tranvere Fracture is more eaie to cure than an Oblique; or when accompanied with apparent Inequalities; that, where but one Bone is broken, than where two are, or where the Bones are much hattered; that, which ‚Ä¢ s made in the midt of the Bone, than what happens to be near the Head; and a ingle one, than a compound. If the Patient remain undreed beyond the eventh day, the Member is in danger of mortifying, epecially if that the Part be too ‚Ä¢ ard bound.
The Cure.] A broken Bone requires thee four Operations; Extention, Conjoining, Ligature, Well-placing; and withal, the application of outward and inward Remedies.

Extention can hardly be performed without pain; which yet will be much les, if the Member be o extended, that the Mucles do not labour; that is to ay, The Part mut be o laid, that when in health, they could hold out longet without tiring. Sometimes the extenion mut be greater, ometimes leer; which will be performed aright, if regard be had to the time of the Fracture, to the Age of the Patient, and to the greatnes of the Bone. A recent Fracture, a tender Patient, a mall Bone, require a gentler Extention: on the contrary, an old Fracture, a trong Patient, and a big Bone, a greater. The manner of extending I decribe not, becaue it is better learnt by the frequent view of Practice, than by Reading.
After Extention, you are to join the Bones together; in the doing of which, the Mucles mut not be wreted, but retain their natural poition and figure.

Then the Part mut be bound with a double Rowler; the firt is to be rowled thrice about the Fracture, and then upwards. The (econd (which mut be twice as long) is to be once wound about the Fracture, proceeding downwards, and then upwards again, a little higher than the firt Rowler; to which you will give more firmnes, if you bind ome convenient Splints (of Wood, or rather of Pat-board) round about the Member.

The Ligature ought not to be too trait, let it
caue pain, and rob the Part of its nourihment; nor too looe, let the Bones lip out of their place. And unles great pain, or other ymptoms require, it mut not be opened before the third day; and at the econd dreing, it mut be bound omewhat cloer; and afterwards changed but once every four, five or ix dayes.

Latly, The Part ought to be well placed, that is, oftly, evenly, and a little raied. If you lay it too low, the Bone will bend outwards; if too high, it will bend inwards: Wherefore you mut oberve a mean.
Now, whether thee four Operations have been duly performed, may be known by the enuing Signs.
The Extention is well done, if the part be trait, and as long as its fellow; if it appear to outward view every where even, and a little hollow about the Fracture.
The joining together is duly made, if the Bone be any thing firm, and all about the Fracture be found equal.

The Ligature is as it ought to be, if the Patient, as oon as he is dreed, find the pain abated; if the pain do omewhat encreae the firt and econd night, and there be perceived the third day, without the place of binding, a little welling yielding to your hands.
The Bone is well placed, if in the econd dreing you find all even.

Before you rowl the Ligature about the Member, bathe the part with Spirit of Wine or Red Wine; or, with Oyl, Wine and Vinegar mix'd together; Or, take the White of an Egg,
with ome Bolus, Frankincene, Dragons-Blood, &c. Or anoint it with Oyl of Roes, Mirtles, Violets, &c. or lay Plaiters on it. In Winter, the Oxycroceum will do well: At all times that which follows;

Take Matick, Frankincene, of each two drams, Aloes, Gum Tragacanth, Dragons-Blood, Bole-Armonick, of each a one dram; Lapis Haematitis, Burnt Talch, of each one dram; Whites of Eggs, and Oyl of Roes, as much as is ufficient. Make it into a Plaiter.

If a Wound accompany the Fracture, then ought you to extend the Part firt (yet omewhat gentler than in a imple Fracture) then you are to join the Bones together; next, to oberve the Wound, to bring the Lips thereof together with Plaiters, rather than with a Needle, and to guard it with a Defenive: And latly, rowl the Part, and lay it conveniently.

If there be a Cominution, or great hattering of the Bones joined with the Wound, then endeavour with Forceps to remove the mall looe Bones, leaving thoe to Nature that are yet any way fixed; for he will, though omewhat later, of her elf throw them out; and ometimes he will unite them again to the whole. Yet, to forward her, you may ait Nature with the following Medicaments.
Take Ahes of Earth-worms, three drams; Virgins-Honey, an ounce and half, mix them, and make an Oyntment.
Or,

Take Aloes, Myrrhe, of each half a dram; Roots of Comfrey the great, Round-Birthwort, of each three drams, Euphorbium, two drams;
Turpentine and Wax, as much as is ufficient, with a little Oyl of Lillies, to make it into an Oyntment.
If the Bone be bare, cover it with its own skin and Nucles, and defend it from the Air as much as is poible.
If it be bare and alo tarted out, endeavour to reduce it again into its place; but if it be got out too far, take away the pieces thus tarted out, with Saw or Nippers.

Now thee Manual Operations being well performed, the Patient mut oberve a good Diet; open a Vein upon occaion, and afterwards purge the Blood. In the Fractures of the lower parts, purging is not convenient; but if the Patients Belly be bound, he mut take a Suppoitory.

In the Fractures of the upper parts, Purging or adminitring Clyters, is oftner neceary, and may be done by the enuing compounded or imple Medicines, which may alo erve you in all other Accidents that we may decribe in this whole Treatie.

div.head: Medicines purging Choler.
div.p: Rhubarb, Caia fitula, yellow Myrobalans,
Tamarinds, Manna, Scammony, Syrup of Sicchory, with Rhubarb, Elect. Catholicum, Hiera picra, Lenitivum, Diaprunum olutivum, & Succus Roarum, Pil. de Aloe Roata, Aureae, Aloephanginae, Ruffi.

Take Electuary Lenitive, two drams; Elect. of the Juice of Roes, one dram; Caia freh extracted, two drams; Cream of Tartar, two cruples; Succory-water, as much as is ufficient; Spirit of Vitriol, a little. Make it into a Potion.
Or,

Take Rhubarb, Senna, of each two drams; Cream of Tartar, one dram; Anieeds, half a dram: Infue them two hours in a ufficient quantity of Sorrel-Water, let it boil a little, and to three ounces of the trained Liquor,
Add of the
Elect. of Diaprun. Sol. one dram, or a dram and half, and drink it.
Or,
Take of Pilulae Aureae, Extract. Catholicum, Rhubarb, of each half a cruple. Make them into even Pills.
Or.
Take Cream of Tartar, Sal Prunella, of each xij grains; vitriolated Tartar, Diagredium, of each vj. grains. Make it into a Powder.

div.head: Medicines that purge Phlegm.
div.p: The Roots of Aarum, Mechoacan white and black, Hellebore, Colocinth, Myrabolani, Belliric, Emblici, Chebuli, Agarick, Turbith, Syrup of Diacarthanum, Electuaries of Hierae with Agarick, Diaphoenicon, Diacarthamum, Confection of Hamech, Powder of Diaturbith, Pills of Cechiae, Foetidae the greater, Aggregativae, Lucis the greater, Aajeret of Avicen, Troches of Agaric, Alhandal.

Take Roots of Gras, two drams; Flower-de-luce, Trochicatum, Agarick, Turbith, of each one dram; Anieeds, Fenel eeds, of each one cruple: Let them infue for three hours in a ufficient quantity of Pary water; boil it, and train it; and to three ounces of it,
Add of
Electuary of Diaphenicon, one dram and half. Make it into a Potion.
Or,
Take Electuary of Diacarthamum, Confection of Hamech, of each two drams; powder of Jalop; eight grains; Cream of Tartar, two cruples, Fennel water, as much as ufficeth. Make a Potion.
Or,
Take of Pill Aureae, ix grains; of Pill Cochiae, Pill Faetidae the greater, of each twenty grains. Make them into even Pills, and gild them.
Or,
Take Extract of Catholicum, xiij grains; of the Troches of Alhandal, one grain. Make three Pills, and gild them.

div.head: Medicines purging Melancholy.
div.p: Roots of black Helebore, Polipody, Senna, Lapis Lazuli, Syrup of Roes olutive with Senna, Electuaries of Diacatholicon lenitive, Confection of Hamech. The Powder of Dia Senna, Pills of Lucis minoris, Troches of Alhandal, Myrobalans of India.

Take Bark of Tamarisk, three drams; Roots of Polypody, two drams; Staechas Flowers, half a pugil; Senna, one dram and half; Anieeds, half a dram; Mirobolans of India, one dram: Infue them two hours in a ufficient quantity of Borage-water; boyl it, and train it; and to four ounces of the trained Liquor,
Add,
An ounce of Syrup of Roes with Senna, Spirit of Salt, as much as will give it a little acidity; and make it into a Potion.
Or,

Take Electuary of Diacatholicon, one dram; the Electuary of Diaphoenicon, Confection of Hamech, of each a dram and half; Cream of Tartar, two cruples; Powder of Jalop, ix grains; Whey, a ufficient quantity. Make a Potion.
Or,
Take of Pill Indiae, of Aggregativae the greater, of each fifteen grains: Diagridium, three grains; Troches of Alhandal, one grain. Make even Pills, and gild them.
Note, All thee Receipts are et down for full-grown Bodies, their quantities being to be leen'd according to the younger age, and trength of the Patient.

div.head: CHAP IV. Of particular Fractures of Bones.
div.p: THe Fractures of the Skull are divided into ix everal kinds; A Fiure, Contuion, Fracture, Inciion, Puncture and Contra fiure.
A Fiure is made by a hard and blunt Intrument, and paeth ometimes through both Tables, ometimes through one only.

A Contuion is made, when by a hard and blunt Intrument the Skull is o hurt, that it appears whole from without, but yet is ever'd from the
whole within: Which yet in little Children may be done without a Fracture.
A Fracture is made, when a part of the Skull is eparated from the whole.

An Inciion is made by a cutting Intrument; where ometimes one part of the Bone is rais'd up and eparated, as it were, but is yet fat to the ret of the Bone; ometimes a part is quite taken away; ometimes there remains a mark in the Bone according to the Figure of the Intrument.
A Puncture is made by a pungent or thruting Intrument, and eldom paeth through both Tables.
A Contra-fiure is made, when the part truck remaining whole, the oppoite part is cleft.

The Signs are, Swimming of the Head, dimnes of the Eyes, Vomiting, Bleeding at the Mouth, Noe and Ears. The Patient grows dumb, and uddenly falls to the ground: whereupon follows Raving, a Feaver, Convulions, Palie. Any hard thing, as a piece of Wood, a Spoon, &c. being put into his Mouth, he is not at all, or hardly able to bite upon it. Here it mut alo be carefully enquired, in what manner, and with what Intrument he hath been hurt? Whether he be young or old, tender or trong, healthy or unhealthy? Preently after the Fall or Stroke, before the Part wells, you may ometimes feel the hurt with your Fingers; and if there be a Wound with it, you may either ee it, or find it out with a Probe.

Prognoticks.] The Fractures of the Skull, how fair oever they may look, is never without danger, but more dangerous, when both the Tables are hurt or broken; and more dangerous
yet, if the Dura Mater, and mot dangerous, if the Pia Mater be alo hurt. The more Symptoms there are, the les hope of a good event. If the Bone grow black in the beginning, that is a mortal Sign.

Cure.] If the Skin be yet whole, or the wound not large enough, make a cros inciion, and divide the Pericranium. If under it you find a fiure, put ome Ink into it, and bind up the wound. The econd day, or as oon as the bleeding is ceaed, crape the Skull at once, or at everal times, until the Ink with the Fiure is altogether gone, and the Bone grow omewhat bloody, then throw the enuing Powder upon it.
Take Dragons Blood, burnt Harts-horn, of each one dram and half; Myrrhe half a dram; Frankincene, and Orrie roots, of each a dram; Make it into a very fine Powder.
If the Fiure pas through both Tables, then are you to make ue of Trepanning; as likewie in the Contra-fiure, Fracture and Contuion of the Skull, or ele you will quickly loe your Patient.
The Inciion is healed like the Fiure.
In the Puncture you mut put the Trepan jut in the middle, and not on the ides of the place hurt.

If you find a Fracture with a Cominution, then take out all the mall looe Bones, committing to Nature thoe that are yet fat to the Pericranium, or cannot be taken away without force. And then if the Fracture be o large, that you can free the Brains from the coagulated or corrupted Blood, or from the pricking Bones, Trepanning will be needles; but if it hould happen otherwie,
you mut, with great care, apply the Trepan, unles the Patient be trong, and the matter very little. The manner of Trepanning will be taught in another place.

2. In a Fracture of the Noe, what is raied, is to be preed down; and what is preed inward, to be raied with a Spatule, or other Intrument: afterwards a Pipe or Quill is to be put up, and continually kept there, till the Cure be done, and a Fracture-Plaiter is to be laid on without. If the Bone be not corrupted, it will be healed in ten or twelve days.

3. A broken Jaw-bone is retored by ones fingers ued both within and without the Mouth; and if thoe be too weak, then one is to draw the Head backward, and the Chirurgeon forward, and o to put it in. It is cured in twenty days.

4. The Clavicle being broken, there mut be one to draw the Arm backward, and another to draw the Neck or Shoulder forward; the Chirurgeon himelf, in the mean time, drawing upwards what was fallen down, and downwards what was raied too high. If a Ball be put into the Arm-pit, and the Elbow be preed againt the Ribs, the Operation will prove more eaie. It is cured in twenty four days.

5. If the Shoulder-Blade be broken about the place where it is united to the Arm, then is the hurt for the mot part incurable. If it break in the Acromion (which may be eaily felt) then let the Arm or Shoulder be pulled down, either with Hands or Ligatures, and in the mean time et it in. If it be broken into everal pieces, make an Inciion, and take them out, unles they be yet fat to the Peri-etium; in which cae, you mut leave
Nature to her elf, which will either make them unite again, or throw them out. It is healed in forty days.

6. The Sternum, or Breat-bone happens either to be broken, and then you'll find an unevennes, which being toucht, will yield to the Fingers, and caue ome cracking; or to be preed in, and then you'll feel a bending inwards, which will caue pain, a hort breath, coughing and pitting blood. To retore the ame, lay the Patient on his Back upon a great tone, preing both his Shoulders downwards; then pres the Ribs backward and forward, until the Bone be reduced again in its right place. This is cured in twenty days.

7. A imple Fracture of the Ribs, which is without any great Contuion, or Inflamation of the neighbouring parts, may be healed in twenty days, applying the Fracture-Plaiter. If the Ribs tand out, they mut with ones Hand be preed in. If they bend inward, let the Patient keep in his Breath, and o pres the Rib outward; in the mean time, aiting him with your hand. If that ucceed not, then lay a ticking Plaiter upon it, and pull the ame off o often, until the Rib return into its place. Cupping-Glaes here are of no ue.

8. A imple Fracture of the Joynts of the Backbone is eaily et again with ones finger, and is made whole in twenty days. But if the Marrow of the Back-bone be o hurt or preed in, that the Arms or Legs of the Patient become lame or eneles, that he cannot retain his Urine, or his Excrement, then he eldom ecapeth death. Yet you are to do your utmot; and if one or more
mall Bones be altogether looe from the Periotium, then make Inciion, and take them out.
9. The ame is to be undertood of the Fracture of the Os acrum, which alone hath this peculiar, that you may put your fingers into the Anus, and retore it to its right place.

10. The Hip-bone being broken, is to be et as oon as poible may be, and then it will heal in twenty four days; otherwie you may expect various accidents. But if it be fractured into many pieces, then you are forthwith, in the firt dreing, to make an Inciion; take out the mall Splinters, and re-place thoe that have yet any hold-fat. Yet, by reaon of the multitude of the Tendons, Mucles, Veins, Arteries and Nerves, that are pread over the whole part, uch an Inciion cannot be made without great danger.

11. If the upper-Bone of the Arm be broken, firt bend the Elbow toward the Breat, then take the lower part of that Bone cloe to the Elbow, pulling it traight down towards the ground, and o retore it; well oberving here, that the Arm, during the whole time of Cure, mut remain in that poture in which it was extended; otherwie the Fracture will, upon the leat change of its poture, lip out again. Where yet 'tis to be undertood, that the Chirurgeon after the econd or third dreing, as often as after that he dreeth the Patient, mut tretch out his Arm trait, to the end that the Tendons which run from the Arm, and are inerted below the Elbow, hrinking by the long lying till, may not caue a troubleome tiffnes. However, this hrinking of Tendons (which are by pretenders to
Chirurgery, ridiculouly call'd Nerves) may yet conveniently be cured in two or three months, if you make the Patient to carry every day ome weight, and endeavor to relax and mollifie the Tendons with Fomentations and Embrocations, abtaining from the ue of any Brandy, or any other corroborating and atringent Medicines. I have always found uccesful the following Unguent.
Take Man's and Duck's Greae, of each one ounce; Oyntment of Marh-mallows, half an ounce; Oyl of Earth-worms, white Lilly, and Camomile, of each two drams. Make an Oyntment.
This broken Bone is cured in forty days. The retoring of the broken Thigh-bone, hath nothing different from this.

12. The Elbow hath two Bones; of which, the greater is called Radius, the leer Ulna; both Fociles: The mall Focile being broken, 'tis eaie to retore it. The Cure is harder, when the great one is broken; and yet harder, when both are broken: In which cae, the extention is to be made the tronger. When they be well et, and bound up, then mut the hand be placed a little higher upon the Chet than the Elbow; and afterwards, every econd or third day (without pain or violence) the Arm is gently to be tretch'd out, to the end that the Humors flowing thither, and there taying too long, may not caue a concretion in the Bones, and a tiffnes in the Arm, as not extenible any more. It is cured in thirty days.
13. The Leg hath alo two Bones, the greater called Tibia, and the leer Fibula. Their Cure had nothing different from the next foregoing.

14. If the Patella, or Knee-pan, break crosways,
the Patient commonly remains lame. If it break long-ways, then by the Mucles that draw upwards, without any great help of the hands, it is almot of it elf retored, and cured in twenty days.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Nature, Difference, Signs, Caues, Prognoticks, and Cure of Dilocations in general.
div.p: A Dilocation is a forcing of the Bone out of its cavity and natural place into another, hindering voluntary motion.

The Differences are taken, 1. From the manner; for ometimes the Bone is altogether forced out of its place, and that is properly called Luxation or Dilocation: Sometimes it is got out but a little or half, which is called Sub-laxation, or Elongation. 2. From the Caue; for ometimes it is from an external accident, as by wretlings, Falls, or Blows, &c. Sometimes from internal Caues, by the afflux of Humors.

The Caues are of two orts; 1. External, Such as are Falling, Beating, Running, Wretling, and vehement extention, as it often happens to Women in Labour, through the unskilfulnes of Midwives; yea, by a violent troke or fall, even the Bones of the Infant in the Womb, may be dilocated. 2. Internal, By the afflux of Humors, which falling into the Joints, relax and reolve the Ligaments, and o caueth the Bones to lip out of their places.

The Signs, epecially in a lean Body, are manifet enough. The Bone caueth in the place to which it is forced, a tumor or riing; and in that whence it is forced, a cavity. If there be a perfect Dilocation, the Member will be drawn up, and horter (unles the luxation happen by the laxity of the Ligaments, than it becomes longer) the part is painful, chiefly upon motion. In a Subluxation, thee Accidents are leer, and eldom all together.

Prognoticks.] In Children and other tender Bodies, the Bones may be reduced more eaily; but are kept in with more difficulty; the contrary happens in trong and full grown perons: The Dilocation of the Head is mortal, that of the Vertebra's dangerous; and that which is inveterate is hard to be cured. That which proceeds from an inward Caue, is of a lower Cure, and does eaily return.

Cure.] The Bone forced out, mut be reduced to its place, either by the Hands, Ligatures, or Intruments; but by which of thee three it hall be performed, the Nature of the affected part will declare. 'Tis certain, that thee four Manual Operations (Extention, Setting, Binding and Well-placing) mut here be ued as well as in Fractures of Bones.

Extention mut be made o great, that there may be a cavity between the Bone that remains well, and that which hath been forced away, to the end that in the etting, the one may not rub againt the other; whence afterwards are wont to rie very grievious, and ometimes incurable Accidents.

In the Setting, care mut be had not to wret the
Bones nor the Mucles, but to keep their natural figure. Before you proceed to binding up the Member, endeavour to preerve the part from inflammation and flux of Humors, and trengthen it with the following Medicines.

div.head: A trengthening Plater.
div.p: Take Frankincene, Matick, Bole-armonick, Dragons-Blood, of each half an ounce; fine-Flower, an ounce; Roots of great Comfrey, two drams; Weather-Sewet, three ounces; white-Wax, as much as ufficeth to make a Plaiter.
Another.

Take Litharge, Wax, Roin, of each three ounces; being melted over the fire, add to them, of great Comfrey, Bean-Meal, Bole-armonick teeped in Vinegar, and dried, of each three ounces; Tragacanth, two ounces. Make it into a Plaiter.

If the pain, or other ymptoms do not necearily require it, you ought not to looen the Bandage before the fifth, ixth, or eventh day, and then do it with as little motion as is poible. Latly, lay the Part even, and in uch a poture, in which, when found, it can longet remain without trouble.

If you find the Dilocation accompanied by an Inflammation, beware of extending the part, or doing ought to it before that be removed; which you are to do, firt with emollient, and afterwards with dicutient, Medicines.

div.head: An Emollient Unguent.
div.p:
Take the compound Ointment of Marh-mallows,
two drams; Hogs-greae, half an ounce; Oyl of white-Lillies, Roes and Mirtles, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Linament.

div.head: A Dicutient Plaiter.
div.p: Take Colophony, Frankincene, Matick, Pitch of each an Ounce; Cummin-eeds, Fennel-eeds, of each ix drams; Wax and Oyl of Dill, as much as ufficeth. Mix them, and make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of particular Dilocations.
div.p: 1. THe Jaw-bone, except it be in young Children, can hardly be dilocated otherwie than forwards. Sometimes it is only dilocated in one ide, and is eaily retored; ometimes in both, in which cae it is difficult to et, and very dangerous, and often mortal.

It is very eldom luxated from a debility of the Mucles; ometimes from the laxity of the Ligaments; for the mot part, from a too wide opening of the Mouth. If it be dilocated but on one ide, it tands a-skew, and is turned towards the ide hurt; ome thing is prominent, the Teeth tand not directly under one another, nor can they be brought together, o that the Mouth remains open. You mut draw it towards the oppoite ide, and reduce it to its place, which is not hard to do; yea, by a tiff box on the Ear it hath often been retored.

If it be dilocated on both ides, then does it fall forwards, the Mouth tands open, both the Apophyes are prominent, the lower Teeth tand further than the upper, and the temporal Mucles are ditended. In this cae, let yout Servant hold the Patient's Head firm, or hold it againt a Wall; draw the Jaw-bone firt downward, putting both your Thumbs in the Mouth, then backward, and latly upward.

2. The Collar-bone rarely happens to be luxated, and is eldom et, but it tands omewhat out; whereby it often comes to pas, that the Patient cannot lift up his hand to his mouth, much les to his head. For retoring it, you are to lay the Patient on his back, and a tone under his houlder; then you mut draw his Arm forward and backward, as the Dilocation requires; then pres the Clavicle, o raied, down into its place.

3. The Great Bone of the Arm (Adjutorium) is never dilocated backward; eldom upwards and forwards, but for the mot part downward: a certain ign of it is, if you find it roundih hardnes under the Arm-pits, and on the top of the Shoulder a hollownes, and the Arm be longer, and the Patient cannot bring his hand to his Mouth. It may be reduced everal ways; but thee are the mot convenient, and the mot ure. 1. Let a trong man hold the Patient fat about the hurt Shoulder, and let another draw the Arm downwards; then lift the upper part of the Arm into its Cavity, and the Bone will be oon retored into its place. 2. Take a trong Ladder, at the foot thereof put a ‚Ä¢ tool for the Patient to tand upon; on the uppermot
tep, bind omething round that may jut fit the Arm-pits; put the Patients Arm upon it, and draw it downward, moving the Shoulder-bone to and fro; let your Servant, mean while, draw the ound Arm downward, and withal, thrut away the Stool from under the Patient, that whilt he is thus pendulous, the Shoulder-bone may be retored. 3. Lay the Armpits of the Patient upon the Shoulder of a trong and taller man than himelf; draw the dilocated Arm downward, o that he lifting up his own Shoulder, the Patient may remain in a pendulous poture: In the mean time, pres his Shoulder downward, working the Arm to and fro, until it be retored to its due place. 4. The Glooc ‚Ä¢
mium decribed by Hyppocrates, and approved by Paraeus, is the mot convenient of all; to be een in the Authors themelves.

4. If the Vertebrae of the Neck be out of joint, the Patient is to be et upon a little low Stool, and his Shoulders preed downward. After this, his Head is to be lifted up with both hands, turning it to and fro (yet with as little force as may be) and thus they are to be reduced. Whereupon the Patient will preently find himelf at eae, and turn his head whithe ‚Ä¢ he pleaeth.

5. If the Vertebrae of the Back be forced outwards, the Patient is to be laid upon his Belly and by two Men and two Ligatures, one tied under the Arm-pits, the other about the Hip he mut be trongly tretched out, and the Ve ‚Ä¢
tebroe's be thrut in again. If they be forced i ‚Ä¢
wards, it is mortal.

6. If the Os acrum be out of joint, put you ‚Ä¢
fingers into the Anus, and pres it from within as well as from without, into its place.

7. A Rib dilocated, mut not remain long out of its place, let more grievous Accidents follow. If it be removed out of its Vertebra upwards, then hang the Patient by his Arms over a Door, and o pres it in. If it be out of joint downward, the Patient mut bend himelf, laying his hands upon his Knees, and the Chirurgeon in the mean time, mut move to and again the diplaced Rib till it be retored to its right place. If it be dilocated inward, lay a ticking Plaiter on it, and often pull it away with violence; and thus ometimes it may be retored; if not, it often proveth mortal, not being capable to be reduced by the Hands.

8. The Cubitus may be dilocated forward or backward, inward or outward. And ometimes the Radius is likewie dilocated with it, ometimes it remains in its place; which by handling the part, is eaily perceived. If the Cubitus be out forwards, the Arm thereby becomes horter, & cannot be bent; the Bone tands out forwards, and behind there is a preternatural hallownes. The forcedout Bone mut, as well in this, as in all other kinds of dilocation of the Elbow, be peedily retored; otherwie there will follow grievous Pain, Inflammation, Feaver, Vomiting of Choler, and ometimes Death it elf. Let the Arm be extended obliquely, and o far, that one Bone may not hurt the other in the etting. If the Hands be not trong enough, then bend the dilocated Arm about a Pillar or a Bed-pot, and by the help of a Bandage extend it, preing the Bone backward, until it be replaced. If it be dilocated back-ward, the Arm will then alo be horter, and
cannot be bent, the Bone will tand out behind; and before there is a preternatural cavity. If it be inward or outward, there are the like igns; only the Tumor will be in the place, to which the Bone hath been forced; whereas the hollownes is there, whence it hath been forced. All thee three dilocations may be eaily cured by a convenient Extention, if they be not inveterate. The ame is to be undertood of the Radius, when forced out of its place.

9. The Hip may be put out of joint four manner of ways chiefly; inward, outward and forward, but eldom backward. If inward, the Leg is longer, and moveth with difficulty; the Knee is turned outward, and the head of the Thigh-bone by the hands may be perceiv'd in the Groin. As it is difficult to put in, o eaily doth it lip out again, whereby the Part affected is wated, and the Patient lamed. To reduce it to its place, lay the Patient upon the midt of a Bench or Table; between his Legs put a trong tick, wound about with Linnen, and upon it let him tifly tretch out his Leg, and the Chirurgeon in the mean time with his hands et it. If outwardly dilocated, the Leg grows horter, and the Foot is turned inwards. The Patient can then indeed bend his Leg, but hardly bring it to the ground. Though it be not et aright, yet the pain vaniheth of it elf, and the Patient in time is able to go without Crutches. Lay him on a Bench or Table as above; let the Leg be trongly extended, either with hands or Bandage, and mean while reduce it into its place. If the Hip be forced out forward, the Groin is woln, and the Buttocks fallen, the Leg is neither longer nor horter, nor
cannot be bent but with trouble; and the Urine is uppreed. Though it be not et aright, yet the Patient in time will be able to go well enough upon it; though ometimes it falls out, that he mut omewhat trail his Leg after him. To retore it, let the Patient lie on his ound ide, and trongly tretch out his Leg, pres it into its former place; and in cae the hand be too weak, thrut it in with your Knee. If it be dilocated backward, the Patient can neither tretch out, nor bend his Leg, nor is he able to bring his Heel to the ground, and if he hould force himelf to do o, he would fall backward; the Leg is horter, there is a hollowles in the Groins, and if the Buttocks be preed upwards, you hall find an unuual welling. Though it be not put in, yet the pain will in time vanih, and then the Leg may be bent again, but it remains horter and traight, nor is the Foot turned inward nor outward. Lay the Patient on his Belly, and trongly extend his Leg; mean time apprehend the Thigh bone above the Knee; tretch it outward from off the ound Leg; pres the Head into its Cavity, in which yet it will not tay, if thenceforth the Patient do not keep himelf very quiet.
10. The Dilocations of the Tibia and Fibula, are cured after the ame manner as thoe of the Cubitus and Radius.

11. If the Knee pan be out of its place, let the Patient tand upright, and pres it in again; lay on the ide whence it hath been forced away, a hollow Splint, anwerable to the hape of the aid Pan, and below in the cavity of the Leg, put one or more compreing Splints, binding the whole Leg o tiff, that the Knee may not bend.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Ruptures.
div.p: HAving thus roughly handled the boney and hard parts of the Body, it now follows, that I treat the oft and flehie more gently, and decribe their Syntheis or re-unition again. Therefore I begin with the broken Peritonaeum, which ometimes gives way to the Intetines, at other times to the Cawl, and not eldom to both, to get out of their natural place into the Groins or Scrotum, there cauing a Rupture called Entorocele, or Hernia Intetinalis, if the Guts come out; an Epiplocele, or Hernia Omentalis, if the Omentum or Cawl be out.

The Peritonaeum is made up of two trong, but oft Membranes, which do o contain whatoever is included in the Belly or lowet Cavity, that when ound, nothing can fall out. In Women, the Os Pubis is its utmot Limit. In Men, its outermot Membrane reaches farther; and contitutes the firt proper Coat of the Teticles. In the Groins, it comprehends the Seminal Veels as in a Sheath, called Proceus, or Productio Peritonaei. This being tretch'd, or enlarged, or coming to burt, is the proximate caue to the lately mentioned Ruptures. The Groins therefore are the uual places of Ruptures: But do not imagine, that the Peritonoeum cannot be ditended or burt in other places, and there to caue a Rupture. It happens ometimes above the Navel, yet eldom: Beneath, and on the ide of the Navel, far
above the Groins, I have not only een it often, with many others, but een it ordered and dreed jut like an Abces; the Chirurgeon giving no other reaon for his mitake, than that it was not the place of Ruptures; which thoe that love the Art and their own Honour, may take notice of.

Mot times the Ileon falls down, yet ometimes the other Guts come out with it, and fall into the Scrotum; which cannot come to pas by a imple ditention of the aboveaid proces, but that necearily in all uch great Ruptures it mut be broken.

The Caues which make the Peritonaeum to burt or to dilate, are Falling, Leaping, Blows, bearing of heavy Burdens, trong Vomiting or Coughing, difficult going to Stool, Winds retained, and all vehement Motions of the Body.

Signs.] The Tumor is ometimes bigger, ometimes leer, ometimes altogether vaniht, but with the leat Motion returning. Though the Caul or Intetines hould be fallen down never o much, they may eaily, without any pain, be thrut in again, unles Wind or Excrement hinder it, in which cae the Rupture is very painful.

If the Intetines be full of Wind, the whole belly is tene; you may hear a noie, and the Patient breaks Wind upwards and downwards. If the Excrements be grown hard, the Patient goes with difficulty to Stool, and the welling, weight and hardnes, little by little encreaeth. If the Peritonaeum be only relaxed and widened, then the Tumor from little becomes bigger by degrees; but if it be broken, it uddenly decends.

Prognoticks.] In little Children, Ruptures are eaily cured; in aged people, lowly or not at all, epecially if the Peritonaeum be burt. If
the Intetines be filled with Wind or Excrements, there follows pain; and if that be not uddenly removed, an Inflamation, Gangrene, and at lat Death it elf.

Cure.] Lay the Patient on his Back with his Legs on high, and a little aunder, by which it often comes to pas, that the Caul or the Intetines return of themelves into their former place; but that not happening, pres them in gently with your fingers. And if you cannot effect this, by reaon of Wind or hardened Excrements, then ue the following Medicines.

div.head: Where the Excrements are indurated,
div.p: Take Roots of Marh-mallows, two ounces: of white Lillies, one ounce; Leaves of Mallows, Violets, Pellitory of the Wall, of each half a handful; Flowers of Camomile and Melilot, of each two pugils; Bran, half a handful: Boil them in Water, and to the Liquor,
Add of
Barly and Bean-meal, of each three ounces; Lin-eed and Fenugreek, of each two drams; Oyl of Roes and white Lillies, Ducks-Fat, and Hens Fat, of each an ounce. Make it into Cataplam.

In cae this Cataplam be not ufficient, or eems not to be o, then bathe the Patient two or three hours in Oyl, weet Milk, or Water, wherein Emollients have been boyled; not forgetting in the mean time Clyters and Purges.

div.head: Againt Wind.
div.p:
Take Oyl of Camomile, Rue, of each one
ounce; Oyl of Nard and Dill, of each three drams; Spirit of Wine, two drams; a little Wax: Make it into an Oyntment.
Another,

Take Oyl of Wormwood, one ounce; Oyl of Nard and Nutmeg expret, of each half an ounce: Oyl of Mace and Carraways ditilled, of each one dram; Malmey, an ounce and half: Boil it a little, then add to it as much Wax as is ufficient to make it into an Ointment.
Inwardly ue the eeds of Anie, Fenel, Carraways, and others Medicines dipelling Wind; which alo are to be mixt in the peculiar Clyters requiite to this purpoe.
Alo the Cumin Plaiter ued by ome, may here do good ervice.
Or,
Take the Styptick Plaiter of Crollius, Gum-Caranna, Tacamahac, of each half a dram; Ol. Philoophorum, and Carraways ditilled, of each an ounce: Make it into a Plaiter.

Thee impediments being thus removed, and the Caul or Intetines reduced to their place; you mut then with convenient Bands or Trues o long keep them in, until the burt Peritonaeum be o firmly grown, either together again, or to the Mucles of the Belly, that nothing can fall out of it any more. And this you will the ooner obtain, if you outwardly lay on it the following Plaiter, and inwardly ait Nature with appropriated Medicines. But here remember, that in old Ruptures, and aged People, the edges of the burt Peritonaeum are ometimes callous, that how fitly oever they are brought together, yet they can never grow together; and
in that cae Bands mut do the bet; but in young Children they eaily grow together; and here Trues are better than the bet Bands: Thoe that are not acquainted with them, mut confult thoe that are.

div.head: A Plaiter for a Rupture.
div.p: Take Roots of the great Comfrey, Bitort, of each an ounce and half; Round Birthwort, two drams; Galls, Cypres-Nuts, Pomegranate-Rinds, of each one dram and half; Flowers of Balautians, Red-Roes, Oak-Leaves, of each half a dram; Aloes, Dragons-Blood, Acacia, Earth-worms dried, Frankincene, Matick, Myrrhe, Sarcocols, Mummy, of each one dram; Pitch, Colophony, Burnt-Talch, of each one dram; Lytharge, Bole-Armonick, Lap. Hematitis, prepared Steel, of each one cruple; Venice-Turpentine, as much as is ufficient to make a Plaiter.

div.head: An Apozem, that the Patient may take five ounces two or three time a day.
div.p: Take Omund-Royal, Rupture wort, of each one handful; Roots of the great Comfrey, Bitort of each one ounce and half; St. Johns-wort Flowers, one handful; Anieeds, two drams; Boyl them in Red-Wine, and to a pint and half of the trained Liquor,
Add,
Of the Syrup of Comfrey of Fernelius, two ounces: Make it an Apozem.

div.head: Pills that the Patient may take five or ix of, mornings and evenings.
div.p: Take Mummy, one dram; Galbanum diolved in Vinegar, two drams; Myrrhe, Filings of Steel, dried Hares-Dung, of each half a dram; Powder of Earth-Worms, two cruples: Make them into Pils about the bignes of a great Peae.

If by a Wound, the Caul or Intetines come out, you are to endeavour to put them in again, before they loe their natural warmth or colour by the Air, otherwie there will remain but mall hopes of recovery.

If the Intetines be wounded, then with a waxed Thread titch the Lips together, and with a gentle hand return it into the Body; as alo the Omentum lipt out, unles it hould have lot its natural colour and warmth; in which cae, you mut tie it in the place where it is ound, cutting off the part that is putrid, and reduce it into the Belly, leaving the Thread hanging out of the Wound, that after Suppuration, it may be conveniently fetcht out.

And then you mut titch together the Wound of the Belly and the Peritonaeum, which is to be done after this manner; Take a Needle, thred it with a Waxen Thread, thrut it from without through the Skin and Mucles unto the very Peritonaeum; leaving it on this ide untoucht, but lay hold on it on the other ide; pierce it through, and the Mucles and the Skin alo, drawing the Lips together; then paing over the pace of an inch, thrut in the Needle on the ame ide again, on which you drew it out lat, through the Skin
and Mucles, leaving again the Peritonaeum on the ame ide untoucht, but holding it on the other ide, thrut it through together with the Skin and Mucles, and o on: Then eeing that by reaon of the continual motion of the Belly, your titches may be eaily undone, the rather, becaue the hate, ometimes here to be ued, will not permit to make them with Exactnes, it is always neceary to apply to the Wound a ticking-Plaiter.

Among thee Ruptures is to be reckoned the Navel-Rupture (called Exomphalos, or Hernia Umbilicalis) which proceeds from the ame caue, and is cured by the ame means: Only you are here to oberve, That upon the Plaiter, you mut put Bolters of Leather, or other hard things, and this according to the bignes of the Rupture; that by this means it may be ufficiently and perfectly kept in.

It is worthy nothing that the Peritonaeum eldom burts in this part. I have divers times found and hewed in diected Bodies, that the Navil, together with the Intetine following, tood out bigger than a mans Head, inomuch that the right Mucles of the Belly were preed to the ide, and evered from one another; and yet was the Peritonaeum but tretched, and no where broken.

Thee are the imple and compounded Ruptures that are commonly decribed; but Practice hews us many others, not mention'd by Writers. For, Experience hath taught me, that the Peritonaeum may burt in the back-part, and there caue a Rupture. We alo find, that the Proceus Peritonaei near to the Groins, may come
o to be lacerated, that the Guts pres not into the Scrotum, but between the Skin and Mucles falls down toward the Thigh. Beides, we have more than once found, that the V√°s deferens was fallen twited into the Scrotum, and had there made a Rupture; which happening, it may with the Hands be eaily reduced, yet, goes in of it elf by lying backward, without any further inconvenience.
The manner of cure had nothing peculiar in it elf, but that you contrive uch Bands, that may reduce the parts fallen out into their right place, without prejudicing the ound ones.

Among thee Ruptures, are commonly reckoned divers Swellings, that belong to other Chapters; where alo we intend to decribe them. But to comply with young Students, I hall here enumerate thoe that in the modern Practice do occur; Namely,
1. Entero-cele, Hernia Intetinalis, or the falling down of the Guts into the Groin.
2. Epiplo-cele, Hernia Omentalis, or the falling down of the Caul.
3. Omphalo-cele, Hernia Umbilicalis, or the Rupture of the Navel.
4. Pneumato-cele, Hernia Ventoa, or the Wind-Rupture.
5. Hydro-cele, Hernia Aquoa, Water-Rupture.
6. Bubono-cele, Swelling of the Glandules in the Groin.
7. Ciro-cele, a welling of the Seminal Veels in the Scrotum.
8. Hernia-Veneris, an hardening of the Teticles by an impure Concu√≥itus.
9. Hernia-Humoralis, a Repletion of the Teticles with unnatural Humors.
10. Hernia Carnoa, a flehy Rupture.
11. Broncho-cele, Hernia Gutturis, a welling in the Throat.
12. Spermato-cele, figuratively o called by me, when the Vas deferens falls twited into the Scrotum.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the falling down of the Matrix.
div.p: THe Matrix does not eaily fall down by Relaxation, much les by Laceration of her broad Ligaments, as mot Writers imagin; from hard Labour, or by an indicreet drawing away of the Secundine. Others with me have een, that the bottom of the Matrix hath been plainly inverted in pudendis, o that the inward part hewed it elf as the outward. We have alo found (epecially in thoe that were ubject to Cotivenes or Belly-ach) that the membranes of the Pudenda were o far tretcht out, that the unskilful have taken it for the Matrix it elf, and do o till. For though many Authors have dared to write, that the Womb may be cut out without danger of life, eems altogether impoible to a skilful Anatomit.

To cure this Dieae, lay the Patient on her back, with her Knees on high, and Legs aunder; then take a Wax-Candle of a competent thicknes, mix therewith ome Catoreum or Aa Foetida, and with it gently pres the Womb inward, and having atened the Candle with a Bandage,
apply outwardly to the Belly the Emplatrum Barbarum, or the following:

Take the Roots of Cyprus, Bitort, of each a dram; Galls, Acacia, of each half a dram: Cypres-Nuts, Date-tones, Myrtle-Berries, of each one dram; Pitch and Colophony, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.
Then preently enjoyn the Patient to lie till, with the Legs cros, and to beware of peaking aloud, of colding, and of whatever may occaion coughing or neezing.

Here great care is to be had, that your Wax-Candle be not too thick, to the end that by its continual friction it may not caue Fluorem Album, whereby the trength of the Body would certainly come to decay. Yet becaue ev'n by the greatet care and circumpection, this inconvenience will hardly be altogether or always prevented; therefore thoe do very well and dicreetly, that longways perforat the Candle, and thereby give a convenient paage for the humors flowing that way.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the falling down of the Fundament.
div.p: IF the Gut be unk down, anoint it with Oyl of Roe and Myrtle, mixing a little Powder of Galls amongt it, and with your Fingers and a mall Linnen-Rag, put it in. If an Inflamation hinder the reducing it, then bathe the Anus with thee Medicines,

Take Flowers of Elder, Camomile, and St.
John's-wort, of each a handful; Red Roes, rwo Pugils; the tops of Wormwood and Melilot, of each half a handful: Boil therein Milk and Red Wine, and bathe the part.

Here epecially care is to be had, that no external cold may come to the fallen-out Anus; for then you may ooner than you are aware of, be urprized with a Gangreen. Wherefore do your utmot to put it in again with peed; and in the mean time, endeavor with the above precrib'd Bathing and warm Linnen Rags, to preerve its natural heat.

There is yet another, though in appearance ridiculous, yet in reality a good way of reducing the Gut. With a trong hand trike five or ix times the Patient's Buttocks, and thereby the Mucles, called Ani levatores, will preently draw the Anus into its right place again. But before the Patient be thus chatized, take care that the Gut may firt be anointed with Oyl of Roes, or of Myrtle.

div.head: CHAP X. Of the econd Operation called Diaereis, or the eperation of what was united together.
div.p: HItherto we have joined together again what had been disjoined; now it follows, that we eparate what is united, and treat of the econd Manual Operation, called Diaereis, which teacheth us the manner of Cutting and Burning, and that both in the hard and oft parts of the Body.

In the oft, the Cutting is called Inciion. In the hard, it is performed four manner of ways: By Terebration or Perforation; by Raion or Scraping; by Limation, or Filing; by Serration, or Sawing. Burning is done either by an Iron (which is the Actual Cautery) or by Medicaments (called the Potential Cautery) as hall be declared particularly hereafter.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of opening a Vein.
div.p: BLeeding (one of the greatet Remedies in the Art of Phyick) is ometimes highly neceary, but ometimes o dangerous, that it ought not to be ued without very urgent Caues. Here therefore I think it will be better omewhat to digres for fuller information, than to leave the unskilful in their error.

The Blood is the darling of Nature, by whoe aitance he performeth all her Operations, and which can hardly be drawn from her without dammage; yet does Art require, that thoe who meddle with it, being neither venturous nor timorous, but dicreet and couragious, and making out of neceity a virtue, do ometimes proceed to the opening a Vein; yet for no other than thee four following caues.
1. In a Plethora, or uper-abundance of blood, that by this means Nature may be eaed of her too heavy burden, and the innate heat preerved from uffocation.

2. For Revulion-ake, when the blood and the (therein) mingled humors, by flowing too plentifully to this or that part, hinder the Cure: Here you are always to chue a Vein of the oppoite ide, and that ometimes the farthet ditant, ometimes the nearet.

3. For the Derivation or conveyance of the Blood (which is already got into the part, but is not yet altogether etled there, nor extravaated) into another place; in which cae a Vein is to be opened the nearet to the Part.
4. For Refrigeration, when the heat of the Blood is o exceive, that it cannot be allayed by cooling Medicines, or not time enough.

Thee limits are too narrow for ome, who will needs take into thoe a fifth caue, which they make the Corruption of the Blood, held by them to be as great an inducement for bleeding as any of the four by us recited; to the end, ay they, that Nature being rid of part of what is corrupt, may be the better able to correct what remains.

But I much wih, 1. That they could make this dicharge without the los of that trength which is o highly neceary. 2. That they would be preent when their Patient is to bleed, and preciely tell to what degree of corruption his blood is come, that o the Chirurgeon may know how much of it he is to take, and how often; foramuch as they will not allow, that Bleeding is good in all orts of the Blood's corruption, but in that only which is not gone coniderably far. 3. That they would declare, why they will have cur'd the greater corruption by Purging, and the leer by Bleeding, ince that they give to the one as well as to the other (and that duly) the name of Cacho-Chimia.
Let them hew, that things differing only ecundum Majus & Minus, do differ in pecie, and o require pecifically different Remedies.

Others proceed yet further, and hed innocent Blood in all orts of Fevers, without any conideration of pots of the Plague, or of Poion it elf; thus freeing themelves from a great deal of labor and trouble, otherwie caus'd to the Phyitian from the variety of Fevers. But becaue the nature of all Poyon and Malignant Humors is continually to aault the Heart, and uddenly to protrate the trength of the tronget Perons; and ince Bleeding doth likewie both, not only diminihing trength, but alo drawing the malignity toward the Heart, and driving in again, for the oppreion of Nature, what he had thrown out for her relief: I do intreat and warn all the Practiers of our Art, That as they love the quiet of their Mind, and the good of their Patients, they would beware of bleeding in Petilential and other Malignant Fevers; as alo in all caes that may befal People by Poyon, either inward or outward.

The French, Italians, Spaniards and Portuguees (great Blood-letters) will, I expect, tell me; That Nature, when by bleeding he hath vent, and is omewhat dicharg'd, hall be better able to throw out the remaining Evil. And this eems to be true, for the blood indeed receives Air, that the Spirits may the better flie away, and is robb'd of that trength which it o necearily wants; whereupon Nature exchangeth the Life of the Patient for death, and extorts tears from the By-tanders.

Without alledging other Reaons, they ground themelves upon Experience. And it were to be wihed they had that ground indeed; for we find
uch Patients of theirs, who in the morning were in no danger, even after but the taking away of five or ix ounces of Blood, to be cold and tiff at night. Whence it may eaily be collected, what it is they call Experience, viz. If the Patient by chance ecape death, then Bleeding mut have the honor of it; but if he die, as for the mot part, then the malignity of the Dieae was the caue of it. Wherefore I alledge Experience againt Experience, and praie God Almighty, that he hath vouchafed to furnih all thoe, who without envy, paion, or lavih dependance upon others, will duly conider Dieaes with urer means.

The more moderate ort of them would have Bleeding only adminitred in the beginning of the Dieae, and before the Malignity appears outwardly. This I hall willingly allow them; 1. In very hot Countreys. 2. In a Plethorick Body. 3. If the humors flying to the head, caue any grievous ymptoms there; in which cae, bleeding in the Hand or Foot may be, I think, very beneficial. Otherwie thoe that ue it in all bodies, and without ditinction in thee cold and moit parts, will find the ill effects of it, and be puzled withal to give a reaon for their Practice, allowable by Art; the rather becaue, by their own confeion, they dare not ue this their Darling of Bleeding at certain times, but find themelves bet in the ue of Sudorificks and cooling Drinks. But enough of this.

Now how many Ounces of Blood ought to be taken at once; the degree of the Dieae, and the Patients more or les trength, will indicate. And 'tis better too little than too much. I have never taken more from the tronget and mot plethoric
Peron under my Cure, than twelve ounces at once, chuing rather, in cae of need, to let out twenty ounces at two times, than fifteen at once; of which method I have found good ucces.

As to the eaon of the year, and the hour of the day, little regard needs to be had in thoe Dieaes, wherein bleeding cannot be deferred without danger, as in Pluriies, Squinancies, &c. Otherwie, the Spring and Autumn, and the Morning are bet.

The veins that are wont commonly to be opened, are thee: In the Forehead, the Vena frontis; in the Temples, the Vena Temporalis; in the Mouth, the Vena ublingualis, or Ranularis; in the Neck, the Jugularis externa; in the Arm, the Bailica, under which lieth an Artery; the Mediana, under which lieth a Nerve, and under both of them a Tendon; and the Cephalica, which hath under, or near it, neither Artery, Nerve, nor Tendon, and therefore may afely be opened: This lat hath but one mall Branch that runs outward to the head, whence it hath got the name of the Head Vein. Without this conideration, it little matters which of thee three be opened, in regard that about the Arm-pits they all acknowledge no more but one Branch. In the Hand, between the little finger and its neighbour, the Salvatella; in the Foot, the Saphena and Ichiatica.

The manner of Bleeding is o well known, that I think it needles here to decribe it; only I could wih, that ome of thoe that let blood, would take care omewhat better to gues of the number of Ounces of Blood they take from their Patients, that o we might not find 12, 16, 18, yea, 22 ounces drawn away intead of 6 or 8, that
were precribed. To prevent o intolerable a mitake, I would advie, that mall Porringers of Tin or Copper were made, in which the number of ounces were mark'd; though expert Maters do not at all need them, as knowing that Blood is really weightier, than it outwardly eems.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the opening of Abcees, or Impothumes.
div.p: THe Humors here and there gathered, do often caue a Swelling, which nature is not always able to diipate, unles Art do uccor her by fit means; which if fruitles, you mut ue Suppuration, and then tay till he of her elf make an opening, except there be a neceity to haten one, or even not to tay for a perfect Suppuration: As, 1. When the matter being very harp or malign, upon which happens a Corroion of the neighboring parts, and a corruption of the Bones, Tendons or Nerves. 2. When it may affect a nobler part. 3. When it lieth in the Joynts. 4. When it is cat out by a Criis.

Before you proceed to the opening, you are to conider, whether the matter be contain'd in its own proper Tunicle, or whether it be without any Tunicle. If without any, then make your apertion with a right Line, oberving the Fibres of the Mucles. For Example; In the head, according to the poition of the Hair, long-ways; in the Eyelids, tranvere; in the Temples, the Noe, Neck, Breat, Back, Arms, Feet, Joynts, long-ways;
in the midt of the Abdomen, let it be long-ways; in the ides of it omewhat oblique; in the Groins, tranvere; but not very deep, by eaon of the ubjacent eminary Veels. Always beware of touching any great Vein, Artery or Nerve, though the Fibres be cut a-cros, let from a leer evil there hould arie a greater.

The properet place for the opening, is the mot raied and oftet part of the Abces, if poible in the depending, that the purulent matter may the more conveniently be dicharged: To which end alo you are with a Tent o long to keep open the wound, until the part, being altogether cleaned of its preternatural Humors, may return to its former Functions.

In the opening, thrut not in the Launcet too deep, nor further into the Cavity than to the matter; and as oon as you perceive that, draw it a little back, and turn the point upward; making your opening through the Skin o big as may afford the contained matter a free vent.

If the Abces be included in a Tunicle, if mall, make the Inciion long ways; if big, then make a double inciion, that is, cros-ways; and beware of touching the Veicle, otherwie you mut expect a foetide and almot incurable Ulceration. This being well done, pres out with your Fingers the Veicle, which eldom or never ticks to the Skin, and eaily follows; cut off the little Artery by which it is fed; and have a care, that not the leat Particle of the Bag may remain on it, let it gather again.

Foramuch as in this Operation I find, that Chirurgeons differ in the Intrument they ought to ue, ome chuing the Launcet, others the Potential Cautery,
and extol it far above the former: I think my elf obliged to declare here what I judge of this matter.

The Potential Cautery hath this Advantage, that it doth not terrifie timorous Patients, nor is painful to the tender; epecially joyning with it the preent and known good Remedies: For unquenched Lime, mixed with Holland Sope, worketh deep enough into the fleh, yet much gentlier than the Corroive of Ambr. Paraeus. But it hath thee Inconveniencies:

1. That according to the tendernes or trength of the Skin or Bodies, ometimes it eats in deeper than needs; for we have found by experience, that in ome it hath eaten through the Skin and Mucles, to the very cavity of the Belly; in others irrecoverably wounded the procees of the Peritonaeum, together with the eminal veels therein.

2. Commonly it preads it elf in length and breadth omewhat further than you would have it, epecially if it be to be applied under the Armpits, in the Groin, or in the Joynts; for it no ooner grows warm, but it melts, and o preads abroad, notwithtanding the Plaiter with which the Surgeon deigned to bound it.
3. There are necearily required ome hours (in ome Bodies more, in others les) before it can perform its Operation; and this the Humor will not always bear, epecially if it be malign.

4. And the Scar falls not preently off; and if you would give a preent vent to the Humors, you will be obliged till to make ue of a Launcet. Be as circumpect as you can, I am ure, you will hardly avoid thee Inconveniencies.

On the other hand, the Launcet hath this trouble,
that many people are affrighted at it, and that it is painful: But the fear may be prevented by ilence, and the pain is little coniderable; mean time you have thee Advantages:
1. That with the Launcet, the Apertion may be made as long and as deep as the Chirurgeon deireth.
2. The matter is uddenly dicharged, and the Patient hath preent relief.
3. The unconcocted remainder may be the ooner concocted, by aiting Nature with convenient Remedies, both inwardly and outwardly.

4. You will not be troubled with a long gleet, which if it happens, the fault is auredly in the Chirurgeon. For almot all Tumors that appear behind the Ears, in the Neck, under the Armpits, or in the Groin, pring from indurated Glandules, replete with a preternatural humor; thee Glandules are all included in their own Membranes, which being toucht, either with a Launcet, or with Corroive Medicines, there mut needs follow a gleet (for 'tis impoible that the Glandule hould be able to preerve it elf, or the contained Humor, its Tunicle being divided) which will continue until the whole Glandule and Tunicle are both conumed.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Separation of Parts unnaturally joyned.
div.p: WIthin the Ear is a thin, but trong Membrane called the Drum. This being overgrown with another preternatural Membrane, or a Caruncle, the Patient loeth his hearing; which is not at all to be cured by any Manual Art, and difficultly by Medicines. But if the Cavity of the Ear come to be cloed up with a Membrane, and thereby the hearing lot, then is it to be opened with a fit Intrument, and as oon as may be, cicatriz'd.

That many have been born with the Anus imperforated, and the Intetine covered with a Membrane, hath been often oberved; which if the Membrane be tender and thin, is to be opened with the Fingers; if thick, with a Launcet, long-ways; and afterwards kept open with a mall leaden Pipe, and drying Medicines.

The Pudenda Virginum are ometimes alo clos'd with a preternatural Membrane, which caueth mot grievous Accidents, when they are grown marriageable. Sometimes the part is altogether grown together; ometimes upon an ill-treated Ulcer, coalecunt Labia & Membrum illud ineptum reddunt congreui virili. Sometimes a preternatural Caruncle huts the Os Vulvae. The two firt are to be opened long ways with a harp Intrument, in part wound about with linnen Rags,
and then cured according to Art. To the lat, which caueth mot difficulty, you'l need in the Operation a Speculum Matricis, and in the latter end of the Cure, a mall Pipe, perforated throughout in length, to promote the Cicatrizing.

Here we hall take leave to peak omething of the Tongue, not of a long and harp one, for which I have found either none, or at leat, no better remedy than contempts, patience and commieration; but of thoe, that being hort and tied, deprive Children, firt, of Sucking, afterwards of Speaking: Which is eaily remedied, by looening the tring of the Tongue, by cutting it tranvere with a pair of Sciars, and anointing it afterwards with Honey of Roes three or four times a day. In the cutting, the neighboring parts and veins mut be carefully hunned; and ometimes the Nerve of the ixth pair of its Branches run o near the String, that by a deep inciion they may be eaily hurt, and the Patient fall into ad Accidents. Here let the Chirurgeon know, that of an hundred Children, carce one needs this Manual Operation; and that thoe Midwives are as rah as ignorant, who in all new-born Babes, do forthwith dilacerate this String, whereby the found parts being hurt, they are often deprived of their neceary Sucking, and, by ubequent ymptoms, of their Life.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Paracentheis.
div.p: ALthough the word Paracentheis, ignifies all Punctures, yet cutom hath appropriated it olely to the opening of the Belly in a Dropie, and to that of the Breat in Empyema, though more to that than to this.

This Manual Operation is ancient, and full of danger; yet ometimes preerves the life of the Patient. Nature and Succes have emboldened us now and then to make ue of it; but Experience hath taught us, that the greatet difficulty conits herein: 1. That the parts debilitated, and deerted of their natural heat, do eaily, after opening, mortifie. 2. That together with the Water, iues out likewie the Spirits. 3. That the preing water can hardly be o kept in, but it will run out in depight of the Chirurgeon; and if, the better to cloe the Wound, you do forcibly pres in the Pipe, a Gangrene oon and eaily enueth.

Who therefore expects a good iue of this Operation, mut ue it only upon a Body that is not emaciated or wated; in a Dropie that is recent (or at leat, when the Tumor in a hort time hath rien to a great bulk) and which, upon the ue of proper Remedies, would not preently be removed; in uch Patients that are not moleted with a Fever, or with difficulty of breathing, and where the noble parts are yet ound and uncorrupted; and in perons of a middle age, ince in Children and in old people it ucceeds not o properouly.

As to the Place; if the Navel tands out, eek for no other, but make your opening therein: But if that be much drawn in (as it commonly happens to be in Hydropical Perons) it is not proper for it: In which cae you mut take for your place three inches beneath the Navel, not in the white-Line, which, to my wonder, I find propoed by ome; but, on the ide of the right Mucle, in the Mucle called Oblique Decendens: Mark it firt with Ink, and then make a mall Apertion through the Skin, Mucles, and Peritonaeum, taking great care that the Omentum, or Guts, be not wounded; which alo, by reaon of the interpoing Water, cannot eaily be hurt. He that will be very careful of the opening, mut make it according to the Ductus of the Fibres, a little obliquely downwards (according to this \) in the left ide; and (according to this, /) in the right ide.

As oon as you perceive Water to come forth, take a Golden, Silver, or Leaden mall Pipe, that is, 1. Smooth. 2. Furniht at the Head with a Button or Wing. 3. Perforated on the ides with three or four holes. 4. No longer than the thicknes of the diected part, that is, an inch broad. 5. Somewhat crooked at the end. 6. Exactly fitting the ize of the Orifice. Put this into the Apertion, lay over it a ticking-Plaiter (others take a Spunge, or a four double linnen Rag) bind up the Patient, and let him ret two or three hours; then open the Bandage again, and take away one, two, three, eldom or never more pints of Water, and o repeating it once or twice a day, till the water be almot all dicharged. You mut not take away all at firt, for the chilnes of
the parts, following o great an Evacuation, very often caueth death. The Pipe is not to be taken out, but mut remain all the time of the cure in the Wound, which you mut at length heal up according to Art.

For the opening of an Hydropical Belly, this is the afet as hitherto practied way, that is left us by the Ancients; but the indutry of their Poterity hath invented for us a much convenienter Intrument, whereby we not only do avoid many of the above-mentioned difficulties, but alo with les trouble preerve the lives otherwie incurable Patients, freeing them from tretching, pain and trouble, according to our pleaure, or the degree of their trength.

This never enough commended Intrument was firt of all brought out of Italy; by the experienced Chirurgeon of this City, Mr. Jacob Block, and by him put into practice, to the great benefit of many Patients.

Commonly he chueth the place lately pointed out by us, viz. about three inches below the Navel, and perforates the Skin, Mucles and Peritonaeum, unto the very Water, taking away no more at once than a quart.

That done, he draws out his Intrument again, puts nothing upon the made hole but dry Lint and a ticking-Plaiter, whereby he ufficiently hinders the running out, againt your Will, of even a drop of Water; for, upon the withdrawing of the Intrument, the opened Skin, Mucles and Peritonaeum are eaily by their natural motion o far drawn aunder, that the holes cannot any more exactly cloe upon one another.

This being once performed, we regulate ourelves
according to the trength of the Patient, taying two, three or more days, before we repeat this Operation; then either the firt Orifice is to be opened, or again a new one to be made, epecially if the Chirurgeon finds, that the Water may be more conveniently drawn away in another place.

In an Hydrocele (when the water is fallen into the Scrotum) the aid Chirurgeon doth by this Intrument o dexterouly dicharge the Water out of the Scrotum, that the next day you hall not, or hardly be able to find where the Hole was.

The Perforation eems to me a little inconvenient, wherefore I have caued this Intrument o far to be altered, as that I make the end not to be wrought round, but harp on both ides, Launcetwie, by which means it may be ooner thrut through the Mucles. But then, his may be made of Silver, mine mut be of Steel.
To the end that you may the better comprehend what we ay, we hall repreent to your view the Intrument, and the Operation it elf, in the enuing Figures.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Opening of the Breat.
div.p: THere is ometimes collected in the Cavity of the Breat a water or purulent matter.
The Water gathers either by ome Lymphatick Veels burt, or from an unconcocted watrines of the Blood. The purulent Matter follows upon Inflammations of the Throat, or Lungs, or a Pleuriie, &c.
If it be Matter that is collected, it is called Empyema; if Water, Hydrops pectoris vel pulmonis, the Dropie of the Breat or Lungs.

The Marks of the Water are, a dry Cough, a painful heavines, a difficulty of breathing, even to Suffocation, great Thirt, little Appetite, a pale Look and ometimes a welling of the Legs, now and then accompanied with a Feaver; and when the Patient turns himelf, you may perceive a rumbling noie.

The collected Sanies may be known by the following Signs; When the Inflamation of the Lungs or Pleura, will not, upon Bleeding, or other convenient means, be ufficiently removed, then may you apprehend a collection of uch matter to come within a fortnight. Between the thirtieth and fortieth day the Tumor commonly breaks. The Patient hall find a great heavines in his Chet without coniderable pain; and in cae it is accompanied with pain, then you are to Expect a new Flux, which you mut divert by Bleeding. The
Patient hath a difficulty in breathing; in motion, he hears a rumbling, at leat he is enible that the matter changeth place, and the ide affected is to the touch, hotter than the other. He cats up, with violent coughing, a purulent matter, having a continual Fever; he finds an anxiety at his heart, and hath little tomach to his meat.
If we cannot expel thee Humors by Expectorating, nor by Diureticks, nor Diaphoreticks, nor by purging Medicines, then are we forc'd to come to Manual Operation.

This cannot be done without danger, and is not to be attempted in cae the Patient be weak, and the inward parts already corrupted. However, this Operation hath les danger than the next foregoing, and people oftner recover upon it; yea, Learned Writers aure us, that by this Operation, and the ue of Injection, they have cured many of Ulcers of the Lungs.

Concerning the Place of Opening, Authors are not agreed in it; the reaon whereof is obvious: For, the Diaphragma runs higher in ome perons than in others; whence it comes to pas, that the collected Humors in ome Patients, lie higher than in others. Secondly, the Chet is raied in ome, flat in others; which here much alters the cae. Beides, the Lungs do often grow o fat to the Pleura, that the anious matter cannot eaily be carried into the Cavity of the Breat: In which cae it would be ill done, to choe the place of Opening lowet, in repect of the Diaphragma. And in regard that in this, as in other wellings, the mot eminent place is, eteemed the mot convenient for opening, it cannot be otherwie but that one Chirurgeon hath made
choice of this place, and another ueth that place as the bet.
