Upon which account, Hyppocrates Guido, Amatus Luitanus, &c. do make the apertion between the third and fourth Rib, counting from beneath upwards: Fienus, Riverius, and many others, between the fourth and fifth; Paulus Aegineta, Vidus Vidius, Fabritius ab Aquapendente, Sennertus, &c. between the fifth and ixth; which place, in my opinion, is the afet; for, if higher, the Pericardium, if lower, the Diaphragma may be wounded, of which there have been many ad Examples. But in this difference of dienting Writers, what hath been aid, will direct you to pas into the afet Haven.

All things therefore well conidered, chue the place where to make your Apertion; not the forepart (for, before, the Sternum or Breat-bone will hinder your operation here; nor in the back-part, for the Ribs are o cloe to one another, that without hurting ome Veels, you cannot make any Apertion there) but on the ide, four or five inches from the Sternum: Neither ought the Inciion to be o near to the upper Ribs, as to the lower, becaue the intercotal Veels, viz. the Vein, Artery and Nerve, lie in the lower part of each Rib, where Nature hath aigned them a place, branching themelves into the middle of the intercotal Mucles; which diemination nevertheles hinders not, but that the Inciion may be made in the middle between the two Ribs.

After you have marked the place with Ink, charge the Patient to breath forth as long as poibly he can, without taking it in, and in the mean time make an oblique, but mall Orifice, and put into it a Silver or Leaden Pipe, and take forth four
or five ounces of Matter to run out in a day. In cae the Matter does not come forth well, place your Patient on the wounded ide, and make him to cough; if by reaon of its toughnes it will not yet come forth, then inject into the cavity ome abterive, exiccating and healing Medicines; As,
Take Goats whey, eighteen ounces; Honey of Roes, four ounces; the Juice of Celandine and Smallage, of each ix drams: Mingle it.
Or,

Take the Roots of Comfrey the greater, an ounce; of Sanicle, half an ounce; the Leaves of Betony, Agrimony, Periwincle, Burnet, of each half a handful; the Cordial Flowers, two pugils; the Seed of St. John'swort, Holy-Thitle, Roman-Nettle, of each half a dram: Boil them in Water and Honey to a pint and half; train it, and keep it for your ue.
Of this Injection, the Patient may alo drink a little twice or thrice a day.

It is yet further to be oberved, that the collected Matter is often contained in a Membrane of its own, and by its riing, manifets it elf from without; and then the Latines call it Vomica Pulmonis: In which cae, you mut not tay till the Membrane breaks of its elf; for by delay, the Matter flowing up and down is more difficulty to be got out of the Breat; but open it preently, taking no other place, but the mot raied part of the welling.

Now, ince an Empyema for the mot part follows upon a Pleuriie, and 'tis dayly found, that ignorant Chirurgeons take all kind of pain in the Sides, Belly and Breat, although caued from Winds only, for a Pleuriie; thereupon immediately
opening a Vein; I thought therefore neceary to write in this place of the Pleuriie, as much as is neceary for a Chirurgeon to know, for the preventing uch mitakes.

The Pleuriie then is an inflammation of the Pleura, and commonly of the Lungs themelves, caued from afflux of Blood, accompanied with Pain Cough, pitting of Blood, hortnes of Breath, continual Feaver, trong and quick Pule.
The Caue is the Blood, ometimes alone (when a true Pleuriie) ometimes mixt with other Humors then it occaions a Batard one.
The Signs, as may be een in the Decription, are o evident, that thoe who know not how to ditinguih it from a Cholick, are not worthy of any excue.

The Prognoticks.] The ooner the matter is concocted, and the whiter and eaier 'tis ejected, the quicker and afer is the Iue. If the Cough, and difficulty of breathing leen not by a copious Expectoration, 'tis an ill ign. If the Patient come not to pit the third or fourth day, then will he carce ee the eventh. If upon Bleeding, and other fit means, the pain ceae not, the Patient mut either die, or the Pleuriie will turn to a Conumption, or an Empyema.

The Cure.] In this cae, Bleeding is one of the mot neceary and afet means of Cure; and if ued in time, the Patient, in the very Operation, and before the Vein be cloed, will find relief, and ometimes be altogether freed of the pain. Nor do I know any Dieae, in which there may, to the Patient's benefit, be o much Blood taken away at once, as in this.

There are different Opinions concerning what
ide the Patient is to bleed on: But thoe have had little Experience of this icknes, who have not found, that Patients (at leat in thee Countreys) are relieved much more and ooner, when they are bled in the Arm of the ame ide where the Pain is, than when it is done in the oppoite ide.
The Pain not ceaing in four and twenty hours, we are neceitated to bleed twice or thrice, mot commonly in the ame Arm; but here you mut well oberve the Patient's trength.

After letting Blood, ometimes Purging, Swearing and Expectorating Remedies, are very neceary. One only Medicine I cannot conceal from you, becaue of its Excellency. The Indutrious Phyitian Dr. Hadden in his Cure of the Pleuriie, hath much commended it, and I have, after once Bleeding, always in the beginning ued it with great ucces, viz.
Take the Juice of Dandelion, an ounce and half; the Water of Plantane, two ounces; of Holy-Thitle and Scabious, Syrup of Poppies Erratick, of each an ounce; Crabs-Eyes, a cruple and half: Mix it.
Let the Patient every half hour take down a poonful or two of it, until the Flux be topped: After which you are to ue other Remedies.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of Removing a Cataract of the Eye.
div.p: A Cataract (by the Greeks called Hypochyma by the Latines, Suffuio; in the German and Belgick Tongue, De Staer) is a concretion of uperfluous Humors, by little and little generating a preternatural Membrane betwixt the Cornea and the Crytalline Humor, covering either totally, or in part, the Pupil of the Eye, and o depriving the Patient, of his ight, or hindring it.

Difference.] It is either Imperfect, when the Humor is thin, or the Apple of the Eye not totally covered; or Perfect, when it is changed into a Membrane, or the Pupil is quite covered. Sometimes 'tis white, gray, yellow, green, ometimes of a leaden colour, &c. according as the green, yellow or black Choler is mingled amongt it.
The Seat of it is between the Cornea and the Crytalline humor, being ometimes nearer to this, ometimes to that.
The Caue is a Phlegmatick Humor, either collected there by the weaknes of the Eyes, or by the Brain tranmitted thither by reaon of its abundance.

Signs.] In the beginning, the Patient ees every thing double, and of many colours; the Air eems to him full of Flies, Nets and Clouds, and cannot endure a great light. Thereupon his ight leens, and all things appear as Spots, and at length there follows blindnes. If it be jut in
the Center of the Pupil, yet covers not the whole Pupil; but leaveth round about the ight ome place free, and then all the Patient ees, eems perforated. If the Pupil preads it elf, when you rub the Eye with your Fingers, then is it yet imperfect; if it remains unmoved, there is no doubt of its being perfect.

The Prognoticks.] The imperfect Cataract may eaily be cured in the beginning, by convenient External and Internal Medicines, in ound Bodies, and in Patients of a middle Age. The les the Pupil is dilated, the les hope of Cure. The nearer the Suffuion is to the Crytalline Humor, the more dangerous. If the Eye be turned to the Sun, and the Patient then ees no glimmering of Light, there is no benefit to be expected from the Manual Operation. If the Humors of the Eye be commixt by the Needle, though the Membrane be removed, then blindnes will certainly remain. If in the Operation you happen to touch the Membrane of the Eye, called the Retina, the Patient will after that always ee the Air, as if full of mall Hair and Flies. A Cataract commonly remains o oft unto the third year, that it will not follow the Needle; after the third or fourth year, it is o firm and hard, that it can by no Art be looned. The Blood pilt by the ue of the Needle, caueth no danger, and oon ceaeth of it elf. Though the Cataract be not altogether uppreed, but divided into everal pieces, the ight doth often perfectly return within ix or eight weeks, though before that time the whole Operation hould eem to be fruitles; which I peak from manifold Experience.

The Cure.] The Imperfect Cataract requires
olely the Aid of the Phyitian, who by Medicines and trengthening the Stomach and Head, have done much; to which purpoe the conerve of Marjoram, Roemary, Beteny, Pulv. Diambre, &c. are very good. And outwardly ue the following means.
Take Gum Tragacanth diolved in Eyebright water, two drams; Burnt Allom, one cruple: Make a Collyrium.
Or,

Take Celandine water, an ounce and half; White wine, half an ounce; Spirit of Wine, two drams; White Vitriol, ix grains; Prepared Tutty, a cruple; Glas of Antimony, five grains; Sugar-Candy, two drams and an half; Camphire, ix grains: Mix it, and make a Collyrium.
Or,

Take Juyce of Fennel, of Celandine, of each two ounces; Leaves of Rue and Marjoram, of each a Pugil; Eye-bright, one handful; of the Gall of an Oxe, four ounces; the Gall of Hens; an ounce; Red-Myrrhe, Aloes, of each a dram and half; Sarcocols, half an ounce; Camphire, two cruples: Mingle them, and let them be dilled in B. M.

If the Cataract be confirmed, then let the Manual Operation be your only refuge; but beware of attempting the Operation, if the Patient have long before complained, and till complains of Head ach or pain of his Eyes; if the Body hath not been cleaned in general, nor the Head in particular; and if the Patient be yet moleted with a Fever, Sneezing, Coughing or Vomiting.

Having choen a convenient eaon of the year, ome morning in the decreae of the Moon, and a
clear and erene Air, et the Patient in a Chair, and againt him let the Operator it in one omewhat higher than his, bind up his ound Eye, and make him clap his hand about your wate, without tirring them at all as long as you are buie in the Operation. Let ome body hold his Head fat behind, and hold you aunder his Eye-lids, charging him to turn the Eye towards his Noe, which when he doth, quickly thrut your Needle into the Cornea, half a traws bredth from the Iris, and bring it unto the hollow of the Eye; when the Needle hath toucht the Cataract, endeavour therewith to pres it gently, and o long from above downwards until it remains there; if it be tubborn, in pringing up again and again, divide it into everal parts, and keep thee particles, or the whole Cataract a little while under, that it may not return again before the Pupil of the Eye; then draw out the Needle, and bind up as well the ound as the unound Eye, with Linnen-cloths moitened in ome Roe water, the White of an Egg, and a little Allom mixed together. Beware in the Operation, of hurting the Crytalline Humor, and the ound Tunicles.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of Leeches.
div.p:
LEeches more advantagious than Scarification, and afer than Bleeding, may with benefit be applied, as well in trong as in weak Bodies, they only draw Blood from the Cutaneous Veels, by which they cure light Dieaes, if only applyed
to the Skin; but if applyed to ome greater Veel, they draw alo Blood from the Internal Parts, and o remove internal and more deperate Dieaes.

There is great care required in the choice of Leeches, for thoe with great Heads, and that are green and hining, with hair or blew tripes on their Backs, are not without Poyon; as alo thoe that live in tanding or putrid Waters: But thoe are to be choen that are lender and long, with little heads, and red Bellies, and uch as are nourihed in clear running Water: They are never to be applied to the Part new taken, but after they have been taken a day or more in fair Water, and fed with a little Blood, that they may be cleaned of all their impurities; the place where they are to be applied, is to be rubb'd till it be red; and if they faten not, 'tis to be moitened with Cream, or with Blood freh taken from a Pigeon, or the part it elf to be prickt with a Needle till it bleed; if they draw luggihly, cut their tails off with a pair of Sciars. After they have uckt a ufficient quantity of Blood, and they fall not off themelves, put upon their Heads a little Ahes or Salt, and they will uddenly deit from their work: they are not to be pull'd off by force, let they leave their heads behind them, from whence incurable wounds, and oftentimes Death ucceeds. 'Tis to be noted, that they rather draw Arterial Blood than Venal, therefore they ought to uck the les.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the Cutting in the Hard Parts.
div.p: THe Section which is ued in the Hard and Bony Parts, is of four kinds, viz. Scraping, Filing, Sawing and Perforating, that is, Trepanning.

Scraping is ued in a Fiure and foul Bone, in the Teeth alo, when they are cruted over with a Tartarous black ubtance; the Bones are to be craped till you come to the ound part, which is white and olid, and a little blood cat forth; and to the Bone thus craped, ome drying Powder is to be applied; the Pericranium and Periotium mut firt be eperated from the Bone, before you go about this Operation; for by no means are they to be touched with the Intrumenr, neither likewie the lips of the Wound.

Filing is ued in the Teeth; for when they unnaturally tand forth, and either in Eating or Speaking, are any hinderance to a man; then that which thus ticks forth, is with a File to be taken off, which mut be done carefully, without any injury to the neighouring parts, and by degrees, neither with two great a Violence, let it looen the Tooth.
The ue of the Saw is in a mortified part, when the Bone is to be cut a under; concerning which Operation I hall uddenly peak.

Perforating or Trepanning is of great ue, when the Bones are extreamly oul, but 'tis of greatet ue in thoe effects, which the Fiure or a Fracture
of the Skull, or a Contuion may produce: Seeing therefore this Operation is o full of danger, 'tis diligently to be enquired in what Caes 'tis neceary, and in what 'tis not; for a Fiure as a Fiure, as likewie a Fracture as a Fracture, requires not the Trepan as an operation without which they cannot be cured: In like manner a light Contuion doth not always occaion uch dangerous ymptoms, that the Trepan may not caue wore; for oftentimes a mall quantity of extravaated Blood, in Robut People, is often dicued by the work of Nature her elf; except the innate heat be weakened by external Cold, which in the ue of the Trepan, let what care poibly be had, cannot be totally avoided; beides this, the Blood is more often extravaated between the two Membranes, the Dura-Mater and the Pia Mater, there the Trepan can eem to promie but little good; but in this cae I would not much matter to divide the Dura Mater; Experience having taught us, that by the help of Art and Nature, hath an Inciion, nay, Gangrene of the Part it elf been cured: Therefore for the mot part but in three caes is the Trepan required.

1. Where the looe pieces of the Bones prick and wound the Meninges; which is to be known by the continual pricking pain preently from the very hurting perceived, granted the Patient be enible; but if not, he is always feeling the Part affected wirh his hands: There happens likewie Contuions of the Eyes, and Convulions of the Limbs: Beides, the quality of the Intrument which the Fracture hath made, will more plainly demontrate it.

2. Where the firt Table is only depreed, but the
econd broke; there being no way to give paage to the pieces, how well oever by Art or Nature eparated. The Signs of this, are, a Dimnes, a Giddines, a Fever, Vomiting, and ometimes an Apoplexy; a feeble mall Pule, and epecially about the Temples, the depreed Bone in ome manner obtructing the Circulation of the Blood in the Brain.

3. Extravaation of Blood, upon which follows Putrefaction, and if not remedied, Death it elf: The Signs which declare this Putrefaction, is a continued Fever, a great Heat in the Head, unquiet Sleep, Watchings, Inflammation of the Eyes, and light Delirium; and moreover, the Temperaments of Bodies are diligently to be conider'd; for in Plethorick People, to thoe above-named Symptoms are joyned, a Laughing, Talking idly, and Rednes of ‚Ä¢ he whole Face. In the Cholerick appears a yellownes of the Face and Eyes, great Heat, and Madnes. In the Phlegmatick, all the Symptoms are les; but ometimes it is accompanied with a Palie, ometimes with an Apoplexy. In Melancholy men, a dread impertinent Talk, and Laughing is uual.
Where the Trepan is neceary, apply it as oon as poible, let the putrifying Blood caueth greater evils, that is, on the third, fourth, or fifth day.

The manner of Trepanning is thus, The Hair being hav'd, Let the Skin be divided with a double Inciion, inform of a Cros to the Pericranium, avoiding with the greatet diligence always the temperal Mucles, and the Sutures of the Head; this done, bind up the Wound, except the Hemorage be mall (which very often is o violent,
that it hinders the Chirurgeon for ome days from any further Operation) if it will then give leave, to divide likewie the Pericranium from the Skull: After ome few hours (the Skull already bar'd of its Pericranium) the Patient well plac'd, his Head mut by ome Peron be firmly held, his Ears being topt with Cotton; then et on the Trepan with a Pin, which mut neither be upon the Fracture, nor upon the Sutures (although there are ome that venture to apply it upon the very Sutures themelves) the Surgeon holding in his left hand the Intrument, and with his right, let him gently turn about the Trepan until it hath taken good hold round; then take out the Pin, and et the Trepan on again without it, moving it till about, and if you ee any mall Filings of the Skull, take off the Trepan and wipe them away; and the Trepan it elf is ometimes to be dipt in the Oyl, that it may the eaier be turned about; and ometimes in Water, that it grows not hot. If any Blood appears, you may be certain that the Trepan had pat the firt Table, then are you to have a greater care, let the Trepan hould unawares lip in, and wound the Meninges, from whence oftentimes follows udden Death: For the Dura Mater invets the inide of the Scull, in the ame manner as the Pericranium doth the out-ide, but yet not o trongly joined to it, but that by a fall or blow, it may be eaily eparated from the Skull.

When the piece of Bone, eparated by the Trepan, begins to be looe, you mut with a little Intrument put in, between the Skull and the Trepan'd part, and free it from the whole, and o gently take it out with a pair of Forceps.
If there remain any inequality from Trepanning, in the inide of the inward Table, that may caue injury to the Meninx, 'tis to be taken away with an Intrument called Lenticula.

And that there may be a dicharge given to the coagulated Blood and Matter, the Dura Mater is to be compreed with an Intrument called a Decuorium. To effect the ame, 'tis commended that the Patient (if enible) his Mouth and Noe being hut, hold his Breath, o that the Brain being raied upward, the concreted and corrupted Matter may be thrown forth; but very eldom is the Matter dicharg'd by this only remedy; for the Chirurgion hath need enough of the Decuorium, Spunges, Lint, and the like Intruments; the decription and delineation of the which, you may find in Joh. Andr. √† Cruce, Paraeus, and others. Read the 4th. Chapter of this Chirurgery, where Fractures of the Skull is decribed.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of tion, or Burning.
div.p:
ENough hath been aid of Cutting, now a little of Burning; when neither Medicine nor Knife bring relief, we mut then come to the Fire, as well in the oft as hard parts: In all Burning, great care is to be taken that the neighboring parts be not hurt; therefore it is very neceary to defend them againt it with Lint: That burning is certainet, which is made by an actual Cautery, viz. a red hot Iron, than that which is performed
a Potential, that is, by Corroive Medicines; yet for the mot part, the Patients fearfulnes makes choice of this; whichoever you ue, beware of applying Oyl alone, or Butter, to remove the Ecar, for it hath been oberved not once only to to have occaioned a Gangrene, Diapalma Plaiter, or Lint, wet in Wine, will be ufficient.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of Iues.

p.hi: ISues are little Ulcers made by Art in a ound part of the Body by a red-hot Iron, Launcet, Sciars, or corroive Medicine, to evacuate uperfluous humors, and o either to cure or prevent Dieaes.

div.p: Thee troubleome Guets are rarely courted, and are chiefly precribed when we ee gentler Medicines to profit nothing, and after the Body hath been well purged.

In what part oever they are made, it is always to be oberv'd they never ought to be inerted in the beginning, middle or end of a Mucle, but always in the pace between two Mucles, which requireth the knowledge of Anatomy, except according to the example of Quacks, whoe cutom hath taught them to find out a place ev'n blindfold. In the Head, the place is the middle of the Coronal Suture, made oftner by other Nations than is a practice amongt us. In the Neck they are not o often made, how neceary oever they may appear. The Italians ue to make them between the Shoulders with ucces. In other places they are either very troubleome or inconvenient.

The Manner of making Iues is divers: If you make ue of the Potential Cautery, apply a Plaiter to the part, having a hole in the middle about the bignes of a Pea, in which lay a little Cotick, and over that a Bolter and another Plaiter; and after three or four hours, take off the Plaiters, and laying on the Ecar a Plaiter of Diapalma; dres it twice a day, that it may the ooner eparate.

Thoe which deire it rather by Inciion, the Skin being taken up either by the Forceps, or by the Hand, divide it with a pair of Sciars or Launcet. If Burning be preferred before the other ways, burn the Skin, but not the ubjacent Mucles; for indeed the Skin it elf is not to be wholly penetrated, oftentimes the touching only the Superficies of it is enough.

When the Scar falls off, take little hard Doels made of Lint, pred upon them ome Deterive Medicine, and pres them into the Ulcer, until they have made a ufficient Impreion; then afterward keep in this Cavity a Ball of Wax, Wood, or Silver, or a Pea, which is to be often taken out, and another put in, and o is to be continued till the Dieae be cured, or Weaknes hinder.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Seton
div.p: ALthough the application of a Seton be with greater trouble than an Iue, yet it brings much greater advantage to the ick Patient; for what two Iues cannot remove, oftentimes is performed by one Seton.

It may be made in the Arms and Legs, and many other parts of the Body; but in the Nape of the Neck, between the firt and econd Vertebra, or econd and third; yea, between the third and fourth, is only in ue amongt us, but I could wih it was more frequent.

There are three Intruments neceary to perform this Operation; A pair of Forceps, a Needle, and String. The Forceps which are to hold up the Skin, mut be perforated of each ide; the Needle mut be three-pointed, and anwer to the hole of the Forceps, which it mut pas through. The String is to be of Silk, not exceeding the thicknes of the Needle: Let the Chirurgion take up the Skin with the Forceps and gripe it hard, which being omewhat tupified, the Patient will feel the les pain; then let him pas the Needle red-hot through both the holes of the Forceps, Skin and all; after which, with another Needle let him bring through the thread: The firt day, to eae pain, apply to the Part Lint dipt in Whites of Eggs and Roewater mixt together: Afterward let Digetion be procured by the ue of convenient Medicines; when digeted, let the String be drawn every day, ometimes to this ide, ometimes to that, o that the mattery part may hang out of the Wound. Thus the Operation being perfected, the Ulcer may be kept open as long as occaion requires, or the Patient pleaeth.

After this manner many Authors, both Antient and Modern, order the making the Seton; but this Oparation is much eaier perform'd, if in the right place the Chirurgion take up the Skin with one hand, and his Servant with another, and o pas it through with a harp-pointed Needle, but
not made hot; the String being of Thread, not Silk, of convenient Thicknes, and rubb'd with Wax.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the drawing forth of Bullets.
div.p: NOw we are come to the Third Part of Chirurgery call'd Exereis, which removes things uperfluous: They are of a two-fold Nature, either they are generated in the Body it elf, or ele brought thither by Accident.

We treat of the lat firt, to wit, The Extraction of Bullets out of the Body; which is not difficult, if it appears whether it be nearer to the part where it made its entrance, or to the oppoite to which it hath penetrated.

If it be oberved to be near the Orifice; let it be drawn forth with a convenient Intrument; if nearer to the oppoite part, let the Inciion be made upon it, and there taken forth: But if the Bullet cannot be found out by a Probe, the Member is to be o placed, that the Bullet by its own weight may come forth; which if it happens not to do, the Wound is to be cured; and let the Chirurgeon expect until the Bullet hews it elf near the Skin, which very often requires a long time.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of the Extraction of a Dead Child and the Secundine.
div.p: THat the Birth may be Natural, it is neceary, That the Infant the whole time of its continuance in its Mothers-womb, lies in uch a poture, that the Arms and Feet being contracted, the Head downwards, having the Face towards the Mothers Back; the whole Foetus lying tranvere in the bottom of the Womb; until requiring greater room, which happens in the eventh, ometimes in the eighth or tenth, for the mot part in the ninth Month, the head of the Infant decends towards the mouth of the womb; the Limbs which were before contracted, being extended, it breaks through the Membranes wherein it was included, by which the water that is contained in them, flows forth, which erve to make the parts lippery, and o is convenient to facilitate the Birth.

If any one of thee be wanting, then one of thee four things necearily happens; either, 1. Both the Mother and the Child, although they may live, yet there follows no Excluion. 2. Or the Mother lives, and the Child dies. 3. Or the Child lives, and the Mother dies. 4. Or both the Mother and Infant dies.

Caues hindering Labour] are, 1. When the Pains of the Birth are none, or not ufficient. 2. The great weaknes of the Mother. 3. The greatnes and trength of the Child; and on the contrary, the
lender and tender Contitution of the Mother, or when the paages are o traight that the Infant cannot come through them. 4. The number of Children, epecially if they endeavor to come forth at the ame time. 5. The tranvere, or any other preternatural poture of the Child. 6. If the Child in the Birth it elf be fallen down with its Head upon the fore-port of the Oa-Pubis: which cae Authors of the greatet account, whom I know, and our Midwives have not at all oberved; o by how much the greater the Pains of the Birth are, there is o much the les hope of coming out, except the Head be firt a little raied, and the Foetus be turned towards the back, and o into its true paage by the hand of the Midwife. 7. The Weaknes of the Child it elf, which makes it not able to add any thing towards its Excluion. 8. The Death of the Child. 9. The not ufficient recees of the Hip-bones towards the Back; for the Oa-Pubis, except in the very hardet Labours, and then but very eldom do divide.

div.head: The Signs of a Dead Child are as followeth.
div.p: The Mother feels no more the Motion of the Infant, although trengthening Cordials be exhibit'd; but in this cae when the Infant is as it were tir'd, tirs it elf a little, you have a much more certain Sign. Take a piece of the Crum of Bread, and dip it in Canary Wine, and apply it to the Navel of the Mother, then open a Vein in the Foot, and if by the ue of thee things, there follows not a motion of the Infant, it is a very ill Sign.

When the Mother turns her elf from one ide to the other, and perceives the Child to fall on the
ide laid upon, like a tone or a great weight; the Face, and chiefly the Lips grow pale, the extream parts cold, as likewie the lower Belly, the Paps begin to grow lank, the Breath becomes fetid, great pains of the Head, Faintings and Fevers, Water and tinking Gleet flows out of the Womb; If the After-Birth be excluded before the Child, 'tis impoible the Child can live long; but the uret ign of all is, if the Membrane of the Head of the Child be not oberved to be any longer tene; for as long as it is tene, the Infant lives.

Prognotick.] Except the dead Child be uddenly drawn forth, it puts the Mother in great hazard of Life. The Fever not being great, other Symptoms, though great and fearful, yet take not away the hope of recovery.

The Cure.] If Medicines, with the aid of Mother and Midwife, profit little, then mut the buines be committed wholly to the Chirurgeon, except the Woman be too weak, or the Child having been dead for many days, which he ought to conider, let he loe both his Credit and Labour.

But firt, it is diligently to be enquired into, which of the Caues it is that hinders the Birth: If the Child be greater and the paage traighter than uually, they ought to be dilated; this ome Midwives do with convenient Intruments, and o draw forth the Child alive; but where they are wanting, the Midwife mut clutch her hand very cloe, and thrut through the Internal Orifice into the Womb it elf; then putting her Fingers one after another through the Orifice into the inner part of the Womb, to dicover the ituation of the Child; and if he finds the Arms or Feet to come inconveniently, let her gently raie it up, bringing
the Head downwards, which if he finds to be next the Orifice, if poible, let her put in her other hand through the Pudenda into the Womb, and o with both her hands laying hold of it, draw it forth.

But if this Operation cannot be performed, then with a hook firmly fixt (let it injure the inide of the Womb) in the Mouth, Eye or Ear of the Child, and o gently draw it forth; and if the Faetus will not follow, then with another Hook, blunt on the out-ide, and harp within, let him cut in pieces the Belly, Breat, or Head of the Child; and if the Arms or Legs cannot be brought forth, let him cut them off; o at length, being deprived of its Limbs, the remainder may be drawn forth.

But if by this way the Woman can neither be deliver'd, with a harp and trong Knife, the Limbs one after another are to be cut out, and o the Child be drawn forth by piece-meal: It is neceary that this be perform'd by none but a good Anatomit.

The Secundine will preently follow the Birth, for it's of no ue, that being excluded; for the Mouth of the Womb, uddenly after delivery, is o cloly hut, that not without great pain it can admit the Hand of the Midwife; therefore the Midwife, as oon as may be, is to draw it forth, and with her fingers, if it ticks very cloe to the Womb, gently to eparate it, but not pluck it a way forcibly, which is mortal; and although many Writers and Midwives of inferior Rank, little regard the retention of the After-Birth for ome time after delivery; yet I think I have good reaon to pronounce it, one of the greatet Symptoms of Womens Labour.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. Of the Extirpating of a Mortified Part.
div.p: WHen a Dead Part altogether becomes ueles, that it may not do any injury to the neighboring Parts, it is to be taken away: But in what place? Mot convenient is the Joynt; but the cure by uch Extirpation is render'd more difficult, and the ue of the Part altogether lot; therefore the Extirpation is better to be made two, or three, or more fingers breadth below the Joynt, except the Mortification hath extended it elf to the uppermot part of the Arms or Thighs; for then we are forced to take the Joynt it elf: But again in what Part: whether in the whole or Mortified? The Amputation is more afe in the ound Part, although accompanied with greater Pain.

div.head: The common way both of the Ancient and Modern.
div.p:
The Patient having receiv'd convenient nourihment, is to be placed upon a Form; then let the Skin and fubjacent Mucles be drawn up as much as poible, by a trong Man, and there kept; and an inch above the place where the Member is deign'd to be taken off, with a narrow Ligature is the Part to be very hard bound; this done, with a dimembring Knife, the Skin with the Fleh is peedily to be cut all round to the Part, and the Periotium, by craping, is to be eparated from the Bone; and
if it be where there is a double Bone, as in the Leg, and below the Elbow, the Fleh and Ligaments between them is to be divided; which being performed, let the Bone be eparated with a very harp Saw. If the Flux of Blood be not great, to apply only thoe Medicines that top Blood, will be ufficient; but if great, an actual Cautery is to be ued, which is only to be applied upon the great Veels; then let the Ligature be taken off, and the Part be fitly bound up.

If either the Patient or Chirurgeon be avere to the ue of a Cautery, then as oon as the Member is taken off, let the Skin together with the Fleh, in four ditinct places oppoite one to the other, be taken up with a Needle and waxed Thread, and the Ligature being looened above, or drawn down, that, if poible, they may meet: So by this way is the Hemorage taid, the Bone preerved from all danger, and the Wound ooner cured. But this way is painful and troubleom, therefore ought it the eldomer to be ued.

div.head: Aquapendens his way.
div.p:
When the principal deign of Art in this Operation, is to put a top to Putrefaction, to caue as little pain as may be, and to tay the Flux of Blood, all which the above-quoted Author thinks may be done, if the Member be amputated in the dead Part, but near to the ound; then the Bone being divided with burning-hot Irons, let the remainder of the dead Part be cauterized, till the Patient perceive the heat of the Fire: So he writes, that by this coure a Flux of Blood is not to be feared, les pain is caued, and within the pace of two
or three days, will appear a eparation of the Mortified Part from the Sound; but in my opinion, we ought to conider well of the Caue. For in a Spacelus, prung from an Internal Caue, in a Body otherwie ound, this way is the bet; but in a Spacelus caued from a defect of innate Heat, the former is more profitable.

div.head: CHAP. XXV. Of the Flehy Rupture.
div.p: SArcocele, which is a Flehy Rupture, is a Tumor beides Nature, produced from impure Blood, flowing in too great quantity itno the Teticles, and there degenerated into Fleh.

In this Definition, received by the bet Phyitians and Chirurgeons, I note two things: 1. The caue of this Tumor, not to be impure Blood, eeing the bet, may produce it; not imply abounding in quantity, becaue it alo happens in wated Bodies, though 'tis not o oon generated, nor arrives to uch a greatnes in thee, as in thoe Bodies; but the true caue is the Eroion, Rupture or Dilatation of the Membranes which cloe the Mouths of the Capillary Veels, that the nutritious Blood may not flow too uddenly into the Part; from whence, more Blood flows into the Part than what is required for its nourihment; and Nature changeth that Blood which otherwie would purifie into a flehy Subtance. 2. This fleh ometimes grows to the econd of the common Tunicles of the Scrotum, and not to the Teticles, in which cae it may be taken aways,
without either hurting, or cutting of them out.
Signs are, the hardnes, and low encreae of the Tumor, which is rather more troubleome than painful, except accompanied with harp Humors; no appearance of any Tumor in the Groin.
Prognoticks.] A Sarcocele is hardly cured by the help of Medicines, and eldom by manual Operation, without taking off the Teticle, if it extends it elf into the Groins, for the mot part incurable.

Cure.] In the beginning, when the Membranes of the Veels being eroded, broke or dilated, do give leave for too much leave to iue forth, Bleeding, and the ue of Repelling and Retringent Medicines profit much; but when it hath begun to augment, then we may ue thee following means: Let there be made a little Orifice into the Scrotum, rather in its Superior then Inferior Part, through which, by the help of Plegets let Suppurating Medicines be applied, o that if poible, to wate the Fleh, every dreing diligently wiping away the Matter, but not at all, that the remaining Fleh may be the better conumed.

If thee things ucceed not, draw forth the Teticle, and by Inciion take off as much Fleh as may be done without injury to it; then retore it again into its place, and the remainder of the Fleh endeavor to conume by Suppuration.

But if there be no hope of curing this Rupture by the recited means, draw forth the Hernious Teticle as far as you may, then pas once or twice a Silken Thred above the Tumor by the Proces of the Peritonaeum; then pas both ends of the Silk through the Orifice it elf, o that which
was on the right ide, may be on the left, and that of the left, on the right; and having ordered that the proces of the Peritonaeum may be tied with a knot, then cut off the Teticle, letting both the ends of the Silk hang out of the Scrotum, and o cure it as another Wound.

I cannot here but friendly advie, 1. The Chirurgeon ought to conider well of the Caue, before he comes to the Operation it elf; for ometimes the Paratates are o well'd, epecially the Teticles being Scirrhous, that they may eaily deceive a very curious Examiner. 2. The Ligature ought to be made as near to the Tumor as poible, for by how much the higher part of the Proces of the Peritonaeum be perforated, it is oberved to be o much the thicker, which thing will retard the Suppuration and the falling of the Thread; in the mean time Convulions coming on, denounce death. 3. The Spermatick Veels detain'd in the Scrotum, oftentimes by Natures variety, exceed the Teticles themelves in greatnes, which caues no other inconvenience but only Fear, which I have oberved to be true, in more than one.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI. The Extraction of the Stone out of the Bladder.

p.hi: THe Stone is a hard Body concreted from Slimy, Salt or Earthy Matter, by a peculiar Lapidifying quality, cauing Pain, Obtruction; and other Symptoms in the place where it is detained.

div.p: The Caue is a Pituitous, Salt or Earthy Matter, which neither by heat nor cold, by a peculiar lapidifying quality is changed into a Stone.

Signs.] The Urine is white, limy, crude and troubled, uddenly adhering to the Urinal; ometimes it is bloody, ometimes andy or gravelly; ometimes full of little Threads, and not eldom uppret; a great thirt, a frequent making of Urine, but with pain and by drops: The Patients place themelves with their Thighs acros, always holding their Privy-Parts in their hands, preing the bottom of their Belly; the Privy-Part is always erected, very painful to go or walk, in the Region of the Belly a weight perceived, the Patient eldom making Water without going to Stool, the Intetine commonly falls out, epecially in young People.

Although all thee Signs eem plain, yet they may ometimes deceive a Phiician; it was formerly the Cutom with a Catheter paed through the Ureter into the Bladder, then thruting in one or two fingers into the Anus, not only to earch for the Stone, but alo undertand its greatnes. But this earching was o very painful, that it was difficult, through fear of pain, to have it permitted a econd time; and this thing gave occaion to have ready at the econd time of earching, all Intruments neceary for cutting out the Stone; but the Omnipotent and great Prince of Phyicians hath now granted to thoe mierable Patients, thoe Chirurgeons, who not only without Catheter, but alo without pain, both in old People and Children, which can mot certainly find out the Stone; and for this Reaon they Excel the o much Eteem'd French-men. I wih other places may may enjoy the ame Artits.

Prognotick.] A crumbling Stone eldom, a hard Stone can never be wated by Medicines, whatoever boating perons may ay; ometimes it is o oft, that by the very Catheter it elf it may be broke to pieces in the neck of the Bladder, and be brought forth; ometimes through its malnes it comes forth whole; ometimes it ticks in the Urethra, out of which, without danger and great pain it cannot be removed; if it ticks in the Tunicles of the Bladder, or grows to the Superficies of the Interior Coat, it cannot be taken away by Section, without the death of the Patient: By how much the greater the Stone is, the Operation is the more dangerous and painful. Stones are often drawn forth out of Womens Bladders about the bignes of an Olive, or a Walnut, without Inciion: but this way by Dilatation, of Extracting the Stone, is o dangerous, that it ought not to be performed but by experienced Chirurgeons.

Cure.] Stones generated in the Kidneys, Bladder, or other parts of the Body (for, they may in any) in general, require the aitance of the Phyician; but we in this place treat only of the manner of drawing them forth out of the Bladder by Inciion. There are everal ways by various Authors propoed; but that which follows, is the mot common, and mot ure.

Let the Chirurgeon place his Patient on a oft Pillow in a trong mans Lap, after he has three or four times jumpt from a high place, then let him tie both his hands to the oles of his Feet, and let two tanders by hold each Knee, extending them as far as may be one from the other; then let him take the firt Finger of his left-Hand, or if neceity requires, the two firt, anointed with Oyl of
Lillies, Roes, or freh Almonds, and thrut them up the Fundament, with his right hand gently compreing above the Os Pubis, o that the Stone may lip down under the Os Pubis, into the Perinaeum, which when brought thither by the foreaid Fingers, let him make Inciion with a harp Knife in the left ide between the Teticles and the Anus, near to the Suture of the Perinaeum, cutting to the very Stone it elf; and if it comes not out of the Wound it elf, nor by the thruting forth of the Fingers which are in the Intetinum rectum, let him draw it forth with a pair of Forceps, or which is better, with the Lapidillum or Spoon. The Stone being taken out, and all the Ligatures looed, let the Wound be bound up according to Art, applying Medicines, topping Blood, viz. of Meal and Bole, &c. with the greatet care to conolidate it as oon as poible, let the Patient labour with a dropping of his Urine through the wounded part: And this is the manner of drawing forth the Stone, which Chirurgeons ue to call Apparatus Minor, which chiefly is ued in Children, although there are thoe which proceed thus in People of full growth: But in our Country always this Inciion is made by them whoe Fingers are fitted for this Operation,

But in People of full Age it is ometimes very difficult to reach the Stone by the Fingers put up into the Fundament, and after the ame manner to bring it down into the Perinoeum, if not altogether impoible, as many think it; therefore there is another way found out, which they call Apparatus Major; the Patient is put on a Table, and bound, and held as above, the Chirurgeon through the Uretra paeth a Director into the
Bladder to the Stone, then Inciion being made as obove, in the hollow of the Director, puts in the Conductor, taking the Director out of the Uretra, he paeth into the Wound the Forceps, the Lapidillum, or other Intrument convenient for drawing out the Stone, by which he may both lay hold of it, and draw it forth, not making ue of his Fingers in the Anus, except great neceity compel him to it. Where the Stone is bigger than the Orifice, and cannot come forth, the Wound is to be enlarged, or the Stone to be broken into pieces by the Forceps, and o drawn forth in parts: This done, the Binding and Conolidating the Wound, ought to be the ame as in Children, giving it a titch if it be too great, putting in a Silver-Pipe for two or three days, that may give paage to the Concreted Blood, Slime and Sandy Urine.
The manner is the ame in Women, but only the Fingers are not put into the Anus, but into the Privy-Parts, and the Catheter mut not be crooked, but traight, and much horter than the other.

There is likewie another manner of drawing forth the Stone; the Chirurgeon thruting his Finger into the Anus, preeth the Stone upwards to the Belly; then through the Wound made in the right Mucle above the Os Pubis, according to the ductus of its Fibres, by the aitance of the Lapidillum or Forceps draw forth the Stone; by this way is never oberved any coming forth of the Urine, and the place uppoed convenient to draw forth the Stone: But this Operation in it elf is dangerous and troubleome, and if the Lips of the Wound made in the Bladder unite not to the Mucles of the Abdomen, there follows an Ulcer of the Bladder, more painful, but les cureable
than the Stone it elf; which inconveniences have caued it not to be reckoned among other Operations by true Practiers.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII. Of the Hare-Lip.
div.p: THe fourth and lat Part of Chirurgery call'd Anaplerois, which retores what is deficient, is chiefly ued when any part of the Noe, Lip, or Ear is wanting, whether it be from the Birth, or from an External Caue,

As to the Lip, in a little defect, let it be firt eparated from the Gums, then let the edges be carified and joined together with a Needle, laying over it an aglutinating Plaiter, and o in a hort time the Cure will be performed.

In a greater Defect, let the Lip be eperated from the Gums, then put a Linnen Cloth between, and let the Extremities be brought together by Bandage, after ome few days, convenient Scarification being made, by the help of a Stitch, and Plaiters, let the ends be united.
The Noe and Ears being depriv'd of any part, after what manner they are cured, Taliacotius in a particular Treatie hath largely et down; to the which I refer the Reader.

div.trailer: The End of the firt Part.

div.head: BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Second Part.
Which treats of Tumors, Wounds and Ulcers: In three Books.
The Firt Book of the Second Part of Chirurgery. Of Tumors.
CHAP. I. Of Tumors in general.
div.p: A Tumor beides Nature, is a Dieae in which the Parts of the Body are indecently inlarlarged and extended, o that they are rendred unfit to perform its Actions.
The Differences of Tumors are taken, 1. From the Part affected; as an Inflammation of the Eyes, Jaws, &c. 2. From the Caues.

The Caues are, 1. The Parts of the Body removed out of their Natural place. 2. The Four Humors,
as well Natural as Preternatural, viz, Blood Choler, Phlegm, Melancholy, to which likewie we add Serum and Wind.
Tumors for the mot part are generated from the Humors, and that either by Congetion, or Fluxion.
They come by Congetion, when the Natural heat of the Part being diminihed, the good Humors are ill concocted, or the vicious are not ufficiently evacuated.
By Fluxion, from a two-fold Caue, External, viz. a Fall, Blow, External Heat, too great Motion, &c. Internal, viz. Pain, Superabundancy, Thinnes, Acrimony of Humors, &c.
The Signs of Tumors are, an Extention of the Part, Pain, Rednes, Heat, Hardnes, &c. But thee are better explained in particular Tumors, than in general.

The times of Tumors (for all curable Tumors have four) are as followeth, Beginning, when the Part begins to well; Increae, the welling, pain, and other Symptoms are augmented; State, the Symptoms tand at a tay, and grow not worer; Declination, when the Symptoms are diminihed.

Prognotick.] Tumors produced from Phlegm or Melancholy, are hard of Cure. Thoe are dangerous, which are generated from corrupt Blood or Choler, which eizeth the Internal Parts, which hew themelves about the greater Veels, Joynts, Nerves, and the Membranous or Noble Parts: Thoe that are of great bignes, and that happen in Cacochymick Bodies.

They are Terminated four ways; 1. By Diipation, which the leening of the Symptoms do declare. 2. By Suppuration, wherein the Pain
and Pulation is increaed together with a Fever. 3. By Induration, which the too often and immoderate ue of Repelling and Diipating Medicines hath caued. 4. Degenerating into a Gangrene, from the defect of Natural Heat.
The Cure is performed two ways: 1. By hindering any further Flux to the Part. 2. In removing that which is already gathered in the Part.
We tay the Flux of Humors, 1. By Intercepting. 2. By Repelling. 3. By Revelling. 4. By Derivation. 5. By Corroborating the Part it elf.

The Matter already gathered, is taken away, 1. By Atringing and Repelling Medicines, to wit, when 'tis thin, and ticks not too firm to the Parts. 2. By Reolvents, when it is thick, and adheres more firmly to the Part. 3. By Suppuratives, when the other are too weak. 4. By Fire and Cutting, when other means effect nothing.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Inflammation.
div.p: A Phlegmon or Inflammation is a Tumor beides Nature, from Blood thrown forth into the Skin or Subjacent Mucles, cauing Heat, Rednes, Pain, Pulation and Tenion.
Difference.] 'Tis Perfect, when from Blood alone: Imperfect, when Choler Phlegm, or Melancholy is mix'd with the Blood, and then 'tis called Phlegmone, Eryipelatodes, Oedematodes, Schirrhodes.
The Caue is ometimes Blood alone, ometimes mixt with other Humors.
Signs, are Heat, Rednes, Pain, Pulation, Shining, Tenion, Hardnes, Renitency.

Prognoticks.] An Inflammation of the External Parts frees the Internal from many Dieaes; always wholeome, except from its too great Extention it produceth a Gangrene; dangerous and of hard cure is that which eizeth on the Eyes, Jaws, Penis, Pudendum Muliebre and Joynts. In a young Peron, and in Summer oon cured; longer of Cure, in a fat, than a lean Body.

The Cure hath four Indications. The firt of thee repects a good Diet; let him chue a clear Air, his Meat and Drink little, and that cooling; all hot, weet and fat things, as Pepper and Ginger, are hurtful; as alo the motion of the Body, epecially of the Part affected; Sleep is very convenient: All Cotivenefs, Anger and Venery are noxious,

Second, that tops the further Flux of the Humor, which may be performed by Revulion, Derivation, Repelling and Interception; therefore let a Vein be opened as oon as poible, it being mot neceary: Revulion is made in the Oppoite and mot Remote part, Derivation in the nearet: If you may not open a Vein, you mut ue Leeches and Scarifications. Whilt thee things are done, eeing the Body is eldom clean, but that always there are ill Humors mixt with the Blood, by Purging rightly ued, and often repeated, as alo Bleeding, we effect much.

In the mean time, the Part affected requires Repelling Medicines, from which we mut abtain, Where, 1. The Noble Parts end the Humors
to convenient places, and to the Glandules. 2. Where the Humors are Malignant. 3. When Critical. 4. When the Body is very impure. 5. When the part affected is very weak or painful. 6. Where the Inflammation is about ome Noble Part.

div.head: Repelling Medicines.
div.p: The Roots of Bitort, Tormentil; the Leaves of Cyprus, Mirtles, Plantain and Oak; the Flowers of Balautians and Roes, Quince-eeds, Red Sanders, Galls, Acacia, Dragons Blood, Whites of Eggs, Vinegar, Red Wine, Allum, Bole, Oyl of Roes, Myrtles, Empl. de Spermate Ranarum.
Take Roe-Vinegar two ounces, Whites of Eggs beat together No. 2. Bole-Armenick, three drams; Lap. Hematitis, a dram; Mix them.

Take the Juice of Houleek, Purlane, and Plantane, of each an ounce; Roe-Vinegar, owr Red Wine, of each an ounce and half; Oyl of Myrtles, an ounce: Stir them together in a Leaden Morter, adding to them of the Powder of Pomegranate Rinds and Bitort, of each a dram: Make it into a Linament.
3. Indication requires the taking away the Humor already in the Part. Here Reolvents are firt to be ued; but they not effectual, then Suppuratives.

div.head: Reolvents or Dicuives.
div.p:
Roots of Galangal, Orrie, Dill, Southernwood, Rue, Savin, Flowers of Camomil, Melilot, Elder, 2 Anieeds, Carraways and Cummin Ammoniacum,
Bdellium, Sagapenum, Tacamahac, Oyl of Dill, Nard, Rue, Bays; Ointment of Agrippa Martiatum; Emplaiters of Betony, Oxicroceum, Diachilon, Leaven, the Dung of Beats, Spirit and Lees of Wine.

Take Roots of Orrie, Marh-Mallows, of each an ounce and half; the tops of Wormwood, Flowers of Camomile, Melilot, of each one Pugil; Herbs, of Pellitory of the Wall, Mullein of each one handful; Meal of Barley, and Fenugreek, as much as is ufficient; Boil them in White Wine, then being beaten together, add of Oyl of Orrie and Camomile, of each an ounce: Make it into a Cataplam.
Or,

Take Cows-dung, three ounces; Juice of Hemlock, one ounce; Oyl of Camomile half an ounce; Cator, two drams, Bole-Armonick half a dram; Red Myrrhe, two drams; Saffron, one dram; Meal of Lupines, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Poultice.

div.head: Suppuratives.
div.p: Marh-Mallow Roots, Mallows, Camomile-Flowers, Figs, Galbanum, Bdellium, Sagapenum, Ammoniacum, Fat of Hogs, Geee, Ducks, Hens, Oyl of White-Lillies; Ointment of Marh-Mallows both Simple and Compound, Bailicon, the Plaiters of Diachylon, of Muilages and Melilot.

Take Onions roated in Embers, three ounces; Figs, No. x. beat them together, adding of Ointment of Bailicon, ix drams; Ducks-Greae, an ounce; Virgins-Honey, and the Meal of Lineed, of each as much as is ufficient to make it into a Cataplam. Or,

Take the Roots of White-Lillies, Marh-Mallows, of each an ounce ane half; Leaves of Mallows, Cows-Parnips, of each an handful; Figs No. viij, Raiins, ix drams; Meal of Marh-Mallow-Roots, or of Wheat, two ounces; Venice-Sope, three drams; being boil'd and train'd, add to them of Hogs-greae on ounce, Oyl of Camomil two ounces: Mix them according to Art, and make a Cataplam.
4. Indication repects the Symptoms, which, if not removed, hinder the Cure; the chief of which are,
1. A Fever; The chief of which concerns a Phyician, except it be removed by Bleeding.
2. Hardnes, whoe Cure look for in the Chapter of Schirrhus.
3. A Gangrene; Which is treated of in a particular Chapter.
4. Pain; Which we do remove by the following Medicines.

div.head: Anodines.
div.p: Marh-Mallows, Dill, Mallows, Camomil, Henbane, Tobacco, Lin-eed, Seed of Poppy, Fenugreek, Sperma Ceti, Cream, White of Eggs, Oil of White-Lillies, Lineed, Ointment of Populeon, fat of Hogs, Hens, and Mans Opium.
The great Vertues of the following Poultice I have not eldom experimented.

Take Flowers of Dill, Camomil, of each a handful; Elder, a handful and half; Lineed-Meal, four ounces; Oil of Dill, White-Lillies, of each half an ounce; Boil them in Milk to the conitence of a Poultice.

div.head: CHAP. III. Eryipelas.
div.p: ERyipelas is a Tumor beides Nature, from Choler, thrown forth for the mot part only into the Skin it elf, ometimes on the ubjacent Mucles, cauing Pain, Heat and other Symptoms.

Difference.] 'Tis perfect, when prung from Choler alone; as it is imperfect, when Blood, Phlegm or Melancholy is mixt with it; from whoe Appellation it likewie takes its name, and is called Eryipelas, Phlegmonodes, Oedematodes, Scirrhodes; ometimes an Ulcer is joined with it, which ometimes conumes only the Skin, other times the Fleh it elf.
Caue is Choler, eldom alone, ometimes mixt with Phlegm and Melancholy, but oftentimes with Blood or Serum; whence, thoe Medicines that are proper for a Phlegmon, oftentimes do good in an Eryipelas.

Signs.] Great heat, harp pain, Rednes mixt with Yellownes, eaily giving way to the touch, but as uddenly returning; the Swelling and Extention of the part little, and the Pulation leer: which lat gave occaion to Authors, of quetioning whether an Eryipelas ought to be reckoned amongt Tumors. It is accompanied always with a Fever, except from an External Caue.

Prognoticks.] An Eryipelas is eldom dangerous, except the Matter be repell'd from the External parts to the Internal; yet more dangerous,
when it eizeth on the Noble Parts and Jaws; and when a Wound; Fracture, Dilocation or Putrefaction are join'd with it.

Cure.] What concerns Diet here, is firt and chiefly to be conidered; Air, Meat and Drink mut be cooling; all harp, hot, fat and weet things hurt; as likewie do too great Motion of the Body, Watchings, Cotivenes, Venery and Anger.
Purging is very neceary, therefore thoe Medicines decribed in the third Chapter of the firt Part, are here convenient.

A perfect Eryipelas admits not of Bleeding; for the fatnes of the Blood bridles the harpnes of the Choler: But if the Fever be vehement, the Flux great, and any Blood (which for the mot part happens) be mingled with the Choler, 'tis convenient to bleed, epecially in Plethorick Bodies: In delicate and weak Bodies, Cupping-Glaes, with Scarification or Leeches, if things hould require, will erve,
Thee being thus done, to provoke Sweat, is the bet of all other Remedies.

Outwardly to the affected part, ought not to be applied, 1. Oyl, or any fat thing; as thoe things which yield matter to the Choler, eaily increae Putrefaction: But if yet it is your pleaure to ue them, they mut be tempered by mixing them with other Medicines. 2. Repellents, except the Eryipelas be very little, the Part affected remote from the Noble Part, and the Humors be yet flowing, and then they ought not to be ued without Reolvents mixt with them.
The Cataplams decribed in the foregoing Chapter, may for the mot part be applied here with ucces.

The Plaiter of Diapalma diolved in Vinegar, is in dayly ue; the leaves of Tobacco, Colewort, and Henbane applied to the part affected, trongly draw forth the heat. There are thoe which ue Sheeps dung boiled in Wine-Vinegar; as alo the Flowers of Camomil, Mellilot, and Elders, boyl'd in new Milk.
Chalk powdred, put upon the Part, laying Cappaper over it, quickly and afely Cures.
The following Fomentations I have experienced to be of great Virtue.

Take Red Myrrhe powdred, two drams; Saccarum Saturni one dram; Camphire a Scruple, Opium 25 grains, White-Wine ix ounces: Let Linnen Clothes be dipt in it, and applyed warm to the Part, often renewing them, when dryed, or cold.
Another,
Take the white Troches of Rhais one dram, Camphire one Scruple, Spirit of Wine an ounce, Elder-water ix ounces: Mingle and apply it as before.
Fumes of Matick, and Frankincene may likewie be ued five or ix times a day, epecially if the Eryipelas be in the Face.

div.head: When an Ulcer accompanies it.
div.p: Take the white Troches of Rhais, two drams; Red Mirrhe, Litharge of Gold, of each a dram; Flower of Brimtone half a dram; Sarcocol, two Scruples; whites of Eggs, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Linament.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Oedema.
div.p: OEdema, is a Tumor beide Nature, ariing from Pituitous Matter, white, oft, without pain, oftner caued by Congetion, than by Fluxion.
Difference.] It is perfect, when it proceeds only from Phlegm: Imperfect, when mixt with other Humors; Thus Oedema, Phegmonodes, Eryipelatodes, Schirrhodes.
Caue is Phlegm, ometimes alone, ometimes confued with other Humors; for the mot part it is produced from the ill dipoition of the Limphaeducts.
Signs are Whitenes, Softnes, yielding to the Fingers; little Pain, and les Pulation.

Prognoticks.] If an Oedema degenerate into a Scirrhus, or Abces, it is hard of Cure. It is dangerous if a Conumption, or Dropie accompany it: it oftner happens in old People, Phlegmatick bodies in the Winter time, and in all thoe who with immoderate eating and drinking continually, debilitate the natural heat.

Cure.] This, as the precedent Tumors, requires a good Diet Meat and Drink, as alo the Air mut be moderately hot and dry: Roted Meat is better than Boiled; Fruit, Cheee, and Fih hurt; as alo too great a quantity of Meat and Drink: Wine, either of it elf,, or altered with hot Herbs is good; moderate Exercies of the body before Meals, is as profitable, as much Sleep, epecially
diurnal is prejudicial; Cotivenes, Ret, and Sadnes are Noxious.
Bleeding is altogether here unprofitable, and very eldom ued; but Sweating and Purging very neceary, ometimes Vomiting: Always regard mut be had to the Stomach.

To the Tumor it elf. In the beginning we apply Repelling Medicines mixt with Dicuives, but o, that the Dicuives exceed; afterwards we ue only Dicuives, though ometimes tronger, ometimes weaker, according to the condition of the Dieae.

Take Aloes three drams; Bole-armenick half an ounce; Acacia, Dragons blood, Cyprus Roots powdered, of each two drams; Saffron half a dram, Roe-Vinegar an ounce and half; Oyl of Mirtle and Earth-worms, of each an ounce; Wax, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Linament.
Another tronger.

Take Crude Brimtone, Ahes of Vine Branches, Sal-Gemme, of each two drams; Beanmeal two ounces, Vinegar an ounce, Oyl of Nuts a dram, Turpentine, and Wax, as much as ufficeth either to make it into the Conitence of an Ointment, or Cerat.
Another yet tronger.

Take Laudanum, an ounce and half; Frankincene an ounce; Styrax-Camitis half an ounce; Brimtone ix drams; Alom, Salt-peter, Ahes, of each two drams; Cows-dung half an ounce; Oyl of Rue an ounce; Turpentine, and Pitch, as much as ufficeth to make a Plaiter.

div.head: An Excellent Cataplam.
div.p:
Take Roots of Marh-mallows, three ounces;
Bryony, Dwarf-Elder, of each 2 ounces; Leaves of Sage and Rue, of each a handful; Savin, half a handful: Boil them in equal parts of Wine and Water; in the end, adding of Vinegar three ounces: then being well beat together, add Bean-meal two ounces and a half; Ahes, half an ounce; Cows-dung one ounce; Salt half an ounce; Leaven an ounce and half; Oyl of Camomil four ounces; Hoggs-greae, two ounces: Make it into a Cataplam.
If it comes to an Abces, which rarely happens, this Poultice is Excellent, epecially if the Vinegar be omitted, and in its room, Onions, and a quantity of Unguentum Bailicon be added.
If an Oedema proceed from a Conumption, Dropie, or ill habit of Body, till thoe Dieaes be cured that cannot.

I have ued often to Cure an Oedema with this Wine or Purging Conerve, and exactly rowling the Arms or Legs with Rowlers of 12 or 15 yards long, beginning from below, upwards, and o allowing no liberty for the Humor to decend: By this way the Noble Parts are Corroborated; the Preternatural Humors Evacuated, and the External Members in a few days pace retored to their former Condition.

Take Roots of Orrie Floren. an ounce; Seaholly and Parley, of each half an ounce: Rhubarb, Agarick, Trochi. of each three drams, Senna, ix drams; Cinamon two drams, Cloves half a dram. Sem. Siler. Mont. two drams: tye them in a Cloth, and let them infue in two pints of old White-Wine, then take every Morning four or five ounces for a Doe.
Or,
Take of Electuary of Juice of Roes an ounce; Jalap, a dram; Spirit of Salt, a cruple: Mix it in an Electuary.
Let the Patient take the quantity of a Bean, or Hazel-Nut every third or fourth day.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Scirrhus.
div.p: SCirrhus is a Tumor beides Nature, ometimes generated of Tough, Vicous Phlegm; ometimes of Melancholy, hard, not yielding to the touch, nor painful.
Differences; It is perfect when prung from Melancholy, or Phlegm alone: Imperfect, when other Humors are unnaturally mixt with it.
Caue, is Melancholy, or tough Phlegm.
Signs, great hardnes void of pain, of a white colour, if from Phlegm; if from Melancholy, Livid.

Prognotick.] A Scirrhus, where there is no pain, and upon which the hair grows, is altogether incurable, and if Livid, it is very dangerous, and often degenerates into a Cancer: An imperfect, mall, and painful one, by means ometimes (although very rare) may be cured.

Cure.] If the Scirrhus be produced from Phlegm, the ame manner of Diet is to be oberved as in an Oedema; but if from Melancholy, you mut chue a clear Air, moderately hot, and
moit; the Meat of the axe quality, and of eaie Digetion; all harp things, and thoe that are hot in the third or fourth degree, hurt: Let the Drink be neither thick nor trong, but warming Sadnes, Anger, Cares, Venery, much Sleep, hurtful; but moderate Exercies very neceary.
Bleeding is carce ever adminitred with any ucces, but Sweating, and Purging with great.
Amongt the External Remedies are Dicuives and Emollients; but yet the whole coure of the Cure mut be mixt, now increaing the quantity of the one, then of the other.
The ue of Suppuratives in the Cure of Schirrhus, hath eldom any good event.
There are thoe which try cutting out, and burning which mut be attributed to their rah ignorance, except contained in a proper Tunicle, and then the name of Schirrhus is ill attributed to that Tumor.

div.head: Emollient Medicines.
div.p: Butter, the fat of Hens, Geee, Ducks, Hogs, Foxes, Bears, Mans; Mallows, Marh-mallows, Orrach, Gums, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Bdellium, Styrax, Liquida; Ointment of Marh-mallows; Plaiters of Diachilon, of Muilages, and Mellilot.
Reolvents are et down in the Chapter of a Phlegmon.

Take Gum, Galbanum, Ammoniacum, Oppoponax of each an ounce; Flower of Brimtone, Red Myrrhe, of each half an ounce: Camphire, a dram; Oyl of White-Lillies, Ducks-greae, of each ix drams; Wax, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Plaiter.

Take Roots of Marh-mallows, three ounces;
Orrie, an ounce; Leaves of Colworts, Pellitory of the Wall, Mallows, Flowers of Camomile and Mellilot, of each a handful; Lineed two ounces, boil them in Water; and being well beat together, add to them Hore-dung two ounces; Hoggs-Greae, Oil of Camomil, of each an Ounce; boil'd Onions half an Ounce: Make a Cataplam.

div.head: CHAP. VI. De Tumore Aquoo, or Watry Tumor.
div.p: TUmor Aquous is a Collection of a Watry Humor in the whole body, or in ome one part; oft, and without pain, yielding to the Fingers, but uddenly returning.

Difference. Sometimes the whole body is well'd with water; which Tumor is call'd Anaarca, ometimes the lower Belly only, or with the Legs, and then it is called Acites; if Wind, mixing with the water, extends the Belly like to a Drum, it is call'd Tympanites: Thee are three kinds of Dropies, whoe Cure rather appertains to the Phyician than Chirurgion; Water collected in the Head, is call'd Hydrocephalos; in the Breat, a Dropie of the Lungs; in the Navel, a Hydromphalos; in the Cods, Hydrocele.
Caue is Serum, to wit Salt-water, produced from the lot heat of the parts that erv'd to Sanguification, and Chylification.
Signs; This Tumor is ofter then Oedema, and more yielding to the Fingers, without pain, with ome itching, and if you look on it by Candlelight, very hining.
Prognoticks.] Watry Tumors are not dangerous, if the principle parts that feed it, are not too much debilitated, yet all are of difficult Cure, epecially thoe in and about the Joynts.

Cure. Diet is here the ame as in Oedema: All Salt things indurated with Smoak, and too great a quantity of Drink, are very hurtful; as alo Spirit of Wine and Pepper; otherwie hot and dry Aliments are bet.
Purging is very neceary, provided it be not too great, let the parts already weak, are more weakned: provoking Sweat and Urine, here are very profitable.
Bleeding, by experience I know it to be hurtful to all Hydropick People.

div.head: Medicines, Purging Water.
div.p: Roots of Aarum, Dwarf-Elder, Jalap, white Mechoacans, Leaves and Bark of Elder, Euphorbium, Turbith, Gum Gutta, Syrup, and Species of Diacarthamum, Cream of Tartar.
Take Syrup of Roes olutive, with Senna, Diacarthamum, of each an ounce; Jalap, eight grains, Cream of Tartar, two cruples, Parley-water, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Potion.

div.head: A Purging Wine, which cures the Dropie it elf.
div.p: Take Roots of Orrie, Gentian, Succhory, Fennel, Materwort, of each an Ounce; the middle Bark of Elder, an Ounce and half; Leaves of Ground-pine, a handful; Roemary, two Pugils; Flowers of Centaury the les, one Pugil; Seeds of Smallage, Coriander, Carraway, Roman-Nettle, Fennel, of each a Dram, Senna two ounces; Agarick three Drams; Jalap half an ounce; Turbith, a Dram and half: Let them be cut, and infued in ix Pints of Rhenih-wine: Doe four ounces.

div.head: Medicines conuming Water, outwardly ued.
div.p: Roots of Orrie, Bryony, Birthwort, Flowers of Elder, Camomil, leaves of Celandine, Centaury, Calamint, Rue, Dill, wild Majoram, Sulphur vivum, Salt, Allum, Bay-berries, Ammoniacum, Bdellium.

Take Cows-dung, half an ounce; Pidgeons dung two drams; Sulphur vivum half an ounce; Nitre two drams; Honey, Vinegar, of each an ounce and half; Bean meal two ounces; Bay-berries, Cummin-eeds, of each half an ounce; Oyl of Dill, Nard, of each an ounce; White-wine, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Poultice.
Or,

Take Frankincene, Matick, Myrrhe, of each half an ounce; Camphire, half a Dram; Goats-dung, an ounce and half; Brimtone, Salt, Cummin-eeds, of each three drams; Turpentine and Wax, as much as ufficeth: According to Art, make it into a Plaiter.

Hydrocephalus is always of difficult Cure: Water contained in the Ventricles of the Brain, or between the Brain and Meninges, is very dangerous; but les dangerous, when collected between the Dura, and Pia Mater, or between the Dura Mater, and the Skull: For the Dura Mater may be divided into a Lancet, if you can come at it; but leat danger of all, when detained without the Skull.

Purging Sudorificks and Diureticks, eldom do any good here; but Cauteries, Bliters, Iues, Setons are more profitable; but ometimes we are forc'd to come to Inciion or Ution, which Remedies, although dangerous, have cured everal.

Some Chyrurgeons ue with an actual Cautery to burn the Skin of the Head in five, ix, or more
places, but not together and at once, but at everal times, let the Patients trength hould be too much pent, continually chooing that place, which the watry Humor makes, to appear mot convenient.
Some with a Lancet open the Skin near to the Sagital Suture.

Which of thee Remedies are bet, cannot abolutely be declared. I mut eteem an Actual Cautery, when the Water is between the Skin and the Skull; but if under the Skull, between the Meninges, I do not ee how this operation can be performed without a Lancet.

But which of them oever you chue, have a care of dicharging all the Water at once, for in the very Operation it elf the Patient dies, or at leat is very much debilitated; for till the end of the Cure, all the Water is not to be taken away, let the debilitated Parts be deprived of that heat which the Water poet, do corrupt: but rather what remains mut be conumed by Internal and External Dicuives; and this is to be oberved in all Watry Tumors that are Cured by a Paracentheis.
In the ame manner the Watry Tumor in the Navel and Cod ought to be handled, after other Medicines have been applied in vain.
Dropie of the Breat belongs not to Chirurgery, except where a Paracentheis is convenient; concerning which, Read the 15th. Chapter of the firt Part.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Flatuous, or Windy Tumor.
div.p: THe Flatuous Tumor is a Dieae produced of Wind, not yielding without reitance to the Fingers.
Difference. Some are without pain, others with it; in the one, the wind is in motion, in the other, quiet.

Caues of Wind, are Phlegm, epecially when mingled with Choler, which, as Ferment doth froth, o it proceedeth wind; it always happens upon a debility of the Parts, by reaon of which, although endeavoring to concoct the Humors, yet are notable.
Signs are Inflation, with a reitance yielding to the Fingers, a rumbling noie, epecially if haken.
Prognoticks.] It eldom comes is flehy parts; in other parts it brings many inconveniencies, in weak and Cacochymick bodies, it's of difficult and tedious Cure.

Cure.] The ame Diet in here to be oberved as in an Oedema: Peae, Beans, Turnips, Chetnuts, and all Crude Fruit do extreamly hurt; On the contrary, Wine, and other things moderately warming, profit; as alo Spices, and thoe things which dipere Wind, as Nutmegs, Mace, Anie, Carraways, Lovage.

The Stomach, and the whole Body require
purging and corroborating Medicines, always mixing with them thoe that dipere Wind, and ometimes alo where Corroboratives are ued, Anodines, Laudanum; Opiatum cautiouly ued (that is, half a grain, or a grain for a Doe) is here excellent: For beides that it ceaeth pain, it alo by its Diaphoretick quality removes the Caue of the Dieae: To caue Sweat, is as neceary as Bleeding is unneceary.

div.head: Outward Medicines dicuing Wind.
div.p: Roots of Galangale, Lovage, Herbs, Dill, Mint, Marjoram, Peniroyal, Roemary, Rue, Chervil; Flowers of Elder, Mellilot, Camomil; Seeds, Anie, Carraways, Cummin, Fennel; Nutmegs, Cardamum, Cator; Oyl of Rue, Nard, Spike, Dill, Carraway ditill'd; Mace, Nucita expret and ditill'd, Mellilot-plaiter.
Take Oyl of Wormwood, Rue, of each two Drams; Oyl of Nucitae expret, one Dram; of Mace ditilled, half a Dram; Cator, diolved in Aqua vitae, two Scruples: Make it into a Linament.
Or,

Take the Leaves of Rue, Calamint, of each half an handful; Bean-meal, two Ounces; Seeds of Cummin and Anie, of each half an Ounce; Bayberries, Salt, of each three Drams; Nitre, Brimtone, of each a Dram; Goats dung, ix Ounces; White-wine, as much as is ufficient: Mix them, and boyl them into the Conitence of a Cataplam.
Or,

Take the Roots of Pelitory of Spain, half a Dram; Venice-Sope, three Drams; Cator diolved in Aqua vitae, one dram; Seeds of Cummin,
Carraways, of each two drams; Ahes of Earthworms, half a dram; Oil of Spike, half an ounce; Matick, three drams, Wax and Turpentine, as much as ufficeth: Make it into a Plaiter according to Art.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. De Herpete.
div.p: HErpes is a Tumor beides Nature, prung from yellow Choler, disfiguring the Skin with corroding and preading Putules.
Difference.] Where Choler olely predominates, it produceth Herpes exedens, but where Phlegm is mixt with Choler, a Herpes Miliaris.

Caue is ometimes Choler alone, ometimes mixt with Phlegm; and I ee not why the erum of the Blood may not often be here taken as a Caue: For the Lymphaeducts being out of order, do produce Mutations in mans body, heretofore unknown.
Signs.] Are little Putules, like to Millet-eed; a heat, itching; and after rubbing, a moitnes, and little Ulcers.
Prognoticks.] Herpes is of difficult Cure, but of little danger, unles o rendred by the immoderate ue of Repellents.

Cure.] The ame Diet is here required, as in an Eryipelas. Moreover, Purging is here very neceary; Bleeding not to be allowed of; the ue of Baths is excellent, and their Waters taken at fit
times, afely Cure this Dieae: The Decoctions of China, Sala, &c. alo benefit much.
Outwardly.] Fating-Spittle oftentimes doth good, becaue if it hould be repelled to the Internal parts, it caueth a Feaver, and other ill Symptoms.

With great ucces many times, have I een applyed the Powder of Lapis Sciilis, mixt with Vinegar; ome ued Mutard boyl'd in Butter; to which they add ome Gunpowder. Lye alo, and Urine have helpt many; Unguent, Fucum, of Felix Wurtz is excellent here; as alo the following Plaiter.

Take Sarcocols, Crude Brimtone, of each two drrms; Matick, Frankincene, Lapis Calaminaris, of each half an ounce; white Troches of Rhais, Litharge of Gold, Myrrhe, of each three drams; Goats Suit, half an ounce; Wax and Turpentine, o much as is ufficient to make it into a Plaiter, according to Art.
Take the Powder of Chalk mixt with Cream, and anoint the part, fomenting it before with the hot Lees of White-wine.

div.head: In a Rebellious Herpes.
div.p: Take the brown Oyntment of Felix Wurtz, three drams; white Ointment with Camphire, one dram and half; Cerae, Brimtone, Myrrhe, of each a dram; Litharge a dram and half; Mercurius dulcis, Verdigreae, of each a cruple and half; Oyl of Roes, as much as ufficeth: Make it into an Oyntment.
Or,
Take Lapis Prunella, one dram; Flower of Brimtone, half an ounce; Salt of Saturn, a dram and half; old Oyl of Rape, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Linament.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Atheroma, Steatoma, and Meliceris.
div.p: A Theroma is a Tumor beides Nature, contained in a proper Cit, caued from a Humor like to the Pap of a odden Barley, without pain, of the colour of the skin, not yeilding to the ingers, nor when they are removed, uddenly welling out again.

Steatoma is a Tumor beides Nature, contained in its own proper Tunicle, caued from a Matter like to Suet, and of the ame colour, oft, from a mall beginning, by degrees increaing, difficulty yielding to to the Fingers, but they being removed, returning again to its former greatnes.

Meliceris is a Tumor beides Nature, included in its proper Tunicle, engendered from a Humor, like to Hony, without pain, round, eaily yeilding to the Fingers, which being removed, returns again to its firt Figure.

Differences.] This Matter like to Honey, Suet, or Pap, if gathered about the Joynts, is call'd a Ganglion; if about the Glandules of the Neck, a Glandula, Scrophula, or Struma; if in the Arms, Legs, or Head, Turberculum; if from the Pox, Tophus.
Caue of thee Tumors is Phlegm, in the one more, in the other les, receding from its Natural Contitution; and ometimes, but very eldom, mixt with Melancholy.
Signs are declared in their Definition.

Prognoticks.] They are carce ever cured, but by Manual Operation: If the Veicle be broken,
or not all taken out, there remains a Fitula, or a foul Ulcer: The Cure of which will be both difficult and tedious.
Cure.] They are ometimes, but very rare, removed by trong Reolvents: I have Cured ome with Balom of Peru; ome ue Oxicroceum Plaiter, or the following:
Take Laudanum an ounce; Red Myrrhe, three drams; Camphire a dram: Mix them; and make it into a Plaiter according to Art.
Another,
Take Gum Sagapenum, Ammoniacum, of each half an ounce; Roots of Pellitory, Euphorbium, of each a cruple and half; Brimtone three drams; Oyl of Amber a dram: Make it into a Plaiter.
If it break, and the Matter dicharge out of the Tunicle, then mut you ue Corroives, for other Medicines are too weak.

div.head: Corroives, and Cathereticks.
div.p: Roots of the black Hellebore, burnt Galls, burnt Date-tones, Verdigreae, burnt Alum, Quick Lime, Vitriol, Mercury Sublimate, and Precipitate; Spirit and Oyl of Vitriol, Spirit of Salt; the Liquor of Tartar; Oyntments of Aegyptiacum Fucum of Felix Wurtz; Ahes of Oak, and Vine branches.

Some ue Arnick, and Orpment; but they are not ued but with the greatet danger in thoe places known by Anatomy, under which the Nerves lye; to the Skin, and Carnous Excrecencies, they may be applyed with the les danger.

div.head: The following Ointment will uffice.
div.p:
Take Vitriol well weetned, a dram; Verdigreae, a cruple, Ointment of Aegyptiacum,
half an ounce: Make it into an Oyntment.
If they tend to Suppuration, which is very eldom, let the Surgeon ait Nature with Maturatives; but the afet Method of taking away thee Tumors, we have hewn in the twelfth Chapter of the firt Part.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Scrophula, Struma, or King's-Evil.
div.p: STruma or Scrophula are Tumors beides Nature, contained in a proper Tunicle of their own, from a Melancholick or Pituitous Humor; hewing themelves in manner of Tubercles in the Neck and adjoyning Parts.
Difference.] They are ometimes noveable, ometimes fixt; ometimes but one, ometimes many.
Caue, is Melancholy or Phlegm, or both mixt together.
Signs.] Are Hardnes, Inequality, and eldom painful.
