Prognoticks.] Thee Tumors are of long and difficult Cure; epecially if many, or fixt; they are dangerous when they grow painful, and threaten to become cancerous; or if fixt to any great Nerve or Vein, ometimes they are Hereditary, and ometimes peculiar to a Region or City; when cured, they for the mot part leave behind them great Skars; where the recurrent Nerve is divided, the Speech is lot, and oftentimes Life it elf.
Cure.] Diet mut be here the ame, as in a Oedema or Scirrhus.
Purging is neceary, but not Bleeding: provoking Sweat, by the ame way and means as in the French-Pox, effects much; yea, it alone cures the King's-Evil.
Sometimes they are conumed by Internal Remedies, that have appropriated Qualities of curing Scrophulas.
Such are thee:

Roots of round Birthwort, Briony, Sow-Bread, Dropwort, Devil's-bit, Orrie, Pimpernel, Pellitory of Spain, Squills, Vervain, Figwort, Leaves of Cypres, Bawm, Rue, Savory, Flowers of Broom, burnt Crabs, burnt Egg-hells, Sal Gemmae, Spunges.

New Spunges are much commended, if boiled in Ale; drinking thereof three or four times a day; or calcined, and taking half a dram of the Powder Morning and Evening. The following Powder is likewie very much praied:
Take the Ahes of Sea-Spunges, Os Sepiae, Long Pepper, Cinamon, Sal Gemmae, Pellitory of Spain, Cypres-Nuts, Galls, Red-Roe Leaves, of each half an ounce: Make a Powder. Doe, two Scruples or a Dram.
Or,
Take of Spunge-tone, three drams; Sal Gemmae, two drams; Salt of Tartar, a dram: Make a Powder. Doe, two cruples, or a dram.
Outwardly Reolving and Emollient Medicines are applied; which if they effect it not, then ue Suppuratives; when 'tis uppurated, it is to be cured as a malignant Ulcer.

But if the above-named Medicines ignifie nothing,
then we come to corroive Medicines, and to the Inciion-Knife.

div.head: An excellent Reolving Emollient Plaiter.
div.p: Take Gum, Galbanum, Ammoniacum, Bdellium, of each half an ounce; Bay-berries, Stavesacre, Pellitory of Spain, Cummin, of each ix drams; Pigeon's dung, a dram; Goat's-dung, three drams; Hog's-greae, an Ounce and half; Oyl of Camomile, an ounce; Wax and Pitch, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: A Liniment that tops the Flux of Humors, and oftentimes wholly cures the King's-Evil.
div.p: Take Oyl of Myrtles and Bayes, of each half an ounce; Ointment of Martiaton, an ounce; Quickilver extinct with Flower of Brimtone, ix drams: Make it into an Ointment.

Let the Scrophula be annointed with it twice a day; and if they are not conumed, at leat they will be diminihed: but the Chirurgeon mut look into the Patient's Mouth each day, let upon the continual ue of Mercury, there follows a Flux, which caues a welling of the Tongue and Jaws: The Plaiter of Frogs, with Mercury, is likewie good here.
Or,
Take Gum-Caranna, an ounce; crude Mercury extinct in Turpentine, three drams: Make a Plaiter.
If the Tumor he painful, there may be added to this Plaiter a dram of Opium, which hath the virtue of reolving and eaing pain, and is not cold, but hot.
Suppurating Medicines are et down in the econd Chapter, and Corroive in the foregoing Chapter.
In Suppurated and open Scrophulaes, this Ligament is much eteemed:
Take Oyl of Bayes, Cerue powdered and allayed with Aqua-vitae, of each an ounce; Roch-Allom, half an ounce; Salt, two drams: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of a Bubo.
div.p: BUbo is a Tumor beides Nature, of the Glandules, from impure Blood, Red, Painful and hard.

Difference.] Where little, and not painful, and eaily brought to Suppuration, 'tis called Phyma; but where there is more of Choler in it Phygeton; in the Arm-pits, Panus; behind the Ears, Parotis: The one Malign or Petilential, the other not; ometimes contracted from unchate Embraces, then 'tis called a Venereal Bubo.
Caue is Blood, never alone, but always mixt with ome other preternatural Humor.
Signs, are Rednes about the Glandules, pain, heat, tenion, hardnes, pulation, and ometimes a Fever.

The Liver and Spleen, according to the opinion of the Ancients, dicharge themelves into the Groins; the Breat and Heart, at the Arm-pits; the Brain, at the Glandules of the Ear; but now far other ue is attributed to the Glandules. Of which there are everal Tracts written, and we hall give our Opinion in another place.

Prognoticks.] The Bubo that is not Malign, is
not dangerous, except it be long dicuing, or uppurating, and then fear let it Fitulate: In the Arm-pits it is ooner brought to maturity than in the Groins; and here ooner than behind the Ears: On the contrary, a Malign is for the mot part a ign of udden Death, although all outward igns may appear well.

The Venereal is not mortal, but of hard Cure, and for the mot part precedes the Pox; chiefly when by Bleeding, or the ue of repelling Medicines, the Matter is returned from the External, into Internal parts.

Cure.] Diet the ame as in a Phlegmon: In a Benign, Purging is neceary, provided it be not with too trong Medicines: Bleeding, except a great Fever, or a Plethora require, I admit no more of it here, than of Repellent Medicines; for 'tis uneemly that Natures Aiter hould return that into the interior parts, which Nature her elf did eject (which for the mot part is Critical.) Sweating in all Buboes, profits much: Scarification hath no place here, except in Malignant, nor Leeches, but where very much inflamed.

The External Cure is to be managed o, that the Humor may be diipated with Reolvents, which by reaon of the frigidity of the Glandules, are required the tronger; adding alo Attractives to them; for in all, I upect let the Matter be not perfectly thrown forth: But in a painful Bubo, 'tis firt neceary to eae the pain, before you come to any other Medicines.

div.head: In extream Pain.
div.p: Take Muilages of the Seeds of Flea-wort, an ounce and half; the Yolk of an Egg, Saffron, a dram; freh Butter, half an ounce: Make it into a Liniment,
Or,

Take Leaves of Mallows, an handful; Meal of Marh-Mallow Roots, and Fenugreek-eeds, of each two ounces; Barley-meal, an ounce; Ducks-greae, Oyl of Dill, of each half an ounce: Boil them in Milk, to the conitence of a Cataplam.
Reolvents are above decribed; Attractives hall be preently et down.

If it yield not to dicuion, Suppuration is to be endeavoured; which is of all, the afet Method: Being uppurated, let it forthwith be opened; but rather by Inciion, than Cautery: And o let it be kept opened until the whole Tumor be diolved.

In Children, for the mot part, we commit it wholly to Nature; only precribing a good Diet, and forbidding the often touch of the part affected with the hands; or we apply the Plaiter of Diachilon, or of Muilages: 'tis alo often cured by the only uing of Oyl of Olives, Rape, Camomil, or white Lillies.
In a Petilential Bubo, neither Bleeding or Purging (whatoever others ay) mut be ued: Sudorificks and Refrigeratives are convenient; outwardly Attractives in the beginning, are neceary.

div.head: Attractives.
div.p: Roots of Aron, Briony, Birthwort, Pellitory of Spain, Dittany, Crees, Virgins-Flower, Leeks, Nettles, Garlick, Onions, Figs, Mutard, Gums, Galbanum, Ammoniacum, Euphorbium, Succinum, Cantharides, Cator, Ox gall, Pigeons greae, and Goats-dung; Quick-Lime, Nitre, Brimtone; Leaven, Black-ope, Plaiters of Diachilon, Oxicroceum, Thereacle, Mithridate.

Take Roots of Marh-mallows, an ounce; Onions, two ounces; Elder and Camomil-Flowers, of each a pugil; Figs, No xij. Fenugreek-meal, two ounces; Pigeons-dung, two drams; Thereacle, three drams: Make a Cataplam.
Or,
Take Roots of Pellitory of Spain, Mutard-eed, of each two cruples; Salt, two drams; Treacle, three drams; Gum Ammoniacum, diolved in Vinegar, as much as ufficeth to make a Plaiter.

Many take a Hen or Frog divided in the midt, and apply them warm to the affected Part, often changing them: Some apply to the Part the Breech of a live Hen or Pigeon, the Feathers being pulled off: Others take away all by Inciion, which is very dangerous, and not to be permitted: But they proceed bet, who forthwith in the very beginning apply a Veicatory to the Bubo; then the following Morning or Evening open the Bliter, and afterwards dreing it with Attractives: This is of great Ue, and of much Eteem.

Take the Plaiter of Diachilon with Gums, of Muilages, of each half a pound; Ointment of Bailicon, four ounces; Mutard-eed, three ounces: Make a Plaiter. More of the Cure of a Bubo, look in our Decription of the Plague.

In a Venereal Bubo, you mut neither Bleed nor Purge, as long as there remains any hope of Curing it by External Remedies, let the Malignant Humors which Nature threw out, hould be returned again into the Body, and o occaion the Pox: But Suppuration is to be endeavoured by all means, and the Suppurated Tumor
forthwith, yea, although the Matter be not perfectly concocted, is to be opened; if it is tough, as for the mot part it is, Attractives are to be applied, epecially Cupping-Glaes; they not being ufficient, when the whole Mas of Blood is infected, the Cure of the Pox is to be precribed; often uing this following Decoction.

Take Roots of China, Saraparilla, of each three ounces; Polipody, an ounce; Bark of Guaicum, three ounces; Senna, two ounces; Agarick Trochicatum, two drams; Cinamon, two drams: Infue in a ufficient quantity of Water over the Fire for 24 hours, then boil them to three quarts, and to the trained Liquor add Syrup of Roes, Sol. with Senna, four ounces: Mix them. Doe, ix or eight ounces.

Some make this Decoction with tale Beer or Wine; but in thee things the Surgeon ought to conider the pat manner of living of his Patient, his Temperature and Age: If you deire that it purge you more, you may add a dram or two of Trochie Alhandal; and if not trong enough, then you may mix it with five or ix grains of white Precipitate, provided trength gives leave.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Carbuncle.
div.p: A Carbuncle is a Tumor beides Nature, from adut Blood, corrupting the Part where it is collected.

Difference.] 'Tis called by the Greeks, Anthrax; by the Latines, Ignis Pericus; by the Germans, Een Kool: Some endeavour a Difference between an Anthrax and Carbuncle, but loe their Labour. There is is no other Difference, but ometimes it is bigger, ometimes leer, ometimes more Malignant, other times les.
Caue is adut Blood, auming the Nature of black Choler, and o apt to putrifie.

Signs are, ometimes but one great Putule, ometimes many litttle ones; which being opened, appear black, and all about enflamed: The Crut being removed, intead of Matter, you find pungy Fleh; the Part affected is very painful, a Fever preent and Watchings.
Prognoticks.] Very dangerous, when black, epecially in Plague time; when near to to a principal part, if great, and uddenly vanihing.

Cure.] Strong Purging Medicines I much mitrut; Cliters or looening Medicines will uffice; viz. Caia Fitula, Manna, Tamarinds, Cream of Tartar, &c. But more upicious to me is Bleeding to fainting (as Galen writes) and in its room, Leeches or Cups with Scarification will be ufficient. But I rely mot upon Sudorifick and Refrigerating
Medicines; uing outwardly the ame Medicines as in the Plague.
This Plaiter is much commended to make a eparation of the Eskar.

Take old Thereacle, Mithridate, of each half an ounce; Leaven, Turpentine, of each two ounces; Honey of Roes, an ounce and a half; Freh Butter, two ounces; White Vitriol, an ounce; Soot, two ounces and half; Black-ope, three ounces; Saffron, three drams; Yelks of Eggs, No iij. Mix them, and make a Plaiter according to Art.

The External Medicines ought often to be changed: Here is no need of Suppuratives; for the Humors are eaily corrupted of themelves; in the place of which, the Eskar being eparated, may be ued Ung. Fucum of Felix Wurtz, Aegyptiacum, and Honey of Roes, &c.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of a Cancer.
div.p: A Cancer is a Tumor beides Nature, prung from Black Choler, round, hard, livid, painful, full of turgid Veins, reembling the feet of a Crab.
Difference.] Where not exulcerated, by the Greeks it is named Carcinoma; when ulcerated, Plagedaena, by the Greeks; and by the Germans, De Wolf.

Signs.] In the beginning difficultly known, carce equalling a Pea in bignes; then ometimes increaing uddenly, ometimes lowly; it makes
it elf, by its grievous Symptoms, eaily enough to be known: The Tumor is hard, painful, hot, livid, or black, round with ome inequality, full of well'd Veins.

Prognoticks.] A Cancer is eldom Cured by Medicines, often by Chirurgery, but not without danger; harp Medicines exulcerate it: It is imprudence to attempt an occult Cancer, or that is detained in any Cavity of the Body, except it be very little, and may eaily be taken away by Inciion.
Cure.] Diet the ame as in Schirrhus; frequent Purging convenient; be cautious in Bleeding, as alo in Scarification. The Moneths flowing in Women, and in Men, the Hemorrhoids, are very beneficial.
Externally, Suppuratives and trong Dicutients are hurtful; the following, good.

div.head: Medicines in a Cancer.
div.p: Roots of Arum, Dropwort, Gentian, Figwort, Mullein; Leaves of Maidenhair, Houleek the greater, Agrimony, Tobacco, Plantain, Nighthade, Hounds-tongue, the Spawn of Frogs, of Whales, Burnt-Crabs, Burnt-Lead, Mans-Dung, Plaiters of Diapompholigos, of Lead, Diafulpharis, of Frogs with Mercury, Sugar of Sat√πrn, Camphire.

div.head: For a Cancer not ulcerated.
div.p:
Take the Juice of Plantain, Endive, Houleek the greater, Night-hade, Roe-Vinegar, Oyl of Myrtle, of each an ounce; Venice-Turpentine, two drams: Stir them together in a Leaden Mortar, with a Leaden Petle; adding of the Rinds of Pomegranates and Citrons, of each a dram; Bole-armonick, Burnt-lead, Camphire,
of each half a dram: Make it into a Liniment

div.head: For an Ulcerated Cancer.
div.p: Take Galls, Pomegranate-Rinds, of each half an ounce; Burnt Talk, an ounce; Bole-armenick, half an ounce; Burnt-Lead, two drams; Ahes of Crab-hells, a dram; Turpentine and Honey, as much as is ufficient: Make an Ointment.

By the ue of thee or the like Medicines, Cancers that are not ulcerated, have been often cured; and ulcerated Cancers have been for many years kept in the ame condition; but for the mot part, the buines is committed to Chirurgery: The Part affected being held by a pair of Forceps, is to be cut off by the help of a convenient Knife, but o that nothing of the Cancer be left behind, left it bud afreh; others holding it only with their left hands, or paing a tring quite cros, take it off by Inciion.
Many with great Praies extol prepared Arenick, or Mercury ublimate; but its Deeds anwer not their Words: Its Preparation John Faber in his Myrotheico Spargirico teaches.

div.head: The Quinteence of Arenick.
div.p:
Take Critalline, Arenick, with the like weight of Salt-Petre, and reduce all into the finet Alchool, and put them into a very trong Glas-Retort; to which joyn a Recipient big and large enough; being well luted together, ditil them with Embers, oberving the degrees of the Fire, at firt gentle, at the end very trong and violent, until all the Spirits of the Arenick and Salt Petre are gone forth: They being come forth, and the Veels cold, disjoyn the Recipient
from the neck of the Retort, having great care of the Spirits that are within, which are venomous; uddenly topping the mouth of the Receiver with a trong Lute; afterwards breaking the Retort, and that which is in the bottom, mut be powdered, and put into a new Retort, and upon the Powder that is put into the Retort, the Spirits of Arenick which were in the Receiver, is to be powred and ditill'd again, being luted well, as at firt: This is to be done three or four times, till the Arenick be well calcin'd with the Salt-Petre; then lay the Arenick upon a trong Tile, and for a whole day make a trong fire about it; o that which could not be Calcined by Ditillation, may be Calcined and burnt by an open Fire: This Calx of Arenick is to be diolv'd in ditilled Rain-water, and the Solution o cleaned and depurated, from its Terretrial Excrements, and by filtring made clear and limphid, is to be evaporated and dried, and calcined again with a very trong Fire, until it remits no Faeces in the Solution, but the whole Calx is diolved, and the Water remains mot clear and limphid; then the Water being evaporated, it is to be dried. Then latly, its above reerved Spirit is to be powred upon it, and mixt with it; but firt it ought to he even times rectified: You mut make this Conjunction in a Matrace (a Glas-Veel o called, by reaon of its roundnes in the bottom, and long neck) and in a warm Balneum, till the Calx hath imbibed its Spirit; then in a Glas-Alembick, you hall eparate by Balneum whatoever of waterih Humidity can be eparated, and there will remain in the bottom the Buttery Calx of Arenick: of great virtue, which mut be kept in a Glas-Veel well topt.

p.hi:
Take ome of this Powder, mix it with
Bailicon, or a Digetive; and thus mixt, apply to the ulcerated Cancer.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of a Gangrene and Sphacelus.
div.p: A Gangrene, is a beginning Mortification of the the oft Parts of the Body, mot commonly following a great Inflammation, or ill cured.

p.hi: Sphacelus, Necrois, Syderatio, is a perfect Mortification, not only of the oft, but of the hard parts alo.

div.p: Differences.] In a Sphacelus, the parts are altogether dead; but in a Gangrene, they begin but to die, and the ene is not perfectly abolihed; there the Skin is firt pallid, uddenly livid, then black; here in a manner red; greater tink in that, than in this.

The Caues of both are ix. 1. The External Cold of the Air, or Repelling Medicines. 2. External Heat, from burning, or ue of Corroive Medicines. 3. A Defect of Nutriment, as in an Atrophia, either by the compreion or obtruction of the Veels, by reaon of which traightnes the Blood cannot pas to the Part. 4. The topping of the Pores, or Perpiration hindred; from whence comes a Suffocation of the Natural Heat. 5. Malign Humor, either begotten in the Body, or contractee from venomous Beats, or Medicines. 6. The Scurvy, which by a peculiar property, caueth the Parts ometimes to mortifie.
Signs.] A Sphacelus is eaily to be known, the Part looks black; Spungy Fleh; Sene, Heat, and Pulation abolih'd.

But the Signs of a Gangrene vary according to the variety of the Caues: If contracted from Cold, a great pricking Pain is felt in the affected Part: Firt, 'tis red, then pale, at length black: The Natural heat by degrees is extinguihed, and there happens a haking, not unlike that in a Quartane Ague.

If caued from an External Heat, or topping of the Pores, the Rednes is changed into White, then into Black; Pulation and Pain ceae; the Senes leened; and at lat there appear ome Putules, from whence iue a gleety Humor.
If from defect of Aliment, there is neither Pain, Inflammation or Tumor; the Body waxeth cold, and for the mot part eizeth upon the Joynts.

If from a venomous Creature or Humor, great Pain and Fever always accompany it; frequent Faintings, and oftentimes Deliriums: Here arieth a Putule, under which appears a black Spot, which preads it elf over the whole part.

If from the Scurvy, it for the mot part begins at the Toes, it hews it elf outwardly with blackih pots and lines, which degenerates into a dry Crut; upon which follows a Numnes of the Part, and at length a Mortification it elf, without any Stink: Sometimes without pain, other times very great, epecially in them that are given to Paion or Sadnes.

Prognoticks.] Except a Gangrene be uddenly topt, it degenerates into a Sphacelus; eailier cured in young, than old People: The Humors continually flowing to the part affected, bring danger with them, and that very great, if they are Malignant: In the Cavities of the Body, to wit, in the Mouth, Privy Parts, and Fundament, &c.
a Gangrene is always difficult of Cure, as alo that which happens among the Nerves and Tendons; in Hydropicks always mortal: That which happens from the Scurvy, may be pun out from many Months, but eldom cured.
A Sphacelus is not cured but by the Knife and Fire.

Cure.] Diet mut be good, the Air, Meat and Drink generally cooling and drying: But eeing the Caues are various, we leave it to the Phyitian to precribe what is convenient; who alo mut well ditinguih concerning Bleeding and Purging, when to be ued with advantage or diadvantage. Sudoriicks and Cordials are of great ue here; and becaue that in this, and other Dieaes, they are often ued, I thought it convenient to et them down in this Place.

div.head: Diaphoreticks or Sudoriicks.
div.p: Roots of Angelica, Scorzonera, Lovage, Contrayerva; Herbs, Holy-Thitle, Fumitory, Scordium; Harts Horn, Unicorns-Horn, Bezoar, the Stone of an Indian Hog, called Pedro Porco; Waters, of Threacle, Alexipharmick; Diacordium, Threacle, Mithridate; Species Liberantis; Antimony, Diaphoretick; Salts, of Wormwood, Prunella, Holy-Thitle, Rob. Sambuct.
Take Diacordium Farcatorii, one dram; Alexipharmick-Water, two drams; Holy-Thitle water, as much as is ufficient; Syrup of Limons, half an ounce: Make a Potion.

div.head: Cordials.
div.p:
Waters of Roes, Borage, Buglos; Conerves, of Roemary-flowers, of Roes, Violets & Borage; Bezoar, Harts horn, Unicorns horn; Confections of Alchermes, Hiacynthus; Rob. of Red Currans,
of Barberries; of Scorzonera Roots Candied, Citron and Orange-peels Candied, Saccharum Perlatum, Salt of Coral.

Take Water of Borage, Buglos, of each two ounces and an half; Alexipharmick-water, three Drams; Cinnamon-water, two Drams; Saccharum Perlatum, half an ounce; Confection of Hiacinth, half a Dram; prepared Crabs eyes, two Scruples; Spirit of Salt, four Drops: Mix them.
Let the Patient now and then take one or two Spoonfuls.

Externally, Cupping glaes, and Leeches; but chiefly Scarification mut be ued; although there are ome of our Chirurgeons, which altogether reject Scarification; nevertheles happily curing their Patients, by the following Medicines, which reit Putrefaction.

div.head: External Medicaments againt a Gangrene.
div.p: Roots of Angelica, round Birthwort; Herbs, of Wormwood, Holy-Thitle, Tobacco, Rue, Colewort, Germander; Flowers of Elder, St. John's Wort, Mellilot, Camomil; Lye, Brine, Ink, Urine, Spirit of Wine, Treacle, Ung. Aegyptiacum, Fucum of Felix Wortz, Hore-dung.
Some mix Hemlock in Plaiters or Poultices, and ue it with ucces:
Or,

Take the Tops of Wormwood, Camomil, and Elder flowers, of each half a handful; Leaves of Germander, a handful and half; Rue, half a handful; Crums of brown Bread, even ounces; Hore-dung, three ounces: Boyl them in Brine, in the end adding to them, Ink, two ounces; Spirit of Wine, three ounces: Make it into a Cataplam.

The ound part ought alo to be preerved;
partly by keeping the Humors from flowing, and partly by keeping the Gangrene from preading: For this purpoe the Red defenive Plaiter, or the Cerot of Virgo is good; as alo this following Cataplam.
Take Bolearmonick, half an ounce; Powder of Galls, Cypres-nuts, Pomegranate-rinds, of each three Drams; Barley-meal, ix Ounces; Oxymel implex; as much as is ufficient to make it into a Cataplam.
Or,

Take Seal'd Earth, Bolearmenick, of each half an ounce; prepared Harts-horn, a dram; Camphire, a Scruple; Roe-vinegar, an Ounce; Oyl of Mirtles, three ounces; white of an Egg: Make it into a Linament.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene, caued from Cold.
div.p: The part gangren'd, if not grown black; but as yet appears very red with pain; the Patient is to be placed at the Fire; but not too near; but at a ditance, that the heat by degrees may be again retored to the part; and to that purpoe, trongly rubbing it with Snow, or cold Water; giving alo to the Patient, Treacle, or Mithridate, in warm Wine. If the pain and cold remit, let the part be embrocated very warm with Oyl of Dill, Camomil, bitter Almonds, or Earth-worms, &c. A Decoction of congeal'd Turnips, is good to foment withal; then are required both tronger and hotter Medicines, viz. Oyl of Earth, of Tiles, Turpentine, Cator, Treacle-water, Mithridate: Or ue the following Fomentation.

Take Herbs of Scordium, a handful and half; Swallow-wort, a handful; Rue, half a handful; Seeds of Roman Nettle, Crees, of each three
Drams; boyl them in White-wine, let them be trained; and to a Pint of the Liquor, add Spirit of Wine, two ounces: Mingle it.
When the part hath begun to Mortifie, Scarifie; continue the ue of the above precribed Medicines.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene from external Heat, or hindred by Perpiration.
div.p: Let the caue of the Dieae be removed, if poible; which if it happens from external Ligature, Hot, or two Atringent Medicines; let them be forthwith removed from the part affected; and let it be wahed, being firt Scarified with the following Decoction.

Take the Water of Endive, Night-hade, of each ix Ounces; of Sorrel-water, eight Ounces, Vinegar, half a pint; Salt, an Ounce and half; Scordium, a handful; Lupines, half an Ounce; Mix them, and boyl them to the Conumption of the third part.
Then let the Chirurgeon ue Ung. Aegyptiacum, or any other of the above precribed Medicines.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene from the Defect of Nutriment.
div.p: Let the Patient ue nourihing Aliments; all trong External, or Internal Dryers hurt; Friction of the part, with moderately hot Medicines, as with Oyl of Sweet Almonds, Olives, Earth-worms, Scorpions, Vipers, Man's Fat, Bears, or Hens, is good. Scarifie, if neceity require. Dicuives here are very injurious.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene from a venemous Humor.
div.p: If the malignant Humor be in the Body it elf, Sudorifick, cooling, and Cordial Medicines are bet: For Purging and Bleeding, I have een them oftner to do hurt than good.
Outwardly, Defenives are ueles; but Cupping-glaes, Leeches, and attractive Medicines are neceary.

But if the Malignant Humor come from an external Caue; the uret remedy is an actual Cautery, let the Malignity pread it elf, which is to be ued the very firt time; and alo to put a further top, apply a Defenive to the ound part, two fingers breadth ditance from the wounded part; o alo it will put a top to the Flux of Humors, or ele all the hope conits in Leeches, Cupping-glaes, Attractive Medicines, and others et down above.

div.head: Cure of a Gangrene prung from the Scurvy.
div.p: Internal Remedies we commit to the Phyitian; Externally, thee are commended.

Take Seeds of Broom, Roman-Nettle, Rue, of each a Dram; Tops of Wormwood, two Drams; Gum, Galbanum Ammoniacum, diolv'd in Vinegar, of each ix drams; Oyl of Juniper, three drams; Wax, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Plaiter.
Or,
Take Oyl of Earth-worms, Bayes, Rue, of each two Drams; Cator, a Dram; Spirit of Wine, three Drams: Make it into a Linament.
Or,

Take the Rapings of Guaiacum, Saafras, of each an ounce; Root of Angelica, Celandines the greater, Tamarisk-bark, of each ix Drams; Leaves of Scurvy-gras, Water-crees, of each a handful; Fennel-eeds, an ounce; Spirit of Wine, a pint and half: Infue them a Night; then ditil them in Balneo Mariae.
Foment the part affected with this, and carifie, if there be occaion; and let the Chirurgeon proceed according to Art.
Where a Gangrene hath degenerated into a Sphacelus, epecially in the Joynts, let the Part be amputated; concerning which, look in the Firt Part.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of a Paronychia.
div.p: PAnaritium, or Paronychia, is a Tumor very painful, in the end of the Finger, from a harp Malignant Humor, corroding the Tendons, Nerves, Periotium, and Bone it elf.
Caue is a harp humor, proceeding from Choler or Serum.
Signs are, an intollerable pain about the Nail, tormenting the Patient day and night; an Inflammation, oftentimes extending over the whole Arm: A Fever for the mot part, and ometimes Delirium.

Prognotick.] By how much the Humor is the more malignant, the greater Symptoms it raieth, corrupting ometimes the Bone, the Finger, the whole Hand, and ometimes from extream pain, it occaions the death of the Patient.
Cure.] Foment the Finger a while in this Decoction.
Take Flowers of Camomile, Mellilot, Elder, of each half a handful; Lineed and Fenugreek, each two drams: Boil them in Milk.
Or, let this Cataplam be applied.
Take Flowers of Dill, Elder, Leaves of Hen-Bane, of each a handful; Poppy-eeds and Lineed, of each three drams; Marh-mallow-powder, an ounce and half.
Boil them in Milk, to the conitence of a Cataplam.

Then make Inciion upon the Part affected, according to the length of the Finger; and for the mot part there appears one or more red pots, containing a harp Matter, but little in quantity, which is the caue of the Dieae.
After the Apertion of the Tumor, at the firt dreing, apply to the Finger Treacle diolv'd in Spirit of Wine, and a Defenive to the whole Hand; o in a day or two, the Cure will be perfected.

But if this Part hould be gangren'd or Sphacelated, either by the neglect of Patient or Chirurgeon, let it be taken off: Except you will commit the buines to Nature, which oftentimes eparates, and throws out this Bone. A great Inflammation ometimes here produceth a Flehy Excrecency, occult and enles; this is removed by Knife, or exeding Medicines: Then cure according to Art.

But if being too late call'd you find a great collection of Humors, let Dicuives or Suppuratives be applied; then the Tumor being either broke, or opened, take great care, let the Tendons (which do very eaily) putrifie, or incline to putrefaction: Separation is here neceary, whether it be by Medicines, or a cutting Intrument: Repellents in this cae, greatly hurtful.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of an Aneurim.
div.p: ANeurima is a Tumor beides Nature, from a Rupture of an Artery, continually beating, eaily yielding to the Fingers, and as uddenly returning.

Caue.] All Arteries, except thoe that are dipered, through the Brain and upper parts, conit of a double Tunicle; the inmot of which being either corroded or broke, the External may be extended o much (without a Rupture of it, whatoever others ay) as to caue an Aneurim: Nevertheles, where the Tumor is of the bignes of ones Fit, it cannot be but that the External alo mut be either corroded or broke. Anatomy doth confirm this Opinion, which the Studious in the Art of Chirurgery may enquire into.
This Tumor alo may be caued, where an Artery be divided; o that the External Tunicle united to the Mucles, the Internal, by reaon of the continual pulation, remains open.

Signs.] A Swelling increaing by degrees, of the ame colour as the skin; a continual Pulation: If the Tumor be little, it eaily yields to the Fingers, o that it altogether diappears, but uddenly returns again; but if great, not o eaily yielding to the touch, not o trong a Pulation: but there is a noie oberved, as of boiling Water; yet in the Head and Jaw, I have found after death an Aneurim, which while the man was alive,
there could be no Pule perceived: In the hard parts is greater Circumpection to be ued, than in the oft and flehy.

Prognoticks.] It is difficultly cured; if great, not at all, except with the taking off the Member; for the mot part it is a long Dieae, although I have een it kill, without any other accidental Caue, within two years: If Inciion be made, Death uddenly follows.

Cure.] In the beginning there may be ome Hopes. Atringents and Repellents, and convenient Ligatures, by which we do not eldom adminiter omething of Remedy to the Patient; as alo the applying a piece of Lead traightly bound on, have ometimes cured little Aneurims.

But where the Tumor is encreaed, there are ome would have the Skin divided, and the Artery tied both above and below, and cut out the middle with the Tumor, and looen not the Ligatures, till the Wound is perfectly cured, and there is no fear of an Hemorrage; but this Operation is dangerous, painful and troubleome, and oft-times of little Benefit: But to preerve Life, I would take off the Member.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of Opthalmia.
div.p: OPthalmia is an Inflammation of the Membranes of the Eye from Blood, with Rednes, Pain, and hedding of Tears.

Difference.] A light Inflammation, and which depends from external Caues, is called a Batard-Opthalmia, Taraxis, or Epiphora; but a great Inflammation, accompanied with pain and tears, a true Opthalmia. And if it be o great, that the Eye-lids are o inflamed, and as it were turned inward, 'tis called Chemois.
Caues are two. 1. Internal, as Blood, oft-times mixt with Serum or Choler; eldom with Phlegm or Melancholy. 2. External, as Smoak, Dut, &c.

Signs vary according to the variety of Caues: If it proceed from too great a quantity of Blood, the Face looks red, and the Veels of the Eyes are extended: If either from more of Serum or Choler, the Rednes of the Face is les, but the Tears are more harp, and the pain greater; if from more of Phlegm, the reddih pain, Heat and Acrimony of Tears are more remis; and the Eye-lids at night are as it were glewed together: If from any thing of Melancholy, there are but few Tears, and the Eye-lids are not cloed together, the Inflammation is not great, but tubborn.
Prognoticks.] An Opthalmia is flower cured in Children, than in old people. Continual pain menaceth Blindnes, by how much greater the Inflammation is, o much the more dangerous it is.

Cure.] The Diet mut be the ame as in a Phlegmon; all harp things are carefully to be avoided; as Garlick, Radihes, Mutard, &c. little or no Suppers profit: Purging, the ue of Gliters, Bleeding ought to be oft-times re-iterated; as alo Cupping-Glaes, Leeches, Bliters; ometimes alo Seatons, Iues, and Artereotomy it elf, which is not to be done by any but an expert Chirurgeon;
Sneezing is hurtful; Provoking of Sweat is ometimes neceary, ometimes not; which the Phyician mut ditinguih: Dieureticks are of great ue, provided they are not too hot.
External Remedies vary according to the variety of Caues; if from Smoke or Fire, let them be extinguihed.
If from Dut, or any thing got into the Eyes, 'tis to be taken forth, which is often performed by blowing, or by the purting in of Roe-water.
If from the inverion of the Eye-lids; the Hairs are to be cut off, or wholly to be pull'd out.

If the Eye-lids are glew'd together, they are to be eparated, with Butter, Beer, or Cream, the Rheum is gently to be wiped; and let the Patient have a Care, let by the rubbing of his Eyes, he increaeth his Dieae.
Fat things are here hurtful: Repellent Medicines, except in the very beginning, are not to be ued, or in a very light Opthalmia.

div.head: Medicines good for the Eyes.
div.p: Roots of Valerian, Solomons-Seal, Orrie, Vervain, Herbs, Betony, Celandine the great, Eyebright, Fennel, Fumitory, Plantain: Flowers of Roes, Violets; Anni-eeds, Quince-eeds, Lineeds: Pippins, boil'd or rotten; Camphire; Muilage of Lin-eeds, Tragacanth; Freh Veal; Whites of Eggs; all orts of Milk, epecially Womans; Tutty; white and green Vitriol; Saccharum Saturni; Glas of Antimony; White Troches of Rhais; freh Cheee not alted; Ung. Saturni.

div.head: A Water for the Eyes.
div.p:
Take Waters of Eyebright and Celandine the greater, of each an ounce and half; White-wine, ix drams; Glas of Antimony, eight grains; prepared
Tutty, fifteen grains; White-Vitriol, two grains; Sugar-Candy two drams; Camphire, four grains: Make it into a Collirium.
Another excellent one.

Take Wheat, three handfuls; Bruied Ginger, three drams; Common Salt, a handful and half; White-wine, Water of Roes, of Fennel, Plantain, of each ten ounces: Infue them in a Copper Veel the pace of forty days, train them, and reerve the Liquor for your ue.
Another very much eteemed.

Take a whole Egg, boil it hard, then the hell and Yolk being taking away, put into the Cavity, Sugar of Saturn, ix grains; Camphire, two grains; White-Vitriol, three Grains; Honey of Roes, half an ounce; then pres it very hard, and let the pret out Liquor be dropt into the Eyes twice or thrice a day.
Another, econd to none.
Take Waters of Fennel and Eyebright, of each a pint; Common Salt, ix drams; prepared Tutty, white Vitriol, of each half an ounce: Let them boil a little, and reerve for ue.

Let not the great quantity of Vitriol afright any; it caueth only a light pain, which uddenly vaniheth; but 'tis of o great virtue, that it cannot ufficiently be extoll'd; but its ue will prove it true.

div.head: A Powder for the Eyes.
div.p: Take Dulcified Vitriol, half a dram, prepar'd Tutty, fifteen grains; Sugar-candy, a cruple: Make it into a fine Powder.
Unctious Medicines eldom are applied to the Eyes, or ele this Ointment is much commended.
Take Verdigreae, twelve grains; Camphire, Lapis Calaminaris, of each half an ounce; prepared Tutty, half a dram; freh-Butter wahed in Roe-water, two ounces: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: An Anodine Cataplam.
div.p: Take Camomile and Melilot Flowers, of each a pugil, rotten Apples, two ounces; Fenugreek-eed, an ounce; Crums of Brown Bread, three ounces; two yolks of Eggs, Saffron, half a dram; Boil them in Cows-milk, to the conitence of a Poultice.

div.head: An Anodine Collirium.
div.p: Take the Juice of Houleek, two drams; Whites of Eggs, half an ounce; Womens-Milk, two ounces; Roe-water, an ounce; white Troches of Rhais, one cruple; Opium, three grains: Mix them.
Another, which I have often found excellent in the greatet pain.

Take Gum Tragacanth, two drams; Muilage of the eeds of Fleawort, three drams; Roe-water, and Plantain-water, of each as much as ufficeth: Make it into a Collyrium of an indifferent Conitence; and let it be intilled by drops into the Eyes, and Linnen-Cloaths wet in it, outwardly applied.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of a Quinie.
div.p: A Quinie is a Tumor of the Jaws, from Blood, hindring Deglutition and Repiration.

Difference.] 'Tis divided into three pecies; the firt is called Cynanthe, when the Mucles of the Larinx are inflamed: the Symptoms here are very dangerous, although neither internally nor externally appear any Tumor; the Patient puts forth his Tongue like a tired Dog, to fetch his breath. Second is Synanche, when the Tumor hews it elf within the Jaws; the Symptoms are likewie here great, but much les than in Cynanthe. Third is, Paraynanche, when the Tumor appears more Externally than Internally; and in this the Symptomes are leat of all.
Caue is Blood, for the mot part mixt with Serum or Choler; eldom with Phlegm or Melancholy.
Signs of an approaching Quinie, are, a tiffnes of the Neck, wallowing and breathing omewhat hindred, an unuual heat and pain in the Jaws, epecially when Quinies are Epidemick.

Signs of a preent are, a uffocating Athma: wallowing hindred, which often increaeth to o great a heighth, that Drink taken in at the Mouth, comes forth again through the Notrils, Pain, Rednes, Tumor for the mot part, alo a continual Fever; the Tongue likewie well'd, and the Voice altered.

Prognotick.] A perfect Quinie never wants danger, but ometimes uffocates the Patient the firt day, generally before the fourth: If the Matter be not uddenly concocted and thrown forth, it is deperate; if the Vertebraes be laxated, death is near at hand; foaming at mouth is a ign of preent death; if the Patient be taken with a pain of the Head, a Delirium, raving and death it elf uddenly follows.

Cure.] Bleeding in this cae effects much, both by taking away of the Inflammation, and by hindering its increae, which is to be performed at firt ight therefore let the Median or Cephalick Vein of the ide mot affected be opened, though in Women with Child, then the Vein under the Tongue: Cupping Glaes with Scarification may alo be applied to the Neck about the econd Verrebra, Shoulders and Breat; Leeches, Cauteries, and Bliters do much good, epecially in them that are Subject to Quinie: In the mean time, if the Patient can wallow, let ome purging Medicines be given him; if not, let a Cliter be cat in, with Bleeding, which mut be often reiterated as occaion requires.

Gargarims then, and other External Medicines are to be ued; which in the beginning are to be more Repelling, afterwards more Dicuing; for Experience and bet Authors have taught, 1. Repellents never are to be ued alone, except in the beginning, and in a light Quinie. 2. That Repellents ought always to be mixt with Reolvents; for Repellents detroy the heat of the Part; Reolvents caue Fluxion.

div.head: Medicines in a Quinie.
div.p: Roots of Marh-mallows, Liquoras; Herbs, Comfrey, Myrtle, Prunella, Dandelion, Scabious, Plantain, Houleek the greater, Sage, Alehoof, Violets, Flowers of Balautians, Red Roes, Saffron; the four cold Seeds, Poppy the Rinds and Juice of Pomegranates; Figs, Album Graecum, Burnt-Swallows, Burnt-Allom, Swallows Nets, Syrups of Maidenhair, Violets, Purlane, Jujubies, Scabious, Lungwort, Honey of Roes, Rob. Diamori.

div.head: A Repellent Gargarim.
div.p: Take Flowers of Red-Roes, Balautians, of each two pugils; Pomegranate-Rinds, half an ounce; Oak-leaves, a handful; Burnt-Allom, half a dram: Boil them in Smith's Water, and add to a pint of the Liquor, two ounces of Rob. Diamori: Mix them.
Another very convenient in the beginning of the Dieae.

Take leaves of Dandelion, two handfuls; Alehoof, Violets, of each half an handful; boil them in Barley-water, and to a point of the trained Liquor, add of common Honey of Roes, and trained, of each an ounce and half; Spirit of Vitriol, 15 drops: Mix them.

div.head: A Repellent, and omewhat Dicuive Gargarim.
div.p:
Take Liquoras, Pomegranate-Rinds, of each
two drams; Balautia Flowers, a pugil; Jujubies, No. xij. Figs, No. iij. Raiins, ix drams; boil them in Barley-water. To a pint of the Decoction, add of common and trained Honey of Roes, Syrup of Maiden-hair, of each an ounce: Mix them.

div.head: A Gargarim greatly Repelling, but trongly Dicuing.
div.p: Take the Roots of Dwarf Elder, Orrie, of each two drams, Flowers of Camomil, a pugil; Red-Roes, Hyop, of each two pugils, Dates, No. iij. Figs, No. vj. Fenugreek-eeds, two drams; Album Graecum, one dram: Boil them in Turnep-Broth. Add to it Syrup of Maiden-hair, and Jujubies, of each an ounce: Mix them.
If the pain be very great, boil them in new Milk, chiefly in Goats.

div.head: External Medecines for a Quinie.
div.p: Oyl of Nuts, White-Lillies, Almonds, Camomile, Dill, Capons-greae, Hoggs-greae, Ointment of Marh-mallows, Plaiter of Muilages, Dogs and Pigeons-Dung, Swallows-Nets.

Take Roots of Marh-Mallows, White-Lillies, of each an ounce; one Swallows Net, Figs, Dates, of each No. iij. Album Graecum, half an ounce; Boil'd Onions, half an ounce: Boil them in Barley-water, and to a point of the trained Liquor, add of Wheat-meal and the Powder of Lin-eed, of each an ounce; Fenugreek and Marh-mallows powdered, of each two ounces and a half; Yolks of two Eggs, Eatern Saffron, two drams; Oyl of
Camomile, two ounces and a half: Make it into a Cataplam.

Take Juice of Onions, two ounces; Oyl of white-Lillies, Orie, of each an ounce and half; boil them a little, adding to them of Swallows-Net, a dram; Pitch and Wax, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.
But if the Tumor tends to Suppuration, 'tis to be forwarded, and then to be opened either by Medicines or Launcet.

div.head: A Suppurating Cataplam.
div.p: Take Roots of Briony, white-Lillies, Orrie, of each three drams; Leaves of Pellitory of the Wall, a handful; Camomile-Flowers, half a handful; Onions, an ounce; Figs, No. xij. Boil them and bruie them, adding of the Powder of Fenugreek-eed and Lin-eed, of each two ounces; Hens greae, an ounce; Oyl of Camomile, two ounces: Mix them.

div.head: A Suppurating Gargarim.
div.p: Take Roots of white-Lillies, and Liquoras, of each three drams; Onions, half an ounce; Raiins toned, an ounce; Figs, No. vj. Lin-eed and Fenugreek, of each two drams; Leaves of Mallows and Coleworts, of each half a handful; boil them in Barley-water, and to a pint of the trained Liquor, add of Syrup of Maiden-hair, two ounces: Mix them.
And to make the Abces break, add to this Gargarim.

Take Mutard-eed, two drams; Roots of Pollitory of Spain powdered, one dram; Saffron,
a cruple; Oximel imple, an ounce: Mix them.
But if it doth not forthwith break by thee Medicines, 'tis to be opened by a Launcet, or ome other Intrument; afterwards uing Emollient Gargarimes, and omewhat abterive.

div.trailer: The end of the firt Book of the econd Part.

div.head: BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Second Book of the Second Part Of CHIRURGERY. Of Wounds.
CHAP. I. Of the Nature, Differences, Caues, and Signs of Wounds.
div.p: A Wound is a Solution of continuity in the oft parts of the Body, from a hard Intrument, cauing an Abolition or Immination of Action.

Differences are taken, 1. From the Form; ome are long, others oblique; ome are little, others great, ome are deep, others uperficial. 2. From the wounded Part, as, the Head, Lungs, Heart, Stomach, Liver, Spleen, Guts, Nerve, Tendon, Vein or Mucle; ometimes the Skin is only penetrated, then 'tis a imple Wound; ometimes a Part of the Fleh is taken away,
and then 'tis call'd a compound or hollow Wound. 3. From the Caues, which hall preently be et down; ometimes a wound happens to be poioned, and to have many Symptoms joined with it.

Caues are five-fold, viz. 1. All things that cut, as a Knife, Sword, Glas, 2. Al things that prick; as Needles, Arrows, Teeth. 3. Which perforate; as hot Iron, Bullets. 4. Which break; as a Fall, Stroke, or the carrying or lifting of any great Burdens. 5. All things which contue; as a Stone, Stick, &c.

Signs.] External Wounds are of themelves manifet enough; but thoe of the Internal parts, are not always o eaily judged of; thee therefore are to be known by Anatomy; 1. What is the ituation of each part. 2. What the ue. 3. The Symptoms are to be conidered. 4. The Quality of thoe things are to be noted, that Nature ejected through the Wound: The other Signs you hall have in their proper places.

Prognoticks. [To know the Events of Wounds, epecially to predict which are Mortal, which not, is a thing abolutely neceary for a Surgeon: For from this judgment oft-times depends the Life of unfortunate Man.

p.hi: A mortal Wound is that, which in the pace of few hours or days, of neceity caues Death, and cannot by any Art be cured.

div.p:
For thoe that in themelves are curable, yet by reaon of ill Symptoms, or through the neglect either of the Patient or Chirurgeon, do occaion Death, ought not to be accounted mortal Wounds: Incurable Wounds themelves are not to be call'd Mortal, if they are not the caue of Death
uddenly to the Patient; but that he not only lives many weeks, but oftentimes many years after.

1. Among the Wounds that are Mortal, are to be accounted the Wounds of the Brain, but not all of them; for Experience hath taught us, that part of the Brain hath been taken forth, and the Life preerved, though the Undertanding lot.

Therefore thoe Wounds of the Brain that be abolutely mortal, are, 1. When beides the Brains, a Nerve is alo wounded. 2. When Blood, or ome other Humor obtructs the beginning of the Nerves: 3. When after a few days the concrete and putrified Blood produceth a Fever, Delirium, and Death it elf.

By concreted Blood, I undertand not that which lies between the Dura-Mater and the Skull; for that is to be taken forth by the Trepan, and the Patient this way may be preerved; but that which is included between the Dura and Pia-Mater, or between the Pia and the Brain: Although ometimes, that which is detained between both Membranes, by the dividing of the Dura, may be taken forth, and o the Patient preerved.
2. The Wounds of the Spinal Marrow are alo mortal, which happens in the Neck, or nearer to the Head; but thoe which happen lower, as about the Os Sacrum, are of leer danger.

3. The Wounds of the Lungs are mortal, if great and deep, where the great Veels, or the Branches of the Apera Arteria are hurt: Where the Veels are divided, there follows a great effuion of Blood; where the Branches of the Apera Arteria, the Breath comes forth more through the Wound than the Mouth.

4. Wounds of the heart are always mortal;
for though one or two wounded in the heart, have lived, two, three, or four days, it was never found yet, that ever any ecaped.

5. The Wound of the Wind-pipe may be cured, if the Membranes only behind, to which the Cartilaginous Rings are join'd, be hurt; but if the Rings themelves are wounded, there's no cure to be expected; yet ometimes thoe wounds being a lingering Death; o that I have een on o wounded, live Eighteen weeks before he died.

6. Wounds of the Diaphragma, thoe that are inflicted in the flehy Part of it, are curable; but thoe that are in the Nervous Part, though thee always occaion not udden Death, yet 'tis impoible ever to cure them.
7. Wounds of the Stomach are ometimes cured; thoe chiefly being mortal, that happen in the upper Orifice, or in Nerves that are ditributed over the Stomach.
8. The Wounds of the Small Guts are eldom cured, but the Wounds of the Great Guts much oftner, epecially if they are not great.
9. Wounds of the Liver and Spleen are mortal, where the Veels themelves are wounded; where not, they may be cured.

10. Wounds of the Kidneys are not mortal; if the Wound penetrate into the Cavity it elf, for the mot part an Ulcer follows, which conumes the whole Kidney, yet the Patient may continue many years: If the Parachyma, only be wounded, ometimes, through difficulty, it may be cured.
11. Wounds of the Bladder are eldom o perfectly cured, but that for the mot part there remains a Fitula; but thoe that are made at the neck of the bladder, are daily cured.
12. Wounds of the great Veins and Arteries are often mortal; but every Surgeon undertands not rightly to bind up uch Wounds; therefore the caue of death is not always to be cat upon the guilty.
13. Wounds of the great Nerves are for the mot part incurable, and ometimes mortal.
14. Wounds from poioned Intruments or Creatures, generally are mortal.
Wounds of Nerves, Veins, Tendons and Membranes, are more difficultly, and longer of Cure, than thoe of the flehy parts.
A Wound from a pricking Intrument, is of les danger, than from a bruiing.
A Nerve, Vein or Artery, if wholly divided, are les dangerous, than if they were but in part.
A great Inflamation coming upon a great Wound, is of no great danger, except it continue too long; but a great Inflamation falling upon a little Wound, is an ill ign.
The Inflamation for the mot part vaniheth by the fifth day; therefore if the Wound then appear white, livid or black, 'tis not void of danger.
A Fever, Vomiting and Convulion, are dangerous; but a Fever and Vomiting of les danger than a Convulion.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Cure of Wounds in general.
div.p: HEre are required four Intentions: 1. To preerve the trength and native heat of the wounded Part. 2. To remove the Symptoms. 3. To endeavour that nothing remains, or be left behind in the Wound. 4. That the gaping Lips of the Wound be joined together; and being o joined, be kept

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the preervation of the trength and Native heat in the wounded Part.
div.p: CHirurgery removes the impediments of Cure, but Nature her elf cures the Dieae; which it will carce effect, where the Native heat is weak, or the Blood vitiated; or where it flows in too great or too little quantity to the Wound: in flowing in too great quantity, it produceth an Inflammation, Pain, Putrefaction, and many other Symptoms; where in too little quantity, the Wound is robbed of its Natural Balam, neceary to conolidate it.

The natural trength and native heat is preerved by a convenient Diet, fitted to the temperament of Mans body in general, and in particular, to the Part affected. Of the Diet of the Sanguine,
Cholerick, Phlegmatick and Melancholick, we have treated of before, when we poke concerning a Phlegmon, Eryipelas, Oedema, Schirrhus.

Then Care is to be had of the Blood, eeing it affords aitance to the matter, and erves to unite the Wound. Where it is vitiated, it requires purging: But if it flow in too great quantity, Intercipients, Repellents, Revellents and Derivation mut be us'd.
If it flow in too mall quantity, Aliments that nourih, are convenient, as alo Medicines that trengthen, and that move Sweat: Outwardly, gentle Frictions and Embrocations moderately hot.
Then the Cure is to be perfected by External Medicines; which hall be declared in the following Chapter, when we peak of the removal of the Symptoms, and the Cure of Wounds themelves.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Symptoms of Wounds.
div.p:
THe chief Symptoms of Wounds are, 1. A Fever whoe Cure we commend to the Phyitian' 2. A Flegmon or Inflamation. 3. An Eryipelas. Of the Cure of both which, look in the econd and third Chapter of the firt Book. 4. Hemorage, which not only impedes the Cure, but alo deprives of trength and life it elf; therefore great Care is to be taken that it be topped as oon as poible, which in the greater Veels, epecially the Arteries, is very hard to do; therefore thoe Wounds are for the mot part Mortal: For Medicines that top Blood are too weak, and hard
Ligatures occaion a Gangrene; the uret way therefore in my opinion, is an actual Cautery; the leer Veels may and will cloe, Some cloe the Wound of the Veels with their Fingers, and o hold them there while the Blood is coagulated, and the Flux topt; but this Operation eldom ucceeds; beides the long holding of the Finger in the Wound is hurtful.

Therefore let the Wound together with the Veels be forthwith clos'd by the Fingers, but if you cannot come to do this, outwardly make a compres upon the Veel; which done, wipe away the Blood with a Spunge, then prinkle ome retringent Powder; but not over the whole Wound (which is ued to be done by the ignorant) but only upon the Veels; then bind up the Wound, continuing the ue of the Medicines topping Bleeding, while there appears no longer any Blood; not neglecting in the mean time, Generals, viz. Scarification and Bleeding, &c.

div.head: Medicines that top a Flux of Blood.
div.p: Roots of Bitort, Cinquefoil, Tormentil, Comfrey the greater, Red Saunders, Lignum Leutici, Pomegranate-rinds, Matick, Talk, Acacia, Dragons-Blood, Amber, Sarcocols, Frankincene; the hairs of a Hare, Os epiae, burnt-Crabs; Whites of Eggs, Mummy, Cobwebs, red, Coral Chalk, Bloodtone, Bole-Armenick, Aloes uccotrine, Frogs dried and powdered, crude Vitriol, burnt Vitriol.

Take fine Meal, three ounces; Dragons-Blood, Frankincene, of each an ounce and half; Bole, Sealed Earth, of each two drams, Talk, ix
drams; dried Frogs, an ounce; Hares hair cut very mall, a dram and a half; Whites of Eggs dried in the Sun, and powdered half an ounce; New Spunges torrified, an ounce; white Vitriol, a dram: Mix them, and make them into a fine Powder.

5. Pain; which mut of neceity be eaed, becaue it creates watchings, and dejects the Spirits, and is caue of the Flux of Humors to the Party affected; and of Inflamation, Fever and Gangrene; but the Caues are diligently to be conidered: For if either Medicines that are harp, or too hot, occaion it, they are preently to be altered: 'Tis better to confes the Error, than pertinaciouly to perevere in it.
If any foreign Body remains in the Wound, it mut be drawn forth.
If pain comes from the choaking in of the Matter, you mut allow it a free paage.

If an Inflamation be the caue of it, its Remedies are et down in the econd Chapter of the firt Book: You mut apply to the Wound thoe things which eae pain, and are anodine; as Oyl of Roes, Lineed, Camomile, Worms, weet Almonds, Poppies, &c.
Take Oyl of Roes, of Poppy-eeds, of Camomile, of each an ounce; the White of an Egg, Saffron, a cruple; Mix them.
But if the pain ceae not with thee or the like Medicines, it is a ign that ome Nerve is wounded, or affected by conent: The Cure hall be et down in the following.

6. Convulion or Spam; this hews the Malignity of the Humor, or the ill contitution of the Nerves, neither of them promiing any good:
Here mut be ued both Internal and External Medicines, appropriated to the Dieae; the Internal, by reaon of the diverity of caues, we commend to the Phyitian.

div.head: External Medicines for a Convulion.
div.p: Balam of Peru, the fat of Geee, Cator, Foxes, Rams, Mans: Hore-dung, Oyls of Juniper, Lavender, Ol. Philoophorum, Amber, Turpentine, Rue, Marjoram, Worms, Cator, Orie, Bays, Petraeleum; Ointments of Agrippa, Martiatum, Ung. Nervorum, Spirit of Wine.

Take Oyl of Snails, Worms, Seamin, of each an ounce; of the Greae of Rams and Foxes, of each half an ounce; freh Butter, ix drams; Spirit of Wine, three ounces: Let them boil till the Spirit be conumed; then add Oyl of Spike ditilled, Roemary, Amber, of each two drams: Mix it into an Ointment.
Againt a Convulion there cannot a better Remedy be invented than ditill'd Oyl of Lavender, ome few drops being given in ome convenient Liquor; and anointing well the convuled part.

7. Hyperarcois, or too great increae of fleh; which if it happens from abundance of Blood, the fleh is olid, and otherwie well conditioned; but if from the too weak quality of drying Medicines, it is pungy; of the ame nature, as when the Bone underneath is rotten. In the former Cae, Bleeding is convenient, and ometimes fating, and the ue of trong drying Medicines: In the latter, the Medicines mut be very trongly drying that are applied: Deterive and Corroding Remedies are here good.

div.head: Medicines againt too great increae of Fleh.
div.p: Burnt-Spunges, Burnt-Allom, Galls, Aloes, the Bark of Frankincene, Tutty, Verdigreae, burnt Vitriol, Praecipitate, Arenick.

div.head: A Green Corroive Water,
div.p: Take crude Allom, Verdigreae of each two drams; boil them in eighteen ounces of white-Wine, to a wating of the fourth part; train them, and add Camphire, a dram: Mix them.

div.head: A Powder very drying, and omewhat corroding.
div.p: Take Galls, Balautions, burnt-Allom, Frankincene, Myrrhe, of each a dram; Dragons-Blood, Cerue, Verdigreae, of each half a dram: Make it into a Powder.
8. A Gangrene and Sphacelus, concerning which, look in the fourteenth Chapter of the firt Book of the econd Part of Chirurgery.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the drawing forth Extraneous Bodies out of the Wound.
div.p:
NO Wound ought to be joined together, as long as any Extraneous Body remains in it; for otherwie, after ome little time, it will break out into an Ulcer: The Blood, by which Nature unites the divided Parts, if it flow in great quantity
to the wounded Part, and there coagulates, 'tis to be removed by Expreion, ucking it out, or by any other way; for o there will be les Matter generated, and the Symptoms fewer; but where an Haemorage is feared, all the Blood is not to be cleaned away.
Where Hairs are about the Wound, they are to be removed.
If Sand; or any uch like thing remain within the Lips of the Wound, they are to be wahed away with warm Wine.

Broken-Bones, if looe, are to be taken away the firt dreing, except an Haemorage hinder; but if they yet tick to the other Bones, then Natures endeavours are to be expected, and ee whether they will be united again to the other Bone, or eparated from it.

If a piece of Glas, Thorn, Arrow or Bullet, or any like thing remains in the Wound, 'tis forthwith to be taken forth; but before the Chirurgeon goes about to draw them forth, let him conider well, whether the Patient, that Extraneous Body being extracted, can live or not; let the Chirurgeon be thought to have occaioned the Patients death.

Of the manner of Extracting Bullets, we have treated before; and Arrows are to be drawn forth almot after the ame manner; but they are not in ue at this day among Chritian Soldiers: But if neither with the Hand nor Intruments, what remains in the wound can be drawn forth, then you mut endeavour it with Medicines indeed with an extractive quality.

div.head: Medicines drawing forth Thorns, Bones, Bullets, &c.
div.p: Roots of Aron, Birthwort, Batard Dittany, Materwort, Polypody, Radihes, Valerian: Herbs, Southernwood, Pimpernel, Anemone, Red-Beet, Ditany: Gums, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Sagapenum, Succinum, Pitch, the Brains and Greae of Hares, Crabs, a live Moue cut in two, Common Flies, Earth-worms, Burnt Frogs, Gooe-dung, Load-tone, Leaven, Plaiter of Opodeldoch.

Take Roots of round Birthwort, Ditany of Crete, of each a dram and an half; Roin of the Pine, Colophony, of each ix drams; yellow Amber, three drams; Gum Ammoniacum, Appoponax, of each an ounce; Pigeons dung, three drams; Oyl of Bays, half an ounce; Turpentine and Pitch, as much as to make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the manner of joining the Lips of Wounds together.
div.p:
THe Lips of the Wound are joined together, either by Ligature or Stitching. Ligature is convenient in Wounds made according to the length of the Member, and not deep; let the Bandage be neither too hard, nor too looe, and of that breadth that it may take in the whole
Wound. If it be a long Wound, the Rowler mut be three Fingers broad, and laying the midt of it upon the Wound, rowl one part upward, and the other downward; which mut neither be too looe, for then it will not keep the Lips of the Wound together; nor too traight, let it caue an Inflamation: In the Winter the Rowlers mut be of greater length than in the Summer: In great Wounds, beides Rowlers, the Surgeon tands in need of Boulters.

Stitching is performed either by Needle or ticking Medicines. It is requiite that the Chirurgeon never be without a Needle; for by it he frees his Patient from Pain, the Wound from Inflamation, and himelf from many inconveniences; and the Wound o requiring it, let him take a three-pointed Needle, with a waxed Thred, which let him pas through the Skin, and ometimes alo through the ubjacent Fleh, taking Care that the Tendons be not prickt; and alo that the Stitches be not too few nor too many; but keeping uch ditance between each, that the Skin may be drawn together, and the edges themelves joyned, leaving a little part for the putting in of a Tent, that may give paage to the uperfluous Matter: Thee Tents are not neceary in little Wounds; and in great, they mut neither touch the Nerve or Tendon, nor reach to the bottom of the Wound.

Where Ligature is not ufficient, and a Stitch with a Needle not convenient, the ticking Plaiter is very neceary; for o firmly doth this Plaiter adhere to the Wound, that neither the matter flowing out of the Wound, nor the Blood, nor any other moiture looens it. Oftentimes in this
cae is ued, the Stiptick Plaiter of Crollius, or Paracelus, but this ticks more firmly.
Take Sarcocols, Bole, Matick, Dragons-blood, Roin of the Pine, of each a dram; Gum-Tacamahack, a dram and an half; Naval-pitch, as much as ufficeth: Make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Medicines neceary for the Curing of Wounds.
div.p: MEdicines neceary for the Cure of Wounds, are of three orts: 1. Digetives, or moving matter. 2. Sarcoticks, or generating Fleh. 3. Epuloticks, or inducing a Cicatrice.

Experience hath taught, that a Wound may be cured oftentimes only by Digetive or Sarcotick Medicines; but this is better, and more certain, when they are both mixt together: In the Flehy Parts, Digetives may alone erve; but in Tendinous, Nervous, Membranous, or other drier Parts, Sarcoticks are convenient, either alone, or mixt with Digetives.

div.head: Digetives.
div.p: Common Oyl, Oyl of Roes, Matick, freh Butter and May-Butter, Gum-Elemny, Turpentine, Frankincene, Matick; the Flower of Wheat, Barley, Fenugreek, Yolks of Eggs, Honey.

Take Oyl of Olives, two ounces; yellow Wax,
half an ounce; Frankincene, Matick, of each a dram; the yolk of an Egg, freh Butter, as much as is ufficient: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: Sarcoticks.
div.p: Roots of Birthwort, Orrie, Sanicle, Comfrey the greater; Herbs, Betony, Centaury, Comfrey, St. John's-wort, Pimpernel, Plantain, Scabious, Scordium, Vervain; of Seeds, Beans, Fenugreek, Lineed, Barley; Frankincene, Aloes, Bole, ealed Earth, Colophony; Gums of Elemny, Pine, Laudanum, Matick, Myrrhe, Dragons-Blood, Sarcocols, Turpentine, Tragacanth; Wax, Honey, Mummy, Cadmia, Cerue, Lapis Calaminaris, Litharge, Burnt-Lead, Phomholix, Lapis Haematitis; Oyls of St. John's wort, Bays, Matick, Myrrhe; Ointment, Aureum, Bailicum, Fucum, of Felix Wurtz, Diapompholigos; Plaiters, Stipticum of Crollius and Paracelus, Oppodeldoch, of Betony, Diaulphuris of Rulandus; Baloms, of Peru, of Crollius, of Magatus, Aqua vitae; the fat of Geee, Foxes, Bears, Goats, Mans.

div.head: An Excellent Vulnerary Balom.
div.p: Take Turpentine, half a pound; Gum Galbanum, Elemny, Ivy, Frankincene, Matick, Myrrhe, of each an ounce; Aloes, Xylo aloes, Galangal, Cloves, Cinamon, Nutmegs, Cubebs, of each half an ounce: Infue them four and twenty hours in a ufficient quantity of Spirit of Wine; ditil them and preerve the Oyl for your ue.
Another,

Take Oyl of Violets, eight ounces; of Bays,
an ounce; Oyl of Venice-Turpentine, half an ounce; of Spike ditill'd, of Junipers, Verdigreace, of each a dram; Roin of the Pine, Turpentine, Colophony, Matick, of each half an ounce; white Calcanthum, a dram and half: Boil them a little, then train them for your ue.
Another,
Take Flower of Brimtone, three ounces; Mirtle, three drams; Camphire, one dram; Venice-Turpentine, five ounces; ditil them, and preerve the Oyl for your ue.

div.head: A Vulnerary Plaiter.
div.p: Take the Roots of round Birthwort, and Comfrey the greater, of each half an ounce; Mummy, Colophony; Aloes, Matick, Dragons blood, Litharge of Gold, Tutia, of each two drams; Gum Elemny, two ounces; Turpentine, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.
Another mot excellent both in old and new Wounds.

Take Gum Galbanum, ten drams; Ammoniacum, three ounces and an half; Oppoponax, an ounce; Bdellium, three ounces: Yellow Wax, twenty ounces; Olibanum, three ounces; Litharge of Gold, a pound; Myrrhe, ten drams; Verdigreace, Matick, Roots of long Birthwort, of each an ounce; Loadtone, two ounces; prepared Tutia, Lapis Calaminaris, of each two drams; old Oyl of Olive, a pint and half: Diolve the Gums in Vinegar, and let the ret be powdered; mingle them according to Art, and boil them into the form of a Plaiter.

div.head: Epulotick or drying Medicines.
div.p: Roots of Comfry, Tormentil; Herbs, St. Johns-wort, Plantain, Sanicle, Fluellin, Betony; Flowers of Balautians, Red Roes; Saunders, Aloes, Myrrhe, Matick, Sarcocols, Lapis Calaminaris, Red Lead, Lead, Litharge, Tutty; Ointments of Diapompholigos, Album Camphoratum; Plaiters, Gryeum de plumbo, Op ‚Ä¢ deldoch de Minio, Barbarum.

Take Oyl of Roes, of unripe Olives, of each three ounces; of Myrtles, Ointment of Poplars, of each an ounce and half; Leaves of Plantain and Night-hade, of each an handful; let them teep together eight days: afterwards add to the train'd Liquor, Wax, two ounces; mingle them over the fire, adding Litharge of Gold, three ounces; Cerue, an ounce; Tutty, a dram; Burnt Lead, three drams; Burnt Bras, a dram and an half; Camphire, a dram; let them be rubb'd in a Leaden Mortar into the form of an Ointment.
Take Roots of Tormentil, Bitort, round Birth-wort, burnt Egg-hels, Frankincene, Dragons-blood, of each half an ounce; Lapis Calaminaris, a dram; Litharge, two drams: Make it into a Powder.
Take Ung. Pompholigos, Diapalmae Griei, of each an ounce; Gum Elemny, two drams; Saccharum Saturni, half a dram; Wax, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.
I never knew any better Medicine, if applied in a fitting time, to bring to a Cicatrice, than an Amalgama of Mercury, of which, this is the decription.
Take two ounces of Lead, melt it, then add to it two ounces of Quick ilver, pour it upon Paper dried and powdered; it may be mixt with the Plaiter of Lead or Diapompholigos.
To thee External Remedies, we join alo Internal Medicines, which have been oberved to profit much at all times in the Cure of Wounds.

div.head: Vulneraries.
div.p: Wintergreen, Sanicle, Ladies-Mantle, Comfry, Mugwort, Saxifrage, Tormentil, Agrimony, Milfoil, Hore-tail, Hounds-tongue, Betony, Periwincle, Moue Ear, Golden rod, Birthwort, Bitort, Dictany, Centory the les, Gentain.

div.head: A Wound Dring.
div.p: Take Roots of Comfrey the greater, half an ounce; of Wintergreen, two handfuls; of Sanicle, two pugils; Straw-berries, Ladies-Mantle, Sage, of each an handful; boil them in red Wine, and to a pint and half of the trained Liquor, add of the whitet Sugar, as much as is ufficient; Doe, three ounces.
Another very effectual, even when the Bone is hurt.

Take Roots of round Birthwort, an ounce and half; Sowbread an ounce; Self-heal, Crane-bill, of each an handful; Savin, three drams; Mummy, two drams; Crabs-eyes, half an ounce; Galangal, two drams, powdered and cut: boil them in red-Wine, and to three pints of the trained Liquor, add of the Syrup of Comfry, of Fernelius, four ounces; mingle them. Doe, two ounces.
If any deires an Ointment, that many boat is able to cure the wound though the Patient be abent; this is its bet decription.
A Sympathetick Ointment.
Take Mos, two ounces; Mummy, half an ounce; Mans fat, two ounces; Mans-blood, half an ounce; Oyl of Lineed, two drams; Oyl of Roes, Bole, of each an ounce: Mix it, and make an Ointment.

Some ue only Vitriol calcin'd in the Sun; but whooever hall ue them without Supertition, hall find many things attributed to Medicines, that are due to Nature; therefore 'tis afet to proceed in the beaten way.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Wounds of the Nerves.
div.p: IN Treating of the Wounds of the Nerves, we alo comprehend thoe of the Tendons; becaue there is carce any difference in the Cure it elf.
'Tis to be ditinguihed here, where the Nerve or Tendon be divided, or only prick'd.

This Wound is known, 1. By conidering the wounded place, and by Anatomy, which teacheth in what Members the Nerves are inerted; but the Tendons eeing they terminate near the Joynts, the Hands and Feet having many; if a Wound hould be inflicted in thee parts, who would not fear them to be o hurt, epecially if it be with a tranvere
wound. 2. From the great Pain, which caues Pulation, Inflamation, Convulion and Delirium, &c. except the Nerves be wholly tranverly divided, and then the Symptoms are altogether not o grievous.

Prognoticks.] All the wounds of the Nerves are dangerous; a Puncture more dangerous than an Inciion: Wounds of Tendons are les dangerous than Nerves. Convulion is an ill ign; Nerves and Tendons wounded, do eaily putrifie.

Cure.] In all Wounds of Nerves or Tendons, eeing pain greatly molets, occaioning many Symptoms, care is to be taken that it be alleviated as oon as poible. Outward cold things do here hugely injure, not only the Air, but Medicines themelves: For Experience hath taught us, that cold, moit and atringent Medicines do nought but hurt; therefore 'tis bet to ue Medicines moderately hot and drying, but void of any harpnes. The Wound alo is to be kept open, till the Cure be abolutely performed, that the Matter may flow freely forth; which if kept in, may increae the pain, and caue the putrefaction of the Nerve; which, if it hould happen, the corrupt Part is to be cut off, or removed by an actual Cautery.

Moreover it is to be oberved, whether the Nerve or Tendon lies bare or not; if bare, warm Medicines are convenient; but if covered, hotter Medicines are required; in the mean time, Purging and Bleeding are not to be neglected.

div.head: External Medicines in Wounds of the Nerves and Tendons.
div.p:
Old Oyl of Olives, of Earth-worms, of Dill,
Rue, Roemary, Cotmary, white-Lillies, St. John's wort, Catore, of Turpentine, Wax, Lavender, Balom of Peru; Gums, Elemi, Tacamahac, Caranna, Opobalamum, Capayvae, Spirit of Wine.

Take Venice-Turpentine, Tears of the Fir-tree, of each an ounce; Gum Tacamahac, half an ounce; of Caranna, two drams; Balom of Peru, three drams; Propoleos, ix drams; Oyl of St. John's wort, an ounce: Make it into an Ointment.
Oyl of Wax, Lime water, and the brown Ointment of Faelix Wurtz, are here excellent, if rightly ued.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Wounds by Gun-hot.
div.p: ALthough daily practice teaches us, that Bullets may be poion'd, yet they are not o of their own nature; for the pain in part, and the other Symptoms arie from the olution of the continuity and the contuion.

Here firt the Bullet, and any thing ele that accompanies it, is to be drawn forth, let pain and inflamation coming upon it, may hinder; and care is to be had, that neither of them increae; and the contued Part, by the following Medicines be brought to uppuration.

Take Oyl of white Lillies, of Violets, of each two pints; two Puppies newly whelp'd; boil them till their Bones be almot diolv'd; then add Oyl of Earth-worms, a pint; and boil them again; train them, and add of Venice-Turpentine,
three ounces; Spirit of Wine, an ounce: Make it into a Liniment.

div.head: A Wound-Ointment.
div.p: Take Venice-Turpentine, an ounce; Galbanum, two drams; Calfs-marrow, half an ounce; Powder of Scorzonera and Scordium Roots, of each two cruples; Oyl of St. John's-wort, half an ounce; the Yolk of an Egg, Threacle, a dram: Make it into an Ointment.
Another more effectual.

Take Roots of Birthwort powdred, a cruple and an half; Mummy, Amber, Matick, of each a dram; Turpentine, half an ounce; Euphorbium, a dram; Ung. Aegyptiacum, half an ounce; yolks of one Egg, Oyl of Elders, as much as is ufficient; Saffron, a cruple: Make it into an Ointment.
Another more excellent than the former, and which likewie reits Putrefaction

Take Tar, Turpentine, Galbanum, of each two ounces; Matick, Frankincene, Nitre, Sal Armoniack, of each an ounce; Allom, half a dram; Verdigreae, white Vitriol, Camphire, Powder of Worms, of each a dram; Oyl of Lin eed, Roes, of each two ounces; Oyl of Worms, and Turpentine, of each a dram: Molax them with a gentle Fire; and make them into an Ointment.
If the Nerve hinder not, in a great putrefaction, there may be added ome Precipitated Mercury.

div.head: An Anodine Plaiter.
div.p: Take Bean-meal, Crums of brown-Bread, of each two drams; let them be put in Milk, adding to them Oyl of Roes, Violets, of each an ounce; Yolks of Eggs, No. iij. Powder of Red Roes, Scordium, of each an ounce and half; Wax, as much as ufficeth: Make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: An Anodine Cataplam.
div.p: Take Roots of Marhmallows, Comfrey the greater, of each an ounce; Flowers of Camomil, Melilot, St. John's wort, of each half a handful; Tops of Wormwood, two pugils; boil them in Milk, adding to them of the Meal of Marhmallow-roots and Beans, of each an ounce and an half: Make it into a Poultice.

If the Wound be quite through, a Tent mut be put into both Orifices; for a Flamula is inconvenient and hurtful. At firt, dreing it once a day, is ufficient; for in Wounds made by Gun-hot, there eldom appears any Matter before the third or fourth day; after this, the quantity or acrimony of the Matter will guide you bet, whether it is to be dret once, twice or thrice a day.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Poyoned Wounds.
div.p:
POyoned Wounds are made ometimes by Bullets, Arrows, Swords and other Intruments;
ometimes by mad Beats, as Dogs, Wolves, which hurt more by their venomous quality, than by wounding.
Signs are, vehement pain, a livid Colour uddenly becoming black; Symptoms more grievous than for the quality of the Wound; a Heat over the whole Body; Trembling, Delirium, Fainting, &c.
Prognoticks.] A poyoned Wound, though little, may bring death, epecially if near to the Heart, or any other Noble Part; or the Chirurgeon not call'd oon enough.

Cure conits chiefly in this, that the Venom be drawn forth by Cupping glaes, attractive Medicines, Scarifications, or, which is afet, by an actual Cautery; but then it mut not be in a Nervous Part, the Ecar to be forthwith removed, and the Wound to be cured by degrees. Inwardly Sudorificks and Cordials profit. Bleeding and Purging hurt.

div.head: A Plaiter that draws forth the Poyon out of the Wound, and corroborates the Part.
div.p: Take boiled Onions, three ounces; Treacle, half an ounce; Goats dung, an ounce; Angelica-Roots in Powder, a dram and half; Oyl of Scorpions, an ounce and half; Honey and Wax, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Plaiter.
That corroborates the Part, extracts the Venom, produceth Matter, and incarns the Wound.

Take Gums, Galbanum, Sagapenum, Opoponax, Aa Foetida, Mirtle, Pepper, Brimtone, of
each ix drams; Pigeons and Ducks-dung, of each an ounce; Mummy, half an ounce; the great Comfrey-Roots powdered, three drams; Oyl of St. John's-wort, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of particular Wounds.
div.p: IN Wounds of the Head, where the Pericranium is hurt, a titch either by Needle or Plaiter, is not convenient; fat things hurt, but comforting and drying profit much.
Take Matick, Myrrhe, Aloes, Sarcocols, of each half a dram; Dragons-blood, two cruples; Bole, a cruple; Venice-Turpentine, two ounces; Honey of Roes, a little: Make it into a Plaiter.

Wounds of the Brain are accompanied with pain of the Meninges, and a great Flux of Blood; to which ucceeds other Symptoms, and for the mot part Death it elf. Oyl of Roes applied warm, greatly eaeth pain, and freh Pigeons-blood effects the ame.

div.head: In an Haemorage.
div.p: Take Myrrhe, Aloes, Matick, Dragons-blood, Rhubarb, Red Coral prepared, Hares hair cut mall, of each a dram: Make it into a very a fine Powder.

Wounds of the Face are not to be titcht; but
always care is to be taken, that the Scars may not render it deformed.

In Wounds of the Eyes, you mut abtain from all Unctious things. The ound Eye is to be bound as well as the whole. The Head mut be placed upright; if there be a Flux of Blood, the following things are convenient.

The Blood of Turtles, Pigeons, Hens, Mucilage, of the eeds of Fleawort, of Quinces, Tragacanth, Bloodtone, Cerue, Tutty, Frankincene, Aloes; the white of an Egg, Water of Roes, and Plantain, Decoction of Balautians, Red Roes, Galls, &c.

Take white Troches of Rais, prepared Tutty, Aloes Powdered, of each half a cruple; Red-wine, an ounce; Red Roe water and Plantain, of each two ounces; Mucilage, of the eeds of Fleawort, Tragacanth, of each a dram: Make a Collyrium.
In pain, Womans-milk freh, is good; or the above decribed Collyrium, adding to it half a cruple of Opium, and applying over it this Cataplam,

Take of rotten Apples, two ounces; Flowers of Lineed, half an ounce; Mucilage, Seeds of Flea wort, two drams; crude Opium, half a dram; Yolks of Eggs, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Cataplam.
A part of the Noe quite cut off, never unites again, although the Wound be but jut made; but if it adheres till to the Body, 'tis to be titched to it with a Needle.
Wounds of the Ears and Lips find greater benefit from the Needle than from Ligature.

Wounds of the Lungs require comforting and
drying Medicines; harp being here very hurtful, though ued in other Wounds.

div.head: Externally.
div.p: Take Roots of great Comfrey, Tormentil, Cloves, of each half an ounce; Flowers of Red Roes, half a handful; Matick, Myrrhe, Aloes, of each a dram; boil them in Barley-water, and to half a pint of the trained Liquor, add Syrup of Mirtles, common and trained Honey of Roes, of each two ounces: Make it into a Liniment.

div.head: Internally.
div.p: Take Leaves of Fluellin, Strawberries, Sanicle, of each half a handful; Lung-wort, a handful; Roots of Angelica, two drams; Liquoras, a dram; Jujubies, No. xv. Raions, half an ounce; boil them in Barley-water, and add to a pint and half of the trained Liquor, Syrup of Diacodion, three ounces: Mix them, let them take four ounces of it three or four times a day.
Half a dram of Sperma Ceti taken every day, is excellent; but it weakens the Brain.

Wounds of the Heart are always mortal, and thoe that penetrate into the left Ventricle, kill uddenly; they eldom live o wounded, above ix, twelve, or twenty hours, although there are examples produced for it.
