If wounded into the right Ventricle, it permits the Patient to live longer; but that which terminates in the ubtance of the Heart, grants yet longer time.

Wounds of the Stomach for the mot part are left to be cured by Nature, which here doth miracles; yet in a Flux of Blood, Bleeding is requiite. In a Wound penetrating into the Cavity it
elf, all the Tunicles being divided, the Wound of the Abdomen ought to be united by a Stitch, a little Orifice being left, through which a Tent is to be put, which mut not enter the Wound of the Stomach, but only outwardly touch it; let it be armed with this, or the like.

Take Oyl of Matick, of Fir-tree, of each an ounce; Manna, of Frankincene, two drams; Powder of the Roots of Tormentil, of the greater Comfrey, of each a dram; Saffron a Scruple; Earth-worms, half a dram; White-Wine, two ounces; boil them to the Conumption of the Wine, and make a Liniment.
Take Turpentine, half an ounce; Yolk of an Egg, Oyl of St. John's-wort, an ounce: Mix it, and make a Liniment.

Wounds of the Small-Guts, ometimes, though eldom, may be cured (this I can prove by a notable Example.) Thoe of the Great-Guts are more eaie. Where the Small-Guts are hurt, the Chyle, and ometimes the Meat & Drink, comes forth through the Wound; there is great pain, with a Fever and Naueounes. Where the Great-Guts, the Excrements come out at the Wound, or at leat the cent; the Body is bound; the Wound is forthwith to be titcht together, and the Gut to be retored into its natural place, well cleaned with warm Water, and this following Powder prinkl'd upon it.
Take Aloes, Matick, Frankincene, Mummy, Dragons-blood, of each a dram: Make it into a Powder.
Wounds of the Liver and Spleen require bleeding, and if the Belly be bound, Cliters are daily to be injected; to the Wound it elf are to be applied Atringent and Drying Medicines.
Wounds of the Kidneys are difficultly and lowly cured: If made into the Cavity it elf, the Blood that comes forth is Serous, otherwie more pure. This Liniment is of great eteem to be ued outwardly.
Take Roin of the Pine, ix ounces; Oyl of Bays and Turpentine, of each an ounce; Gum Elemny, four ounces and an half: Mingle them.
Inwardly are to be given the Troches of Alkakingi, Gordonius, de Carabe, or Sealed-Earth, Bole, Turpentine and Wound-Drinks.
Wounds of the Bladder are generally cured after the ame manner; but it is very eldom that they leave not behind them a Fitula.
The following Pills are of great ue in Wounds and Ulcers in the Kidneys and Bladder.

Take Mans Bones calcin'd,, three drams; Chalk, Burnt Talk, of each a dram, Troches of Winter Cherries, three drams; Venice-Turpentine a little boil'd, as much as is ufficient: Make them into Pills about the bignes of little Peae, rowling them in the Liquoras-powder; let the Patient take morning and evening ix of thee.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Part of the Second Book.

div.head: BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Third Book of the Second Part Of CHIRURGERY. Of lcers.
CHAP. I. Of the Nature, Differences, Caues, and Signs of lcers.

p.hi: AN Ulcer is a Solution of continuity with Diminution of Magnitude in the oft Parts, from a Corroding Matter.

div.p: Differences are taken, .1. From the Form of the Ulcer; o 'tis great, little; long, hort; broad, narrow; right, tranvere; equal, unequal; deep, uperficial. 2. From the Part affected; which ometimes is the Skin and Fleh only, ometimes the Tendons; Nerves and Veels that carry the Blood. 3. From the Caues; which hall be preently poken of. 4. From the Symptoms; o 'tis painful, itching, obtinate, verminous, carious.

Caue is a harp and corroive Humor, and that is twofold. 1. Internal, as Choler, Melancholy, Serum, Salt, Phlegm, and other Malignant Humors. 2. External, as Burning and Corroive Medicines: the Sweat of Man infected with the Itch, Leproie or Pox.
Signs of Ulcers in general are manifet enough; the particulars you hall have in their places.

Prognotick.] By how much deeper the Ulcer is, o much the longer 'tis in Curing. Ulcers in Parts that are ubject to much Humidity, are difficultly cured. If an Ulcer cannot be cured in a long time, or when Cicatriz'd, breaks out again, the Caue is, the Bone being foul under it. Ulcers near to the Nerves, Veins or Tendons are dangerous. In Cacochimick Bodies, their Cure is tedious. If the Matter which comes from them be good, it gives hope of an eaie Cure. Good Matter is of a middle conitence between thin and thick, white, light, equal, and not at all tinking. That which is ill, is thin and fluid, pale, livid, and of ill mell. Old and inveterate Ulcers are not cured without danger, except the Body be well purged, and a good order of Diet oberved, otherwie ome Dieaes will enue.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Cure of lcers.
div.p:
PUrging and Bleeding are here often neceary, but a good ordered Diet always. Hot Meats and Drinks hurt, as alo all Sweet and Salt things.
Outwardly, the Humor ought to be concocted and turned into Matter; the lot fleh ought to be repaired, and then to be skinn'd. Remedies neceary to perform thee, are Digetives, Sarcoticks and Epuloticks, which are et down in the eventh Chapter of the econd Book of the econd Part. We will add ome Compounds.

div.head: A Defenive.
div.p: Take Guaiacum-Wood, long Birthwort-Roots, of each an ounce; Centaury the les, Wormwood, Agrimony, of each a handful: Boil them in white Wine, and to two ounces and an half of the trained Liquor, add of the Meal of Orobus, half an ounce; Myrrhe powdered, two drams; of honey of Roes, two ounces; Spirit of Wine, an ounce; Venice-Turpentine, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Liniment.

div.head: A Sarcotick.
div.p: Take the Brown Ointment of Foelix Wurtz, three drams; Bailicon, half an ounce; Gum Elemni, two drams; Turpentine, ix drams; Colophony, Mirrhe, Aloes, Matick, of each half an ounce; Litharge of Gold, three drams; Oyl of Roes, as much as ufficeth to make it into an Ointment.

div.head: An Epulotick.
div.p: Take Sacchar. Saturn. Litharge, of each two drams; Lapis Calaminaris, one dram; Roots of Tormentil, Bitort, round Birthwort, Dragons-Blood, burnt Egg-hels, of each half an ounce: Make them into a Powder.

Let it be prinkled upon the Ulcer, or mingled
<2 pages missing>
Gall, half an ounce; Honey, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Linament.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of an lcer with foul Bones.
div.p: IT falls out ometimes that the Bone which lies underneath the Ulcer to be foul: Bones are corrupted and contract a rottennes, either from the long Flux of Humors, or from the Acrimony and Malignity of them, or from an Occult quality, or from a Contuion, in ome manner injuring the bone it elf, or from harp Medicines.

Signs of Corruptions are many: Where the Bone lies open to the ight, at firt it appears of the colour of fat, then yellow, afterwards black and unequal; but where it cannot be een, Chirurgeons may judge that there it is a Corruption. 1. If a Fitula preceded, or the Ulcer hath been of long continuance. 2. If the Ulcer being skinn'd break out again. 3. If the fleh above it becomes looe, pungy, pale or livid. 4. If with the Probe you find no reitance, but an Inequality. 5. If the Matter be much, thin and tinking.

Prognotick.] If the Caries be near the Nervous parts, or in the Joynts, or about the Tendons, Arteries or Veins, 'tis not eaily cured; but for the mot part the Tendon and Nerve are corrupted with it: No Ulcer can be cured whilt the Bone remains foul.

Cure.] The corrupted Bone ought to be corrected, either with Medicines, or with Chirurgery,
or by both. Therefore the fleh mut be divided as oon as may be, that the Carious Bone may be laid open (left ome coniderable Nerve, Tendon or Artery be hurt) according to the length of the Part, and the Ductus of the Fibres, not tranvere; then let thoe Medicines be applied that may eparate the Corrupted Bone from the Sound; and that may preerve the Sound from Corruption.

div.head: Medicines againt Corruption of the Bone.
div.p: Roots of round Birthwort, Briony, Orrie, Dragons, Hores-trong, Guaiacum, Bark of the Pine, Aloes, Euphorbium, Mirrhe, Alom, Chalcanthum, Lime, Chryocalla, burnt Pumice, the Scales of Bras, Aqua-fortis, Spirit of Brimtone, of Vitriol; Salt, Tartar; Oyl of Vitriol, Brimtone, Antimony.
Take Mummy, Sarcocols, of each half a dram; Euphorbium, a dram: Mix them, and make a Powder.

Take Roots of Round Birthwort, Orrie, Hore-trong, of each half an ounce; Mirhe, Aloes, of each a dram and half; Bark of the Pine, Scales of Bras, of each a dram; Earth-worms, two drams; Honey as much as ufficeth to make it into an Ointment.
Take Juice of Celandine the greater, two ounces; Spirit of Wine, an ounce; Mirrhe, Aloes, of each two drams; White-Vitriol, a cruple: Mingle them for an Injection.

If the corruption of the Bone be o great, that it cannot be removed by Medicaments, then we mut come to Chirurgery, and either crape the
foul Bone, if the corruption be mall; or Perforate it, if great; or rather ue an actual Cautery; for without thee, you will carce be able perfectly to cure it.

div.head: CHAP. VI. De lcere Depacente, &c,
div.p: AN Ulcer further and deeper preading, is call'd Depacens; and if it be with putrefaction, is called < in non-Latin alphabet > ; if without it, Phagaedaena; if only in the Skin, Herpes; if ill-natured Cacothe.
Caue is, the alt Serum of the Blood, alt Phlegm, burnt Choler, or ome other Malignant Humor.
Thee Ulcers can carce be cured, unles the Caue be firt removed, and the whole Blood purified; therefore here mut be oberved a good Diet, often Purging, and ometimes Bleeding.

div.head: External Medicines for Depacent Ulcers.
div.p: Plantain, Night-hade; Flowers of Red-Roes, Balautians, Cypres-Nuts, Pomegranate rinds, Frankincene, Matick, Tutty, Cerue, Litharge, Red-Lead, Burnt-Lead, Brimtone, Pepper, Ginger, Mercury, Ung. Aegyptiacum, Fucum, Diapompholigos; Emplat. de plumbo, de minio, Gryeum, de ranis cum Mercurio.
Take flowers of Red Roes, Balautians, of each a handful; Leaves of Plantain, half a handful; Cypres-nuts, Mirtle-berries, Pomegranate rinds, of each half an ounce: Boil them in Red Wine.
Wah the Ulcer with it, then ue over it this following.
Take prepared Tutty, half an ounce; Burnt-Lead, wahed Cerue, of each an ounce; Bole-Armenick, half an ounce; Ung. Aegyptiacum, as much as is ufficient to make it into an Ointment.
Or,

Take Long-Pepper, half a dram; Ginger, a cruple; Flower of Brimtone, Litharge of Gold, each two drams; Gunpowder, a dram; Ung. Fuci of Felix Wurtz, three drams; Ung. Album, Camphoratum, as much as ufficeth: Make it into an Ointment.

Take Matick, Frankincene, Mirrhe, of each three drams; Litharge of Gold, Burnt-Lead, of each half an ounce; Quickilver extinct in Turpentine, two drams; Brimtone, half an ounce; Pitch and Wax, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Plaiter.

Concerning the Cure of thee Ulcers, 'tis to be noted, 1. External Medicaments ought to be changed three or four days; for Nature rejects the bet, longer applied. 2. They ought not to be dret above once or twice a day, except the Matter be very harp, that the Medicine may not be diturbed in its Operation. 3. Repellent and Mercurial Medicines are not to be ued, except with continual Purging you drain the Body of its Impurities. 4. Thee Ulcers are eldom cured without the ue of purging or drying Decoctions, made of China, Guaiacum, Sara, &c.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Fitula's.
div.p: A Fitula is a long, narrow hollownes, or a inewous Ulcer, narrow and callous, not eaily receiving Cure; for the mot part, taking its beginning from an Abces.
Difference, are traight, oblique, imple, manifold, that is, having many hollowneses; ome going to the Bone, ome to the Veins, Tendons, or Nerves.

Signs.] The edges of this Ulcer are white, hard, without pain, or but little; ometimes moit, but commonly dry: Outwardly the Cavity may be perceived in one place or other by preing the Part; in which alo ometimes there is a noie perceived, and the Matter now in leer quantity, otherwhiles in greater, is pret out through the Orifice of the Fitula: By a Probe we can earch the Cavity of a traight Fitula; but in an oblique, we ue a Wax-Candle intead of a Probe. That is more convenient when the Fitula penetrates to the Bone; this, when it is in the flehy and enible parts: If the Fitula remains only in the flehy parts, that which is touched by the Probe, is oft, and the Matter that comes out, is white, equal, and in great quantity. If it extend to the Nerve, there is great pain in earching it to the bottom of the hollownes, and the Matter is fat and oyly, but is les in quantity, and the action of that Member which the Nerve goes to, is rendred very
uneaie: If it paeth to the Bone, that which is touched by the Probe, is hard, not yielding, and painful, where the Periotium is not conumed; The Bone, is foul, is rough, and eems unequal to the touch, the Matter is black, tinking and very thin: If the Cavity joins to a Vein, the Matter is like dregs, but reder and thicker, where the Vein is eroded: If it penetrates the Arteries, that which comes forth, is thin and hining, and comes forth with a leaping.
Prognotick.] All Fitulas are of hard Cure; ome incurable, others that ought not to be cured; to wit, thoe by which the uperfluous Humors have for long time been vented.
A recent Fitula, and not deep, in a young body, and otherwie ound is eaily cured; but an old deep Fitula, having many Sinew's in an ancient, emaciated, cachochimick Body, is very difficult.

Thoe are alo difficultly cured, yea, for the mot part incurable, which touch the Tendons, Nerves, Veins, Arteries, Bones, and thoe that are in the joints, Vertebra's, Cavity of the Breat, and lower Belly, the Womb, Bladder, or Guts.
Fitulas are wont to come in thoe places, where Nature is accutomed to dicharge her elf of vitiated Humors, to wit, in the Abdomen, Groins, Buttocks, Fundament, Cod and Perinaeum.
Where the edges are not very hard, but omewhat oft and mattery, they do promie peedier Cure.

Cure of Fitulas are twoold, one Real, and the other Palliative; by this the Fitula is dried within, and skinned without; the hollownes nevertheles remaining, commonly continuing ome
little while cloed, but eaily breaks forth again, except by a good Diet, often Purging and Bleeding, it be perfectly cured: The true Cure is performed in this manner; good Diet, Purging, Bleeding and Wound-Drinks effect here very much; but the Haemorrhoids flowing more. Natural Baths do oftentimes cure the greatet Fitula's; in defect of them, may be prepared Artificial, of Brimtone, Alom, Salt and Tartar, boil'd in Water; afterwards let the Fitula be dret according to Art: Externally, the Part is to be corroborated, the Humor contained in the Sinus to be dried; but epecially the Calloity of the edges is to be taken away; therefore are Medicines for this purpoe to be us'd; by whoe help many Fitulas have been cured: but thee not being ufficient, an actual Cautery is to be applied, having firt divided the edges; for which purpoe the Syringotomon of Fabritius Aquapendents is a mot ueful Intrument.

div.head: Medicines for a Fitula
div.p: Roots of Hellebore, Cuckopittle, Gentain, Birthwort, Euphorbium, Juice of Celandine, Smallage, Dragons, Spunge, Flax, trong Vinegar, Lye, Lime, Alom, Vitriol, Verdigreae, Orpine, Mercury-precipitate and ublimate; the Phlegm and Spirit of Vitriol, Ung. Egyptiacum, Fucum.

div.head: A Corroborating and drying Plaiter.
div.p:
Take Matick, Frankincene, Pomegranat-rinds, of each two drams; Dut of a rotten oaken Pots finely earc'd, three drams; Red-Roes, Myrtle-berries, of each a dram; Yellow Wax, Roin of
the Pine, Oyl of St. John's-wort, of each an ounce; Make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: An Oyntment.
div.p: Take the Juice of Smallage, two ounces; of Celandine, two drams; of Onions, one dram; Honey of Roes, three ounces; Turpentine, as much as is ufficient to make it into an Ointment.
Another,

Take Juice of Flower-de-luce, an ounce; of Celandine, half an ounce; Red-Wine, ix drams; Honey, four ounces: Let them boil a little, then add of Aloes, Mirrhe, of each half a dram; White-Vitriol, a cruple; Litharge, two drams; Turpentine, a little: Make it into an Ointment.
Another more Excellent.

Take Powder of Briony-roots, a dram; Frankincene, Mirrhe, of each two drams; Verdigreace, half a dram; Sal-Armoniac, a cruple; Hogs-greae, Oyl of Olives: of each as much as ufficeth to make it into an Ointment.
Another of greater Vertue
Take White Vitriol, four ounces; Alom, Verdigreace, of each half an ounce; Strong Vinegar, ix ounces: Calcine them in a luted Veel, and powder it.
Mixt it with Ung. Aegyptiacum, and arm the Tent with it.

The brown Ointment of Felix Wurtz, is a
mot excellent Medicine in this cae, if it be reduced by boiling into the form of a Suppoitory, and o put into the Fitula: You will do well to prepare it your elf; for 'tis not rightly made by every one: The following Suppoitories are excellent, epecially in Fitulas of the Fundament, and other oft Parts.

Take Agrimony, half a handful; Scordium, a pugil; Flowers of St. John's-wort, two pugils; French-Barley, an ounce; boil them in White-Wine, and train them, adding of Virgins-Honey, four ounces: Boil them to a thicknes, then add of Male Frankincene, choice Matick, of each two drams; Red Myrrhe, a dram and half; Sarcocols, three drams; white Vitriol, a dram: Make them into Suppoitories.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Burns.

p.hi: BUrning is a Solution of Continuity, caued by an External burning-Matter always hurting the Scarf-skin, for the mot part the Skin, and ometimes alo the Mucles, Veins, Nerves and Tendons.

div.p:
Difference.] It admits of three orts. 1. Sometimes there is a Heat and Pain, at leat in the Part affected, caued from burning; and except Remedies are preently applied, the Scarf-skin is eparated and divided from the Skin, and Bliters are raied, which contains in them clear Water. 2. Sometimes the Skin it elf is burnt, then preently
a Bliter is raied, but no Ecar made. 3. Sometimes alo the ubjacent fleh is burnt, here the Skin is black and void of ene, and after the Ecar falls off, leaves a deep Ulcer.
The Differences pring from the Caues; for Lead, Tin, Iron, Powder, Lightning, do vehemently burn; Oyl, Vernice, Pitch and Wax les; Straw, Water, Flax, and the like, leat of all.
Signs, by what hath been poken, are manifet enough.

Prognotick.] A deep and great Burn, very eldom but leaves ugly Scars behind it; Burning from Lightning, is for the mot part Mortal: That which penetrates to the great Veels, generally occaions a Gangrene; if to the Intetines, incurable; Burns of the Eyes and Groins, very dangerous. If a hairy part be burnt, it remains bald; never hair grows there again.

Cure.] The chief care mut be to draw out the fire, by which in a light burning you preerve from Bliters and Ulcers; in a great one, you free from all danger; therefore what Medicine oever is at hand, is preently to be ued; let the hurt Part be held to the Fire, and fomented with warm Water, Ink, Lye; or let there be applied Soot, or an Onion beaten with Salt, or any the following.

div.head: Medicines in Burning.
div.p:
Roots of White Lillies, Liquoras; Leaves of Bete, Coleworts, Hemp, Onions, Garlick, Henbane, Tabacco, Leeks, St. John's-wort; Flowers of Camomile, Melilot, Elders; Seeds of Quinces, of Line; Camphire, Myrrhe, Olibanum, Soot,
Whites of Eggs, Hogs-fat, Pigeons-dung, Sheeps-dung, Hens-dung, Nitre, Cerue, Ink, Brine, Lye, Oyl of Nuts, Rape, white Ointment with Camphire, Plaiter of Red-Lead.

div.head: An Ointment.
div.p: Take Juice of Oni ‚Ä¢ ns, two ounces; Venice-Sope, three ounces; common Salt, two drams; Hogs-greae, two ounces; Waht Lime, three drams; Oyl of Rape, Muilage of Quince-eeds, of each an ounce; Turpentine, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Liniment.
Another, by whoe means a poor Souldier became rich.

Take Leaves of new gathered Sage, a handful; of Plantain, two handfuls; Freh Butter without Salt, ix ounces; New Hens-dung, and the whitet as you can, three ounces; fry them together for the pace of a quarter of an hour, pres them hard out, and reerve the pret-out Liquor for your ue.

This Ointment is excellent in Burning of all orts, even in the greatet; it being melted, let the hurt Part be often anointed with it in a day; then lay over it a freh Leaf of Colewort, Bete, or Plantain.
If any Putules are raied, and yet the Burnt not great, open them the third day, and let not the opening be prolonged further, let there follow a Corroion.
If the Skin be wrinkled and dried, all the Putules are preently to be cut, then let the precedent Ointment, or this following be applied.

Take Oyl of Violets, white Lillies, weet Almonds, Butter without Salt, of each an ounce; Muilage of Fleawort-eed, Meal of Marhmallows, of each an ounce and half; Saffron, half a Dram; Soot, Ung. Bailicon, of each an ounce: Make it into an Ointment.

If there be an Ecar, let its Separation be endeavoured the firt or econd day; for which the lat above-precribed Ointment is exceeding good; but if it eparates not, then Inciion is to be made into the ound Fleh: When 'tis eparated, it is to be cured as a common Ulcer.
If there be danger of a Gangrene, or already preent, it requires its Cure, which is already treated of in its place.
Where the Eye brows, Lips, Fingers, or Toes are burnt, a clean Linnen Cloth, or Plate of Lead is to be put between them.
If a tender part be burnt, you mut abtain from the ue of Onions, Sope, Salt, and uch like harp Medicines.
That ugly Cicatrices may not be left, you mut forbear the ue of trong, drying Medicines.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of particular lcers.
div.p:
IN an Ulcer of the Head, neither Unctious, or Repellent Medicines are convenient. If the ill quality of the Humor requires the ue of Mercury, great care is to be had, that it be well prepared; for Crude is very dangerous; which ought not to
be applied where the Ulcers are about the Sutures, eeing a Salivation may be eaily raied, which will difficultly afterwards be uppreed.

Ulcers of the Eyes, for the mot part, leave Blindnes, epecially where the horny Tunicle is wholly corroded, by which the Watry Humor is let out, as alo oftentimes the Chritaline. An Inflammation generally is very painful, which is forthwith to be removed by thoe Remedies delivered in the eventeenth Chapter of the Firt Book. To the Ulcer it elf; firt, Abterive, then Cicatrizing Medicines are to be applied.

div.head: An Abterive Collyrium.
div.p: Take white Amber, red Mirrhe, of each half a Scruple; Eatern Saffron ix Grains; white of an Egg, Sugar-Candy, a Dram; Eye-bright-water, two ounces and an half: Mix them.
Another,
Take Aloes, Frankincene, prepared Tutty, of each half a Scruple; Glas of Antimony, ix grains; Gum, Tragacanth, a Scruple; Celandine-water, three ounces: Mix them.
Or,

Take red Coral prepared, Frankincene, of each half a Dram; white Troches of Rhais, prepared Harts-horn, of each a Scruple; burnt Lead, fifteen Grains; crude Antimony, a Scruple; Honey of Roes, as much as is ufficient to make it into an Ointment.

div.head: A Cicatrizing Collyrium.
div.p:
Take burnt Lead, white Troches of Rhais,
Sarcocols, Sac. Saturni, of each half a Scruple; Roe-water, four Ounces: Mix them.

Ulcers of the Noe mot commonly yield an ill Scent, whence they are called Ozaenae. Caue is a harp, bilious, alt, or malignant Humor, which ometimes corrupts the Bones themelves; but chiefly the Cartilage; o by a flat Noe deforms the Face. They are hard of Cure, and therefore repect mut be had to the whole Body; at leat the Head, which requires corroborating, and moderate Drying.
External Applications are to be abterive, and becaue of the Humidity of the Part, omewhat drying. The Juice of Scharley, mixt with Honey of Roes, is excellent here.

Take one Pomegranate liced, Litharge of Gold, two drams; red Lead, a dram; burnt Alom, ae Scruple; Mercurius dulcis, half a dram; whitet Sugar, an ounce; White Wine, ix ounces: Let them boyl a little, and preerve the trained Liquor for ue.

Take Burnt Lead, waht Cerue; prepared Tutty, Litharge, of each two Drams; Frankincene-bark, one dram; Myrrhe, round Birth-wort, Mercurius dulcis, of each half a dram; Ung. Fucum of Felix Wurtz, three drams; Ung. Album, Champhorat as much as ufficeth to make a Liniment.

Fumes of the following powder, put upon Coals is very good, provided it is ued cautiouly, and not above once, or at mot, twice a day, let a Salivation hould be raied; which alo will cure the Ulcer: The quantity of a Nutmeg is ufficient for a Doe.

Take Benoes, Sandarach, Matick, Frankincene, Storax, of each a Dram; artificial Cinabar,
half an ounce: Make it into a Powder for Fuming.
Ulcers of the Mouth require often Purgings, ometimes Bleeding; and if there be Malignity, Antivenereal, Sudorifick Decoctions, which are here of great ue.
External Remedies alo here, are Abterives and Driers: I have tried the following to be of ingular Vertue.

Take Oak-leaves, a handful; Flowers of Roes, Balautians, of each a pugil; Pomegranate-rinds, two drams; Burnt-Alom, two Scruples; white Vitriol, half a Scruple; boil them in red Wine; to half a pint of the trained Liquor, add Honey of Roes, Rob. Diameron, of each an ounce: Make a Gargarim.
Or,

Take common Chalk, burnt Talk, red Lead, burnt Alom, of each a dram; Bole-Armenick, two drams; Mercurius dulcis, half a dram; Vitriol, a cruple; boil them in white Wine; and to ten ounces of the Liquor, add Syrup of Comfrey of Fernelius, two ounces and an half: Mix it for a Mouth-water.
Or,

Take burnt Talk, Flower of Brimtone, Bole-Armenick, Frankincene, Comfrey-roots, the greater, Pomegranate rinds, of each a dram; burnt Alom, two Scruples; Verdigreece, half a dram; Honey of Roes, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Liniment.
Or,
Take Ung. Fucum of Felix Wurtz, three drams; Honey of Roes, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Liniment.

The Fume for Ulcers of the Noe, is here ueful;
as alo common Ink. If Medicines effect nothing, an actual Cautery mut be ued.

An Ulcer of the Bladder is troubleome, and for the mot part incurable, having its beginning from a Wound, the Stone, a harp Humor, or Diuretick Medicine, it requires many Internal and External Remedies; which that we may not exceed our bounds, we leave to be precribed by the Phyician, except ome few, whoe vertue hath been often experimented by us.

Take Roots of round Birthwort, Comfrey the greater, Omond-royal, of each half a dram: Myrrhe, Frankincene, Storax, Matick, Gum Tragaganth, Seeds of white Poppy, Henbane, of each a cruple; Juice of Liquoras, half a dram; Venice-Turpentine, as much as to make them into Pills of the bignes of a little Pea.
Or,

Take Troches of Alkakingi, de Carabe, Burnt-Talk, of each half a dram; Bole-Armenick, Sealed Earth, Mans-skull, of each a dram; Venice-Turpentine, as much as to make them into Pills of the bignes of a little Pea.
Let the Patient take ix of thee Pills, or of the former every day Morning and Evening.
Take Lime-water, three ounces; Plantain, two ounces; white Troches of Rhais, a dram; Mix them for an Injection, to be ued twice or thrice every day.
Lime water in this place, is nothing ele than common-water wherein quick Lime hath been quencht: have a care of making it too trong.

Ulcers of the neck of the Bladder are cured after the ame manner, though indeed more eaily; and thoe of the Penis far more eaily; although
contracted from a virulent Gonorrhaea. Thee are to be known by the pained Part, and by the coming forth of the Matter, before or after making of the Urine; except timely you endeavor their Cure, the Dieae lides inwardly, and will perforate either the Bladder or Perinaeum: Sometimes there are here one or more Caruncles, which, becaue they cannot always be cured by Medicaments, they may be taken away by Chirurgery, by the aitance of an Intrument decribed by Pary and others; yet many times have I cured thee Excrecenies, by uing of mall Suppoitories made of the following Ointment, thickned by gentle boiling.
Take Ung. Fucum of Felix Wurtz, Honey of Roes, of each two drams: Make it into an Ointment.
In thee Caruncles, before they are fixt, we effect much by Vulnerary, Sudorifick and Anti-venereal Decoctions, outwardly uing the following Medicine.

Take Litharge of Gold, Flower of Brimtone, of each three drams; prepared Tutty, two drams; Red Lead, half a dram; Ung. Aegyptiacum, a dram, Honey of Roes, as much as is ufficient to make it into an Ointment.

Anoint a Wax-Candle with this Ointment, and put it into the Urinary paage, renewing it twice or thrice a day, until there is an abolute Mundification. Its Conolidation is performed with no better Medicines (that I know of) than by the Amalgama of Mercury, decrib'd in the eventh Chapter of the econd Book, if it be mixt with Ung. Diapompholigos, and the Wax Candle annointed with it, and put into the Urethra, as is already aid.

Ulcers of the Neck of the Womb, though light, they are of difficult Cure, and if thoe Ulcers are negligently handled, they produce grievous Symptoms, and ometimes a Gangrene; after Purging, and the ue of Vulnerary, and Venereal Decoctions, as alo Bleeding, the following is good.

Take Roots of Orie powdered, Litharge of Gold, Flower of Brimtone, of each two drams; Matick, a dram; Mercurius dulcis, half an ounce; Ung. Fucum of Felix Wurtz, two drams; Honey of Roes, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Liniment.

div.head: A Fume.
div.p: Take Gum of Juniper, an ounce; Matick, Myrrhe, Laudanum, of each two drams: Make it into a Powder.
If they had their Original from the French-Pox, add to this Powder a dram of Cinnabar, and ue it twice a day.

Ulcers of the Legs, epecially thoe that are upon the Shins, occaion great trouble to the Chirurgeon, becaue the Humors of the whole Body continually flow to thoe parts; for which reaon the Medicines are oftentimes ued to little purpoe; the Part mut be well rowled from the Foot upwards, and the Body once or twice a week well purged.
A Plate of Lead, or Plaiter of Lead, or Diapompholigos, of Mineum, Grieum, or the following is very good in this cae.

Take the Plaiters of Lead, Grieum, of each an ounce; Litharge of Gold, Cerue, of each three drams; Sac. Saturni, half a dram; Gum
Elemny, two drams: Make it into a Plaiter.
Another very good in thee, or other Malignant Ulcers.

Take Album-Graecum, Froth of the Sea, of each an ounce; Oyl of bitter Almonds, four ounces; Sheeps-Sewet, ix ounces; White Wax, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter; to which, if you pleae, you may add ome Diapompholigos.

div.head: Factotum Magitri Chritiani.
div.p: Take Oyl of Roes, twelve ounces; Cerue, Muilage of the Roots of Comfrey, of each ix ounces; White Wax, four ounces; Litharge of Gold, Red Lead, Lapis Calaminaris, of each three ounces: Make it into an Ointment according to Art.
Another.

Take Flowers of Red-Roes, one ounce; Balautians, two drams; Elder-flowers, an ounce and half; Roots of Tormentil, Round-Birthwort Roots, long Pepper, Lapis Calaminaris, of each an ounce: Prepared Tutty, two drams; Bole-Armenick, half an ounce: Litharge of Gold and Silver, of each an ounce and half; Roe-water, five ounces; White Wine, twelve ounces: Mix them.

div.trailer: The End of the third Book of the econd Part.

div.head: THE AUTHOR'S PREFACE TO THE STUDIOUS READER.
div.p:
AS Chirurgery is a of Phyick, that ought not to be eparated from it; o alo let not any imagine to himelf, that he can deerve the name of an Experienced Chirurgeon, except he underdertand ome part of it, epecially Anatomy, the only Foundation of Chirurgery. But eeing that the tudy of ome mot curious Anatomits, hath found out many excellent things in this happy Age, altogether unknown to the Ancients (though ome foolihly affirm the contrary, with great pains, acribing thoe things to them, which they never o much as dream'd of) which indeed are not to be accounted of, as ingenious ubtleties; but as the Fundamental Rules
and Cynoure to thoe that Navigate through the vat Ocean of this Art. It is every ones part to labour in it, that it may be perfected, and every day more and more illutrated; which may at length be brought to pas, if with the greater Pains, Indutry and Curioity, we enquire into the unknown Regions and Tracts of the Microcom, and not given to loth, plough our Ground with other Mens Oxen, only truting on the Authority of the Ancients, which the Learned wiely call Ainorum Pontem. As for me, I have ventured to introduce ome new Opinions; becaue that I deemed them in the nature of things, to exceed thee and me, and all in Antiquity. If thou enquiret into it with the ame labour, perchance thou mayet embrace the ame Opinions: That of the Circulation of the Blood is now pread over all Europe; yea, the principal Profeors in the Illutrious Univerities, do all with one voice approve it; the Salivous paages and Limphaducts, as alo the Lacteal Veels, both the greater and leer, may o plainly be demontrated, that they may be perceived as it were with one Eye. My own proper and peculiar Opinions I have confirmed with Reaons, which I uppoe are agreeable to our Art: In the ret, if thou findet any thing new,
it is nothing but what can be demontrated by Diection. What others have writ at another time, pleaeth us alo; for I cannot, nor ought not to change the parts of the Body; nevertheles the Dipoition of my Genius is o pregnant, that I hope it will free thee from great pains and trouble.
For, firt I thought it convenient largely to dicoure of the imple Parts, their Affections and e, that thou mightet not be neceitated to repeat in following the ame thing a hundred times.
To this end I have retained the Terms of our Art, ued by the Ancient Latine Writers.
Then I expound the elaborating the Blood, which properly is the Foundation of all Phyick, and which the Wits of the Learned have long and much wreted: O foeliciimum qui metam proxim√® attigerit.
Latly, all the parts of the Head, Breat, Abdomen and Joynts, I have o decribed, having not at all eparated them, that thou mightet not be forced to eek one here, and another there.

But that this knowledge might become the more profitable, I have hewn the es of it in Chirurgery, which I hope you will well apply, and endeavour with me, as much as poible, to perfect this Imperfection.

div.head:
BARBETTY'S CHIRURGERY. The Third Part of Chirurgery; OR, The PRACTICAL ANATOMY: In FIVE BOOKS.
1. Treats of the Parts in general.
2. Of the Head.
3. Of the Breat.
4. Of the lower Belly.
5. Of the Joynts.
CHAP. I. Of the Practical Anatomy. THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THou which deiret to know thy elf, come hither and view; the little World will declare how thou oughtet to value the great one. The Architecture of thy Creator, by no Art to be bettered; the Eence of thy Soul, not to be
reach'd by the greatet trength of thoughts, and the fragility of thy Terretrial Manion will teach thee, to eteem thoe things more that are above thee, to ue better thoe things that are within thee, and to carry thy elf with a more compaionate mind towards thy Neighbour, although thou walket here as a tranger; the conideration of thee things will hew thee, that thou oughtet not to be a tranger in the mot neceary knowledge of thy Duty, by which thou mayet ue it to the greater good of thy elf; o of others, if thou dilligently require, of what parts the Fabrick of thy Body conits; to this end, firt we will hew the imple parts and their ue; then after the diviion of the whole Body, the compounded Parts.

div.head: The Chirurgical ue.
div.p: Seeing 'tis very neceary, even at firt ight, that thou houldt know the nature and temperaments of Men, becaue they give the Rules of what is to be done in the curing of each Dieae, we have thought it convenient in the very beginning of this Treatie, to decribe their Signs.

The Sanguine abound with Hair, but lank and yellowih; in proces of time declining into blackih, handom, red cheek'd, frehy, trong: When young, addicted to Venery, not enduring
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ours, eaily weating, phthiical, affable in their Converation and Dicoure; not upicious, equally prone to laughter and tears; they leep oundly, their dreams are pleaant; Pule is great and trong; Urine yellowih, and in great quantity, oluble; They hate Women, and, except in their company, eldom think of them.

They bear Bleeding, provided it be at a fitting
time, and in a convenient quantity; otherwie they eaily fall into a Dropie. Strong Purges, to wit, Euphorbium, Scammony, Colloquintida, and thoe that are compounded of them, they cannot bear; though gentle Medicines, eaily; as Cream of Tartar, Manna, Tamarinds, Pruines, Syrup of Roes with Senna, Syrup of Succory with Rhubarb, Pulp of Caia, Electuaries of Diacatholicum Lenitive, &c. As they eaily fall into a Dieae, o they quickly again recover.

The Cholerick have black Hair, and for the mot part curled; lean but very trong: Coition profitable; they are judicious, and wift in action, avoiding idlenes; they trut neither the words or getures of Men; oon ubject to Laughter, if the thing require it, otherwie grave: When irritated, addicted to trike; more inclined to Drink and Watching, than to Eating and Sleep; their dreams are of Fire, Thunder, Quarrels, Battels. Pule trong, quick and great: Urine high-coloured, as alo their Excrements.

Choler requires not Bleeding, yet permits it, if there be a quantity of Blood joined with it; but it mut neither be exceive, nor oftner repeated, than jut neceity requires, let the Choler hews its Malignity; gentle Purges relieve it, but trong irritate it; it produceth vehement and dangerous Dieaes, and for the mot part hort.

Phlegmatick have long Flaxen Hair, which eaily falls off, and as eaily grows again; Pale-fac'd, cold and weak Body; long ere they deire Marriage, and oon debilitated by it; loathful, unfit for Converation; not ollicitous about publick Affairs; difficulty brought to Laughter or Anger, which then lats not long: They eat and drink
little, prone to leep; Dreams are of Fih, of the Water and Rain; Pule mall and low; Urine pale, and ometimes thin, but generally thick and darkih; the Belly oluble: they bear not Bleeding, except upon neceity; they endure trong Purging; their Dieaes are long, but not dangerous.

The Melancholick are almot detitute of Hair, which is lank and black, of a grim Countenance, the whole skin livid, lean, low, and addicted to Venery, prudent, moroe in converation, readier to give counel to others, than to themelves; not ubject to Laughter or Anger, but long before appeaed; they eat and leep much; Urine copious, Excrements little, grievous Dreams, Pule mall, low and hard.
Bleeding is hurtful, Purging profitable; the Dieaes which it begets, are tubborn and tedious, and oftentimes more dangerous in the end than in the beginning.

Let thee general Signs uffice in this place. But 'tis to be oberved, that the Temperaments are mixt, and then the Signs are alo. Yea, many Mutations, Vices and Diimulations, as alo Virtues and Ingenuity may be attributed to them, which is your part judiciouly to ditinguih; but we aent not to Galen, who held that the dipoitions of the Mind relie upon the Temperaments.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Parts in general¬∑
div.p: A Part (properly o call'd) is a firm, limited Body, which is nourihed by other living Parts but doth not nourih; having a peculiar ue and operation for the advantage of the whole.

It is ditinguihed, 1. Into the Principal Parts, or or thoe not o: Principal are thoe that perform ome Noble Operation common to the whole Body as the Heart, Liver, Brain, Teticles: Thoe not o, are thoe that erve the Principal, and whence they are call'd their Servants, as the Eye, Ear, Hands, &c.

This ditinction pleaed ome Anatomits many years ince, whom I much eteem; yet not me: For if the Liver and Heart are numbred amongt the Principal Parts becaue they elaborate the Blood for the advantage of the whole Body, why is not the Tongue accounted a Principal Part alo? which is not only an Intrument of Speech, by which we are ditinguihed from Beats, but alo of Tates, by whoe aitance we chue thoe Aliments which are bet; which if wanting, how the Heart and Liver could upply the Body with good Nutriment, I ee not. The Brain governs all, but how I beeech you? If the Intetines did not perform their Orifice aright, what would it effect? How hould we be eteem'd, if, like an Oiter, we hould want Eyes and Ears? How depied are the Feet and Hands, yet in how many conditions
do they erve? For thoe not tirring, both Chilification would be impaired, and the Blood and the Spirits rendred thicker, and the Brain made unfit for all actions: In how hort a time would the Limpha of our Body be corrupted, if, beides its own motion, it was not alo moved with the whole Body? All things in our Body are joyned together as in a Clock, one cannot be without the other; neither is the mot depicable Wheel les neceary than the Hand of the Clock itelf, without which, it cannot be accounted a Clock.
2. Into imilar Parts and diimilar: A imilar, which divided into many parts, yet, whoe ingle parts be of the ame Nature with the whole.
Diimilar are made up of more or les imilars, as the Hand, Fingers, Feet.
There are ten Similars found in the Body; a Bone, Cartilage, Ligament, Membrane, Fibre, Nerve, Vein, Artery, Fleh, Skin; the eight former are made of Seed; Fleh, of Blood alone, the Skin of both.

This Diviion is ubject to greater difficulties than the former; but eeing it is not convenient to reject it, without the greatet confuion in the practice of Phyick, let us conider the thing it elf, committing the Diputes concerning the Name, to the Schools.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. A Principal Part being affected or wounded, renders the whole Cure dangerous: therefore Prognoticks are not to be given here, but with limitation, let the udden alteration be rather acribed to thee, than to the Dieae.

2. Wounds of the imilar Parts are les dangerous
than of the diimilar; yea, oftentimes they are ooner cured by imple Medicines, than by compound; the conent of the Parts, by reaon of the Vital and Animal Spirits, is o great, that carce a Joint of the Finger being hurt, can be cured, without regard had to the whole Body. In deed by the aitance of the Ligaments, Tendons, Membranes, &c. the Parts are o traightly knit together, and o abound with Sanguinary Veels, that oftentimes upon the lightet hurt, the greatet Symptoms enue, if you order not every thing aright.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of Bones.
div.p: A Bone is a Similar Part, cold and dry, compoed of Seed, that it might afford trength to the Body, and help its motion.
Naturally, 1. It is hard. 2. Covered with a Membrane. 3. White, with ome Rednes, 4. Hollow, or Spungy. 5. About the Extremities covered with a Cartilage. 6. Smooth. 7. Moitened with a fat Humor.
It is nourihed by Blood brought from the Arteries (every where o mall, excepting the lower Jaw, that Writers of great eteem have denied them to the Bones) but epecially contained in the Marrow.

The Marrow is inveted with a Membrane, it elf is altogether inenible; in the Cavities of great Bones, 'tis White mixed with Red; in the
leer, White; in the Spungy Bones, oft and juicy
Its Sene it borrows from the covering Tunicle for the mot curious Oberver never aw Nerves.
The Bones are joined together, partly for the greater firmnes, partly for the better Motion.
That Conjunction which is for their firmnes, is called Symphyis, and is ix-fold.
1. Suture, as in the Bones of the Skull.
2. Harmony, whigh is by a right or oblique Line, as in the upper Jaw.
3. Gomphois, as the Teeth in the Jaws.
4. Sinchondrois, which is by an interpoing Cartilage, as in the Os Pubis, or the Sternum.
5. Syneurois, which is by the aitance of a Ligament, as the Thigh-Bone with the Hips.
6. Syarcois, which is by the acceion of fleh, as in the Os Hyodis.
That Conjunction which is for Motion, is call'd Articulation, and is twofold.
1. Diarthrois, to wit, a looe Articulation: And 2. Synarthrois, to wit, a traighter Articulation.

And both is performed by three manner of ways. 1. Enarthrois, When the Cavity receiving the Bone is great, and the proces of the Bone to be received alo great, as in the joining of the Thigh-bone with the Hips.
2. Arthrodia. When the Cavity is uperficial, and the Proces little, as in the hinder part of the Head, with the firt Vertebra of the Neck.

3. Gynglymus, When one Bone takes into its Cavity the proces of another, and contrariwie the other Bone receives into its Cavity the Proces of the former; as the Bone of the Thigh with the Tibia, and the Shoulder-bone, the Ulna.

The number of Bones is greater in Children than in adult People; for by years, many of them o grow together, as that they cannot be eparated any more; alo their number is much leened, when conideration of the Procees and mall Bones is not had; from hence it is that ome reckon 360. ome, 304, others, 249,
The ue of the Bones, is, 1. To be a tay or upport to the Body. 2. Together with the fleh, to give it its hape. 3. To help motion. 4. To defend everal Parts.

Although the Bones ought to be decribed in particular by us in their proper places, yet an Anatomit cannot be perfect, that is ignorant of the Bones; therefore, before we begin the Examination of other parts, we think it convenient to exhibit to you the Skeleton in this place.
The Bones of the Head, we divide into the Skull and Jaws.

The Skull conits of eight Bones; which are, 1. The Bone of the Forehead. 2, and 3. Bones of the fore part of the Head. 4, and 5. Bones of the Temples, 6. The Bones of the hinder part of the Head. 7. Os Sphoenoides. 8. Os Ethmoide.
The upper Jaw conits of eleven Bones, to wit, five of each ide, and one common; of thee,
1, 2. Os Zygomaticum. 3, 4. Os Lachrymale. 5, 6. Os Maxillare, 7, 8. Bones of the Noe. 9, 10. Bones of the Palat. 11. Vomer.
The under-Jaw hath only one Bone, except the Cavity for the Teeth, of which are numbered 32.
Four Fore-Teeth, two Dogs or Eye Teeth; all the ret are Grinders.

In the Internal parts of the Ear are four Bones,
which are called, 1. The Hammer. 2. The Anvil. 3. The Stirrup. 4. The round Bone.
The Mouth hath only one Bone, called Os Hyodis.
The Neck is compoed of even Vertebra's; of thee, 1. Is called Atlas. 2. Epitropheus. 3. Axis; the ret want Names.
The Bones of the Breat, in the upper parts, are,
The two Collar Bones; on the ides, fourteen true Ribs, ten Batard, in all 24. On the fore-part, the Sternum, with the Sword-like Cartilage.
In the upper part of the Back are two Shoulder Blades; in the middle twelve Vertebra's.
The hinder part of the Abdomen exhihits five Vertebra's of the Loins, to which are joined the Os Sacrum, and to it is joined the Os Coccygis.
On the ide of Os Sacrum there is the Os Innominatum, or Bone of the Hip, which is divided, 1. Into Os Ilium, which is the greatet. 2. Os Ichium, the lowet. 3. Os Pubis, in the fore-part.
The Arm conits of only one Bone, which is called the Shoulder-Bone.
The Cubit of two, the uppermot of which is the Ulna, the lowet, the Radius.
The Metacarpus contains eight Bones, to which as yet there are no Names given; the Carpus four.
The Fingers 10, each of which coniting of three Joints.
Beides thee, about the Joints of the Fingers. are ound the Oa Seamoidea, 10, 12, 15, or 20.
The Thigh hath only one Bone.
The Leg conits of two, one of which is the innermot, called Tibia; the other, which is outermot, the Fibula.
Between thee, and the Bone of the Thigh, is placed forward the Knee-Bone.
The Tarus hath even Bones, which are, 1. Tarus, or, Atralagus, 2. Calx. or the Heel-Bone. 3. Os Naviculare, or, Cimbiforme. 4. Os Cuboides, or, Teerae. 5, 6, 7. Oa Cunciformia, or Sphoenoidea.
The Metatarus hath five Bones.
The Bones of the Toes are 14; for there's only two in the great Toe.
The Oa Seamoidea are found here alo, 10, 12, ometimes 15, or 20.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: The Bones are ubject to many Dieaes. Fractures and Dilocations are already dicoured of, as alo Putrefaction: But eeing there may be everal ways produced, we will declare thoe which are chiefly worth our conideration.

Preternatural Humors, by what caue oever, either General or Particular, penetrating the Bone, ometimes produce an Ulcerous Excrecency with moitnes of the Bone; ometimes a Cancer of the Bone, to wit, Spina Ventoa, effects neceary to be ditinguihed; which becaue no Phyician hath made it his buines to decribe, I will impart that which Reaon and Experience hath taught us.

The caue of an Ulcerous Excrecency with the Humidity of the Bone (which effect is called by the Dutch, een Beenuyger) is preternatural Phlegm, depriving the Bone of its temper and hardnes; the fleh cannot be aid from this oft foundation to keep alo its Natural tate; but its nourihment paeth into oft pongy fleh, which by degrees encreaeth, and at length caueth an Ulcer; from
whence the Tendons Ligaments, and Nerves are corrupted, and the whole Member ubject to danger.

In this cae you mut not flatter your elf, that Medicines can effect any thing before you come to the bottom, that is, the Bone it elf: And the Bone being made ound, the Ulcer will be cured, and the fleh return unto its natural Contitution. It is therefore neceary to make Inciion, even down to the Bone it elf, and if there be a great excrecency, extirpate it; and if it be oberved to rie again, apply an actual Cautery, always conideration being had of the Bone.

Remedies proper againt Putrefaction of the Bones, are already, both by us and others, ufficiently decribed. To take away the Excrecency of the Fleh, Oyl of Vitriol, Oyl of Antimony, Spirit of Vitriol, Ung. Aegyptiacum, Fucum of Felix Wurtz, are very good; and this Powder is excellent.
Take the Retaurative Powder, an ounce; white Vitriol, a dram; prepared Arenick, two drams: Mix them.
Sprinkle it upon the proud Fleh, laying over it a drying Plaiter, and it will make a thick Ecar, without great pain, which may be taken off the next day.

2. The Caue of a Cancer of the Bone (by the Dutch named een Beenvreeter) is a harp Humor, firt corroding the Bone, then making its way through the Periotium; then follows an Ulcer of the Fleh and Skin, incurable, before the Bone be made ound; its Orifice is very little, the edges are pale, the Matter that flows forth, is thin, the Fleh oft, and omewhat well'd, at leat (as we have
poken in an Ulcerous Excrecency) encreaeth of its own accord.

Here alo is Inciion neceary, made according to the length of the Part, to the Bone it elf; forthwith mut be applyed thoe things that correct Putrefaction, to wit, Euphorbium, Spirit of Vitriol, mixt with Spirit of Wine, &e.

I have not only once experienc'd the Powder of Turpentine, hardned by boiling, to be of great virtue, mixt with Ung. Fucum of Felix Wurtz, or Aegyptiacum; an actual Cautery is very convenient: The Cure alo will be accelerated, if intead of Tents made of Lint, you ue Elder-pitch, becaue this inbibes the harp and thin Humors, by which the Action of Nature is promoted.

Seeing that for the mot part thee Dieaes arie from the ditemperature of the whole Mas of Blood, and when one Cancer is almot cured, another appears in ome other place, therefore 'tis highly neceary to have regard to the whole Body: For which purpoe, the following, or the like Medicines may be taken.

Take Roots of Comfry the great, Omund Royal, China, Saraparella, of each an ounce; Guaiacum Bark, two ounces; Rhubarb, ix drams; Senna, ten drams; Agarick, ix drams; Cloves a dram; Cinamon, two drams: Infue them 24 hours in a ufficient quantity of Barley water, then boil them with a gentle fire, and to two quarts of the trained Liquor, add of Syrup of Comfrey of Fernelius, four ounces: Make it into an Apozeme.
Let the Patient, of a middle age, take three, four, or five ounces; it purgeth gently, forwards the Cure, and preerves from further michiefs.
3. The Bones alo are ubject to certain Tubercles called Tophs and Nodes. Thee for the mot part are the Symptoms of the Pox. I hall only et down here ome External Medicines, approved by long Practice.
Take Oyl of Venice-Turpentine, of Euphorbium, of Guaiacum detilled, of each two drams; Crude Opium, half a dram: Make it into a Liniment.
Or,

Take Matick, Male-Frankincene, of each two drams; Ladanum, half an ounce; Quick-ilver extinct in Turpentine, an ounce: Crude Antimony, three drams; Crude Opium, a dram; Venice-Turpentine, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.
Or,

Take the Juice of Houleek, Henbane, Celandine the greater, of each a dram; Mans-fat, three drams; Oyl of white Lillies, Camomile, of each two drams; Boil them to the Conumption of the Juices, afterwards add of Mercury ublimate, a dram and cruple, Venice-Sope, two drams; Crude Antimony, three drams; Mummy, Opium, of each a dram; Ladanum and Wax, as much as is ufficient to make it a Plaiter according to Art.
4. Moreover it is to be oberved, that no Fat, or Oyly Medicines are to be ued to the Bone, except they are dxtream drying, or that by Ditillation, have lot all their Unctiounes.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of a Cartilage.
div.p: A Cartilage is a imilar, permatick Part, drier and harder than a Ligament, but moiter and ofter than a Bone, rendring the Articulation the more pliable, and defending everal parts from external injuries.
Difference.] Some are ofter, epecially about the Joynts; others harder, and differing not much from the nature of a Bone.
'Tis nourih'd by little Arteries.
It is endowed neither with Nerves, nor Membranes, and by conequence without ene.
Its ue is to facilitate motion, and to defend ome Parts from external injuries, whereupon it is carce ubject to any.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: Not eldom are the Cartilages, together with the Bones, both corrupted and cured; other particular Dieaes it carce hath any, beides too great a hardnes or oftnes: Of both which we will give Examples.

1. The Epiglotis ometimes is o indurated, as that it not only deprives of Speech, but alo hinders the Patient from wallowing, except a great piece; for Drink and all other liquid things pas into the Wind-pipe, as not being well cloed by the tiff Epiglotis. This Dieae is incurable.

2. Glottis, or Chink of the Larinx, either from Meat, or Drink, or Medicine, is ometimes o traight cloed together, as the Patient cannot make any noie; this we remedy by the following Medicines; Purging and Bleeding if neceary, having gone before.
Take Milk, ix ounces; Yolk of an Egg; White-Sugar, three drams: Mingle them; let the Patient take often a poonful or two.
Or,

Take Frankincene, Mirrhe, of each a cruple, Eatern Saffron, half a cruple; Juice of Liquoras, a dram and an half; Gum Tragaganth, two drams; Sugar, as much as ufficeth to make them into Troches, always holding one of them in the Mouth, and wallowing them down.

I deem thoe Anatomits to have committed a great Error, who have acribed this Malady to be an Inflamation of the Larinx; although I deny not, but that the Cartilages may be inflamed, and alo corrupted; yet 'tis certain, that which they have et down, is not of the Cartilages, but of the neighbouring Glandules, and of the flehy parts of the Jaws; for it would not be o frequently cured, becaue an Inflamation and Corruption of the Larinx I always eteemed a mortal Dieae.

2. The Sword-like Cartilage of the Breat is oftner than Practitioners take notice of, unnaturally bent inward, from Humors flowing in too great quantity; and o inclining with the point inward, preeth the Stomach, from whence comes a diminution of the Appetite, a Vomiting of what is taken in, with a continual pain of the Stomach,
and a wating of the whole Body; 'tis eaie for an Anatomit, by the touch to apprehend this Malady, and in the pace of few hours to cure it; for otherwie men are mierably troubled for many years.

'Tis corrected by a large-mouth'd Cupping-glas, outwardly applied upon the depreed Cartilage, and being there fixt, let it remain, till breathing is hindred; then uddenly remove, and the Cartilage oftentimes at the firt time, returning again into its natural place; which if it appears not to do, the Chirurgeon mut repeat this Operation once or twice; then having embrocated the Part with Oyl of Roes, and Myrtles, apply this Plaiter to the Part, which mut remain there everal days.

Take Bitort-Roots, Cypres-Nuts, of each a dram; Matick, Frankincene, of each half a dram; Balautians, a cruple; Oyl of Nutmegs Expret, one dram and an half; Naval-Pitch, and Turpentine, of each enough to make it into a Plaiter.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Ligaments.
div.p: A Ligament is a Similar, Spermatick, dry part, adhering firmly to the Bones, tying the parts of the Body mutually together.

Difference.] Some are Broad and Membranous, ome Round and Nervous. 'Tis here to be oberved,
that the Names Membranous and Nervous, are much ued both by Writers and Practitioners, and hath deceived many of them; for 'tis requiite to know that here it hath regard only to their external form, not their internal eence; for the Ligaments, both the Membranous and the Nervous are void of Sene, which they would not be, if they were compoed of their true ubtance of Nerve or Membrane.
There is no Ligament hollow, if you except the lender Ligaments of the Womb; and are all detitute likewie of Sene of Motion, as from themelves.
Ue is to connect the parts of the Body, epecially the Bones, and preerveth them from continual Luxation.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. Ligaments hurt, by reaon of their want of ene; eldom draw other parts into conent, and by the ue of drying Medicines, are eaily cured. I cannot but again in this place (taught by Experience) commend the Retaurative Powder, of which this is the Decription.
Take Roots of Comfrey the greater, Aloes Succotrine, Calcis vivae, of each two ounces; Matick, Mirrhe, Mummy, of each two drams; Precipitate, two ounces: Make it into a Powder.
Here diligently at the firt time is the weak heat of the Ligaments to be conidered, eeing it may give occaion to a copious collection of Humors, and other grievous Symptoms.

2. The Ligaments alo are not eldom Relaxt: Yea, although the Ignorant do contradict, ometimes
they are o much extended that they may give way to a Luxation, which the Sciatick pain hath more than once given us example of; in uch a cae, external Bleeding and Purging profit much; outwardly the Application of corroborating and dicuing Topicks: The following Plaiter is excellent.
Take Stiptick Plaiter of Crollius, an ounce; Oyl of Earth, of Tiles, of each a dram: Make it into a Plaiter to be pread upon Leather.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Membranes.
div.p: A Membrane is a Similar, Spermatick Part, broad, oft, dilatable, white, inveting the Parts, and carrying ene to them.
Difference.] Some are very thin, others thick; ome flehy, but for the mot part not.
The Parts which invet, are properly call'd Membranes; thoe which contain the Humors, Tunicles; and thoe which cover the Brain, Meninges.
It is endued with ene from itelf, for all Membranes are enible; yea, the Nerves themelves owe their ene to the Membranous ubtance of them.
Membranes therefore only are the true Organs of feeling, they erving the Animal Spirits to this purpoe.

Ue is, 1. To invet the Parts of the Body 2. To defend it from Injuries. 3. To keep them
united. 4. To trengthen them. 5. To give them ene. 6. To cloe the Mouth of the Veels, that the Nutritious Blood be not carried too uddenly into the Part, or out of it, into the Vein it elf 7. To eparate the Parts.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: The Membranes being o very enible, they cannot bear harp Medicines; they are not endowed with great quantity of Blood, whence when they uffer a olution of continuity, they are not eaily united again. But I have oberved oft entimes that by the Mucles, and the aitance of the Quittour, they are joyned together, as in the Bladder it elf, whoe Wounds and Ulcers otherwie are eteemed incurable.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Fibres.
div.p: A Fibre is a Similar, Spermatick Part, dipered through the Skin, Fleh and Membranes, to make them the tronger, and being naturally ditended, to contract again into the ame manner.

Differences are, right, oblique and tranvere, and ome round; the right attract, the oblique thrut forth, tranvere retain, round contrain; but this they do not o by their own ingular virtue, as by the common virtue of the Member which they erve, and from whom they have their ene and nourihment, for of themelves they are eneles.

Ue, is, to trengthen the Membranes, Skin,
and Mucles, and when dilated, to reduce them into their natural tate.
Whether the Blood it elf hath Fibres, as many have delivered, and as it eems very probable to us, hall be explained in another place.

div.head: Chirurgical Conideration.
div.p: Thee offer nothing worthy conideration, except that, when they are wounded, the conolidation of the Fleh and Skin is the longer, and there is a greater tiffnes of the Mucles about the place, and makes them difficulter to contract and extend. The Ductus of the Fibres is diligently to be oberved by them which are to make any curious Inciion.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Veins.
div.p: A Vein is a Similar, Spermatick, Membranous, long, hollow Part, every where joined by Anatomoes to the Arteries, receiving the Blood, wanting further Concoction from them, and carrying it to the Heart and Liver.
Difference.] Veins of a four-fold condition are found in the Body.
1. Vena Cava. 2. Vena Porta. 3. Vena Pulmonalis. 4. Vena Lacteae.
Of the lat of which, a more convenient occaion will be offered to treat of in the following.

The Venae Cava and Porta take their beginning from the Liver. There are thoe which would
have them come from the heart, from a weak Argument taken from unborn Embrio's. But where I find many Branches inerted in the Liver, few or none in the Heart; yea, I have oberved, that it hath not entred into the Heart it elf, but only to be joined to its right Auricle: I rather embrace the old Opinion, willingly granting thoe honours to the Liver that I think belongs to it.

That the Roots of the Vena Cava and Porta were united by mutual Inoculations, the old Anatomits perwaded themelves; but the curious Inquiition of the Moderns hath both found out and clearly demontrated, that they mutually touch one another, but not o united, that the Blood can pas out of one into the other; for the extremities of the foreaid Veels, by means of the Parenchyma of the Liver, do o mutually conent, that Milk or any liquid thing cat into the Vena Porta with a Syringe, finds an eaie paage into the Vena Cava, without either an injury of the Veins or the Parenchyma. Concerning which, read Glion. Anatom. of the Liver, pag. 272.
Veins have only one Tunicle with many Valves within, epecially in the external Joints.
They are nourihed with Blood from the little Arteries, not that contained within themelves.
They are endowed with feeling, both from themelves, and ometimes from the Nerves.
Ue is, to receive the Blood not ufficiently elaborated from the Arteries, and return it to the Heart and Liver, there to be more perfectly concocted.
For the better Methods ake in the following, we mut be forced to decribe all Veins here particularly, and divide them into their Branches.
Vena Cava taking its beginning in the Liver, as is before aid, is eparated into the acending Trunk, and decending.
The Acending, which is the greater, perforates the Diaphragm, and is divided into four Branches, of thee,
1. Phrenica, which dipereth it elf through the Diaphragma and Pericardium.

2. Coronaria, appropriated to the Bais of the Heart, proceeds from the Trunk it elf, after it hath penetrated the Pericardium, and inwardly united it elf by a large flehy Orifice to the right Auricle of the Heart.

3. Azygos, or ine pari, coming from the right ide of the ame Trunk, when acending, it hath paed the upper part of the Pericardium, affording chief Branches to the eight lower Ribs, then about the flehy appendices of the Diaphragm, it enters the Cavity of the lower Belly, where, on the left ide 'tis inerted into the Emulgent Vein, on the right into the Trunk of the Cava.
4. Subclavia, from whom comes forth everal Branches which go both upward and downward:
The Superiors are,
1. Mucula Superior.

2. Jugularis, externa & interna; that on both ides (ometimes ingle, ometimes double) goes to the Neck, Head and Face; this to the thick Meninx of the Brain, to whoe third Sinus its greater Branch is united.
The Inferiors are,
1. Intercotalis, erving the four upper Ribs, and their Intercotal Mucles.
2. Mammaria, which is carried to the Breats.
3. Mediatina, which goes to the Mediatine and Thyme.
4. Cervicalis, which goes to the Neck.
5. Mucula inferior, which goes to the Mucles of the Neck.
6, 7. Thoracica, inferior, and uperior, which goes to the Mucles of the Breat.
The Subclavials being come out of the Breat, are called Axillares, then go to the Arms, where they are divided into 3 great branches, which are,
1. Cephalica, in the hand between the little Finger and its next; 'tis named Salvatella: Its Branches are variouly mixt with the Branches of the Median.
2. Bailica, or Liver-Vein.
3. Mediana, which proceeds with other branches from the Bailica.
The decending Trunk, which is the leer, and is undivided till it comes to the fourth Vertebra of the Loins, then it communicates,
1. Adipoa, to the Membranes of the Kidneys.
2. Emulgens, to the Kidneys themelves.
3. Spermatica, to the Teticles.
4. Lumbares, two, three or four, to the Loins, and to their Vertebra's.
Nearer to the Os Sacrum, it is eparated into two Branches called Illiaci. Before they go to the Feet; the Trunk it elf preents,
1. Mucula Superior, which goes to the Mucles of the Loins and Peritonaeum.
2. Sacra, ometimes ingle, ometimes double to the Os acrum.
3. Mucula Media, to the Buttocks.
4. Hypogatria, to the Bladder and its Neck; to the Sphincter Ani, to the Penis, and to the neck of the Womb.
5. Epigatrica, to the Mucles of the Abdomen, and to the Peritonaeum.
6. Pudenda, to the privy Parts.
7. Mucula Inferior, to the joint of the Hips.
The Iliack Branches, as oon as they have left the Cavity of the Belly, are called Crurales.
From thee proceed,
1. Ichiatica minor, which goes to the Skin, and Mucles of the Hip.
2. Ichiatica major, to the Hip, then to all the Toes.
3. Proplitea, to the Ham.
4. Suralis, to the Mucles of the Calf of the Leg.
5. Saphena, To the Knee, Ankle, and to the upper part of the Foot, and to the great Toe.

The Vena Cava, where it comes out of the Heart, receives three Valves, called Tricupidales, looking internally, for this purpoe, that the Blood may freely enter into the Heart, but to hinder its return.
The Ue of the Vena Cava is, to receive the cruder Blood from the Arteries, and remit it to the Heart.

Vena Porta, much leer and looer than the Vena Cava, arieth from the Umbilical Vein, and with many Roots is inerted into the Liver; without the Liver, it is divided into Trunk and Branches, all which are ditributed into everal Parts contain'd in the lower Belly.
From the Trunk proceeds,
1. Gatroepiplois, which goes to the Caul and Stomach.
2. Intetinalis, to the intetine Duodenum.
3. Cyticae Gemellae, to the Gall.
4. Gatrica minor, to the left ide of the Stomach.
Then this Trunk is divided into two great branches, the Splenick and Meenterick.

p.hi: Ramus Splenicus,
p.U: ometimes joyning to the Sweet-bread, ometimes paing through it, divides into four little Branches, as oon as it hath left it; which are thee,

div.p: 1. Vena Gatrica major, which goes to the Spleen, communicating from thence three or four mall Veins to the Stomach: Thee being blown up in living and dead Bodies, manifetly declare, nothing at all can enter into the Cavity of the Stomach, & o by conequence no Humor coming from the Spleen, as long ince Learned Men have imagined, taught and writ, eeing they terminate in the Coats of the Stomach, and open not into the Cavity it elf.
2. Epiploica dextra. 3. Coronaria tomachi. 4. Epiploica initra.
Meenterious ramus is alo divided into four others; of thee, the
1. Retains its old name, and is ditributed with fourteen or more Branches through the Meentery.
2. Vena Haemorrhoidalis, and goes to the Spleen, the Womb, and the right Intetine.
3. Vena Coecalis, to the blind Intetine.
4. Ramus Meocolicus, and goes to the Intetine call'd Colon.
The Ue of the Vena Porta is, to take the Blood not ufficiently elaborated, from the Arteries, and carry it to the Liver, for the perfecter concoction, and for the eparation of the Choler.

Venis pulmonalis (which the Ancients corruptly call'd Arteria venoa, eeing that it hath but only one Tunicle, beats not of it elf, nor returns the
Blood) coming out of the left Ventricle of the Heart, with a wide Orifice goes to the Lungs, to receive the more imperfect Blood from the Pulmoniack Artery, and carries it to the Heart.
About its egres from the Heart it hath two Miter-like Valves, hindring the regres of the Blood to the Lungs.
Its Ue is, to carry the Blood received from the Pulmoniack Artery, into the left Ventricle of the Heart.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. We have in another place treated of the Wounds of Veins; we hall only add, that if the Bandage, by which you tay the bleednig, be bound too hard, it will eaily induce a Gangrene.

2. We have admitted only four general Indications of Bleeding; to wit, for the Refrigeration, Imminution, Revulion, and Derivation of the Blood; but pecial Dieaes requiring one Vein to be choen before the other, which are thee following; in a Delirium and great pain of the Head, the Vein of the Forehead or Praeparata, or Vena puppis, may be cut; ometimes the Temporal or Saphena.
In an Inflamation of the Eyes, the Cephalica, and if you deire to evacuate from the whole Body, the Bailica or Mediana.
In a Quinie, the Ranina, which mut be but with a little Inciion, eeing we cannot carce by any means top the Flux of Blood, and ometimes alo the External Jugular.
In a Pleuriie, the Bailica of the affected, not oppoite ide; here is requiite the greatet Circumpection; for under it lies the Tendons of the Mucle Biceps, and near it the Artery.
In anger, fear, or any Caualty, &c. the Mediana or Bailica.
In Chronick Dieaes, and quartane Fevers, the Salvatella, epecially in the Full and New Moon.
In Women that lie in, and in uppreion of the Menes, the Saphena; In the Sciatica, the Ichiatica.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Arteries.

p.hi: AN Artery is a Similar, Spermatick, Membranous, round, cavous Part, joined every where to the Veins, by the aitance of its Ocultations, containing the Nutritious Blood with the Vital Spirit, carrying it to all the Parts of the Body.

div.p: Difference is two-fold, the great Artery or Aorta, and Pulmoniack.

The great Artery comes from the left Ventricle of the Heart; which except in the Brain and other ofter parts, every where ele conits of a double Coat; the outermot of which is of the thicknes of the Veins; but the inmot is five times thicker, let by continual pulation about the hard and olid Parts, it might incur an incurable Rupture.
It receives three Valves, call'd Sigmoides, looking outwardly.

Coming out of the Ventricle of the Heart, with a great Orifice before it, perforates the Pericardium, it affords to the Heart it elf the Coronary Artery; when pat the Pericardium, it is divided
into the Acending and Decending Trunk.
The Acending Trunk, which is the leer, reting upon the Wind-pipe, is eparated into the two Subclavials, from which, being yet within the Breat, proceeds,
1. Intercotalis uperior, proper to the four upper Ribs.
2. Mammaria, to the Breats.
3. Cervicalis, to the Mucles of the Neck.
4. Carotis, externa & interna, proper to the Larinx, Tongue, Neck, Head and Brain.
When they have left the Thorax, they are called Axillares, and carry Nourihment to the outward part of the Breat.
1, 2. By the Thoracica uperior & inferior. 3. By the Scapularis. 4. By the Humeraria.
Then they approach the Arm, where they accompany the Branches of Vena Cava, and are call'd by the ame name as they are.
The Decending Trunk, which is the greater, being yet within the Breat, ends,
1. The Intercotalis uperior, to the eight lower Ribs.
2. The Phrenica, to the Diaphragm and Pericardium.
Then having perforated the Diaphragm, it communicates.
1. The Coeliaca, to the Stomach, from which proceeds the Splenica and Gatro Epiploica dextra.
2, 3. Meenterica uperior & inferior, to the Meentery.
4. Emulgens, to the Kidneys.
5. Spermatica, to the Teticles.
6. Lumbaris, to the Loins.
7. Mucula uperior, to the Mucles of the Abdomen.
Then at length it is divided into the two Iliac Branches: About this Diviion exhibiting,
1. Mucula uperior. 2. Epigatrica. 3. Hypogatrica. 4. Umbilicalis. 5. Pudenda.
Out of the Abdomen they change their names, and are call'd Crurales; and o they decend into the Feet, and all along accompanied with the Veins, from whom they borrow their Names.
Ue is, to carry the nutritious Blood with the Vital Spirit into all parts.

Arteria Pulmonalis, (which the Ancients did fally call Vena Arterioa, eeing it hath Pulation, is made up of a double Coat, and contains the Nutrious Blood) iuing out of the left Ventriticle of the Heart, with a double Branch enters the Lungs, and is ditributed through them by many little Branches, carrying to them the Nutritious Blood: And then what in the Blood is not ufficiently concocted into the Pulmoniack Vein, by whoe means 'tis returned into the left Ventricle of the Heart.
It hath three Valves called Sigmoides, which look outward, let the Blood that having entred it, hould lide back again into the Ventricle of the Heart.

Its Ue is, to convey the Blood out of the right Ventricle of the Heart, into the Lungs, by which they are nourihed, and what remains above, then erves for their Nutriment, is brought back again by the Pulmoniack Vein, into the left Ventricle of the Heart.

Here it pleaeth the curious Obervers of Anatomy, to take notice of (beides the eleven Valves which we have declared to be dipoed in the four already named Veels) that many others are
found in the Heart, which as yet want any certain name.

div.head: Chirurgical Conideration.
div.p: In an Haemorrage of the Noe, the Blood flows from the Arteries, not Veins, which not only the colour of the Blood witneeth, but alo the great weaknes which always follows uch a Flux: I ue to tay it after this manner;

Firt, let a Vein be opened, then let there be applied in Men, to the Teticles, in Women, to the Hypogatrium, a Linnen Cloth, four double, wet in cold water; or let the Face of the Patient be uddenly prinkled with cold Water: Internally, let there be exhibited now and then a poonful of the following Mixture.

Take Plantain-water, two ounces and an half; Alexipharmick-water, half an ounce; Cinamon-water, three drams; Confection of Hyacinth, half a dram; Dragons Blood, Lapis Haematitis, of each fifteen grains; Julep of Roes, an ounce; Laudanum Opiat, two grains; Spirit of Vitriol, ix drops: Mix them.
The following Water is alo commended.
Take Lapis Prunella, half an ounce; Plantain-water, ix ounces; let it be divided into three Does.

The manner of opening Arte ‚Ä¢ ies, delivered by the Ancients, is o dangerous and frightful, as that there is none of the Moderns but what dilike it; yea, Arteriotomy hath been wholly rejected, had not the Diligence of their Poterity found out other ways: That which I (with others) have
found always to be the bet of them, I will here et down.

Chirurgeons were wont to tie a Bandage about the Neck; but eeing when it is hard bound, it is very troubleome; it is better that the Ligature be made under the Arm-pits, which mut be o traight, that the Jugular Veins, and Carotide Artery may appear both by welling and touch; then let the Arteries be compreed by the Thumb, a little below, where you intend to make the Inciion; and being opened, (which mut be done by a teddy and trong hand) take forth as much Blood as is ufficient; which done, trew Atringent Powder upon the Wound; then put over it a double Linnen Cloth, with a Plate of Lead; then bind it up with a convenient Bandage, and within five or ix days pace, it will be perfectly well.

In the Head-ach, Madnes, Epilepie, great Inflamations of the Eyes or Ears, the Arteries of the Forehead, Temples, or thoe behind the Ears, are opened; as alo the Arteria puppis, all of them being branches of the external Carotide.
In the Inflammations of the Liver and Diaphragm, the Artery between the Thumb and forefinger is opened; in palpitations of the Heart, either that, or the Saphena is to be opened.
Other Arteries are not to be opened, except a Bone lies under them, for fear of an Aneurim.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of Nerves.
div.p: A Nerve is a Similar, Spermatick, Membranous, round, white, hollow part, erving for the carriage of the Animal Spirits to the Parts for Sene and Motion.

The Nerves take their Original from the Brain, and are divided within the Skull into eight Parts, without the Skull, to wit, thoe that come out of the Spinal Marrow, into thirty Pares; even of which proceed from the Vertebra's of the Back, five from the Vertebra's of the Loins, ix from the Os Sacrum.
The eight Pare within the Skull, proceeding from the Brain, are,
1. Smelling pare, which adheres to the Mammillary Procees.
2. Optick pare, which is the greatet, and united in the middle.
3. The pare that moves the Eyes.
4. The Tating pare.
5. The econd tating pare.
6. The hearing Pare.

7. Par vagum, which is veted with trong Membranes; it decends through the Orifices of the Bone of the hinder part of the Head to the Throat, afterwards ending Branches to the Neck of the Larinx, to the Mucles of the Tongue, and Os Hyodis; then is divided of each ide into the external and internal Branch.

The right External Branch, having ent ome Branches to the Mucles of the Breat, makes the right recurrent Nerve; this contributes to the Voice, as alo to the feeling in the Pleura, the Coat of the Lungs, the Pericardium, and to the upper Orifice of the Stomach, eeing all thoe Parts obtain Branches from it.

The left external Branch contitutes the left recurrent Nerve, which goes to the ame Parts, as we have declared the right doth; being brought to the aid Orifice of the Stomach, it is joined to the right recurrent, and o goes to the lower Orifice of the Stomach, and to the lower part of the Liver.

p.hi: The right internal Branch
p.U: ends Branches to each intercotal Mucle; then having perforated the Diaphragm, furniheth all the parts of the lower Belly with a Nerve, ending about the Os Sacrum.

div.p: Of the left Internal Branch is the ame Ditribution.
8. The Part moving the Tongue.
The Nerves have a Cavity, but o little, not to be ditinguihed by the ight, except in the Optick Nerves, and thoe of the Pudendum.
Ue is, to carry the Animal Spirits for ene and motion of the whole body.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: The Cure of wounded Nerves and Tendons is o like, as it hath been more than once the occaion of Confuion among the bet Authors; therefore for the better ditinction ake,

1. The frequent contuion of the Nerves by a Fall or Blow: the Skin having uffered a olution of continuity, there happens an Ulcer, and many
other Symptoms, from the afflux of Humors. It requires the ame Cure we have propoed in another place, of Wounds of the Nerves.

But if the contued Nerve be not bare, which may be dicerned from the greater and more connual pain than is uual, in a imple contuion of the Fleh, the greatet care is, that the coagulated Blood be as oon as poible reolved; for if it hould uppurate, the Nerve eaily would putrifie; therefore let there be applied a Cloth dipt in one or other of the following Oyls, warm to the affected Part.
Oyl of Cator, Worms, Dill, Rue, Camomile, Roemary.
