Or, let this Fomentation be applied very hot with Spunges.
Take our Orie Roots, two ounces; Leaves of Roemary, Marjoram, Hore-Mint, of each half a handful: Boil them in white Wine for a Fomentation.
Or let the following Plaiter be laid on:

Take Sow-bread Roots in Powder, two drams; Species Diambrae, one dram; Oyl of Cator, three drams; Turpentine, a dram; Plaiter of Betony, on ounce; Virgins-Honey, as much as to make it according to Art into a Plaiter.
Oyl of Lavender is excellent in this Cae, if taken to the quantity of two drops, epecially where Convulions happen.

2. The Nerves are not eldom obtructed with a pituitous and tough Humor, from whence a tuppor of the Part, and ometimes alo a tiffnes; thee Symptoms I ued to remove after the following manner; the whole Body, if occaion, being firt purged.
Take Gum Caranna, half an ounce; Galbanum; an ounce; Oyl of Euphorbium, a dram and an half: Make it into a Plaiter.
Or,
Take Mans-fat, Gooe-Fat, of each an ounce Oyl of Earth, three drams: Make it into a Liniment.
Let the Part affected be anointed with it Morning and Evening, then lay on the Stiptick Plaiter of Crollius, or of Ladanum or Diachilon with Gums.

You will haten the Cure, if you ue Internal Corroboratives, which do wonderfully alter the Nerves, although thee things properly belong to the Phyician, yet I think it convenient to precribe this Decoction of great efficacy, of which, let the Patient take three or four ounces twice a day.

Take Roots of Piony, Sea-holly, of each half an ounce; Orrie, three drams; Leaves of Marjoram, Roemary, of each an handful; Flowers of the Lime tree, Lavender, and Lilly of the Valley, of each a pugil; the leer Cardomomes, three drams; Nutmegs, a dram: Infue them ix hours in a ufficient quantity of White-Wine, afterwards boil them, and to a quart of the trained Liquor, add three ounces of Syrup of Stoechas: Mix them.

There often happens through a Chronick Dieae, or from a Luxation or Fracture, a Contraction of the Member, which is not to be acribed to the Nerves, but Tendons. This is eaily remedied by the ue of Oyls and Ointments that have the property of mollifying the indurated Tendons, epecially if
there is to be ued a daily extention, either by the Hands, Weights or Intruments.
Take Oyl of Camomile, Olives, Foxes, of each half an ounce; compounded Ointment of Marhmallows, an ounce; Capons-greae, an ounce and an half. Make it into a Liniment.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Fleh.

p.hi: THE Fleh is a imilar, Bloody, Soft, Thick part, together with the Bones, to yield a trengthening to the Body, and to cover the permatick Parts.

div.p: Difference.] Fleh is three fold.
1. Muculous. 2. Glandulous. 3. Vicerous.
Muculous is oft, red, and is properly call'd fleh, and for thee many ages hath come under the name of Mucles.

But yet a Mucle is not a Similar Part, but compounded of many others, to wit, Fibres, Tendons, Nerves, a Membrane, Veins, Arteries, that it might be a fitter intrument of voluntary motion, to which the Fibres, Tendons and Nerves do chiefly contribute.
It hath a Tendon in its begining and end, ometimes round, ometimes broad, ometimes but one, ometimes double.
Its end is in that place where the Tendons are greater and more.
Its Head, or beginning, where the Nerve is inerted, the middle, where the fleh wells out.

Ue is, to promote voluntary motion, which
is performed after a three-fold manner.
1. When the Contraction of the Mucle is o, that the end comes to the beginning, and then its Antagonit is quiet.
2. When the Motion is Tonick, o that being contracted, it remains for ome time in the ame condition.
3. When it relaxeth, o that it is retored into its former eat and quiet, by its Antagonit.

The Glandulous fleh is white, thick and pungy, formed of eed (from whence it cannot properly be call'd fleh) to this purpoe ordained, 1. To prop up the Veels. 2. To receive the uperfluous Humidities; whence they are called the Emu ‚Ä¢
ctories of the noble Parts.
Some Anatomits make trange diverities of them, but it will appear to any one that diligently enquires into all the Glandules, that they differ not o much in ubtance, as in their Ue and Humor.

The Vicerous fleh, or the Parenchemick is red, hard, convenient to prop the Veels, and to erve for many particular and various operations; this is the fleh of the Lungs, Heart, Liver, Spleen, which hall be treated of in their places.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: The Mucles are ubject to many Dieaes, very many of which are of o little conequence, that they hall not be numbred here; ome we have declared in another place: the following require conideration, oftentimes wonderfully exerciing the patience and diligence of the Chirurgeon.

1. An Atrophy of the whole Body oftentimes comes from an Internal Caue: But if of the Finger,
Hand, Arm, Foot, for the mot part from an External Caue. Thus a Fracture, Luxation, Contuion, Tumor, too hard Ligature, and the like, o vehemently compreing the Veins and Arteries, that it hinders the free paage of the Blood to the Parts, upon which happens an Emacitation; for where the Veels are wholly divided or topt, o that the leat quantity of Blood cannot be carried to the Parts, there follows not a Wating of the Part, but a Mortification; in this Cae the External Caues mut be removed: And care is to be taken that the Blood may again be carried to the Part: Here chafing the Part, and the ue of Nettles (as many will) is good; the Chymits commend much Alumen Plumoum; all hot Oyls likewie are here good; and this Oyntment is of excellent vertue.

Take freh tops of Savin, Juniper, Lovage, of each two handfuls; Camomile Flowers, Juniper-berries, of each two handfuls; Oyl of Bayes, White-Lillies, of each twelve ounces; Hogs-greae, three ounces; Dogs-greae, an ounce and half; Aqua vitae, two ounces; Boil them to the conumption of the moiture; then add to the expres'd Liquor, Oyl of Spike, three drams; Juniper, a dram; Mutard-eed in Powder, half a an ounce; Roots of Pellitory of Spain, Long-Pepper powdred, of each two draws; Yellow wax as much as is ufficient to make it into an Ointment.
Or,

Take Pulvis Amianti, three drams; Roots of Pellitory of Spain, a dram and half;
Cator, Euphorbium, Oyl of Earth, of each two drams; Gum Ammoniacum, an ounce and half; Laudanum and Wax, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.

2. The true reaon of the generation of Wens, in my opinion, is this; the mouths of the Arteries appointed to carry nourihment to the Mucles, ometimes are more opened than they ought to be, whether it be by Fall or Blow, or from an internal Caue, epecially in Plethorick People, and in Parts diorderly moved, the native heat converts the extravaated Blood into Fleh: But eeing the Member requires not o great a quantity of nourihment, it increaeth into a preternatural Swelling; and if this Blood be impure, Choler produceth Pain, Phlegm, Vicounes, Melancholy, a Cartilaginous hardnes; and 'tis to be attributed to thee Humors, that this preternatural fleh is more yellow, white or livid.

'Tis eldom included in a proper Tunicle, except where Phlegm is its greatet Caue, and then thoe Tumors are generally in the Neck: The Veins grow big, according to the increae of the Tumor, o that under the Skin they appear as thick as ones Thumb.
'Tis not in it elf malignant, yet by ill applications may be eaily made o: Air is very hurtful, if the Tumor be expoed to it.
For the mot part the bet Remedies are here ued to little purpoe; on the contrary, the Tumor more and more increaing. You cannot promie any Cure, except you take it away by a Thred, Knife, or both.

In the beginning, the Medicines that are to be applied, ought to be very atringent and repelling,
the Part is gently to be rouled, having applied to it, either a Plate of Lead, or a Diachalcitheos Plaiter, or of Frogs with Mercury, or the following:

Take Pomegranate-rinds, Bitort-roots, of each one dram; Scales of Iron, Quick-ilver, Burnt-Lead, of each two drams; Bole-armenick, Lapis Haematitis, of each a dram and half; Turpentine, Wax, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Plaiter according to Art.
In the mean time, Purging, Bleeding, Scarification, and the Application of Leeches are not to be neglected. Sweating, alo Watchings and Abtinence, profit very much.

But if the Tumor yields not to thee Remedies, but daily increaeth, Suppuratives are to be applied; but if thee within few days effect nothing, and the Tumor continuing in the ame tate, an actual Cautery may be ued; which, let not the contrary Opinions either of Chirurgeons or tanders-by hinder; for by its ue, the increae of the Tumor will be tayed for a long time; yea, ometimes the Dieae will be wholly eradicated.

But if the Fleh begins to repullulate again beyond expectation, the Surgeon ought not to defer to endeavour either by a Thred or Knife its extirpation; the Thred being mall and trong, mut be twice wound about the neck of the Tumor, and tied with a double knot, which mut be traightned the ame day, and o every day until the Tumor be deprived of its colour, ene and life, which is within even or eight days; then 'tis to be taken off with a crooked Knife, which is very eaie to perform, eeing neither any great pain or flux of Blood is to be feared: If the Thred be
wet in Mercurial or Arenick-water, it hatens the mortification of this Tumor: But in this Operation, a Phlegmatick Body is required; for in other Bodies pain and inflamation do o much afflict the Patient, that 'tis eldom that the Thred in a hort time hould take them off; yet the Chirurgeon may to leen the Symptoms, and to cool, anoint with a Feather the part which the Thred toucheth, with white camphorated Ointment, of Roes, or the like, continually putting the Patients in mind how that others bear it more quietly.

But if you deign to ue a Knife only, the whole Tumor mut be endeavoured to be taken away, except you will conume the remaining by Medicines, which is very rarely effected; beides the Chirurgeon mut have a Care that he divides not the greater Veels, let there follows a Flux of Blood not to be topped.
3. The Vicerous Fleh belongs rather to the Phyicians care, than the Chirurgeons.

4. Of the Glandulous Fleh we have treated particularly in everal places. In general 'tis to be noted, 1. That the Glandules are of a cold temperament, therefore require hot Medicines, but very ill uffers cold. 2. The Tunicle inveting them, being eroded or divided, the Skin cannot be conolidated, before the whole Glandule, together with its Tunicle, be conumed with the Ulcer. 3. If Corroive Medicines cure not the Ulcers of the Glandules, within the pace of few weeks, no hope remains of a ound Cure, becaue of the continual Flux of Humors: And this is the reaon why we are for the mot part compelled to take them away by Inciion.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Skin.

p.hi: THe Skin is a imilar, permatick part, having ome Blood mixed with it, reddih, white, looe, inveting the Body, and erving for feeling.

div.p: 'Tis covered by a Scarf-skin, for the greater defence, every where perforated with Pores, to give vent to the ueles Fumes and Vapors; endued likewie with manifet Perforations, as are the Mouth, Notrils, Ears, &c. whoe ue is ufficiently known.
It hath Cutaneous Veins and Arteries, as alo Nerves.
Its Ue is, to cover the Body, as moreover it is the Intrument of feeling.

div.head: Chirurgical Conideration.
div.p: 1. The Skin being dicoloured by the Jaundies, Freckles and other Spots, this Water renders again mooth and fair.

div.head: Cometick Water of Minicht.
div.p:
Take white Frankincene, Sugar-Candy, of each two ounces; white Hermodactils, Florence-Orrie, Venice-Borax, of each an ounce; Salt of Tartar, Burnt Ivory, Camphire, of each half an ounce; Flowers of white Lillies, of the white Water-Lillies, of the white Garden-Mallows, of each three handfuls; Virgin-Honey, three ounces; Goats-Milk, two quarts; Bean-flower-water,
and white Roe-water, of each a pint and half; white Lilly-water, and Solomons Seal-water, of each a pint; being mixt, let them be ditilled in Balneo Mariae.
2. Scars remaining after the Small Pox, Wounds or Burns, we take away by the following Medicines if deep and great, firt, having ued Exedents, then Sarcoticks.
Take Venice-Borax, three drams; Camphire, a cruple; Oxes-Gall, a dram; Oyl of Mirrhe, two drams; Capons-greae, half an ounce: Make it into a Liniment.
Or.

Take Powder of the Roots of Snake-weed, of Orrie, of each three dams; Seeds of Melon blanch'd, of Raddihes, of each a dram; Burnt Egghels, half a dram; Common white Chalk, a dram and half; Frankincene, a dram; Sugar-Candy, three drams; Gum Tragaganth diolved in Roe-water, an ounce; Gooe-greae, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Liniment.

3. Scabs blemihing the Skin, are ometimes moit, dry, preading, eating, cruty, malignant; this difference is of o mall conideration, that generals being well known, 'tis not difficult to one that well weighs every thing, to proceed aright in particulars.

Seeing the Caue of this Dieae is a harp, cholerick, erous, alt Humor, mixt ometimes with Phlegm, the often ue of Purging, Sweating and Vomiting, of Bleeding, Scarification, Leeches, Natural and Artificial Baths, as alo of cooling, drying Medicines, and thoe that temper the acrimony of the Blood, Lotions and Unctions are here very profitable; an Example of each I here give.

div.head: A Purging Decoction.
div.p: Take Roots of Aparagus, Gras, Polypody, of each ix drams; Liquoras, three drams; Leaves of Fumitory, Succory, of each an handful; Senna, an ounce and half; Rhubarb, half an ounce Tamarinds, an ounce; Anifeeds, two drams: Cream of Tartar, three drams: let them infue 24 hours in a ufficient quantity of Whey; then boil them, and to a pint and half of the trained Liquor, add Syrup of Dianicum, three ounces: Make it into an Apozem. Doe, three ounces.

div.head: A Vomit.
div.p: Take Oxyaccharum Vomitivum, Syrup of Roes olutive with Senna, of each an ounce; Fumitory-water, as much as is ufficient: Make it a draught.

div.head: A Sudorifick.
div.p: Take Flower of Brimtone, Antimony Diaphoretick, Salt of Holy-Thitle, Sal Prunellae, of each a dram: Make it into a Powder, to be divided into ix equal Does.

div.head: A Bath.
div.p: Take Roots of red Docks, Briony, of each ix ounces; Leaves of Fumitory, ix handfuls; Camomile Flowers, three handfuls; Bran, a pound; Brimtone, two ounces; Nitre, an ounce; Alom, an ounce and half; common Salt, two ounces; Mix them.

In a grievous and rebellious Scab, the Powder
of Snakes is excellent; this is the Preparation of it: Take a Snake (in March, if poible, before it hath laid its Eggs) the Head and tail being cut off, and the Skin tript off, all the inward Bowels (except Tongue, Heart and Liver) thrown away, let it dry in an Oven moderately warm, to a Powder: The Doe from four grains to fifteen.
Vipers dried after the ame manner, excel Snakes, and are commended in the Leproie it elf.

div.head: A Fomentation.
div.p: Take Burnt-Talk, an ounce and half; quick-Lime, two ounces; Litharge of Gold, half an ounce; Bole-armenick, an ounce; dry Tabacco-Leaves, three ounces; White-Wine, a pint; clear Water, a quart: Let them boil a little, and keep the trained Liquor for ue.

div.head: A Liniment.
div.p: Take Crude Brimtone, two drams; Venice-Sope, a dram and half; prepared Nitre, half a dram; Litharge of Gold, two drams; Mercurius dulcis, a dram and an half; White Camphorated Ointment, an ounce; Oyl of Rhodium, eight drops: Make it into an Ointment.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Fat, Nails and Hair.
div.p: IT hath been long diputed, whether the Fat, Hair and Nails ought to be accounted Parts of the Body, or Excrements. I neither think them Excrements, nor Parts properly o call'd.
Not Excrements, for they are Bodies, enjoying with the ret Life and Nourihment, but not nourihing others, and are of ingular ue for the publick good.
They are not Parts properly o call'd, being detitute of any certain bounds, and have no particular operation: Fat nouriheth in Famine; the Hair and Nails, without injury to the whole, may be cut off.
Adeps, or Fat, is a imilar, oft, white, inenible part, made to preerve the Natural Heat, to help Chylification, to facilitate Motion, to moiten the Parts, and to nourih the Body in Famine.

p.hi: Hair is a imilar Part, produced by the wort part of the Blood, covering ome Parts, and in ome manner adorning them.

div.p: 'Tis outwardly four-quare, inwardly hollow; the variety of Colour it owes to the Temperament & Age of Men, to the Contitution of the Air or Country.

The Nail is a imilar part, prung alo from the impuret part of the Blood, flexible, hard, defending the Fingers from external injuries, as alo adorning them. Its Root is joyned to a Ligament,
and is very enible by reaon of the neighbouring Tendons.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. Blood wholly, or in part detitute of Fat, is not much to be commended; for its abundance contitutes flehy, its unctiounes, fat Bodies, as where but little fat, lean; this fatnes of the Blood dipered into the parts of the Body, changeth into natural Fat more copiouly in the cold parts, to wit, in the lower Belly, Breat, &c. than in the hot. Thee Signs may confirm our Opinion, as often as they are required from the Blood, after the opening of a Vein; for the upper part of the Blood, which is erroneouly taken by many, to be the Phlegm of the Body, and o the vitious part, oftentimes is the very bet of it: This may be ditinguihed by the Fire; for if it be fat, it will flame; if Phlegm, it ueth to crackle; hence it comes to pas, that the Fat, when it is any obtruction in the Cure of an external Dieae, may be cut off without any pain, or other inconvenience.

2. The Nails are oftentimes ubject to clefts, to be rough, and of ill colour; the Caue is a vicious Humor, or ome External Accident; thee may be cured by the often paring of the uperfluities, and the applying the following Plaiter.
Take Roin, half an ounce; Turpentine, Frankincene, Matick, of each two drams: Goats-Suet, Green-Wax, of each five drams: Make it into a Plaiter acco ‚Ä¢ ding to Art.

p.hi: Blood
p.U: ometimes remains coagulated under the Nails, which may be dicued by this Plaiter.

div.p:
Take Roots of Crow-foot, of Solomons Seal, red Mirrhe, of each a dram; Gum Sagapenum,
an ounce; Oyl of Nuts, a dram: Make it into a Plaiter.
For the falling off of the Nails, a Finger-tall may be prepared of Green Wax, Laudanum and Amoniacum, &c.

3. The hedding of the Hair is a frequent evil; the caues of it, are Burning Fevers, old Head-aches, the Leproie, and the French Pox; and there is not to be expected any new in its room, before the Caue for ome time hath been taken away; which being done, the following external Applications may be made ue of.

Take Southern-wood, Maiden-hair, Mallows, Marjoram, of each one handful; Cummin, roots of Parley, of Radihes, Storax Calamit, and liquid, red Mirrhe, of each five drams; Euphorbium, Cantharides, of each a dram; Gum Laudanum, three ounces; Oyl of white-Lillies, an ounce; Roman Nettle-eeds, half an ounce: Infue them 36 hours in three quarts of fair Water, then ditil them in Balneo Mariae.
Or,

Take Aloes, a dram; Agarick, Coloquintida, of each two drams; Rocket-eeds, half an ounce; Salt of Camomile, two cruples; infue them twenty four Hours in fifteen ounces of White-Wine, and keep the trained Liquor for your ue.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Generation of the Blood, and its Circulation.
div.p: WE have hitherto treated of the Similar Parts, properly and improperly o call'd; from whom are the Diimilars compounded. The Blood erves to their Conervation, as doth the Spirits to the Actions from thence proceeding; but how the Blood is generated in our Body, and how many Spirits are there found, is not as yet ufficiently undertood by us. In this thing Writers differ among themelves, o that the very Truth eems to lie hid in the profoundet darknes; yet the love and deire of earching out the Truth exactly, gives me freedom to declare my Opinion, yet till giving place to a better.
Sanguification I conceive to be performed after this manner: The harder Meat received in by the Mouth, chawed by the Teeth, and by the Spittle moitened, is in ome manner prepared to be made Chyle.

This Spittle, from whence it hath its beginning, no man as I know of, hath rightly demontrated: Thoe that derived it from the Veins and Arteries, it is upon this reaon, becaue they communicate everal Branches to the Maxillerary Glandules, through which the late invented Ductus Salivales pas; and moreover, a Salivation raied by Art, eems to confirm this Opinion.

But how the Arteries and Nerves can eparate
o great a quantity of Spittle, as we have often known to have been thrown forth in o hort a time, eems not poible to me, I do rather derive it from the Stomach and Limphaducts, which I uppoe to adhere to the Salivals, upon the following Reaons.
1. As often as voluntary wallowing is deigned, we oberve the Spittle to acend as it were from the Stomach into the Mouth it elf, epecially if the Meat be moitened by Drink.
2. The Tongue, Mouth and the whole Stomach have inwardly a common Tunicle.
3. The Meat in the Mouth, as in like manner in the Ventricle, ought to be mixt with Spittle.
4. It would be very troubleome continually to drink in eating; for it is very eaie for ome time to keep the devoured Liquor in the Stomach, and then enibly to communicate ome part of it to the Mouth.
5. The Limphaducts are dipered through the whole Body, and they go both unto the Stomach and Tongue.

6. I judge no Humor to be thrown out of our Body, except by peculiar paages; and o for everal reaons, I think the Tears alo to be hed though particular Channels, which a more accurate hand (whether mine or others) may ometimes find out: Yea, the mot Noble Lewis Bills, the great Anatomit, attets to have already dicover'd them and promieth to demontrate them in the Body, and in Figures to the Favourers of Truth.

If you enquire of me of what nature Spittle is, I anwer, that it is Salt; yet 'tis not always neceary that this altnes be perceived by the Tongue, which thoe that Undertand the Nature
of Artificial Salts, ufficiently know: It is certain that there is ome natural Salt in all Meats and Drinks; 'tis alo certain, that Salt not only helps the commixing and concoction of the Meat, but alo contributes much to the fermentation of the Humors.
The Ductus Salivales, which we have now made mention of, have but one trong Tunicle, not unlike the Ureters, but that they are leer.
Of each ide one.

They take their Original, endued with many Roots, from a certain great Glandule, lying under the Tendon of the Muculus Digatricus, not far from the upper Part of the Jaw; then they run under the Tongue, above the great Nerve of our eighth Pare, to the more inward parts of the mouth, where, in the two ranine Glandules, near the bridle of the Tongue, they terminate; from whom being variouly perforated, iues out the Spittle into the Mouth; of which, the enquiring Reader may more largely atisfie his curioity, out of the Writings of Glion and Van-Horn.

The Meat thus chewed by the Teeth, and prepared by the Mouth, through the Gullet, by the aitance of proper Mucles, is carried into the Stomach, which that it may the better keep it, it preently pureth it elf together, o that the upper Orifice is cloe hut, but the lower not o traight, that though very lightly preed, may there find paage.

The Meat received by the Stomach, and moitened by Spittle, Drink, and its own humidity, forthwith by the heat of the Stomach, begins to be concocted; the Order is not oberved here, which was in the eating of the Meat; yet in the beginning
I have oberved the Meat to be dipoed in the ame order, as it was devoured by the Animal that was diected; but afterwards the Stomack continually digeting, firt ends away that Meat which is of eaiet Digetion, to the Guts, and it doth not detain it, whilt the other is alo concocted, which Loonees and Vomiting evidently enough declare, if you look into the Excrements.
The Meat being concocted, aumes a whitenes like to Cream, and this is called Chile.

The Chile out of the tomach through the Pylorus enters the Intetines, in which paage there is a notable Peritaltick motion: Out of this the Venae Lacteae uck what is ueful to nourih the parts; and the unueful is cat out through the Belly: The Venae Lacteae conit of one very thin Tunicle, but are endowed with everal Valves, extended from the Liver towards the Glandules, they are ditributed through all the Meentery, and o are carried for the mot part to the mall Guts, epecially the Jejunum; but yet the great Guts are not altogether detitute of them, that none of the Nutriment may be lot.

From the Intetine, both thee Veels and the Chile contain'd in them, go to the three Glandules of the Chile, the greatet of which is in the middle of the Meentery, called by Aellius, Pancreas; the two leer are call'd the Lumbar Glandules, ituate near the left Kidney.
Each of thee Glandules end forth a Branch, which joining above the left Kidney, contitutes a Veel called Vena Lactea, about the bignes of a great quill.

This great Lactean Vein, lying between the Arteria
aorta, and the Vertebra's of the Loins, cover'd with Fat, runs upwards, and above the Heart, acends by the Gullet, and o hatens to the left Subclavial Vein, where it ends in one, two or three branches; here a mot thin valve occurs at the very end of the Vein looking inwardly, that the Chyle might not return back again, or run further into the Arm; out of this Subclavial they decend by the acending Trunk of Vena Cava into the right Ventricle of the Heart, that there by the help of the heat, and natural quality, it may be changed into Blood.

Being converted into Blood, it paeth by the Pulmoniack Artery to the Lungs, which are by part of it nourihed, and the ret of it goes through the Pulmoniack Vein to the left Ventricle of the Heart, that it may be more perfectly elaborated; thence by the great Artery is carried to all the parts of the Body, communicating to them nourihment for the preervation of Life.

Thee ways of Conveyance is dipleaing to ome, who would rather retain that by the Mearaick veins known, and o greatly cried up by the Ancients, than admit of a new Truth; therefore they ay that the Chile, together with the Blood, may by this way be mot conveniently carryed to the Liver, eeing that the Venal Blood is carried not from the Liver to the Guts (which was the fale Opinion of the Ancients) but from the Guts to the Liver, and o not here to be allowed a contrary motion of each Liquor, already ufficiently known.

But in truth thee Opinions they defend, rather by a probable Ratiocination, out of their old affection to the Liver, than that they can make it out by natural or demontrative Arguments, or anwer thee Queries following.
1. What is the ue of the Lacteal Veins?
2. Why is their rie in the Guts?
3. Why the Valves are o placed, that they may hinder the regres of the Chile into the Guts.
4. Why do they all go together with the Chile to the Glandule of the Chile, and none of them to the Liver?
5. Why are the great Lacteal Veins joyned together?
6. For what end doth the Chile pas into the Subclavial Veins? All which can be made appear in the Body to the ight.

That part of the Blood which is not altogether ueles, yet not fit for Nutrition, paeth out of the Arteries, ever joyned together by Inoculations with the Veins, into the Vena Cava and Porta, and o by their means is brought again into the Liver and Heart, that it may be amended, and again concocted.
I do not only ay that the Blood is carried by the Vena Cava into the Heart, but alo by the Vena Porta into the Liver, which I prove by thee Reaons.

1. The Liver is the bigget of all the Vicera; not that I would infer its pre-eminence from its greatnes (ee Chap. 2.) but I uppoe Nature would never have created o great a Body, but for the performing of ome extraordinary operation.

2. Its greatet Vein, coming out with a large Orifice, forthwith goes to and enters the Heart. What neceity is there for the Vena Cava to be ditributed with uch numerous Branches through the Liver, and o preently to acend into the Heart; for indeed it ought to convey back the Blood not
amended. Its Trunk likewie, and that of the Arteria Aorta might acend directly up the Body to the Heart, without concerning it elf with the Liver, epecially when the Vena Porta, near the Liver, may alo yield ufficient ways for freeing all the Blood from Choler: It ought to receive the Blood concocted in the Liver, and convey the ame to the Heart.

3. Its colour is red. I well know that it is ometimes oberved to be white, pallid, yellow, green; but this colour is to be acribed to the Dieae, not to its natural Contitution; for in all Bodies perfectly ound, it is found red.

What wonder is it, that the Liver being red, in weaknes hould contract a whitenes; doth not a red face grow pale, when the Body is affected with icknes? How eaily likewie that the Liver eparating the Choler, hould be died with a yellow or green colour? 'Tis alo oberved in the firt xx or xxx days after conception, it is naturally white, neither becomes red before the maternal Blood (concerning which, ome of the Moderns have far otherwie acribed) comes to the nourihment of the already formed parts, which is the ame in all Spermatick parts, even in the Heart it elf: But will you conclude from hence, that this red colour only happens to the Liver, and is not more proper to it, than it is to the Mucles, which yet therefore do not make Blood? To this I anwer, that the affluent Blood is o neceary here, and o appropriated to the Liver, that without it it cannot be called a perfect Liver; but both the colour, ubtance and number of Veels are o difierent in a Mucle, and in the Liver, that in no wie the parts deerve to be aid to be like one another; and what
aburdity is it to ay; that a Mucle anguifies, when even the Heart it elf by the principal Anatomits and Philoophers, is acknowledged a Mucle.

4. The Maternal Blood comes firt up the Umbilical Vein to the Liver, ere it goes to the Heart of the Infant: And the Valves and Ligatures evidently demontrate, that the Arterial Blood is carried by the Umbilick Arteries from the Child to the Womb, but the Venal by the Umbilick Vein from the Womb to the Child; but whether the Infant is nourihed by the Maternal Blood, or by an External Humor, like as a Chicken in the Egg, is to me all one; when 'tis evident, the Blood, which either coming from the Mother or Infant, paeth firt to the Liver, before it enters the Heart.
5. The Choler is eparated from the Blood in the Liver; for every one knows, that there can no eparation be made, without there be firt a Concoction.

From all thee Arguments I cannot gather any thing, but that the returning Blood is carried by the Vena Porta to the Liver, that it may there be purified, and in ome manner concocted, in which its operation, that the Blood may be rendred more perfect, 'tis carried to the Heart, epecially when by reaon of its continual and neceary Pulation, the Blood cannot remain long in the Heart: and for this reaon I judge, the whole Blood mut needs be moved about with a circular motion.
The Blood made in the Liver, as is declared but now in the eighth Chapter, enters the Vena Cava, and from thence into the Heart.
And thus the Royal Liver, at the ame time, when Kings are taken away, may yet ue a limited power, and may remain with honour in its own Kingdom.
But what hall we do with the Melancholick Spleen, which makes many laugh? It hath many accuers, and not fewer excuers.
1. It was never accounted by Hippocrates the Learned Greek, a receptacle of the Excrements; or is it any where to be found in him, that he call'd the Spleen another Liver.
2. The great number of Veins and Arteries, and o by conequence the abundance of Vital Spirits, do not permit the Excrements to be collected here.
3. It hath not any convenient Cavity wherein the Melancholy, Faeculent Juice can be received.

4. And if you imagine that there is no neceity here of a Cavity, its Parenchyma is too thick, and not porous enough, therefore unfit for the reception of o thick a Humor; which alo is never naturally found in it.
5. It is too great a Bowel to perform o vile an Office.

6. In dead men, where Melancholines hath been the caue of their death, upon the examination of the Internal parts, there none of them les recede from its natural tate than the Spleen, the Heart only excepted, whom the Vital Spirits do o greatly defend, that it is les affected than other parts, which eldom happen to the Intetines, Kidneys, Gall and Bladder.

What is therefore its Ue? It elaborates the Acid Humor, which is very neceary, but not
Excrementitious, and mingles it as a Ferment with the Blood, by which it becomes more perfect, and fitter for Circulation.

In my judgment the Salt of the Blood affords matter to this Humor, which it greatly requires that it may not be corrupted; but this Salt which proceeds from the Meat and drink, is never o pure, but that it hath need to be brought to a more perfect tate in our Body. But this is my Opinion.

The Supremet of the Kings is the Heart; to this are two others ubject, the Liver and Spleen (I beeech you give me leave to make ue of this Similitude in favour of the Ancients) the Heart makes the Blood, the Liver repeats the Concoction, and eparates the Choler; the Spleen from its own Salt, by an innate vigor, produceth an Acid Humor, which as a Ferment by the Venal Splenic Branch, it mixeth with the Blood, to render it the perfecter, and the more fit for Circulation; if any Excrementitious part hould be there eparated, it is all by the Caeliack Artery, and the Haemorrhodal Veels ent to the Guts.
If it appears to any one to be a contradictory, that by Salt a Humor hould be made Acid, we advie that peron to tate ome Spirit of Salt.

About ixteen years ince, the great Anatomit Francicus Sylvius put forth ome particular things concerning the ue of the Spleen; he was of opinion, that the Blood was not made in the Ventricles of the Heart, neither that it was carried from the Heart by the Arteries to all the parts of the Body, for nourihment-ake alone, but that it likewie underwent ome other Mutation in the ret of the Vicera's, particularly that the
Spleen further concocts the Arterial Blood, and brings it to a higher degree, yea that it more then perfects it, o that the Blood in a manner in this place aumes the nature of Ferment, by whoe means in a hort time, a great quantity of Mas may become acid; in the ame manner he affirms, that the Blood more and more concocted in the Spleen there receives trength, by which it retores the returned and weakned Blood, and preparing together with it the Chile, that it may the ooner be turned into Blood: The Reaons which he produceth for it, are thee:
1. The Spleen receives a much greater quantity of Blood from the Heart, than is neceary, for its nourihment.

2. That it can be returned back again to the Heart, by no other way than by the Branches of the Vena Cava and Porta; for what hath hitherto been delivered of the hort Veel, are to be accounted but ridiculous Fictions, as may mot evidently be made appear in diected Bodies.

3. Seeing this Blood is continually mix'd with the returned Blood and Chile in its paage to the Heart, it ought not to be an Excrement; for o the Noble Parts, and the whole Body would not be purged, but the more injured.
4. Chymitry hath long ince taught us, that uch mutations happen daily in Nature.

The Remaining Part of the Blood unueful to the Body, therefore Excrementious, is thrown out through the Guts, Ureters, and Parts of the Skin, &c. concerning which it is not neceary to add more here; but now we are forced to decribe thoe new watry paages, which the tudious
in Anatomy have long and diligently inquired into. The watery paages, the Lymphatick Veels have their rie both from the Liver, and from the Joints, and receive the liquid Juice from the Arteries with which they correpond.

Thoe which come from the Liver, embrace the Vena Porta, and o pas to the Miaraick Glandules of the Chile, as do thoe alo that acend from the Feet; thence they dicharge their Water into the great Lacteal Vein, which as we have already declared, carries the Chile to the Heart.

Thoe which proceed from the Arm, both lie above and under the Veins, until they come to the Subclavial Vein, which they enter about the ame place; where the great Lacteal Vein doth, being furnihed with a particular Valve jut at their entrance, and o altogether they carry the Water to the Heart.
This Water is Sweet, not being as Urine is, Salt.
Thee Veels conit of a very thin Tunicle, whence they are oon broke.

Ue of them in my opinion, is to take the uperfluous Water from the Arteries, and carry it to the Glandules of the Chile, and Lacteal Vein, by which the Chile being made more Liquid, may the more conveniently be conveyed through the narrower paages, thence to return the ame to the Arterial Blood, making it fitting to erve to the nutrition of the moit parts, and to the cooling and moitening of the hot.

But that it may the more clearly appear, in what manner I conceive, how what hath already been aid, is perform'd in our Body; oberve that the Meat is converted in the Stomach into Chile,
to which part of the Drink is mingled, this mixture is carried through the Glandules of the Chile, and the great Lacteal Vein into the Heart, where it is changed into Blood, which is by means of the Arteries to be conveyed through the whole Body; every part of this Blood nouriheth thoe parts which are of the like temperament with it elf; the Hot part of it nouriheth the Hot; the Dry, the Dry; the Moit, the Moit, &c. that which is here not well concocted, mut be brought back again to be perfected. Why we ay that the Veins are not ufficient, and the paages not commodious enough to perform the ame, whoe Office we know is to bring back to the Heart the Blood not ufficiently concocted; the Reaon is that the Water always remaining in the Veels, rendered the Blood too thin, o deprived it of its natural conitence and trength.

From all thoe o clearly and ditinctly laid down, it ufficiently appears what the CIRCULATION OF THE BLOOD is, to wit, a continual motion of the Blood out of the Arteries into the Vena Cava and Porta to the Liver and Heart, that in them it may be fitted for the Nutrition and the life of the whole Body.
Out of the ubtilet part of the Blood are the SPIRITS produced, which are two-fold:
1. Vital, which begotten in the Heart, carry life to the parts of the Body.
2. Animal, who out of the Vitals elaborated in the Brain, impart Sene and Motion to the Body.
The Natural at the ame time that the Circulation of the Blood was found out, vanihed.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. The Ductus Salivales, when the tring of the Tongue is to be cut, or the Ranine Vein to be opened, or any other Dieae of the Tongue that is to be cured by Manual Operation, warn you to have great care of thoe little Glandules in which they end, that they might not be hurt with the Launcet, let there follow a continual pitting.
The great Glandule alo of the Neck, from whence thee Ductus's take their rie, when it is inflamed, admits not of the ue of Mercury; for from hence a dangerous Salivation may very eaily be raied.

2. The Lacteal Veins, either the greater or the leer, are oftentimes from a Contuion or Wound o greviouly hurt, that they cannot carry the Chile to the Heart; and though the wound be cured with great diligence, care, and peed, yet the Patient will fall into a Conumption, whence follows Death inevitably: This Truth will defend Chirurgeons from many Calumnies.

In Children, and older People, is often perceiv'd an induration and inflamation of the Abdomen; the caue of which is the hardnes of the Mearaic Glandules, which allow not paage for the Chile to the great Lecteal Vein, except the very thinnet of it; whence the fleh of the Mucles wats, the Body becomes heavy and weary, and at length a Feaver, and a wating of the whole Body. This evil I ue to remedy without any great trouble, with this External Liniment.

Take compound Oyntment of Marhmallows
Ointment of Sow-bread, of Martiaton, of each two drams; Oyl of white Lillies, of Camomile, of each three drams: Mix it into an Ointment.
Inwardly the following Troches are excellent, being continually ued the whole time of the Cure.

Take prepared Steel, prepared Crabs-Eyes, of each a cruple; Vitriolated Tartar, half a dram; Sal Prunella, xvj. grains; Species Aromatici Roati, a cruple; white Sugar, two ounces: Make them into Troches according to Art.
In this cae Purging is not to be ued, but with Caia, Cream of Tartar, and Laxative Syrups; for the Glandules will not bear trong Purges.

3. The Blood taken out upon the opening a Vein, oftentimes after ome few hours pace, appears very dry, and detitute of all Serum, which for the mot part is acrib'd to its too great Heat, and Adution: but this Argument is very invalid for if the ame day, the ame, or another Vein be again opened, there will be found a great quantity of Serum in the Blood; therefore the true Caue is to be deduc'd from the Circulation of the Blood, but epecially in the Lymphatick Veels, which at that time draws the Serum and Humidity, and o leaves the Blood dry.
It very often alo happens, that the Body becomes Tumid, Turgid and Languid, upon which the fearful Phyitian forthwith pronounces nought but dangers.

When with the ue of Internal and External Sudorificks, the Patient in a hort time may be cured: The Caue of this Dieae is not from the intemperature and debility of thoe parts the Ancients call'd Noble; for it may eaily be ditinguihed from the Dropie, which thee parts occaion;
for although the ick perons are very dull and weary, yet are they not anxious, but breath free, and the Belly wells not much. In the Face, and Joynts epecially, is a watry Matter collected; but if the well'd parts are compreed by the Finger, we perceive much les Serum to be contained in the parts, than in a true Dropie; from whence thoe that undertand not the true Caue, are wont to acribe this Inflammation to wind: But the Lymphatick Veels when compret, broke, or by any other way obtructed, o that the natural motion of the Lympha is hindred, occaions this evil.

1. The Circulation of the Blood, requires all venomous and deprav'd Humors, which are thrown out either by Nature it elf, or that outwardly happen to the Body, at the very firt intant, forthwith to be expelled out of the Glandules and the Skin, by the means of attractive Medicines, let that the whole Blood in a very hort time be infected, and the Heart it elf oppret, and uffer under it: The which doth ufficiently declare, how dangerous it is to open a Vein, and to purge in a Venereal and Petilential Bubo, nay, in all venomous Wounds; as on the contrary, how neceary it is to cat forth the offending matter; by the ue of Sudorifick and Attracting Medicines: As moreover, how that the invention of the Circulation of the Blood, is of very great ue in the Art of Phyick.

div.head: CHAP. XV. The Diviion of the Body.
div.p: MAn's Body is mot conveniently divided into the Venters, or Regions, and Joynts.
There are three Venters.
1. The Head, or the upream Region or Cavity, to it is joined the Neck, which is its prop.
2. The Thorax, Breat, or middle Region.
3. The Abdomen, lower Belly, or lower Region.
The Joynts are the two Arms, and the two Legs.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: We divide the Body after this manner, that it may be known what place each part of the Body ought to keep; to thoe that read the following, every thing will become more manifet.

But there is o great conent of all the Parts, o great concord, that no part may be by it elf conider'd, without a conideration of the whole; therefore I think it neceary, that in a few words the foundation of this mutual conent be here declar'd.
1. In every part is required a natural temper; for the Liver being too hot, the Stomach too cold, the Brain too dry, &c. the whole Body mut be out of order.
2. A ufficient number, for in the Hand, if the leat Bone, Tendon or Artery, &c. be wanting, forthwith its operation is injured.
3. A jut magnitude: one Foot greater than the other, caueth a troubleome walking.
4. A Natural Figure, Softnes, Thicknes: yea, colour it elf.
5. A convenient Connection and ight.
6. The preence of the Vital Spirits, which are brought to the Part by the Arteries.
7. The preence of the Animal Spirits, which are carried by the Nerves.
8. Outwardly the Skin, that covers the whole Body; Inwardly, the Dura Mater, the covering of the Brain, Palate, Tongue, Jaws, Breat and lower Belly, requires alo a particular Conideration.
9. It is likewie neceary that the Nutriment be well concocted, naturally carried and receiv'd, that there may no defect be oberved in the Parts.

div.trailer: The End of the Firt Book of the Third Part.

div.head: The SECOND BOOK. OF THE HEAD.
CHAP. I. Of the Outward Parts of the Head.
div.p: THE Head, as Supream Lord, both of its own, and of a thouand other Bodies, not only governs it elf, but others well, when formed with a healthy Contitution, and intructed with the knowledge of its own Office; but they live a mierable life, whoe Head is not jutly and with Art compoed, and who neither enquire into, or know its Subtance or Figure.
Its Figure is Oval, the upper part is call'd Vertex, the fore-part Frons, the hinder-part Occip√∫t, the ides Temples, the ret is call'd the Face, and conits of the following parts.
Firt appears the Skin, in everal places endowed with Hair, but in all with a Scarf-skin.

Under this lies the Membrana Carnoa and Pericranium, which takes its rie from the Dura
Mater; and paing through the Sutures of the Skull, firt invets the Skull, then all the other Bones.
Anatomits that are very curious, make the Pericranium to be double; the outward retains the old name of Pericranium, the inward is called Periotium.
The Bones which lie under thee Membranes, firt we divide into the Skull and Jaws, then into many other Bones.
The Skull is compoed of eight Bones, joyned together by proper and common Sutures.
The proper Sutures are true or purious.
The true are three.
1. The Coronal. 2. The Sagittal. 3. The Lambdoidal.
The Spurious are the two quamous Sutures of the temporal Bones.
The common are three likewie.
1. The Frontal. 2. The Sphoenoidal. 3. The Ethmoideal.
The Bones themelves which have many perforations and cavities for the paage of the Air, of the Veins, Arteries and Nerves, are eight.
1. The Bones of the Fore-head, always in Children, ometimes in old people, is divided jut to the root of the Noe by the agittal Suture.
2, 3. The Bones of the fore part of the Head, or Bregma.
4, 4. Temporal Bones, or Petroa.
6. The Lambdoidal, or Bone of the hinder-part of the Head.
7. The Sphoenoidal, or Wedge like Bone.
8. The Ethmoideal Bone, or Cribroum.

The Mucles of the Forehead are the two Attollentes;
Mucles of the hinder part of the Head, are the two Deprimentes.
The Jaws conit of everal Bones conjoined o by Harmony, that in old people they appear but as one; the one is called the upper, the other the lower Jaw.
The upper Jaw is compoed of eleven Bones, of each ide five, the odd eleventh is placed in the middle.
1, 2. Os Zygomaticum, or yoke-bone makes the lower part of the Orbite of the Eye, contituting with its Apophiis the Os Jugale, or Zygoma.
3, 4. Os Lachrymale makes the internal corner of the Eye, having a large Orifice decending to the Noe.
5, 6. Os Maxillare, or Jaw-bone, particularly o called, which is the greatet of all the Bones, which contitutes the Jaws.
7, 8. Os Nai, or Bone of the Noe, which in its end hath five united Cartilages.
9, 10. Os Palati, or Bone of the Palate.
11. Vomer, A peculiar Bone above the Palate, which upporting the intertice of the Noe, and joined to it by Harmony.
The upper Jaw moves not but when the whole Head moves, therefore needs not proper Mucles.

The lower Jaw (which generally remains divided in the fore-part till the eighth year, and afterwards is o cloly joined together, as it appears to be but one Bone) hath two Procees, and in them a Cavity, big enough to allow a convenient ituation to the Veins, Arteries, and Nerves, from whence the Teeth receive their Nutriment and Sene: The Branches of the Nerves about the Chin, pas out again through a little Orifice are
ditributed into the Mucles of the Lips.

It is moved by ix pair of Mucles, which are,
1. Pterygo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Internus. Attollentes.
2. Digatricus. Attollentes.
3. Latus, Deprimens.
4. Pterygoideus Externus, bringing them forward.
5. Maeter.
6. Muculus Temporalis.

This Mucle hath this peculiar to it elf, that it is covered by the Pericranium, by which the ubjacent temporal Bones are altogether detitute of it, which is not oberv'd in any other part of the Body. But no man hitherto as I know of hath yet given the Reaon of it; for whatoever hath been delivered by others concerning this, hath been o light, that they give little atisfaction to the lovers of Truth. But of late, Job Mekeren an Experienced Chirurgion of this City, hath in an Epitle communicated omething particular relating to this matter, the ubtance whereof I here give you, until he put forth his Obervations (ome of which I have een.)
TO Dr. PAUL BARBETTE Phyician at Amterdam.
SIR,
I Will truly declare to you my Opinion concerning the Quetion I informed you I had moved in the company of ome Phyicians, which was, Why the Bones
which lie under the temporal Mucles, are not covered and inveted by the Pericranium as are the other Bones.
On the 6th. of Janaury 1654, being commanded by the Honourable Senate of this City, to open the Head of PETER JACOBS, Brick layer, then was my Opinion, which I had been hitherto big withal, ufficiently confirmed; for as oon as I had oberved a great depreion in the upper part of the Skull, I alo found a great quantity of coagulated Blood, which had part of it pat through the Ears, and part of it remained yet in the Cavity of the Ear; then being very deirous to know the way by which this Blood had decended into the Cavity of the Ear; which, when I had diligently enquired into, I alo dicovered the reaon and caue wherefore the Pericranium covers in this place the temporal Mucles, and not the Bone under them.
Firt, The Opinion and the Anwer (which the Honourable and Experienced Dr. TULPH Burgomater of Amterdam, had given to the propounded Quetion, to wit from whence this Blood hould come, which very often in Wounds of the Head flows out of the Ears?) I found to be true and reaonable; for I perceived, as the Noble Conul had affirmed to me, that the Blood from the upper part of the Head, did decend between the Skull and Pericranium, and o did enter the pace that is between the Os Parietale and Petroum, and from thence to be as it was trained through a Sieve into the Cavity of the Ear; afterwards in earching further, I found the Os Petroum to be removed a great ditance from the Os Parietale; o that in the place where the Bones did recede from each other, was a motion oberved, beginning at the Os Petroum, and ending in the Os Parietale,
there where the Toothy unition in the Os Jugale in the inward part, which is covered with a Callus (as it ought to be in every Articulation) to hinder bruiing, is oberved.
And this being o, it may be concluded, that the Pericranium, if it had inveted the Bone under the temporal Mucles, without all doubt it would have paed it elf between the Os Petroum, whence from its moving and rubbing in eating, peaking, or any other Motion, would haue always felt intollerable pain. Thus have you, Sir, what I thought (hoping to proceed further) the reaon to the Quetion propounded, &c.
Farewel.

This Opinion is indeed judicious, and very probable; for in dead Mens Skuls the upper Bone of the Temple is movable as is the lower; and in the Suture of the Zygomatick Bone, is a Cartilage found, which is neceary in every Joynt; for I confes the motion is little, but greater would not be required than what ufficeth to afford paage to the thick Humors, either from External or from Internal Caues, collected ometimes in the Cavity of the Ear, by the which the Brain and Ears may be freed from many and various inconveniences: I hope time and diligence will give us greater light in this thing.
Each Jaw is armed with neceary Weapons, which are called Teeth.
In Men, for the mot part thirty two; in Women, twenty eight.
Four are called Fore teeth, or Cutters.
Two Dog, or Eye-Teeth.
All the ret are called Jaw-Teeth, or Grinders.
After the 20th, 40th, 80th. year, oftentimes comes forth with pain, two Teeth in the very furthet part of the Jaw, which ome call the Teeth of Manners or Widom, others the late Teeth.
Before we come to the other Mucles of the Head, we deem it neceary to decribe ome parts which are not as yet mentioned, that is, the Eye, Ear, Noe, Mouth.
The Eye with the Lids, to wit, the Membranous coverings before Cartilaginous and Hairy, defend from External Injuries; hath two Corners or Angles.
In each corner is a Glandule; that which is in the leer External Corner, is great, white, hard; that in the greater External Corner, is leer, oft, red, and covers the Punctum Lachrymale.
Four Tunicles contain the three Humors.
One of them, which comes from the Pericranium is likewie common to the Lids, and is called Conjunctiva or Adnata.
The other three are proper, and are thus reckoned.
1. Cornea, coming from the Dura Meninx.
2. Uvea, from the Pia Mater; this ometimes dilating it elf, then again contracting it elf, contitutes the Pupil, hewing the many coloured Oval Circle, call'd the Iris.
3. Retina, from the Brain it elf, or rather from the Optick Nerve; which proceeding further, is changed into the Aranea.
To thee three may be added a fourth, Vitrea, which is ill omited by many.
The Humors of the Eyes are,
1. The Aqueous. 2. The Chrytalline. 3. The Vitrecus.
The econd pair of Nerves, or the Optick Nerve brings the Spirits for ight; the third pair, or the Motorious, for Motion.
Branches of the Internal and External Carotide-Artery bring to it the Nutritious Blood; and the uperfluous is returned by the Internal and External Jugular Veins.
Fat and Mucles make up the ret of the Eye.
The Fat erving to the Calefaction, Humectation and better motion, is here in great quantity, every where ditributed between the Veels and the Mucles.
The Eye-lid hath four Mucles.
One traight Mucle, three orbicular.
The Eye it elf hath ix, of which four are traight.

list.item: 3. Adducens, or the Drinking or Reading Mucle.

div.p: Two oblique, which are call'd the Lovers Mucles; of thee,
1. Obliquus Externus, or Troclearis, becaue it paeth through a Pully.
2. Obliquus Internus.
The outward Ear, or the Cartilaginous Auricle, is join'd to the Bone of the Temples.
It hath a very enible Membrane, and behind it alo ome Glandules, to which the Head ends the uperfluous humors.
Veels, it receives from the External and Internal Jugular and Carotide.
Nerves, from the econd pare of the Nerves of the Neck, as alo from the ix pare of the Nerves of the Brain.
Here is but little Fat; what little there is, is below the Lap; it receives four Mucles, of which, the three former are to it common with other parts, the fourth proper to it elf.
1. Antrorum ducens, which moveth it forward.
2. Retrorum ducens, which pulleth it backward.
3. Quadratus, deorum trahens, pulling it down.
4. Tripartitus, lifting it up.
The inward part of the Ear hath four Cavities for ound; and for defence and trength, as many Bones.
The Cavities are.
1. Meatus Auditorius, whoe extremity a little and trong Membrane covers, which is call'd the Tympanum, and Membrane of the Drum.
2. Tympanum. 3. Labyrnthus. 4. Cochlea.
The little Bones are of the ame bignes in Children, as in older People; which are,
1. Malleclus, or the Hammer.
2. Incus, or the Anvil.
3. Stapes, or the Stirrop.
4. Os Orbiculare, or the Orbicular Bones.

The Noble Lewis de Bils, the great Anatomit, in a particular Treatie, hews, that the Os Petroum (which hitherto by reaon of its great thicknes and olidnes, was a vat hindrance to thoe that had a deire to view thee Bones of the Hearing in their natural ituation) not to conit of one only Bone, but to be made up of four, joined together by Harmony, which may very eaily be eparated by <‚Ä¶> .
Within are two Mucles, the one joined to the Meatus auditorius, the other to the Malleclus.

The Noe covered with a Scarf-skin, Skin, Mucles, and the Periotium, hath two Cavities eparated by a Cartilaginous Septum; each of thee again is divided into that which acends to the Os Ethmoides; and into that which decends above the Palat, into the further part of the Mouth.
The ides of it are called Pennae, Alae, or wings; the lower flehy part is called Columna, or the flehy Pillar.

In the inide they are inveted with a thin Membrane, which is very enible, ariing from the Dura Mater, which is as to the Noe, likewie common to the Mouth, Palat, Tongue, Larinx, Gullet, and to the Stomach it elf.
The Bones of which it is compounded, are many and pungy, replete with Caruncles, that the Snot might not voluntarily ditil forth.

Arteries from the Carotide, bring nourihment to it; Veins from the Jugular, return the Blood that is not perfectly concocted. Nerves from the firt pare, according to our order, erve for the melling, as do thoe from the fifth pare, erve to the feeling.
It hath no Fat; Its Bones we have already given you; its Mucles are ix.
1, 2. Deprimentes, depreing the Noe.
3, 4. Dilatantes, or dilating the Notrils.
5, 6. Contringentes, or pulling the Notrils together.
In great Noes there are likewie two other Mucles, which we call'd Aperientes, which open the Notrils.

The Mouth, the Gate of Air, Speech and Nourihment, hath two Lips, the parts of each
ide, call'd Cheeks, as that below is call'd the Chin.
The Lips have two Mucles common to the Jaw.
1. Quadratus, or drawing backward. In ome this motion is performed by the Zygomative.
2. Buccinator.
The upper Lip hath two Mucles proper to it elf.
1. Surum Trahens, or drawing it upwards.
2. Deorum Movens, or moving it downwards.
The under Lip hath but one, Deorum trahens, or drawing it downward.
Common to both the Lips, are
1. Obliqu√® orum trahens, or drawing them obliquely upwards.
2. Obliqu√® deorum trahens, or drawing them obliquely downwards.
3. Sphincter Oris, Contrictor, or Orbicularis which pureth the Mouth together: The inward parts of the Mouth, are the Teeth, the Gums, the Palat, Uvula, Tongue, and Os hyodis.
Of the Teeth we have treated.
The Gums offer nothing worthy a particular conideration.
The Palat conits of a enible Membrane common to the Stomach, which hath its rie from the Dura Mater.
The Uvula is a long little Body, it hath two Ligaments, & as many Mucles, but very little.

The Tongue (as a Sword-cutting out Honour either well or ill, as it is moved by pure or impure Spirits) behind, is fatned to the Larinx, Os Hyodis, to the Jaws, and to the Tonils; before, to a certain Membranous and trong Body, whoe extremity makes the String of the Tongue.
Of both ides the tring lies a Glandule call'd Ranina, from the neighboring Veels.
It hath two Veins call'd Raninae, from the Jugulars; two Arteries from the temporal; two great Nerves from the eventh pare, as alo many little ones from the fourth and fifth.
It is detitute of Fat.
Its Mucles are,
1. Genioglous, which brings the Tongue forward.
2. Styloglous, which draws it upwards.
3. Myloglous, which draws it obliquely upward.
4. Baiglous, which draws it directly inward.
5. Ceratoglous, pulling it downwards.

Os Hyodis, by the aitance of Mucles and Ligaments, is tied to the harp proces of the temperal Bones, and to the Buckler-like Cartilage of the Larinx; it is compoed of five united Bones; the middlemot of thee, which is the greatet, call'd the Bais of the Tongue, hath two Cartilaginous Productions, which often degenerate into Bones.
It hath four Mucles on each ide.
1. Geniohyodes, raiing it directly upwards.
2. Sternohyodes, moving it directly downwards.
3. Styloceratohyodes, obliquely bringing it upwards.
4. Coracohyodes, obliquely drawing it downwards.

All thee are the outward parts of the Head, which is either olely moved by its own proper Mucles, or together with them likewie with the Mucles of the Neck; thee hall be treated of hereafter. The proper Mucles are.
1. Flectens, or the nodding Mucle.
2. Splenius, or the Mucle that hakes the Head.
3. Complexus, the aociate of the Splenius.
4, 5. Obliqui, drawing the Head obliquely backwards.
6, 7. Recti, drawing the Head traight backwards.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: Very many, as well Internal, as External Dieaes, take their rie from the Head, which is is not improperly compared to a Houe-roof that receives the vapours of the whole Houe; which afterwards being changed into a Catharre, ditils upon the inferiour parts, creating a Pain, and Palie in the Joynts; an inflamation in the Eyes and Jawes, &c. a hortnes of breathing in the Breat, and in the Stomach a depraved Chylification; in the Guts a looenes, &c. ome of the External Dieaes hall here be conidered by us, the Internal belong to the conideration of the Phyician.

1. There is often in the Head Porago, Achor, or Fav ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ s, which is a cruted Scab, happening as well in old as young people; thee Scurffs are oftentimes very thick, ometimes accompanied with moiture, which caueth great itching and a very ill mell.
The Caue is alt Phlegm; it is for the mot part a tubborn Dieae, and very eaily returning again.

The Cure] In this cae are generally ued, trong Purging, Bleeding, Sweating, Salivation, Unctions, pulling out of the Hairs: But without uing
any of thee Remedies, I have often cured this Dieae, only with this Decoction.

Take Ahes, (which are call'd by the Dutch Weidach, in Englih Pot-ahes,) with White-Wine, make a Lixivium of a moderate Acrimony, in a quart of which, boil the Leaves of Marjorum, Southern-wood, of each two handfuls; of Maiden-hair, a handful and half; Roe leaves three pugils: Make a Fomentation.

With this let the head be wahed twice or thrice a week warm; then dry it well with hot Linnen Clothes, and in a few weeks pace, the Patient with thus doing, will be cured: You may likewie ometimes ue gentle Purging Medicines.

2. In a Hydrocephalus, and great Cathars, an Iue with great ucces may be made in the Nape of the Neck, becaue the Cavities of the Dura Mater are thereabouts joyned to the Jugular Veins; epecially in Children, in whom very often the Sutures do too much gape.
3. Fat things hurt the Head, becaue it is not covered with many Mucles.

4. In the Skull ometimes a rough matter is collected in everal places, which if not remov'd by thoe Medicines that purge Phlegm, and outward dicuives, in proces of time acquire a very great hardnes, which till increaing, grow into a perfect Horn, not to be cured, but by Chirurgery.

5. Upon the Skull likewie comes other Abcees, which although they may belong to a Steatoma, Atheroma, or Melicerides, yet in the Head epecially they are call'd Tetudo, Talpa, Natta. Thee give little hope of Cure, where the Bone is much corrupted;
otherwie they may be taken away by a Thred, or what is better, by a Knife, when they reject other Remedies. The manner of taking them away by a Knife, is this; the Skin being divided in form of a Cros, the Bladder is to be taken out, then the Pericranium being eparated, the Cranium is to be craped with a Rapatory, till you come to the ound part, then prinkle upon it ome Atringent powder, and let the Skin forthwith be conolidated again; which if it be too looe, a little part of it may be taken away, which is very eldom neceary to be done, when it may be cloed enough in the time of the Cure.

6. If the Sutures of the Skull are too open, they bring a weaknes upon the Brain; if they are too traightly united, they caue the pain of the Head. Experienc'd Chirurgions affirm, that it is as afe to ue the Trepan in the very Sutures themelves, as any other part of the Head.

7. The Mucles of the Head occaioning nothing differing from other Mucles, except upon a Wound, or Contuion of the temperal Mucle, a Convulion eaily follows; neither ought it to be tranverly divided, let there happen a ditortion of the Mouth.

8. The Teeth, eeing they neither are furnihed with Membranes, nor Nerves, are altogether inenible; but they which attribute the pain to thoe Membranes which cover the Alveolus, it ought to be acribed to many Nerves that are ditributed through them; yet the Caues in this Cae are various, and mut be well ditinguihed, to wit, 1. a hot Ditemperature, 2. a cold ditemperature, 3. a harp humor, 4. a olution of continuity.

In a hot ditemper, Bleeding, and Purging is very neceary; apply Cupping-glaes to the Neck and Shoulders; let the Head be purged with Errhins: In the beginning, this Water being held in the Mouth, profits much.

Take the Roots of Tormentil an ounce; Leaves of Vervain, a handful and a half; Flowers of Balautians, two Pugils; Cypres Nuts, two drams; red-Saunders, three drams; Scales of Iron, one dram; Vitriol, two cruples; Roe-Vinegar, two ounces. Let them boil in a ufficient quantity of Red-wine, to a pint and half; keep it for your ue.
The Flux being tayed, we dicus the remaining with the following Decoction.

Take the Roots of Bitort, three drams; of Flower-de-luce, two drams; Leaves of Sage, Hyop, of each half a handful; Galls, a dram; Frankincene, Sandarach, of each two drams; Juniper-Berries, an ounce: Boil them in Red-Wine.

In a cold Ditemperature, the Patient mut avoid all cold potable Medicaments, yea the very Air it elf, thoe Medicines that purge Phlegm profit, Bleeding hurt. The following Medicine which is of great vertue may be held in the Mouth.

div.head: My Spirit for the Tooth-ach.
div.p:
Take havings of Guaiacum, four ounces; Seeds of Staveacre, Pomgranate-rinds, Galls, White-Frankincene, of each an ounce; Crude Opium, red flowers of Poppy, Camphore, White-Ginger, Cloves, Long-Pepper, of each half an ounce,
Leaves of Sage, Armart, Tobacco, Hore mint, of each one handful; Roots of Henbane, Pellitory of Spain, Mandrake, Hounds tongue, Nettles the les, of each an ounce and half: Let them infue fourteen days in a ufficient quantity of Spirit of Wine, then ditil it in Balneo Mariae.

A harp Humor falling upon the Teeth, is cured almot in the ame manner as a hot ditemperatur; but if thoe Remedies are not ufficient, the following Mixture is to be ued in a Spoon, which is not only of great virtue in this, but in all the other kinds of Tooth ach.

Take water of Plantane, an ounce and half; of Roes, Mint, of each an handful; Alexipharmick water, half an ounce; Cinamon-water, two drams; Julip of Roes, or Syrup of Red Poppies, an ounce; Laudanum Opiatum, three grains. Mix them.
In olution of continuity, and rottennes of the Teeth, it is bet to pull them out.

In the Breeding of Teeth in Children, the pain may be mitigated with freh-butter and Virgins-Honey, or with a Decoction of the Brains of a Hare or Coney in Ale; but in a long pain it is very convenient to cut the Gum, to give paage to the Tooth.

9. From the Blood and mixt Humors arieth the Ophthalmia, ometimes true, ometimes purious, ometimes eizing on one Tunicle of the Eye, ometimes on more; that which happens only in the great corner of the Eye, is call'd Aegylops; the white of the Eye may be vexed with little Bladders called Phlyctenae, which being broke, there follows an Ulceration, except tayed, corrupting the whole Eye.

But if this Ulcer eizeth only the Caruncle, & that the Punctum Lachrymale afterwards grows callous, it becomes a Fitula Lachrymalis. If thee Dieaes yield not to thee Remedies propoed in our Chirurgery, others are to be made ue of; Phlectenae are oon removed by the following Powder.
Take white Sugar-Candy, prepared Tutty, of each half an ounce; red Coral prepared, Camphore, white Vitriol, Saccharum Saturni, of each two cruples: Mix them, and make them into a Powder.
A beginning Ulcer of the Eye requires firt mundifying, afterwards conolidating Medicines.

div.head: A Mundifying Medicine.
div.p: Take Mirrhe, 15. grains; Aloes, ix grains;
Sugar-Candy, one dram; the yolk of an Egg, Goats-milk, three ounces: Mix them.

div.head: A Conolidating Medicament.
div.p: Take red Coral prepared, burnt Harts horn, Sarcocol of each a cruple; Dragons Blood, half a cruple; burnt-Lead, a cruple; Starch, half a dram; Crocus Metallorum, half a cruple; Gum Tragaganth diolved in Roe-water, a dram; Hore-tail-water, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Collyrium.

If the Punct√ºm Lachrymale, in the great Glandule of the Eye be callous, and from the continual Flux of Humors, degenerates into a Fitula, firt, the Calloity is to be removed, before the other accidents will ceae, for which the following are ued by us; the Phlegm and Spirit of Vitriol, burnt
Alom, blew Vitriol, Verdigreece, Mercury water, Aqua Fortis, Unguentum Aegyptiacum; but the bet of all is Unguentum Fucum of Felix Wurtz, boil'd to the conitence of a Suppoitory, and put into the Fitula.
The Calloity being taken away, the Ulcer may be cured by the following Medicine.

Take Roots of Flower-de-luce, round Birthwort, Bark of Frankincene, of each dram and half; Mirrhe, Matick, Sarcocols, Aloes, Cadmia Foilis, of each a dram; Honey, as much as is ufficient to make it into an Ointment.

If the Os Lachrymale, or Zygomaticum be foul, the Skin being divided, an actual or potential Cautery mut be applied, that the Caries may be removed, otherwie it is impoible to cure the Fitula, that not taken away.

10. The pain of the Ears proceeds from a cold or hot ditemperature, or from a olution of continuity, which oftentimes an Ulcer follows; for a cold ditemperature, and what accompanies it, the Wind, beides the common and particular Medicines, outwardly may be applied this with very good ucces.
Take Oyl of Rue, Henbane, of each half a dram; of ditilled Marjoram, half a cruple; Cator, ix grains; Eatern-Saffron, four grains: Mix them.

The Smoke of Tobacco blown through the bole of a Pipe put into the Ear, hath done good to many for the pain of the Ears, and for Deafnes; oftentimes alo a decoction of Cloves in Red Wine, hath profited, if two or three drops of it be intill'd warm into the Ear, and the Ear afterwards be topt with one of the boil'd Cloves.
Two drops of the following Spirit, Morning and Evening dropt into the Ear, is excellent.

div.head: My Spirit for the Ears.
div.p: Take Ants-Eggs, No 100, Cator, Pulp of Coloquintida, Marjoram, Savin, Wormwood, Rue, a handful; Seeds of Cummin, Anie, Fennel, Caraways, of each three drams; Bay-berry-husks pull'd off, Juniper-berries, of each half an once; Pomegranate-rinds, ix drams; Roots of black Hellebore, round Cyprus, Raddihes, Sow-bread, of each an ounce; middle-iz'd Onions, No vij. bitter Almonds, two ounces: Infue them 14 days in a ufficient quantity of rectified Spirit of Wine, then ditil them in Balneo Mariae.
In a hot ditemperature, firt we ought to divert the Flux of humors by Bleeding, Purging, Scarifications, Gliters, &c. then the following Medicines by Cotton inbibed, we may put into the Ear.
Take womans-Milk, two ounces; Whites of Eggs well beaten, half an ounce; Oriental Saffron, half a cruple; Gooe-greae diolved, two drams; Crude Opium, five grains: Mix them.
Or,
Take Oyl of Violets, weet Almonds, Roe-Vinegar, of each an ounce; Philonium Romanum, two drams; Eatern Saffron, half a cruple: boil them, and train them for your ue.
Or,

Take Roots of Marh-mallows, an ounce; leaves of Mallows, of Mandrake, of each one handful;
Heads of Poppy, No. ij. flowers of Dill, Camomile, of each two handfuls; Lineed, three drams; boil them in Cows-Milk for a Fomentation.
The Flux and pain being ceaed, what yet remains, may be dicued by thoe Remedies but now et down in a pain from a cold ditemperature.
Where the Inflamation Apotumates, which we undertand by a Feverih Pule, and by the continual increaing, we mut ait Nature by uppurating Medicines.
Take Unguentum Bailicon, two drams; Oyl of Lineed, three drams: Mix them.
Or,
Take Gooe greae, Oyl of weet Almonds, of white Lillies, of each two drams: Mix them.
Or,

Take Roots of white Lillies, an ounce and half; a large Onion roated in the Embers, and beaten together; add to them the Meal of Marh-mallows, half an ounce; Lineed, ix drams; freh-Butter, an ounce and half; Oyl of Camomile, & Lineed, of each half an ounce; Saffron, half a dram; Make it into a Poultice.

The Apotume being broke, the Ulcer is firt to be mundified; for which purpoe are convenient Honey of Roes, of Centaury, the juice of Smallage, Fennel, Bete, Onions, Leeks, Decoction of Agarick, Lupins, Urine, Lye, Oxes-gall, Unguentum Aegyptiacum.
Then mut be ued thoe Medicines that may dry and conolidate the Ulcer.

Take Roots of round Birthwort half a dram; of Flowerdeluce, a cruple; wah'd Cerue, prepared
Tutty, of each a dram; Mirrhe, Sarcocols, Litharge of Gold, of each two cruples; artificial Cinabar, half a dram; Scales of Iron, a cruple; Honey of Roes, as much as is ufficient: Make it into an Ointment.
Where Worms come in an Ulcer from an impure matter, the following are convenient to kill them.
The juice of Wormwood, Centaury, Armart, a decoction of Coloquintida, of white Hellebore, Ox-gall, Oyl of Wormwood, of bitter Almonds, &c.
Or,
Take Aloes, Mirrhe, of each two drams; Coloquintida, half a dram; tops of Wormwood, half a handful: Boil them in white Wine for an injection.

11. The Noe as well as the Ear is ubject to inflamation, which preently in the beginning we are forced to remedy by the Medicaments formerly mentioned in an inflamation, let otherways its Cartilages hould become carious, which may caue a great deformity.

Sometimes a Tumour call'd a Polypus, eizeth the inward Cavity of it, occaioned from impure and pituitous Blood; which is two-fold: for it either reembles a Tent or Pellet, and is call'd by the general name Sarcoma, or it preads it elf with many mall branches into the inward parts of the Mouth, or into the external parts of the Noe, & is in pecie call'd a Polypus; that which it of a whitih colour, not painful and oft, is eaily cur'd; but that more difficultly, which is very red; never that which is livid, black or tinking; being touched, it turns into a Cancer, and overpreads the whole Face.
The Cure of it is performed by Medicaments by a Thred, or by a Knife; in the beginning thoe Medicines that are dry and atringent are mot convenient.

Take Pomegranate-rinds, flowers of Balautians, of each a dram; Cadmia Foilis, two drams; Crude Antimony, Crocus Martis, of each half a dram; Matick, Mirrhe, Loadtone, Litharge, of each a dram: Make them into fine Powder.
Thee effecting nothing, Exedents are to be us'd.
Take burnt Alom, Bole-Armenick, Balautians, of each three drams: Make them into a Powder.
Another tronger.
Take Vitriol, half an ounce; Alom, Pomegranate-rinds, Galls, of each two drams; red Mirrhe, burnt Birthwort, of each a dram: Make them into a Powder.
Another yet tronger.
Take Vitriol, four ounces; Alom, Verdigreece, of each half an ounce; Vinegar, ix ounces: Calcine them in a luted Veel.
Another, very effectual.
Take red and yellow Arnick, Alom, Galls, of each half an ounce: Make them into fine Powder
I have een thoe Tumors totally eradicated by the water wherein Mercury ublimate is boiled.
But they eldom are cured by Medicine; for the mot part we ue here an Intrument decribed by S ‚Ä¢ nnertus and Aquapendens.

It may alo be drawn forth with a pair of Forceps;
they may alo be removed by a Thred (if it can be conveniently put about it) what remains may be cured by application of the Medicines but now mentioned.

12. The Mouth is inflamed upon many Caues; the chief are, 1. The heat of the Blood. 2. The acrimony and altnes of the Spittle. 3. A Rheum from the Head; generally there follows little Bliters, and an Ulceration, which not being carefully looked after, turns to a Gangrene, epecially in Children after the mall Pox and Meales; in this cae, beides the common Means, this is excellent.
Take Felix Wurtz his brown Ointment, two drams; Honey of Roes, an ounce and half; Spirit of Vitriol, half a cruple: Mix them.
13. Under the Tongue happens a Rannula or Baetrachios, a Tumor which is more frequently produced from Phlegm, than from any other part of the Blood; and it is often cured by this Powder.
Take Pepper, Ginger, of each a dram; Sal Gemmae, and common Salt, of each two cruples; wild Marjoram, Calamint, Orie-roots, Hermodactils, of each half a dram; Matick, a cruple: Make it into a Powder.

Strew it often upon the Tumor, which if it goes not away, open it in one or more places, that the moiture may come forth, and apply Honey of Roes to the Wound; ome in this cae ue an actual Cautery, but I rather approve of a Launcet.
14. For the Corruption of the Gums, this Powder is good.

Take Roots of Comfrey, Pomegranate-rinds,
of each a dram; Frankincene, Mirrhe, white Vitriol, of each half a dram; burnt Vitriol, a cruple: Make it into a Powder.
15. Epulis, a Tumor of the Gums mut be uddenly taken away by a Thred or Knife, let it hould turn into a Cancer.

16. For the taking off an ulcerated and rotten Uvula, Bartholine hath decribed an excellent Intrument in his Anatomical Obervations; but it may be conveniently enough cut off with a pair of Sciers, and the Bleeding may be topt with Cyprus Vitriol, Unguentum Aegyptiacum, or the like, is ufficient to perfect a Cure. Fabritius Hildanus judiciouly took it away by the help of a Thred, which is to be imitated by them who fear an Inciion.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the internal Parts of the Head.
div.p: NOw we approach Palas's Tower, which is ometimes empty, and ometimes fill'd with Folly; wherein, if an ill mind, be, as it were, a familiar Inhabitant, Virtue mut prudently look to it elf; but yet let it continue its Dominion, whilt its Enemy in the mean time lurking in ome corner, hall no where be at quiet.
Before we can enter into it, and look into the Brain, there are two Curtains to be drawn open, the Pia and Dura Mater.

The Dura Mater in the outide rougher than in the inide, encompaeth the Brain very looly, let
its Arbitrary Motion hould be hindred, dividing the ame by the help of certain foldings, which is call'd Falx, into the right and left part, and alo eparating it from the Cerebellum. In this Falx are always found four Cavities, ometimes even; in which many of the branches of the Carotide-Arteries are inerted, afterwards joining with the Jugular Veins.
Thee Cavities have the ue and ubtance of Veins, o that they may not unproperly be reckoned among the Veins.
The Pia Mater is more enible, & hath more Arteries than the Dura, which doth not only invet the whole Brains, but alo enters the winding every where; which, for this caue may more eaily be eparated.
We do divide the Brain into three Parts, which are, 1. The Brain it elf. 2. The Spinal Marrow. 3. The Cerebellum, or little Brain.

The Brain is of an Ahy colour, and of a ofter ubtance than Marrow (which is both whiter and olider) whence alo it was wont to be call'd Rind; it receives everal Branches from the Carotide-Artery, and is detitute both of Nerves and Sene.
It hath divers turnings and windings, which fold in deeply, epecially thoe in the fore-part of the Head, where the great Fiure divides the Brain outwardly even to the Marrow.
The Marrow is the Mother of all Nerves; within the Skull 'tis call'd the Marrow of the Brain; but without it is termed the Spinal Marrow.
The Cerebellum, or little Brain, is more of an Ah-colour than White, receives Arteries from the Cervicalis and Carotide; yet there are fewer branches here than in the Brain, as being much les.
