It hath no windings, but is made up as it were of everal thin plates lying one upon another.
Thee being thus conidered, the Anatomit takes off ome part of the Brain with a Knife, & forthwith the Corpus Calloum, and the Fornix joyning to it, come in view.
Under thee laterally lie two great Ventricles, in figure reembling a Hore-hoof, which the Septum Lucidum ditinguiheth into the right and left, or into the firt and econd.
In them is contained the Rete-Mirabile, or Plexus Choroides, coniting of many little Glandules, compoed from the branches of the temporal Artery, twited together in form of a Net.
In the fore-part thee Ventricles are united, and make a third.

In this third Ventricle are two Cavities; the firt of them runs to the Infundibulum, and to the Glandula Pituitaria, the other to the fourth Ventricle contained in the Cerebellum; above this Ventricle are oberved four round Bodies, which are call'd Tetes and Nates, to which joyns the Glandula Pinealis, which is fally call'd by ome the eat of the Soul Of late the famous Sylvius hath demontrated it not to reide in the Ventricles, but without them; by whom alo it is eteem'd but a Glandule: and that with more reaon, becaue that both he and I have found in it not eldom two or three Stones, but ometimes four, which we yet keep by us.

The Bodies being removed, eight pair of Nerves appear, which we have already treated of; on the fore-part of whom joyns the Rete Mirabile of Galen, which is a complication of the Cervical and Carotide-Arteries.
After thee, the Cerebellum comes in view, like a double Globe, in the midt of which is the Proceus vermiformis, and Pons Varolii, under it lies the fourth Ventricle.
Lat of all, the Spinal Marrow hews it elf, divided in its beginning into two Parts, not unlike a Writing-Pen, which decending down the Back, imparts its branches over the whole Body.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. In Wounds of the Dura Mater, two Symptoms render their Cure very troubleome, to wit, a Flux of Blood and extream Pain; if the Skill be not ufficiently open, without any delay the Trepan is to be applied on the Part affected, and forthwith the extravaated and grumous Blood being dicharged, let this Ointment be applied.
Take Manna of Frankincene, two drams; Aloes, one dram; Mirrhe, a dram and half; the oftet Hares hair, half a cruple; white of an Egg, as much as ufficieth to make it into a Liniment.
The Powder is alo very ueful, that is decribed in the Chapter of particular Wounds, in the econd Part of this Chirurgery.
To mitigate the pain, Oyl of Roes, Violets and Myrtles ued warm, as alo the warm Blood of a Hen or Pigeon, &c. is very much commended.
The Flux of Blood and the Pain being ceaed, the following Medicines are to be ued, which are not to be left off, unles the Matter begins to flow too plentifully.
Take Oyl of Turpentine, two ounces; Spirit of Wine, Syrup of Wormwood, of each an ounce: Mix them.
But if a Gangrene or Putrefaction hould happen, the following Liniment is of great ue.

Take Sarcocols, Mirrhe, Aloes, of each a dram: Syrup of Wormwood, Honey of Roes, of each two drams; Ung. Aegyptiacum, two drams and an half; Aq. vitae, an ounce and half; White-Wine, an ounce: Let them boil gently, then train them.
Neither do I apprehend any danger is to be feared in the taking off part of this Membrane when putrifi'd, o that you can come at it with a pair of Sciers, and that the Sinus or Pia Mater be not hurt.

2. When the Pia Mater is likewie affected, the Chirurgion mut abtain from all Oyls, although they be drying, let a Corruption of the oft Brain be caus'd: Drying Cephalick powders are very convenient to be ued here. But eeing that thee Wounds for the mot part are Mortal, I hall ay no more of them.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Neck.
div.p: THe Neck under the Scarf-skin, Skin, and flehy Membrane, and the common and proper Membrane of the Mucles, hath of each ide four Mucles.
Of thee, the Longus and Scalenus bend it.
Tranveralis and Spinatus draw it back of each ide.
It hath five Veins, Cervicalis, Mucula Superior and Inferior, Carotis, Interna and Externa.
And as many Arteries, Cervicalis, Mucula Superior & Inferior, Carotis Interna & Externa.
It hath Nerves from the Par Vagum, and the Spinal Marrow.
In the fore-part of it, are many Glandules, which are greater in Women than in Men.

Under thee the Larinx, the Organ of the ound lies, compoed of five Cartilages, which are,
1. Thyroides, or Buckler-like.
2. Crycoides, or Annular.
3. Arytenoides.
4. Glottis.
5. Epiglottis.

It is moved by ix pair of Mucles, which are,
1. Hyothyrodaei, the pair that lift up the Larinx.
2. Bronchii, the pair that pull it down.
3. Cricothiroidaei antici, the pair that dilate.
4. Cricothiroidaei laterales, puring it together.
5. Thyro-arythenoidaei, that open it.
6. Arythenoidaei, Sphincters that cloe it.
After thee, the Almonds or Parithima (by ome call'd Tonils) offer themelves; then the Pharynx, to which appertain even Mucles, by whoe aitance the Meat and Drink are wallowed.
1, 2, Sphenopharyngaei, which raie up the Pharinx.
3, 4. Cephalopharyngaei, moving it inward.
5, 6. Stylopharyngaei, dilating it.
7. Contrinctor or phynctor, which cloeth the Gullet.
The back-part of the Neck hath even Vertebra's, the procees of ome of which are perforated, to give paage to the Veels that carry the Blood into the Brain.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. We have already ufficiently treated of the Cure of Scrophulas or the Kings Evil; I will only give you here the Oyl of Langius, whoe Virtues are very excellent, not only in the Kings Evil, but alo in malignant and ordid Ulcers, if it be carefully ued.

Take Oyl of Philoophers or Brick, half a pound; Frankincene, Matick, Gum Arabick, Turpentine, of each three drams; pound them togather, & ditil them in an Alembick; then add to the ditillation Salt of Holm-Oak, two drams; and ditil it again, and reerve the ditillation in a Glas for ue.
In the room of the Salt of Holm-Oak, which grows not in Holland, Sal Gemmae may erve intead of it.

2. In a Hernia gutturis, or Bronchocele, eldom Medicaments effect any thing, when for the mot part the Caue of the Dieae (to wit, preternatural Phlegm mixt with Wind) is contained in a peculiar Bladder, and the Tumor lies under the Mucles, having its Original not from the Glandules, but from the Apera Arteria, or Wind-pipe; yet in the beginning, the following do good.

Take Roots of Ireos, Galangal, of each a dram and half; Penny-royal, Savory, Rupture-wort, of each a dram; Seeds of Fennel, Annie, of each a dram; Parly-eeds, half a dram; Long-Pepper, Spikenard, Nutmegs, Cinamon, of each two drams Mirrhe, half a dram; Burnt-Alom, half an ounce; White Sugar, three ounces: Make it into a fine Powder.
Let the Patient take of this Powder each Morning a dram and half in White Wine.

Take Gum Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Bdellium, diolved in Vinegar, of each an ounce; powder of Orrie-roots, two drams; Mutard and Nettle-eeds, of each a dram; Pulp of Coloquintida, Eatern Saffron, of each a cruple; Sal Gemmae, Alom, of each a dram; Naval-Pitch, ix drams; Roin of the Pine, an ounce: Make it into a Plaiter.

Thee Medicines effecting nothing, after this manner the Tumor may be taken away. Firt, Take up the Skin, and divide it long-ways; then it being eparate of each ide to the bottom, from the Tumor, take out the Bladder, whole if poible; for if any part of it be left behind, the little Artery which brings nourihment to the Tumor, mut be divided; let it increae a new. Then let the Part affected be wahed with Vinegar, wherein a little Salt and Nitre hath been diolved; for the Flux of Blood is not in this cae at all coniderable; Latly, Bring the Lips of the Wound together with a titching Plater, it being not neceary to ue a Needle here.
Of the Angina and luxation of the Vertebra's of the Neck, we have poken of in their places.

div.trailer: The End of the econd Book of the third Part.

div.head: The THIRD BOOK Of the Thorax or Breat.
CHAP. I. Of the External Parts of the Breat.
div.p: THe middle Region of the Body, whoe upper part is call'd the Shoulders, fore-part the Breat, hinder-part, the Back; under proper and common Teguments, hath proper and common Mucles.
The common are thoe of the lower Belly and Scapula's; thoe we have hewn already; thee are four.
1. Serratus Anticus minor, which brings the Scapula forward.
2. Trapeius, or Cucullaris, which moves it upward, and obliquely backward.
3. Romboides, which moves it obliquely downwards.
4. Levator.
The proper Mucles of the Thorax are twelve,
1. Subclavius or Extenor.
2. Serratus Anticus major, or the inferior raier up the Ribs.
3. Serratus poticus uperior, or the uperior rier up of the Ribs.
4. Serratus poticus inferior, or the depreor of the Ribs.
5. Sacrolumbus, which draws the Breat together.
6. Triangularis, which likewie draws the Breat together.
Under thee Mucles lie the Breats, in both Sexes abounding with quantity of Fat, and in the Female with many Glandules.
The Back and Loins (whoe Mucles in this place we are forced to decribe) have four pair of Mucles.
1. Quadratus, or the flexor of the Vertebra's.
2. Longiimus, or firt extender of the Vertebra's.
3. Sacrum, or the econd extender.
4. Semipinatum, or the raier up of the Back.
After the Muclers, follow the Collar-bones, the Shoulder-blades, the Breat-bone, the Ribs, and the Vertebra's; of the Veins, Arteries and Nerves we have formerly treated.
The Clavicles, or Collar-Bones, being pungy bones, are joyned to the upper proces of the Shoulder-blade, by trong Ligaments and movable Cartilages.
The Scapula or Shoulder-Blade is a broad and thin Bone, lying upon the outide of the Ribs, furnihed with two Ligaments, three procees, and five appendices.

The Sternum, or Breat Bone being ditinguihed in Infants, by even or eight lines, and by three or four in old people, is very pungy, and
hath in its lower part a Cartilage, call'd Cartilago eniformis or mucronata.

The Ribs in each Sex are twelve; the even uppermot, which are the true, are joyned with a double Tubercle to the Vertebra's, but with a Cartilage to the Sternum, are hard and round; the five lowermot, which are the Batard-Ribs, are leer, ofter and horter, having Cartilages about the Os Sternum, but not touching it.
Between thee Ribs on each ide, are Mucles found, which are call'd Intercotals, eleven within, and as many without; o that in all there are forty four, the Fibres here are placed cros-wie.
In the Cavity of each Rib, formed in the lower part of it, reides a Vein, Artery and Nerve, which extend themelves into the middle of the foreaid Mucles.
The Vertebra's of the Back are for the mot part accounted twelve, and have nothing coniderable.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: I omit here divers operations, having already treated largely enough of them before.

What now offers it elf, is a Fitula of the Breat, of a more difficult cure in that, than in any other part, by reaon of the continual motion of the Mucles; therefore 'tis highly neceary to ditinguih thee Fitula's; for the oblique do very hardly admit of any Cure: Thoe that perforate the Breat, are not eaily made whole again; thoe that have their rie from between the Pleura and the Mucles, the matter
falls down; whence it comes to pas, that afterwards it is difficultly dicharged; therefore in this cae there necearily is a hort breathing, and a lower motion of the Breat: The Callous is to be removed by the ame Remedies we have et down in the Chapter of Fitula's, and o ometimes the Pleura, and the fleh of the Mucles unite again; but if thee effect nothing, let the Chirurgeon put a little crooked Silver-pipe into the Fitula, o that the end of it may touch the bottom, through which let him pas a Needle fitted with Silk, anwering to the crookednes of the Pipe, which being done, let him with the Needle perforate the Skin, then the Needle being drawn through, let both ends of the Thred be tied together, and the Thred every day be anointed with ome Exedent Medicines, and the Calloity being taken away, let the Ulcer be skinned. The Intruments which are ued in this cae, are decribed in Tab. 38. Figure 5. of Scultetus, of the old Edition.

The Breats of Women often in thoe that give uck, from the great quantity of Milk, wax hard and painful, and by the Dutch is called Drop; which affect may be cured in one days pace, with compound Ointment of Marhmallows, the watry matter being uckt out by a Woman or Whelp: but this dicharge being neglected or delayed, every day the Breat grows harder and harder, nay, becomes enflamed; then Bleeding, Purging, Sweating is requiite: Outwardly this Cataplam may be applied.

Take meal of Marhmallows, of Fenugreek, of each an ounce; Flowers of Elders, Camomile,
of each an handful; red Roes, two pugils; Crums of coure Bread an ounce and half: Boil them in Ale, adding to them of Roe-Vinegar, an ounce. Make a Cataplam.
The Flux of Humors and Pain being ceaed, the remaining may be dicued by the following Cataplam.

Take Meal of Beans, of Lineed and Fenugreek-eed, of each an ounce; Cummin-eed, three drams; boil them in Wine, adding to it compound Ointment of Marhmallows, Oyl of Camomile, of each half an ounce: Make it into a Cataplam.
When it begins to apotumate, Maturatives are to be ued.

Take Leaves of Mallows, Marhmallows of each a handful; Powder of Lineed, an ounce; of Fenugreek-eed, an ounce and half; Leaven, half an ounce; boil them in Milk, adding to them nguentum Bailicon, an ounce; Saffron, a cruple: Make it into a Cataplam.

The Tumor being uppurated, mut be opened with a Cautick; or, what is better, with a Launcet, and put a Tent into it, dipt in common Balom of Brimtone until the end of the Cure; laying upon the Breat Emplatrum Diaulphuris Bulandi.

3. A Gibboity arieth from the pine of the Back, when the Vertebra's are removed outwardly, or of one ide, from their natural place; which is occaioned ometimes by an External Caue, ome by an Internal, epecially when ome pituitous Humor is collected about them; this Humor mut be taken away by dicuive Oyl; and Plaiters, before what is tarted out,
can by a Steel-compres, fitted to the Body of the Patient, be reduced: This reduction is not o much performed by the Compres, as it is by the Emollient quality of the Iron: For this reaon, it is neceary that the Patient, though cured, for a year or more after, ue another Bandage, that the oft Bones may not again tart out.
It is here likewie to be oberved, that in the middle of the Back, about the eventh Vertebra, with great ucces may an Iue be made, to intercept Rheums flowing to the Hip, Kidneys, Feet, &c.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Internal Parts of the Thorax.
div.p: THe Breat now comes to be opened, that we may view the Fountain of Life, which the Celetial Truth affirms to conit in the Blood; for what reaon is it therefore that the Sovereign Sanguification is not attributed to the Heart, where every where, and by all, it is call'd the Original of Life.

Within, the Breat is inveted by the Pleura, which is afterward doubled, and at length quadrupled, extending it elf from the Vertebra's to the Sternum, and then it is called Mediatinum, dividing the Lungs and Thorax.
Near to the Throat there adheres to the Mediatinum, a Glandulous Body call'd Thymus.

The Lungs drawing in the Air, & o cooling the Heart, is furnihed to this purpoe with a Trachea,
Apera Arteria, or Wind-pipe; this lies upon the Gullet, and conits of Cartilaginous Rings, and a double Membrane.
The outermot of thee Membranes which is the thinner, arieth from the Pleura; the innermot, which is the thicker, from the Dura Mater.
The annulary Cartilages are joyned together with Ligaments, and make not a perfect Circle, as being detitute of a fourth part that lies upon the Gullet.
The Wind-pipe ditributes Branches through the whole Lungs, which are trong enough, but not at all Cartaliginous.
The Lungs themelves covered with a thin, porous Tunicle, conit of a oft, red, pongy ubtance.
In the fore-part they adhere to the Sternum; in the back-part to the Vertebra's, filling the greatet part of the Breat.
It hath even leer Veels, of which we hall peak in their places.

The Heart, the Work-houe of the Blood, the Fountain and Origin of Life, as the Sacred Writ it elf alo witneeth, is included in a certain Cae, call'd by Anatomits, Pericardium: It conits of two Membranes, the outermot comes from the Mediatinum; the innermot from the Veels of the Heart; it contains a clear watry Liquor, void of all Acrimony, which we no longer doubt of to be brought from the Ductus's of the Limpha.
The Heart it elf conits of a flehy, erene and hard ubtance, which is inveted with a proper Tunicle, furnihed with Fibres of all orts, and like a Mucle is continually moved.
It is placed in the middle of the Breat, but the point of it inclines ometimes to the left ide.
In Figure it is like to a Pine-Apple, having in its upper part two Auricles or little Ears, which alwayes beat before the Heart it elf.

In old people, the right Auricle is bigger than the left, which in Infants is the contrary; in the throwing forth of the Blood, the Auricles, as well as the Heart it elf, are purt together, and dilated as often as they take in the Blood; and this Contriction and Dilation makes the Pule.
For the concoction, reception and throwing forth of the Blood, it hath two Cavities, and four Veels.

The Cavities are ditinguihed by a flehy Diviion, in which I could not yet find any way appointed for the motion of the Blood out of the right Ventricle into the left, although many Anatomits do certainly affirm it.

Thee Cavities are divided into the right and left; the right, which is the greater, receives the Vena Cava, and Arteria pulmonalis, or Vena Arterioa; the left, which is the leat, receives the Arteria aorta, or great Artery, and Vena pulmonalis, or Arteria venoa.
Of thee Veels, as alo of the Nerves, and Chylous paages, or the Thoracick lacteal Veins, we have treated of in the firt Book.
Under the Wind-pipe in the Cavity of the Breat, lies the Oeophagus or Gullet, reting upon the Vertebra's.

About the fifth Vertebra of the Back, it inclines a little to the right ide, that it may give way to the Arteria aorta, unto the eleventh
Vertebra; thence with a traight Ductus it paeth the Diaphragm into the lower Belly.
It conits of a double Membrane; the outermot is flehy, having treight and round Fibres, the innermot tranvere and oblique: Many add to thee a third from the Peritonaeum, and rightly in my opinion.

The Diaphragm, in nature of a Fan, erving to repiration, divides the Thorax from the Abdomen, and adheres to all the Batard-Ribs, to the Cartilage of the Breat-bone about the Vertebra's, ending two flehy Procees to the lower parts.
Its edges round about are flehy, variouly movable like a Mucle, but its Center Membranous and very enible.

It hath three perforations, 1. In the middle of it, through which the Vena Cava paeth. 2. In the left ide, through which the Gullet, with the adjacent Nerves. 3. About the Vertebra's, for the paage of the Arteria aorta, with the Vena azygos.

It receives more Nerves than any other part of the Body from the Collar-Bones to the Feet, which arie not only out of the Brain, from the Parvagum, but alo from the Spinal Marrow, and from the fifth and ixth Vertebra of the Neck. Of the other Veels we have already treated.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p:
The Pleura is not only ubject to Inflammation, upon which follows a Pleuriie, an Empiema, and Impotumation; but alo a certain pain, which a alt Humor produceth: This may
be ditinguihed from a Pleuriie, becaue here is a dry Cough, yet no Fever, alo free breathing enough. I have ued to remove this by Bleeding and Sweating, and if you fear a Pleuriie, apply outwardly this Plaiter.

Take Marrow out of an Oxes-bone, Ducks-greae, of each three ounces; the Muilage of Marhmallows, Lineed, Fenugreek-eed, of an ounce; Frankincene, Matick, of each half an ounce; Oyl of Nucita expret, two drams; yellow Wax, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.

2. Mediatinum, hath not o great a Cavity in Man, as in Dogs and other creatures; yet it happens ometimes that a purulent matter decends between the two Membranes of it, which can by means be evacuated by the Lungs; therefore we are forced to perforate the Sternum with a Trepan, that o through the made Orifice, by the ue of Tents, Spunges and other Intruments, the Matter may be dicharged.

3. In that kind of Quiney, which we above call Cynanche, where the Patient is almot uffocated, we remedy by Laringotomia, or opening the Wind-pipe; the Dieae it elf is far more dangerous than this Operation; therefore it would be well if it was oftener practied; nevertheles there is required a diligent conideration, that the other parts, to wit, the Lungs, Pleura, Gullet, &c. be not alo enflamed, or already full of matter, which may frutrate your labour, & afford caue of candal; but every thing being well weighed, the Operation is to be performed in this manner; Let the Head be a little bent backwards, that the Wind-pipe may
the more plainly appear, and the annulary Cartilages recede the further the one from the other; then divide the Skin according to the length of the Larinx unto the hollow, and let a tander-by with his Fingers pluck open the Skin of each ide, that the Chirurgeon may ee the two long Mucles, Sterno hyoidei, which he mut remove a little aunder either with a Knife of Wood or Bone; then the Larinx appearing, he mut make his Inciion with a Launcet, in the middle between the third and fourth annulary Cartilage, taking great care that he hurt not the Cartilages themelves; upon the Breaths coming forth, take out the Knife, and put a Silver Pipe into the Wound, which mut not be o long as to reach the hinder part of the Wind-pipe, let it caue a continual Cough; the danger of uffocation being over, which for the mot part happens to be about the third or fourth day, or at leat ought then to be, the Pipe mut be taken forth, and the Wound is to be cured in the ordinary manner according to Art, from which it differs not.

4. 'Tis no new thing for Worms to generate in the Pericardium, which, except kill'd, corrode the very Heart it elf. They may be detroyed with a Decoction of Scordium, Wormwood, Centaury, &c. drunk twice or thrice a day.
Concerning the Wounds of the Lungs, Heart and Diaphragm, ee our Chirurgery. A Wound of the Gullet is cured after the ame manner as that of the Stomach.

div.trailer: The End of the third Book of the third Part.

div.head: The FOURTH BOOK. Of the Lower Belly.
CHAP. I. Of the External Parts of this Belly.
div.p: THE lower Cavity, properly call'd the Belly, is divided into three parts; of which,
1. Is the Epigatrium, each ide of which is call'd Hypochondria.
2. The Region of the Navel whoe ides are call'd Ilium.
3. Hypogatrium, the ides of which are the Groins.
The lower hairy part is call'd Pubes.
The Abdomen under common Teguments, hath ten Mucles, of each ide five, very neceary for the excluion of the groer Excrements contained in the Guts; they are thee.
1. Obliquely decending, which in the upper part, the Navel; in the lower, in Man, the proces of the Peritonaeum; In Woman, the long Ligaments of the Womb perforates.
2. The Oblique acending.
3. The Recti, or traight.
4. The Pyramidal.
5. The Trarvere.
In the middle of the Abdomen, between the two traight Mucles, arieth the Linea Alba, or White-Line, from the meeting of the broad Tendons of the other thin Mucles, which is very enible.

Of the Veins, Arteries & Nerves, both of the outward and inward parts of the lower Belly, we have already treated of in the firt Book; as likewie omething of the Bones. But the more curious Examiner meets withal, firt, five Vertebra's of the Loins, which are very full of holes, and greater and thicker than all the ret.
Next to them follows the Os Sacrum, which is triangular; in old people being only of one Bone, but in young, coniting of five or ix.
To this is joyned the Os Coccygis, bent in Women more outward, in Men more inward.
On the ides of the Os Sacrum is the Os Innominatum, or Coxae, coniting of three Bones joyned together with a Cartilage. Of thee,
1. Is the Os Ilium, much thicker in Women than in Men.
2. Os Pudis, more eaily eparable in the fore-part in Women than in Men.
3. Os Ichion, or Coxae, furnihed with a large Cavity, which is call'd Acetabulum or Pixis, appointed to receive the head of the Thigh-Bone.

div.head: Chirurgical Conideration.
div.p:
The outward Diviion of the Lower Belly, plainly declares what Internal Parts may be affected: In the right Hypochondrium, the Liver is
ituated, extending it elf beyond the Batard-Ribs two fingers breadth, to the Sword-like Cartilage of the Sternum.

In the middle lies the Stomach, extending it elf to the ofter parts of this Belly, o that it reacheth four fingers breadth beyond the Batard-Ribs; Beyond the oft places near the Kidneys lies the Spleen.
In the middle of the mbilical Region, and about it lies the Small Gut, which being wounded, is mot dangerous.

In the right ide, about the Kidney, the Gut Colon takes its rie, tranverly running between the Stomach and Navel to the left Kidney, where winding downwards, and becoming narrower, is the frequent receptacle of Wind, and whence long pain and great tenion, which is undeervedly attributed to the Spleen on the other ide, the Intetine rets upon the Meentery, as doth the Stomach upon the Pancreas.
In the middle of the Hypogatrium, are the Bladder and Womb placed, and under them the Intetinum rectum.
On the Side lie the Spermatick Veels, and the Glandules, in which both benign and malignant Buboes are produced.

But all thee Parts cannot be wounded, except the Peritonaeum and Omentum be firt perforated, yet in many men the Omentum decends not below the Navel; and contrariwie in others, it reacheth to the Os Pubis it elf.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Internal Parts of the Abdomen.
div.p: THe firt of the Internal Parts is the Peritonaeum, comprehending all the others, before and behind, above and below.
It is a double Membrane; its rie is rather deduced from the membranous quality of the Soul, than from the Meninges of the Brain.
It is joyned to the Diaphragm, and to the firt and third Vertebra of the Loins.
It is thicker in Women from the Navel to the Privy Parts, and therefore tronger, terminating about the Os pubis.

In Men it is thicker from the Navel to the Diaphragm, and after it hath received the Spermatick Veels, as in a Sheath, it ends them through the outer Membrane to the Teticles, where it contitutes their firt Coat. Between the foldings of this Peritonaeum, lie four mbilical Veels.
1. The mbilical Vein.
2, 3. The two mbilical Arteries.
4. rachus, coming from the Navel, which is nothing ele but an indurated knot of the aforeaid Veels.

In Infants thee Veels are open, in old people altogether cloed, and turned into Ligaments: Yet I could never by any means oberve in Abortives of ix, even or eight months, the rachum pervious into the Bladder; for neither Probe nor Wind would pas.
The Umbilical Vein goes to the Liver, the rachus to the Bladder, both the Umbilical Arteries to the Iliack Branches of the great Artery.
The Omentum or Caul, keeping the Stomach and Intetines warm, is very fat and double; yet it conits of very thin Coats, which are perforated with many little holes.
It takes its rie from the Peritonaeum, under which it alo lies, for the mot part extending it elf as far as the Gut Colon, and ometimes as far as to the Os Pubis.

The Stomach, the Work-houe of the Chyle, is compoed of three Tunicles; the outwardmot is common from the Peritonaeum, the innermot from the Dura Meninx, the middlemot is proper to it elf; the firt is the thicket, the middlemot flehy, and the innermot wrinkled.
It hath Fibres of all orts, inwardly cruted over with pungy fleh.
It is ituated in the middle of the Hypogatrium reting upon the Vertebra's of the Loins; its left Orifice is called Os, or Stomachus; its right Orifice Pylorus.
The Guts are joyned to the Stomach, which convey the Chyle, and expel the Excrements; they are almot of the ame ubtance with the Stomach, and are all divided very well into the thick and thin.
The thin Guts are,
1. The Duodenum, in which the Veica Fellea, with the Ductus Coledochus, and the new Ductus Pancreaticus are inerted.
2. Jejunum, in which are more Lacteal Veins than in any of the ret.
3. Ileon, which is the longet of all.
The thick Guts are,
1. Coecum, with its worm-like appendix.
2. Colon, with two outward Ligaments, and one internal Valve.
3. Rectum, with the two Mucles, Ani levatores, and with one Sphincter all thee Guts are joyned together by the help of the Meentery, and alo to the Vertebra's of the Loins.

The Meentery conits of a double trong Membrane, with many Glandules between each Membrane, which are o very mall, that they can carce be perceived by the Eye; but commonly after a long icknes, three excepted, they hew themelves, and are greater than their natural contitution, long, white and hard.

The greatet of them is eated in the midt of the Meentery, which being pret, yields Milky juice, ometimes thicker, otherwhile thinner, which is nothing but Chyle, as likewie do the other two, which for the mot part are in the left ide, under the Emulgent Vein, above the Mucle Poas, not far from the Vertebra's of the Loins.

As thee Glandules receive many Lacteal Veins, o each of them again produceth a Branch, which forthwith being joyned together, make the Thoracick Lacteal Vein, which acending, as hath already been declared, carries the Chyle to the Heart.

The Pancreas or Sweet-bread, lies under the Stomach like a Pillow, joyned to the Gut Duodenum, into the which the late invented paage, from the Author, call'd Ductus Wyrungianus, penetrates; in this is often Choler found, but never Blood.
The Spleen, which perfects the Blood, contains an Acid humor, which it ends not to the Stomach by the Vaa brevia, but to the Liver by the Ramus Splenicus.
It conits of a rare ubtance, covered with a proper Tunicle, not proceeding from the Peritonaeum.
It is of a darkih red colour.

It joyns to the bottom of the Stomach by the means of the hort veels, and to the Batard Ribs, and left Kidney, to the Caul & Peritonaeum, and to the flehy part of the Diaphragm, by the aitance of Carnous Fibres.
There is no Bowel abounds with o many Arteries as the Spleen, except the Brain.
The Nerves, which it receives from our eventh pair, are ditributed through its Tunicle, rather than through its Parenchyma.
It is not placed in the fore, but back-part of the left ide, near the left Kedney, lying upon the Batard Ribs and Vertebra's, which is to be well oberved.
The Liver, the Intrument of Blood, Mother of the great Veins, is ituate in the right Hypocondrium, and covers a great part of the Stomach.
It is divided (as it were) into two parts, by the Umbilical Vein, which after-birth erves it for a Ligament.
It is a great, thick and hard Body, of a red colour.
It is fatened to the Diaphragm by two Ligaments from the Peritonaeum, and to the Mucles of the Abdomen by the Umbilicial Vein.
Some few Arteries it receives from Coeliaca, and erveral Nerves from the Spinal Marrow, and from our eventh pair.

In the right ide of it, underneath, is inerted the Veicula Fellis, or Gall, with the Porus Biliarius; the branches of both together with the branches of the Vena Porta, are comprehended in a certain common Bladder, call'd by Glion, Capula; thee branches of the Veica Fellis & Ductus Colydochus, or Biliarius, being detained in the Liver, are dipered through its whole Parenchyma, every where included in the above-named Capula, wch is red, about the thicknes of an Artery, taking its Original, as it appears, from the Peritionaeum.
The External Branches being joyned, perforate the Gut Duodenum, taking two little Arteries from the Coeliaca, and Veins from the Vena Porta, call'd Gemelle, together with the Bladder it elf.
The Kidneys, which depurate the Blood, conit of a peculiar hard fleh, inveted with a proper Tunicle,
Outwardly they are encompaed with Fat, and with a large, looe Coat from the Peritonaeum.
They lie upon the Mucles of the Loins (yet the left is higher than the right) within the folding of the Peritonaeum.

And above the Kidneys are two hollowed Glandules, called Renaes uccenturiati, or Capulae atribilariae; thee are furnihed with Branches from the Emulgent Veins and Arteries, and with Nerves from the Par vagum.
The Kidney being opened, appear the nine Carunculae pupillares, through which the Serum ditils into the Pelvis, to be carried through the Ureters into the Bladder.

The Ureters or the Urinary paage, whilt
within the Kidneys themelves, is very large, but when come from them, is very narrow; it is furnihed all along with two Coats, the innermot is proper, the outer common from the Peritonaeum.

Within the duplicature of the Peritonaeum, it decends downward upon the Mucles of the Loins to the Bladder, into whoe Neck it is inerted; then it acends upwards between the Membranes, where it perforates the innermot Coat; and through the ame hole, together with the Ureter of the other ide, enters the Bladder, which is o very little, & o traightly cloed, that there needs not here any Valve to hinder the return back again of the Urine.
Veicae rinaria, or Bladder conits likewie of two Membranes, the External is thick and flehy, the innermot not.
It is eated between the Duplicature of the Peritonaeum, in the Cavity of the Hypogatrium, which is commonly call'd Pelvis.
In Women it is joined before by its Neck to the Vagina uteri.

The Neck of the Bladder is very flehy, and by the aitance of the Fibra's, like a Sphincter it opens and cloeth the Bladder; in men it is longer, narrower, and more crooked; in Women, horter, wider, and traighter.
The Veels that bring Blood to the Bladder, are the branches of the Hypogatrick Veels; it receives many Nerves from the eventh pare, and from the Os Sacrum.
The Spermatick Veels yet remain, which wonderfully vary according to the diverity of the Sex.
In Men the Spermatick Veins and Arteries firt appear, of each ide one, which erve for the bringing of the Blood to the Teticles for its preparation.
The right Spermatick Vein comes from the decending Trunk of the Vena Cava, the left from the left Emulgent, and both the Arteries from the great Artery.

Thee four Veels being very crooked, and covered by the Ureters, pas to the Teticles; but before they come to them: near, and in the proces of the Peritonaeum, are united by everal inoculations, and joining themelves with the Nerves, make one Body, which is call'd Pampiniforme.
The Teticle, or Stones themelves, the Organs of Seed, have each a Mucle, call'd Cremater, they have two common Tunicles; and three proper.
The common are,
1. That wrinkled Pure which is call'd the Scrotum, to wit, the Skin which is thinner and ofter than in other parts.
2. Dartos, to wit, the Carnoa Membrana, which hath many Veels.
The proper are,
1. Elytroides, ariing from the proces of the Peritonaeum.
2. Erithroides, from the Mucle Cremater.
3. Albuginea, from the Spermatick Veels.
The ubtance of the Teticles is white, oft, thin, omething like to the Glandules.
Upon them with a tranvere ituation lies the Corpus vermiforme, which enibly becoming narrower, contitutes the Vas ejaculatorium, which is Epididymis, or Paratata.
Vas ejaculatorium, is white and hollow like to the Ureters, which carries the Seed about the neck of the Bladder into the Veiculae eminales, where it is kept till a convenient time.
Proceeding a little further, before, you hall find two great Glandules, in which, an Oily Liquor is contained, to mitigate the acrimony of the Urine, thee are called Protatae.
At lat comes the Penis or Yard, appointed for the evacuating of the Seed and Urine.
Its Subtance is peculiar to it elf, the like being not in the whole Body.
It hath no Scarf-skin, and is detitute of Fat, even in the mot fat Bodies.
It is covered with a looe Skin, which is double, and makes the Praeputium, and covers the Glans, to which it is tied by means of the Froenum or Bridle.
Under the Skin and flehy Membrane, lie the Veels above decribed.
Near to thee are the four Mucles, which are the two Erectores, and the two Ejaculatores; under the Mucles, are two Nervous Bodies, which make the greatet part of the Yard.
By their fungounes, rendring it either tiff or flacid. In the lowet part of the Penis appears,
The rethra, or paage for the Urine, coniting of two Coats, the innermot is very thin and enible, the outermot thick and flehy.

In Women, the Spermatick parts in this, differ from Mens, that they are horter and les, and by a wreathing and winding approach the Teticles; likewie they communicate everal Branches to the Uterine Tubes, and to the Womb it elf.
The ofter Stones are placed on the ides of the Womb, qualified to elaborate the Seed; they are covered with only one Coat, and that is proper.
They have no Paratats. The Teticles inwardly are full of little Bladders, which both contain the Seed, and by means of the Tubes conveigh it to the Womb.
Thee Tubes joyn to the Womb of each ide, and to the Teticles but only of one ide.
Thee have a Cavity coniting of a double coat, which alo contains ome little Bladders, in which many will have the Seed to be further perfected.
The Womb, the receptacle both of the Seed and Child, is ituate in the middle of the Hypogatrium, call'd Pelvis, between the traight Gut and the Bladder.
It hath two trong and thick Coats the firt, which comes from the Peritonaeum, the other is proper, and between both many flehy Fibres.
It is conveniently divided into the Fundus or Botton, the Orifice and the Neck.

The Fundus, the Globous part of the Womb, hath four Ligaments; the two uppermot are broad and membranous. which are joyned to the Os Ilium, the two lowermot are red and round, and pervious to the Clitoris, thence like a Gooe-foot, detitute altogether of their hollownes, they pread themelves upon the forepart of the Thigh.

The Oriice of the Womb, which at one time can very traightly cloe it elf together, yet at another is very dilatable, hath in its lower
part a Tubercle or knotty ubtance, as alo many little holes.

The Cervix or Neck of the Womb, appointed to receive the Penis, is very much wrinkled within, and almot eight inches long. To the Diector comes firt in view the Meatus rinarius, or the paage for the Urine, which is hort and traight, then in this Cavity is the Clitoris eated, which is omething in oftnes or hardnes reembling to a Mans Yard.

To this joyns the Hymen, perforated in the midt for the paage of the Urine and Coures, to which joyn four Caruncles, call'd Myrtiformes; then follows the Alae, Nymphae or wings which defend it, and the hairy Lips.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. The Coats of the Peritonaeum grow very thick in Hydropick perons, nay in proces of time they acquire a Cartilaginous hardnes, which is very neceary to be known; in a Paracentheis or opening of the Abdomen, there oftentimes uddenly follows a watry welling in the Cod.

After a Paracentheis made by the formerly decribed Intrument; the reaon of it and the paage are true, that the Water by little and little inks down above the proces of the Peritonaeum, in the pace between the Peritonaeum and the right Mucles of the Abdomen.

2. Sometimes between the fouldings of the Caul is Wind detained, the caue of long continued pain, which brings along with it fear alo of a future abces. In this cae, beides
Sudorificks, we ue dicuing Oyls and Plaiters. In the ame folding is Water alo ometimes included, which promieth no certain hope of Cure.
Steatoma's and other Abcees are often generated in the Caul, by reaon of its great quantity of Fat, and its many Glandules, which are very difficultly cured.

3. The Guts, which move themelves variouly like to Worms, ometimes they fall inwardly into one another, epecially when afflicted with great pain; in this cae the Excrements cannot pas to the Fundament: this Malady is call'd Mierere mei, or the Iliack Paion; ordinary means effecting nothing, a great Cupping-glas without Scarification, is often to be applied to the Part affected, and taken off again; but whether it is not better to divide the Mucles of the Abdomen and the Peritonaeum, and draw out with the Fingers the fallen-in Gut, than to uffer the Patient inevitably to die.

4. The Meentery, from it elf, and alo from the great number of the Glandules is ubject to Inflammation, Tumors, lcers, and to Corruption. Thee Dieaes, eeing they are very difficultly ditinguihed from others, require an experienced Phyitian; we llkewie peak the ame of the Sweet-bread, and of the Spleen: Yet in the mean time, I will communicate to you this Plaiter, whoe virtues I have often experienced in the Cure of the Tumor of the aid Parts.

Take Gum Caranna, Ammoniacum, of each a dram; Quickilver kill'd with Turpentine,
half an ounce: Make it into a Plaiter.

5. The Ligaments of the Liver, which joyns it to the Diaphragm, and to the Sword-like Cartilage, are often o much relaxt, that the Liver decends to the Region of the Navel; this we remedy with this Plaiter.
Take Roots of Bitort, three ounces; Bole-Armenick, two drams; Cummin-eeds, a dram; Gum Galbanum, an ounce; Ol. Nucitae expret, a dram: Make it according to Art into a Plaiter.
Moreover the Liver is not freed from Inflammations, lcers, nay not from Gangrene it elf.
6. The Gall may be broke from an extream Cough; a Stone alo, nay ometimes many, are generated in it.
I was lat year with a certain Scot, who in the pace of four weeks voided two hundred Stones and more by Stool, and was cured only by the ue of the following purging Conerve.
Take Electuary of the juyce of Roes, an ounce; Powder of Jalop, a dram; Spirit of Salt, a cruple: Make it into a Conerve. Let him take each day or each other day the quantity of a Nutmeg.
7. For Wounds and lcers of the Kidneys, our Chirurgery furniheth you with ufficient Medicines.

The reters are alo ubject to Exulcerations, but are cured by the ame means, which are proper in lcers of the Kidneys: If they are broke either by a great Stone, or other Caue, the Dieae is accounted incurable.

8. Beides Stones, Worms alo are generated in the Bladder, which may be expelled by Diureticks
mixt with thoe things that kill Worms.

Take Aqua Antinephritica, an ounce; Water of gras, two ounces; Spirit of Salt, ix drops; Corallin, a cruple; Syrup of Wormwood, an ounce; Mix them. Let the Patient take one half in the Morning, the other in the Evening.
This injection alo is covenient, it bringing them forth in a hort time.
Take Holy-Thitle-water, ix ounces; Mirrhe, Aloes diolved in Spirit of Wine, of each a cruple; Honey of Centaury, half an ounce: Mix them.
9. The Teticles may as well as the other parts be inflamed; where, beides the general means, thee outwardly are convenient: In the beginning let this Cataplam be applied.

Take Powder of Red-Roes, Myrtles, Balautians, of each two drams; Barley-Meal, two ounces and an half; Oyl of Roes, Elder-Vinegar, of each an ounce; Red Wine, as much as is ufficient to make it into a Poultice.

div.head: In a vehement pain.
div.p: Take Meal of Linced, Barley and Fenugreek, of each an ounce; Leaves of Henbane, a handful; Mallows, half a handful; Hogs-greae, an ounce; Oyl of Poppy-eeds, an ounce and half; Milk, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Cataplam.

If after the Inflammation an Ulcer follows, let the Chirurgeon ait Nature with Suppuratives; the following Plaiter is excellent to mollifie, eae pain, and to uppurate, which is
alo very good in any other Tumor.

div.head: Emplatrum Filii Zachariae.
div.p: Take Yellow-wax, Oxes-marrow, Hens and Ducks-greae, of each a pound; the Muilage of Lineed, Marhmallows, Fenugreek, of each four ounces; Oyl of Lineed, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.

The matter being come to uppuration, mut be dicharged, which the Chirurgeon may do with a Launcet; for I cannot commend to him here a potential Cautery, from which I have oberved very ill ucces: Let the Orifice be little, and penetrate only the Tunicles, For in this cae although the matter be good, nevertheles the dieae is dangerous, and eaily degenerates into a Cancer or Gangrene, which cannot be taken away more conveniently than with a Knife, and mut be done at the firt appearance of it; then let the Chirurgeon endeavour to cure the Ulcer as oon as poible, after the following manner; let the Part be defended from all cold, and continually corroborated by Medicines, that the natural heat may be preerved in it: This Lotion ued warm, is good.
Take Flowers of Balautians, Red-roes, Myrtles, of each two pugils; Aloes, a dram; Franckincene, two cruples; Plantane-water, three ounces; Red-wine, as much as ufficeth: Boil them, and train them.
This being ued, apply the following Ointment, putting over it a Plaiter or Cataplam moderately dicuing.

Take prepared Tutty, Cerue waht, of each two drams; Red-lead, Litharge of Gold, of each a dram; Sarcocols, three drams; Burnt-lead, two drams; nguentum Apotolorum, half an ounce; Oyl and Wax, as much as ufficeth to make it into an Ointment.
10. If the Yard be wounded, for the mot part it is mortal: This Ointment is very excellent.

Take waht Cerue, three drams; Mirrhe, Litharge, of each a dram and half; Sarcocols, prepared Tutty, of each a dram; Tragaganth, two drams; Oyl of Roes, as much as ufficeth to make it into an Ointment.

An Inflammation of it is cured in the ame manner as an inflammation of other enible parts; but if an External lcer hould happen, the Cure mut be performed both by Internal and External Medicines, let it contracts a Malignity, and degenerates into a Sphacelus.

Take Litharge, half an ounce; Burnt-lead, three drams; prepared Tutty, two drams; Aloes, a dram and half; Pine-bark dried, four cruples; Lapis Haematitis, a dram; Seeds of Dill burnt, of Gourds burnt, of each two cruples; Oyl of Roes, Quickilver, of each three drams; Wax, as much as ufficeth to make an Ointment.
But if it yields not to this by reaon of its foulnes,
Take Verdigreece, half a dram; Water of Plantane and Roes, of each two ounces; White-wine, four ounces; Spirit of Wine, an ounce: Mix them, and boil them a little.
To this may be added, Mercury precipitate, if there be occaion.
A Sphacelus in this cae, hath no certainer cure than extirpation in part, or wholly, let the michief creep inwardly, and kills the Patient.
How the Internal lcers of the Yard ought to be cured, we have et down in the Chapter of particular lcers: But in this we may decribe this Medicine, by the ue of which a Cancerous Yard was cured.

div.head: An nguent of Peter Baierus.
div.p: Take the juice of the tops of Bramble, Stalks of Roes, Vinegar, of each two ounces Franckincene, Matick, of each three drams; Litharge of Gold, an ounce; Sack, four ounces; Juice of Houleek, three ounces; Aqua vitae, four ounces: Verdigreece, two ounces and half; Vitriol, Burnt-alom, of each a dram and half; Camphire, a dram; Oyl of Roes, four ounces: Powder thoe things that are to be powdred, very fine, and being earched, let them boil all together upon a gentle fire, except the Camphire, which is to be put in at the end, to the conumption of the Juices, then add the Wax, and make it into an Ointment.
11. The Spermatick Veels ometimes in Women, are o greatly obtructed, that together with the Teticles in the ide of Hypogatrium, they well to the bignes of ones Fit.

12. In the Tubes of the Womb, the Womans Seed is ometimes corrupted, from which arie grievous Symptoms; the Coures being for ome Months obtructed, oftentimes there
follows a Dropie; the Water here collected, we have oberved in dead Bodies that have been opened, to flow directly through the Tubes into the Duplicature of the Peritonaeum.

13. The Womb, from the preternatural afflux of Blood, is often inflamed, epecially in lying-in Women, and in thoe whoe Coures flow diorderly, this Inflammation oftentimes is changed into an Abces, if negligently handled; whoe Cure belongs to the Phyitian: But a Sphacelus is incurable. For what the Ancients relate concerning the extirpation of the Womb, to wit, that it may all be taken off without any great danger, is to be reckoned amongt their other Errors; but whether this Animal in living Creatures, this neceary part, joyning to o many other parts, and furnihed with uch abundance of Arteries, may be cut out without danger of Life? The ame thing I believe hath hapned to them in this cae, as hath hapned in the decribing and curing the falling down of the Womb, who here and there have taken the extended Tunicles of the Vagina teri for the Womb it elf; for I eaily grant thee Tunicles may without any great danger be taken away: But I truly eteem a Sphacelus of the whole Womb to caue certain death.

14. The Neck of the Womb is ubject to Haemorrhoids in the ame manner as the traight Gut is; thee flowing, may be ditinguihed from the Coures by thee following igns; in the flowing of the Coures, we can oberve no Branches of the Veels in the Neck of the Womb, they come out of the Womb it
elf, and they caue no pain, except in the Hypogatrium; thee Veels by which the Evacuation is made, are the Hypogatrick and Spermatick Arteries; but the Haemorrhoids are the Branches of Vena pudenda, they may be known both by the ight and feeling, and there is no pain but in the privy part it elf: They ought to be treated in the ame manner as the other Haemorrhoids are; to eae pain, this Ointment is excellent.
Take Muilages of the Seed of Quinces, Marhmallows, of each half an ounce; Saffron, Oyl of Roes, Hens-greae, of each a dram; the Yolk of an Egg Make it into an Ointment.
This Mixture is excellent.
Take Litharge of Gold, waht Oerue, burnt-Lead, of each a cruple; Purlane-water, five ounces: Mix them.
Let the Haemorrhoids be waht with it, and let a Linnen Cloth dipt in it be applied to the Part affected.

div.trailer: The End of the fourth Book of the third Part.

div.head: The FIFTH BOOK. Of the Joynts.
CHAP. I. Of the Hand.
div.p: UNder the name of the Hand, we comprehend alo the Arm, whoe Teguments, both proper and common, as alo its Veels, are already ufficiently decribed.
It is commonly divided into three parts.
The Shoulder, or upper part of the Arm, conits of one Bone, and nine Mucles.
The Mucles are,
1, 2. Deltoides, and Supra pinatus, which two raie it upward.
3, 4. Anicalptor, Latiimus, and Rotundus major, which two pull it downward.
5, 6. Pectoralis & Perforatus, or Coracoidaeus, which two draw it forward.

7, 8, 9. Infra-pinatus, Rotundus minor, and
Immerus, or Subcapularis; which three move it backward.
By thee three lat moving together, the Arm is as it were turned about, and obliquely outwardly raied up.

The Bone is great and long, its Head or upper extremity is inveted with a Cartilage, Membranous Ligament, and four Tendons, and furnihed with a particular Cavity, in which the Tendon of the Mucle Triceps lies.
The Lower Extremity is like unto a Pulley, which permits the Cubit to be bent very much inwardly, but not to extend beyond the right Line.
The Cubit conits of two Bones, which are by proper Mucles properly moved, which although out of order, we are forced to et down in this place.
The Lower Bone, which is greater and longer than the other, is call'd lnae; in its upper extremity are two triangular procees oberved, which are call'd Rotra or Glandes.
The Lower Extremity ends with a round Knob, to which is joyned a harp Proces, which is call'd Styloides.
It is moved by four Mucles, of which two are Flexors.
Two Extenors.

The upper Bone, which is les and horter, is call'd Radius, or the leer Focil, it is received in the upper part by the lna, in the lower part
it receives the lna, in the middle they are a little ditant from one another, which pace is yet fill'd with a thin Ligament.
It is alo moved by four Mucles, whereof two are Pronatores, or pullers down.
The other two are Supinatores, or raiers up.
Some add to thee two other Mucles, but they are very eldom found, and diverly decribed.
The Hand is divided into three parts, the Carpus, or Writ, the Metacarpus, or the ditance between the Writ and Fingers; and the Fingers themelves.
The Carpus hath four Mucles.
Two Flexors, the Cubitaeus, and the Radiaeus internus.
Two Extenors, the Cubitaeus, and Radiaeus externus.
Under thee lie eight little Bones, as yet without name, which are in the firt years Cartilaginous and oft, but afterwards become harder; they are tied and joyned together with trong Ligaments.
The Metacarpus hath two Mucles, call'd Palmares, longus & brevis.
And four Bones fatened to the Carpus by the aitance of the Cartilaginous Ligaments.
The Fingers conit of fifteen Bones, which as yet have no certain names given them, and fourteen Mucles; whereof,
Two are Flexors, ublimis & profundus.
Two Extenors.
Four Adductors, Lumbricales.
Six Abductors, or Interoei. Three are External, and as many Internal.
Beides thee, the Thumb and Little Finger have a particular Flexor and Extenor.
Thee are beides to be conidered in the Hand,
1. The Armilla Membranoa, which is a round Ligament, comprehending the many Tendons of the Hand, as it was in a Circle, eaily diviible into many others.
2. Vagina Membranoa, which hold in the Tendons contained in the Hand.
3. Fiura oblonga, framed in each Tendon, for the paage of the Tendons of the Mucles moving the third Joynt; this erves in nature of a Pully.
4. Oa Seamoidea.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: 1. The Shoulder oftentimes is broken or put out of joynt, but is oftner afflicted with a Cathar and Gout. In a cold Gout, I never found any thing more efficacious than the Stiptick Plaiter of Crollius, mixt with Oyl of Bricks or Philoophers; as alo the following Plaiter.

Take Naval-Pitch, Colophony, of each three ounces; Muilages, of Marhmallow-roots, two ounces and an half; Ammoniacum, Galbanum, Matick, Mirrhe, Frankincene, of each an ounce and half; Propoleos, Miletoe of the Oak, round Birthwort, burnt Bras, yellow-Wax, Turpentine, of each three ounces;
Oyl of Earth, two ounces; Make it into a Plaiter according to Art.
In a hot Cathar, or the like Gout, I have always found this Fomentation of ingular ue.

Take Vitriol, white and green, of each half an ounce; prepared Nitre, ix drams; Crude Alom, one dram; Mirrhe, two drams: Opium, a dram; White-Wine, half a pint; rectified Spirit of Wine ten drams: Elder-Vinegar, three ounces: Mix them for a Fomentation.
Under the Arm-pits, Veneral Buboes appear as well as in the Groins.

2. Often tough Phlegm eizeth upon the Joynt of the Shoulder and Elbow, from whence comes a tiffnes. I have learnt by experience to eteem much in this cae of Balom of Peru, as alo of the following Ointment.

Take Fox-greae, and Rams-greae, Freh-Butter, of each two ounces; Oyl of Earthworms, an ounce; rectified Spirit of Wine, four ounces; boil them to the conumption of the Spirit of wine, then add Oyl of Roemary, of Amber, of each three drams; of Tiles, or of the Philoophers, two drams: Mix them, and make it into an Ointment.
One or more of the little Bones of the Carpus oftentimes are dilocated, which, if not preently reduced, becomes an incurable evil.
A Ganglion is here very frequent, beides the Cathar and Gout, whoe cure we have but jut now taught.

4. In the Metacarpus and Fingers, both above and below meet many Tendons, which are eaily injured in Wounds and Ulcers, which is carefully to be oberved, let a Palie follow:
In which no other Medicines are needful, than what we have already in the foregoing declared: But thee are chiefly to be conidered of; 1. That the Bandage is not to be bound too hard. 2. You mut not put in the Probe too deep, nor too often. 3. The Hand and Fingers are to be placed upright, not depending. 4. Thee Parts are eaily affected with a Sphacelus, which thee igns certainly denounce: When there is no matter in due time; the Lips in the beginning are dry, or yield a little thin moiture; the heat, pulation, and rednes is greater here, than in the flehy parts; afterwards the Lips are turned in, and become livid, and at length black. In this cae, all thoe Medicines are to be applied that may put a top to the Gangrene, and as formerly we have et down.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Foot.
div.p: THe Foot is alo divided into three parts, to wit, into the Thigh Leg, and Lower Foot.
The Thigh hath but one Bone, to whoe motion erves fourteen Mucles.
Two Flexors, Poas and Illiacus.
Three Extenors, Glutaeus Major, Medius and Minimus.
Three Adductors, Triceps.
Six Abductors, Quadragemini & obturatoris duo.
The Abductors and Adductores working together, rowl about the Thigh.
The Thigh-Bone is the greatet of all the Bones of the Body, outwardly it buncheth forth, and is a little bended inwardly, and o decends internally oblique to the Knee.
It hath three Procees, eaily eparable in Infants.

The Leg conits of two Bones; the greater of which, is in the inide, and is called Tibia, or the greater focile; the leer, which is in the outide, is call'd Fibula, or the leer Focile; both very much reembling the Bones of the Cubit; they are a little ditant one from the other, but are tied together by a Ligament.
It is moved by eleven Mucles, which are,
Four Extenors, Rectus, Crureus, Vati duo.
Four Flexors, Biceps, Semimembranous, Seminervous, Gracilis.
Two Adductors, Longus and Poplitous.
One Abductor, Facialis.
Between the Thigh and Leg lies the Patella or Knee-pan, in Infants Cartilaginous, in old people, hard and trong, placed on the outide of the Joynt.
The Foot is divided into three parts, the Tarus, Metatarus, and Toes.
The Tarus is moved by ix Mucles, viz.
Two Flevors, Tibiaeus anticus & Peronaeus.
Four Extenors, Biceps, two Gemelli, and Sole ‚Ä¢ s, to which many add a fifth, Tibeaeus poticus.

Three of thee Extenors from one very trong Tendon, which is called Cordia Hipocra
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a.

It is made up of even Bones, which are,
1. Talus, or Atragalus.
2. Calx, or Os Calcis,
3. Os Naviculare, or Cimbiforme.
4. Os Teerae, or Cuboides.
5, 6, 7. Oa tria Cuneiformia, or Shpaenoidea.
The Metatarus conits of five Bones.
The Toes have fourteen Bones; for the great Toe hath but two Joynts.
The Matacarpus hath no Mucles, except Plantaris, which is not unlike Palmaris.
The Mucles of the Toes are eventeen, to wit,
Two Flexors.
One Extenor of the four Toes, for which ue 'tis furnihed with a fourfold Tendon.
Four Adductors or Lumbricales.
Ten Abductors, or Interoei.
To the great Toe are peculiar,
One Flexor.
One Extenor.
Two Adductors.
One Abductor.

Here alo, as in the Hand, are oberved the Oa eamoidea, which are always placed between the full grown Joynts, partly that they may corroborate the Joynts, partly that they may defend the tender Joynts; in old people they are alwayes numbred from ten to twenty, never in Children.

div.head: Chirurgical Coniderations.
div.p: The Foot in its natural contitution, as alo in its Dieaes, hath many things agreeing with the Hand, therefore it would be uperfluous to repeat them over again.

1. Coniderable here is the Sciatick pain, caued from a harp Humor gathered in the Joynt, where the Thigh-bone joyns with the Os Ichium; when the Ligament tying thee Bones together, is from uch an Humor relaxed, the Bone recedes from the natural places, and brings upon that part a lamenes: If the Bone or Cartilage be corroded, and the Veels compret, there follows an Atrophy of the Legs, and ometimes of the whole Body.

2. Tumors in the Knee, are very dangerous and hard of Cure, by reaon of the firmnes of Mucles, the great number of Ligaments, Tendons, and Bones, and the cold and dry nature of the parts, not being of force ufficient to diipate the moiture; therefore 'tis mot neceary to ait it with warm Medicines as oon as poible; and if any igns of Suppuration appear, forthwith let it be opened, let otherwie the Patient becomes lame, the Part wates, and at lat happens death it elf. Upon the opening of the Abces, for the mot part there follows a gleet of ome Humor, which renders the Cure very difficult: For this I commend the often praied Retorative Powder.
3. A great Tendon is inerted in the Calcaneus, or Bone of the Heel, which being wounded, or much contued, brings Convulions, and death it elf.

About this place comes Kibes, whoe caue is intene cold or heat with drines: Here firt are oberved Fiures in the Skin, then follows an Ulceration: All fat things and Plaiters profit here, epecially the following.

Take Powder of Galls, of round Birthwort, of each half a dram, red Lead, a dram; Mercury ublimate, ix grains; Litharge, Mirrhe, of each a dram and half; Camphire, a cruple; Franckincene, two drams; green Wax, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.
In the room of green Wax, you may take the Fat of Deer, or of Rams.
4. The Fingers or Toes being frozen, mut be rubb'd with Snow, or with a bruied frozen Turnep; then this following Plaiter is much commended.
Take Hogs-greae; freh Oyl of Olives, of each an ounce; white Wax, two ounces: boil them a little, and make a Plaiter.

5. Iues are often made in the Joynts; we have formerly declared the place: In the Arms, between the Mucle Deltois and Biceps; in the Thigh two fingers breadth above the Knee in the inide; in the Leg, the uppermot, two fingers breadth below the Knee; the lowermot, two fingers or three above the Ankle. That you may make thee Iues without pain, intead of a Concluion, take this Cautick, which works without pain; which is alo very much to be commended in ordid and cancerous Ulcers, and in Excrecencies.

Take Crude Brimtone, white Arnick, Crude Antimony, of each two ounces; the Brimtone being melted by a gentle fire, and
tirred about with a Spatula, add the Arnick and Antimony powdred, and mix them whilt they are incorporated with the Brimtone, and look red. Afterwards,
Take of this Mixture, an ounce; Caput mortuum, of Vitriol, half an ounce: Mix them, and make a Powder; let it be waht ix times in Spirit of wine, and dried for your ue.

THE Plague is a Dieae whoe nature is not to be comprehended by us; the Caue thereof eems to proceed from a Spirituous and Infectious Vapour, which is powerful enough to make a udden diolution of the conitence of the Blood, by which means the Heart is deprived both of trength and life.

I do aert that the Nature of it is not to be comprehended by us, as well becaue it is a Punihment inflicted on us by the immediate hand of Almighty God, who vouchafes not that his Incomprehenible Widom and Eence (which is ometimes faintly decribed to us) hould be narrowly pryed into by his creatures; as alo that it is in it elf o mutable, that if we hould eriouly recollect our elves, and recount the everal Petilences wherewith all former Ages have been viited; we hall not thereby be able to intance in two of that whole number which have agreed with each other in all circumtances: From whence we may eaily infer, that in
the Cure of this Dieae, an Experienced Phyician may much more afely follow the Dictates of his own Reaon, than adhire trictly to the Method & Precriptions of others. For although it doth ometimes by the more remarkable ymptoms ufficiently evidence it elf, yet we cannot likely dicover its Nature and Eence, although we hould the mot indutriouly attempt it.

But that we may cautiouly enquire into it, we mut know that it is ometimes not accompanied by any Fever: And it is neceary that what Phyician oever is ignorant of this hould either by peruing good Authors, or his own Experience, acquaint himelf throughly with it. I have been ent for to everal Patients my elf, who although they appeared otherwie in good health, not refuing their meat, nor diturb'd in their leep, have nevertheles had Buboes ariing in their Groin, on their Neck, under their Armpits, or behind their Ears, which have apparently dicovered a greater Malignity than could be dicerned in thoe Buboes, which in other perons have been attended by a violent Fever: And many hereupon who have been incredulous, and lightly regarded the cautions which I have given them upon this account, have with great danger to themelves experimented, that as oon as thoe Buboes have unk down, the Petilential Symptoms which have appear'd, have been very dreadful, and much more dangerous than in thoe that have carefully ued the means precribed to them, who have been alo much more eaily and peedily cured than the other.
Sometimes the Plague is accompanied with a Fever; and again, there are ome Petilent Fevers without the Plague.

To ditinguih this Fever from the Plague, I ued to oberve, that they that are eized with it, complain of pain in their Head and Stomach, which ometimes is dipered over the whole Body; ometimes it confines it elf to the Arm-pits; the Neck, the Parts behind the Ears, or to the Groin. To outward appearance, there is not the leat welling. If the Patient by uch means as is requiite be provoked to weat at the beginning of the Dieae, the pain utterly ceaeth, and in a few dayes he will be perfectly retored to his health, the Dieae not having at all dicovered it elf by any outward Symptoms. Why uch a Fever hould be accounted a Species of the Plague, I ee no reaon; But there is no one but will confes it to have eized on that Body on which Buboes, Carbuncles, and Spots do outwardly appear.

The caue of the Plague is either Internal or External; but unto which oever we impute it, it is neceary to conclude, that there is in it a power of diolving the natural Conitence of the Blood, and depriving the whole Body of its trength.

As to the Inward Caue, which is Meat and Drink, it is evident to all, that it cannot produce in any Body whatoever o great & udden a change; but it is mot certain, that by a long & continued coure of bad Diet, the Blood may by degrees be after uch a manner diolved, weakned, and corrupted, that ome part of it auming to it elf a malignant quality; a man
may be urprized by a udden Dieae, & ometimes be deprived of life it elf; which hath been oberved in ick perons at everal times, when there hath been no contagion in the place, nor any upected, who have been troubled with perfect Buboes, and other Symptoms of the Plague, much more intolerable than others have been at any time when the Air hath been infected.

As to the outward Caues, every one confeeth that there are uch; but their Nature is known but to few: The Chymits, who are able by the force of Fire ditinctly to eparate the Parts of imple Drugs, endeavour to find the Original of the Contagion in a Volatile Salt, which uddenly diolves the fixed Salt of the Blood; which hath indeed ome appearance of truth, though it will not be relihed by all men.
If you enquire into the Caue hereof from others, their anwer will be various, but mot of them very idle and impertinent.

It hath by ome been thought probable that a Plague might proceed from the Heavens; they affirming that the Stars do actuate the Subluminary Bodies, both by the influence of their Light, and by everal other qualities inherent in, and peculiar unto them. But the Conjectors raied from hence, are very uncertain, and the foundation of them unecure. We are not ignorant of the Fopperies of Atrology, and of the vanity of thoe Predictions, which have no other Foundation than the everal Coures, the Conjunction and Oppoition of the Stars; which are all o frivolous, that we cannot think it worth our labour to refute them.

We acknowledge that the Air may be everal ways corrupted; from whence the Vapors which have been received from the Earth, are ent down again amongt us, which like Fire may inkindle our Blood, Corrupt waters, Carcaes either not at all buried, or ele hallowly interred; the South-wind, which may be uppoed to promote the Putrefaction; Men already infected, & ucceively imparting the Contagion to the ound, & by that means preading the Venom through the Bodies of Men, & the Air itelf.

This Petilential Infection may likewie for a long time lie couched and concealed in Straw or Stubble, amongt Garments, Hangings, and the Furniture of Beds; which we have ometimes oberved trangely to impart their Malignity to thoe that have handled them, or approached unto them.
But all thee things only inform us of the means by which this Petilential Poyon is conveyed unto us; but no one hath as yet declared what it is, and wherein its Nature doth properly conit.

The Symptoms of it are thee. The ick perons are eized with a hivering all over their Body, which is preently followed with an inward heat, which is oft-times very intene, yet without any great thirt; omtimes the thirt is exceive, & the Fever moderate. But whether the heat of the Fever be great or mall, it is mot commonly accompanied with a drynes of the Tongue, & an Urine of the ame contitution which you might expect from a man in perfect health: They are taken ometimes with a great drowines, ometimes with a Dilirium, or with
an exceive pain in the Head; & in this cae, the white of the Eyes appeareth of a Saffron-colour, & they are more wakeful than is conitent with their eae & quiet: great pain at the Heart, the Pule eems mall, if not at firt when you touch it lightly (for then it oftentimes appears to beat high) yet at leat when you pres it cloely with your Fingers. The trength fails in the beginning of the Dieae, & decreaeth much more viibly than in the mot burning Fever, which hath no Malignity attending it. Some are taken with a Diarrhaea, which can by no means be topt: Others bleed much at the Noe, the Eyes, the Ears, or Mouth; ome at the Yard or Womb. Some are troubled with a continual Vomiting, others with a Naueounes. On ome Bodies there appear red or purple pots; & on others Buboes behind their Ears, on their Neck, under their Chin, in the Groin, and under the Arm-pits: In ome there break forth red Wheals or Puhes; in others white Bladders, or Carbuncles. And whereoever thee Bladders, Buboes, Carbuncles, &c. do appear, they are a mot certain ign of the Plague, although the bignes of them may be inconiderable; epecially if they either accompany, or are Conequents of a Fever.

As to the Prognoticks, we mut conider, that the Plague is a very treacherous Dieae, and whilt it flatters us mot, it intends us the greatet michief. A Bubo is les dangerous than a Carbuncle, and a Carbuncle than the Spots, which very eldom portend les than preent death whereoever they are diplay'd.

A Bubo behind the Ears, on the Neck, or
under the Arm-pits, is more dangerous than that in the Groin.

Carbuncles on the Hands and Feet, may by ome be thought les pernicious, becaue they are more remote from the Heart; but ince they happen amongt many Nerves and Tendons, they are more to be feared than thoe which appear in other parts of the Body which are better covered with fleh.
A Carbuncle ariing after a Bubo, is a ign of Death. If a Bubo or Carbuncle appear before the Fever, there is les danger than if they follow it at a ditance, and arie lowly.
A blew Circle encompaing the Bubo the econd day after its appearance, is a ign of Death.
If a Bubo uddenly diappears, the tate of the Patient is dangerous, unles Nature dipatcheth the Malignant Humour to ome other Part.

Thus we have often oberved, that upon the retreat of that Morbifick Matter which hath caued a Bubo in the Groin, there hath appeared a Gangrene in the Foot, and on the ame ide which was before affected, and many have by that means ecaped.
If a Cupping-glas applied to the Patient, raieth no Bliter, we may reaonably conclude his condition to be deperate.

It is an infallible ign of Death, if after Cauterization, or the application of a Cupping-glas, the Carbuncle abates not in 12 or 24 hours, as likewie if there is no moiture proceeding from it; but if a Bladder appears, or any eparation of the matter be made
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
(which is o much the better, by how much it is the greater) with a ufficient purulency, the Patient is then pat danger.

A Carbuncle which eems to have a little tail, or puh at the end of it, is very dangerous, as are likewie thoe which look white; which, unles the Fever doth very much abate, are certain forerunners of Death.

If the Patient that hath a Bubo in his Neck, or behind his Ears, be troubled with a pain in his Throat, and a difficulty in wallowing, and no coniderable Inflammation appear, we have always found it a certain Rule, that in this cae he outlives not 12 or 15 hours.

Sleep more ound than ordinary, Diliriums, waking often in the night, inflammation of the Eyes, pain at the Heart, a trembling and convulion of the Joynts, are all very dangerous Symptoms, but do not always portend Death.
A great Fever without a pain at the Heart, is not o dangerous as a leer, which is accompanied with that Symptom.
The greatnes of the danger may ometimes be judged from the great drynes of the Tongue.
If by the adminitration of Sudorificks, Sweat is not provoked, the Patient uually micarrieth.

A Flux of Blood was heretofore held dangerous in all Plagues; but in our Age, all that can either bleed at the Noe, or have their Mentrua's, come off afe: We have no preident of any that have pied Blood; but a Dientery is the ign of an approaching Death.
It is very certain, although it but eldom happens, that incurable Carbuncles do break out about the Eyes, Noe & Stomach, & even amidt the Entrails themelves.
If they eize on the Bladder, they become mortal to the Patient, and put him to exceive pain.

I can intance only in one, who after he had for 30 hours or more been troubled with the Spots, at length, after exceeding great pain, accompanied with a Delirium, he voided firt, Blood and after that, a purulent matter through his Yard, by which means he was retored to his health; I conjectured that there was a Carbuncle in the cae, which eized not on the Membranous part of the Bladder, but on the Neck thereof.
As to the Cure; Blood-letting is very prejudicial to thoe that already have the Plague, and dangerous to uch that would prevent it.

The Poion oftentimes lies hid within the B ‚Ä¢ dy for ome dayes, weeks, or months, before ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dicovers it elf by eizing on the conveyances of the Blood. Wherefore I would advie you eriouly to conider, if by opening a Vein, you invite it immediately to the Heart, whether the diminution of Blood, Spirits and Strength, which is effected by this means, be not the Caue why the Heart is uffocated and deprived of that vigour which it hould make ue of to repule the Enemy. I confes ome Experienced Phyitians of good credit, have reported, that in hot Countries there is no better means for retoring a Patient viited with the Plague, unto his health, than that of opening a Vein, provided it be done cautiouly, and at the beginning of the Dieae; but whooever have attempted it in colder Climates, have quickly learnt by experience, that it ought to be forborn.

Purging, which is oftentimes very neceary in other gentle Dieaes, is excluded by the Malignity of this. But every one is not quick-ighted enough to dicern when it is requiite to be done, and when to be forborn: Moreover, it is evident, that in a Malignant Dieae, the Phyick which is adminitred to a Patient, ought to be more mild and gentle than at other times; for beides that the Body cannot then bear trong purgations, a Dyentery is oftentimes the conequence of them. I have when I have been fully perwaded that there was no Malignity in the Dieae oftentimes ued this, or ome uch like Potion with good ucces, viz.

Take Rhubarb, a dram and half; Senna, two drams; Cream of Tartar, a dram; Scorzonera-Roots, half an ounce; Anieeds, half a dram; Boil them in Holy-Thitle-Water, and to three ounces of the trained Liquor, and Syrup of Succory, with Rhubarb, ix drams; Spirit of Salt, a little; Confection of Alkermes, a crupel: Make it into a Potion.

I never adventured to precribe any thing Purgative to uch as have been taken with the Plague, before the fourteenth day, at which time the Fever and the other Symptoms of the Dieae would be abated. There are ome who have attempted it while the Carbuncles remain purulent, and before the Bubo is perfectly cured.
But I dare not advie any one to follow that Method, whatoever Remedies they adminiter at the ame time, which may be intended pecifically againt the Plague.

But if it happen that the Patient for everal
days be very cotive, and troubled with a pain at his heart, and hopes to be relieved by Purgation,

It is to be conidered, that the Venom of the Dieae, and not the Cotivenes is the caue of the pain at the Heart; it is therefore mot requiite to make ue of Sudorificks, to corroborate the Heart, and not to concern your elf for the cotivenes of the Body: but if you deire to open it a little, it is better to make ue of a Suppoitory than a Glyter, which is not altogether o afe, but hath been prejudicial to many on this occaion: and to others it hath done but little good, and not at all oppoed the Malignity of the Dieae: But to uch as will not take this advie, which hath been very confirmed by experience and everal good Reaons, and will till perit to make ue of Glyters, it is fit however that they forbear to precribe Scammony as an Ingredient, epecially to Women in the time of their Flowers.

Juleps are in this cae very neceary; but all perons may not make ue of them, nor any at all times. I am never wont to precribe them without joyning with them ome Sudorificks (which will appear hereafter) and this I take to be the afet coure; for if the ick peron hould make ue of uch things only as refrigerate while he weats freely, the Sweat would oftentimes trike inward, and the Venom would be conveyed to the Heart, from whence would follow udden Death.

There is no means more requiite than that of Diaphoreticks and Cordials, epecially thoe that are acid, which produce uch effects as are
certain, and therefore the more laudable; for they rectifie the Mas of Blood, and free it from the venom which infects it. They diolve the pituitous Matter which is lodged in the Stomach and the Entrails, and correct the Choler, which in this Dieae is the caue of much michief. Nevertheles the everal diguies of this Dieae, and the vanity of the Symptoms which attend it, do require that they hould be often changed; ince when the Dieae is more gentle, thoe things are not to be ued, which would do good ervice in an accute one.

div.head: Medicaments againt the Plague.
div.p: Roots of Zedoary, Butter-Bur, Angelica, Ditamny, Galangal, Vipers-gras, Gentian, Mater-wort, Lovage, Burnet, Orrie Florentine, and ours, China, Saraparilla.
Leaves of Rue, Scordium, Sage, Holy-Thitle, Swallow-wort, Wormwood, Southern-wood, Centuary the leer, Valerian, Sorrel, Fluellin, Balm, Marjoram, Roemary, Thyme, Mint.
Flowers of Borage, Buglos, Violets, Roes, Marrigolds; St. John worts, Roemary, Indian-Spikenard, Jeamy.
Seeds of Citrons, Oranges, Rue, St. Johns wort Anie, Coriander, Lovage.
Fruits, Citrons, Oranges, Walnuts, Figs, harp Cherries, Pippins, Ribes, owre Pomegranates, Barberries.
Spices, Musk, Ambergreece, Civet, Benjamin, Storax Calamita, Cinamon, Mace, Nutmegs, Cardamums, Camphire.
Animals or their parts; Fleh of Vipers, Mummy, Serpents, Quails, Thruhes, Harts-horn, Unicorns-horn, Bezoar, Stone of an Indian Hog, Ivory, Cator.
Precious Stones and Earths, the Jacinth, Granate, Emerald, Ruby, Carbuncle, Pearls, Coral, Bolearmenick, Earth of Lemnos, and Seal'd, Gold, Silver.
Salts, Common, brought lately from the River Nile, which moveth Sweat mot powerfully; of Scordium, of Wormwood, Rue, Self-heal; Holy-Thitle, Vitriolated Tartar, Bezoarticum Minerale.
Threacle of Andromacus's, Diateeron, Mithridate of Damocratis, Diacordium of Fracatorius, Confection of Alkermes, of Hyacinth.

p.hi: Species Liberantis.

div.p: Electuaries, of the Egg, Rob. of Currans, of Barberies.
Conerves of Balm, Mint, Roemary-Flowers, Borage, Buglos, Marigold-Flowers.
Troches, of the Juice of Barberries, of Citrons.
