p.hi: Out of all which, you may make choice of uch as you judge mot fit for the purpoe.

div.p: The Writings of Authors, who have treated of this Dieae, will give you an account of other Compounds, out of which you may chue uch as pleae you bet.

I hall here propound uch only as I have found to be mot efficacious, and which I hall contantly make ue of, till by experience I hall dicover ome others, whoe nature is more excellent; and that the ue of them may
the more plainly appear, I hall premie ome Medicaments that ome years ince were precribed by my elf, and thoe Learned Men, Dr. Francis Sylvius, and Dr. Francis Vanderchagen, wherewith we thought it neceary to oppoe that pernicious Enemy with which we were to contend.

div.head: Our Prophylactick Water.
div.p: Take Roots of Angelica, Zedoary, of each an ounce; Roots of Butter-Bur, two ounces; Leaves of Rhue, four ounces; Leaves of Balm, Scabious, Marrigold-Flowers, of each two ounces; unripe Walnuts liced, two pound; freh Citrons liced, a pound: let them be all bruied together, then poure upon them ix quarts of the bet Wine-Vinegar ditilled by it elf in a Glas-Cucurbit in Sand.
Let them diget a night, then ditil them with a gentle fire of Embers to drines, but without burning, and preerve this Vinegar for your ue.

If you deire an Extract or Salt, poure ome of the ditilled Liquor upon the Caput Mortuum, or to the remander, and let it diget for three days, till it hath drawn out a Tincture, with filtre, and ditil the filtred Liquor in Balneum Mariae, to the conitence of an Extract: After the Extract, calcine the Caput Mortuum, and draw forth the Salt.

div.head: Our Prophylactick Conerve.
div.p: Take freh Citrons, two pounds, the Juice hard pret out, the outward Coats eparated from the inward Pulp, and bruied very mall; adding Conerve of White-Roes, half a pound; of Red-Roes, of Borage-Flowers, of each half a pound; preerved Orange-peels, four ounces: Make it into a Conerve.

div.head: Our Alexipharmick Powder.
div.p: Take Roots of Contrayervae, half an ounce; Petilent-wort, Tormentil, Elicampane, of each 2 drams; ealed Earth, Bole-armenick, of each three drams; Shavings of Harts-horn, Ivory, of each a dram; Red Coral prepared, four cruples; Biting Cinamon, two drams; Diaphoretick Antimony, half an ounce: Make it into a Powder.

I have made ue of thee three foregoing Medicines with very great ucces, as have alo thoe famous Phyicians before-mentioned, when they have applied them to everal that have been viited with the Plague. When I have given them for a Preervative againt the Plague, I eldom mixed any other with them; but for the Cure of it, I never made ue of them ingle, but have always given them with thee, or ome uch like, viz.

Take Diacordium of Fracatorine, four cruples; Salt Prunella, a cruple; Salt of Wormwood, half a cruple; our Prophylactick Water, Holy-Thitle-water, Syrup of Barberries, of each an ounce: Mix them for a draught.
Or,

Take our Alexipharmick Powder, a cruple; Vitriolated Tartar, eight grains; Salt of Coral,
15 grains; Confection of Alkermes, half a dram; our Prophylactick Water, an ounce and half; Rue-water, as much as ufficeth, Syrup of Holy-Thitle, an ounce: Mix it for a draught.
Or,

Take Antimony Diaphoretick, a cruple; Salt of Scordium, of Rue, of each half a cruple; our Prophylactick water, an ounce; Fumitory-water, as much as is ufficient; Julep of Roes, an ounce: Mix it for a draught.
Take Confection of Hyacynth, Diacordium, Threacle, of each two cruples; our Prophylactick extract, fifteen grains; Spirit of Salt, half a cruple: Mix it into a Bole.
Take our Prophylactick Conerve, a dram and half; prepared Crabs-Eyes, a cruple; our Prophylactick-water, half an ounce; Syrup of Limons, an ounce; Elder-Vinegar, half an ounce: Mix it for a draught.
Take Bezoartick Minera, fifteen grains; Sal Prunella, a cruple; Lozenges of Sugar pearl'd, half a dram: Make it into a Powder.

Let the ick peron take ome of thee Medicaments for the provoking of Sweat plentifully; to which purpoe, let him take Mutton or Chicken-broth an hour or two after he hath taken his Medicament; let the Sweat be gently wiped off with a warm Cloth, and another applied to his Breat: For we have found it not afe to change the Shifts, and other Linnen about the Patient, unles they are too much moitened by Sweat.

We may afely adminiter thee, or the like Sudorificks twice in a day to the Patient, or thrice
in 24 hours, and that very much to his benefit.

There are ome, who every ix hours have very advantagiouly made ue of a new Sudorifick. Nor are you eaily to be peruaded to ceae from the ue of thee means, although the Patient hould tell you that he is well in health, let you find the treacherous Dieae of a udden to urprize you both again.

For young Children (who do uually abhor the taking of Phyick) I have found nothing better than the following Powder, given them in their ordinary Drink two or three times, in the pace of 24 hours; the Sugar may be omitted, if the Patient diguts weet things.
Take Diaphoretick Antimony, 15 grains; Lozenges of Sugar pearl'd, a cruple and half: Make it into a Powder.
Or,
Take Crabs-Eyes prepared, Shavings of Ivory, Bezoartick Mineral, of each ix grains: Make it into a Powder.

p.hi: We will treat of Juleps when we come to dicoure of the Cure of the Plague.

div.head: The Symptomes of the Plague.
div.p:
THey are many, and very various, but mot of them are accompanied with ome others; which when the former are cured, the latter are very eaily removed. We therefore think it very needles to give an account of
them all in this place, it will be ufficient to intance in the chief of them, amongt which, we in the firt place encounter with.
A Fever: Of uch a Nature, that it admits not of any purging, or letting of Blood, which the Experience of everal hath ufficiently confirmed.

The Sudorificks before precribed are no les ueful for this Sympton, than for the Plague it elf; but the Fever and great drines of the Tongue, requiring uch things as refrigerate, they are not to be adminitred, except they are mixed with Sudorificks, as we have hewn before.

Take Water of Borage, Sorrel, of each two ounces; our Prophylactick Water an ounce and an half; Juice of owre Oranges freh Citrons, of each two drams; Julep of Roes, as much as will make it conveniently weet; Oriental Bezoar, fifteen grains: Mix them.

Let the Patient often take the quantity of a poonful hereof at once, whereby his thirt will be much better allayed, than if he hould drink ten times the quantity of Beer, and that without any check or hinderance to the Sweat.
Or,
Take Holy-Thitle-Water, a pint; our Prophylactick Water, two ounces; Syrup of our Pomgranates, two ounces and an half: Mix them.
Or,

Take Scorzonera-roots, Butter-bur-roots, of each an ounce; Sorrel-leaves, two handfuls: Boil them in Barley-water, & to a pint of the Liquor, add Syrup of Violets, two ounces; Sal
Prunella, two cruples; or Spirit of Salt, as much as is ufficient: Mix them.
For the Rich, uch like Juleps as thee may be prepared, which are both pleaant to the Palate, and very Cordial.

Take Borage-water, three ounces; Holy-Thitle-water, a pint; Roe-water, an ounce; Lozenges of Sugar pearl'd, an ounce; Amber-greece, two grains; Musk, a grain; Juice of Citrons, as much as ufficeth: Mingle them.

Weop-Ale, or ome uch like, which is well boyl'd, may here be very ueful, epecially if ome Nutmeg crap'd, or a piece of calcin'd Harts-horn be tied up & teeped in it. Nor need we fear any michief from exceeding either in the quantity or the frequent repeating of it; but we mut take heed that it be not given cold, let Gripings, Flux, and a pain at the Heart, & uch like Maladies hould be caued thereby.

To uch who have weak tomachs, & a pain at their heart, I do ue to give the liberty, when their Fever abates, to drink Moel, or Rhenih-wine with Sugar, & the juice of Limons, provided that they take it in a moderate quantity: But I believe they do err very much, who precribe to their Patients, whilt the Fever continues till very high, ome ort of French Wine, either alone by it elf, or mixt with their Sudorificks.
That Oriental Stone, call'd Lapis Porcinus, or Pedro Porco, is of very great ue, if it be teeped for a while in your ordinary Drink; for it trongly provokes Sweat, and very much refreheth the Heart.

This Stone, if I mitake not, is generated in the Gall of an Hog, for it is exceeding bitter; and
though it be very hard, yet every time it is infued, it abates omewhat of its quantity, which is dicoverable by the Tincture which it imparts to the Liquor. Nor is the Gall of a man ometimes void of uch Stones, which are like unto thoe taken out of an Hog, in avour, hardnes and colour; and we might find them too perhaps in their efficacy likewie, if we thought fit to make trial of them.

This Fever is often accompanied with drowines, which forbids the ue of the principal Sudorificks, uch as Treacle, Mithridate, Diacordium, &c. becaue there is Opium in their compoition, which makes them not o effectual for the preventing of leep. It is more requiite to ue this following, which is agreeable for dipelling the Vapours which infect the Head, and the heat about the Heart.

Take Salt of Rue, of Scordium, Prunella, of each half a cruple; Vitriolated Tartar, 8 grains; our Prophylactick Water, an ounce; Balm-water, as much as ufficeth; Syrup of Betony, an ounce: Mix them for a draught.
Let Sweat be thereby provoked, and let it be the care of the Attendants, that after the firt or econd day, the Patient may be kept from leep, if it be found that he hath trength to bear it.
There is ometimes joyn'd with the Fever, continual Watchings, and a great pain of the Head.

I do not ue to be much concerned for the watchings, although it hould continue for the firt three days without intermiion, for it often falls out, that by the ue of Sudorificks only, the pain is the firt day abated, on the 2d becomes tolerable, and on the third is quite taken away.

Opium hath in it the virtue of cauing Sweat, and is a great Ingredient in Treacle, Diacordium, and Mithridate, which without it, would not in my judgment have that Sudorifick quality, for which they are now noted. It is alo reckoned by everal Authors amongt thoe Medicines which are famous for dipelling of Poion, whoe ue is very requiite in all malignant Fevers; nor do I believe that there can any other Medicine be named which gives o preent relief to the Patient as Opium; concerning the operation whereof, they are able to give a better account, who have been frequent and curious in the ue of it. I have ometimes in this cae (though contrary to Cutom) given it paringly, when I have found the ick peron not to leep in the firt, econd or third days: But when he hath waked for ix or even days together, and found a great decay of trength, this following Precription, taken every quarter of an hour by a poonful, till leep hath eized on him, hath afforded great relief, and the leep produced thereby, hath been unditurbed, and of long continuance.

Take our Prophylactick-water, an ounce & half; Borage-water, an ounce; Cinamon-water, three drams; Confection of Hyacinth, a dram; Lozenges of Sugar pearl'd, three drams; Laudanum Opiat, two grains: Mix them.

You may afely make ue of Opium, after the manner before mentioned; but in Gachectick & infirm Bodies, whooever gives it too boldly, or is fearful of precribing it at all, dicovers that he undertands not its Virtue and Efficacy.

Before I come to the ue of Opiat Laudanum,
I endeavour to eae the pain of the Head by thee following, viz. by applying Ground-Ivy bruied to the nape of the Neck, and to the oles of the Feet, and palms of the Hands; this, or ome uch like Compoition.

Take Leaves of Rue, a handful and half; owre Leaven, two ounces; Pigeons dung, an ounce; common Salt, half an ounce; Elder-Vinegar, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Poultice, to be applied to the oles of the Feet, and palms of the Hands.
Or,
Take Bolearmenick, eal'd Earth, common white Chalk, of each half an ounce; Vinegar of Marigolds, as much as ufficeth: Apply it as before.
To the Forehead I have often applied the Powder of Cloves, moitened with the Spirit of Wine; for I take Vinegar to be hurtful, as are alo all Emulions.

Vomiting and the Hiccough is another ymptom of the Plague. It hath been oberved by everal who have been o curious as to open Bodies which have died of the Plague, that Carbuncles have often appear'd in the Stomach, and amongt the Entrails, whoe tetimony is not to be rejected, ince it is o agreeable both to Reaon and Experience.
Thee (If they are not the Caue of the Vomiting and Hiccough, may be eaily removed by a poonful of this following Preparation, taken cold every quarter of an hour.

Take Mint-water, our Prophylactick-water, of each an ounce and half; Cinamon-water, half an ounce; Confection of Hyacinth, a dram; Salt
of Coral, a cruple; Syrup of Myrtles, half an ounce; Roe-Julep, half an ounce: Mix them.
By the ue hereof, the Vomiting is uually tay'd, epecially if the Stomach be ometimes anointed with this following Oyl.
Take Oyl of Nutmegs by Expreion, a dram and half; Oyl of ditill'd Mace, half a dram; Oyl of Wormwood, a dram: Mix them.
In the mean while, let the ick peron forbear to drink too plentifully, and as oon as the Vomit is tayed, let him make ue of ome good Sudorifick.

Another Symptom of the Plague is a great Flux which is uually a ign that Death approacheth; but when the ick peron hath not voided meer blood, nor any thing of a bloody ubtance, I have ometimes found thee following Precriptions to be uccesful.

Let him abtain from all things that are either acid or alt; which except in this cae, are of great ue in the Plague; and likewie from drinking much: But if his thirt be o exceeding great, that he cannot bear it, let him take one, two or three poonfuls of this following Mixture.

Take Tormentil-Roots, an ounce; Red Roes, a handful; Shaving of Harts-horn a dram; Seeds of Sorrel and Mirtle, of each a dram: Boil them in Smiths water, and to nine ounces of the Liquor, add of the Confection of Hyacinth, a dram; Syrup of Mirtles, an ounce. Mix them.

Many have alo from Treacle alone received great benefit by wallowing a little of it every four hours, till they have taken the quantity
of a dram; as likewie from this following, taken by poonfuls.

Take Fracatorius his Diacordium, two drams Amber, half a cruple; red Coral prepared, Dragons blood, of each a cruple; prepared Pearls, half a cruple; Fennel-water, an ounce; Plantane and Roe-water, of each an ounce and half; Syrup of Comfery of Fernelius, an ounce Mix them.
Clyters of an atringent, drying & emollient quality, given twice or thrice in a day, have likewie in this cae been found very neceary.

Take Roots of Comfrey the greater, an ounce; Bitort and Tormentil Roots, of each three drams; Oak-leaves, half a handful; Flowers of Balautians, Red Roes, of each a pugil; Anieeds, three drams: boil them in Cows Milk that hath been burnt to; into 8 ounces of Liquor, diolve of Venice Turpentine, two drams: one Yolk of an Egg, white Troches of Rhais, a dram; Honey of Mercury, half an ounce; of Roes, an ounce: Make a Clyter,

The Bathing of the Belly with the Lees of white or rather of red Wine, and the applying to it afterward a warm cloth three or four times doubled, have by ome been found to be of ingular benefit, or ele the Ointment and Plaiter following may be made ue of.
Take Oyl of Matick, of expret Nutmegs of each a dram; Oyl of Dill, Wormwood, Myrtles, of each two drams; old Treacle, three drams: Mix them.

Take Bolearmenick, Franckincene, Matick, Dragons-blood, of each two drams; Mummy,
three drams; Powder of Galls a dram & half; Seeds of Carrots Lovage Anie, Myrtles of each a cruple; Oyl of Nutmegs by expreion, three drams; Venice-Turpentine, as much as ufficeth to make it into a Plaiter.
And thus much may uffice to have been poken concerning the inward Symptoms of the Plague; the outward are three, the Spots, call'd Petechiae, the Bubo, and the Carbuncle.
The Spots can hardly any other way be better removed than by inward Remedies, but they do uually portend ome michief.

The Bubo, I am wont to deal with after this manner following. At the firt appearance of it, and although the welling hath arrived to no coniderable height, I draw a Bliter, without making ue of Cupping-glaes, which by reaon that they caue a great deal of pain, & create a Fever, & draw unto them both the good & bad Humors, & caue a greater alteration than was before in the Blood, I do utterly lay aide: After 7 or 8 hours cutting the Bliter. I apply unto that part a Magnetick Plaiter of Arenick; the virtue whereof is o great, that I know not any more excellent; which will appear to whomoever hall make ue of it; the account of it out of Hartman and Agricola, is as followeth.

div.head: The Magnetick Arenical Plaiter.
div.p: Take Crude Antimony, yellow Brimtone, white Arenick, of each two ounces.

When you have beat them very mall, let them be put into a Viol covered in Sand, to which you mut apply fire till they are all melted, & appear to be of a dark red colour; when
it is cool, it may be taken out of the Veel, and this is that which they call the Arenical Magnet, and hath not in it any thing of Poyon, as it may be eaily experimented upon Dogs afterwards.

Take Gum Sagapenum, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, of the Arenical Magnet, of each three drams; Turpentine of the Larch-tree, Wax, of each half an ounce; Oyl of Amber, two drams; Dulcified Earth of Vitriol, a dram.

Let the Gums be diolved in the tronget Wine-Vinegar, and trained through a Linnen Cloth, let them after that be boiled up to their former conitence, then melt the Wax and the Turpentine together by themelves, & when you have taken them off from the fire, tir them well till you have brought them to the conitence of an Ointment; then add to them the Gums beforementioned, & the Arenical Magnet, together with the Earth of Vitriol, and Oyl of Amber, & you will have that plaiter which is mot effectual for drawing forth all orts of Poyon.

I have found the virtue of this Plaiter to be uch, that if it be applied to thoe parts where the Skin is omewhat hard, it leaves not the leat ign of a Scar, and yet doth o plentifully draw forth the malignant Humor, that a Bubo of the bignes of a Walnut, will in the pace of 5 or 6 days be utterly taken away; but becaue it doth not always o uddenly produce this Effect, it is often very neceary to raie a Bliter for evacuation of the Humors. And it is obervable, that in ome trong Bodies it caueth no Ecar at all, unles when the Bliter hath corroded,
not only the outward, but alo the inward Skin. But in Children, and more tender Bodies, it will of it elf caue an Ecar, although there be no Bliter drawn before the application of it.

This Ecar or Crut is the true eat of the Venom, which is extracted, & is of that thicknes (epecially conidering that the Skin is but uperficially corroded) that it is well worth our while to conider it. For I do believe that to be the reaon why it is much ooner eparated than other Cruts or Scars that are caued by Art; for in the pace of 24 or 36 hours, if no Scarification hath preceded, it may be eaily taken off without any, or at leat with a very mall pain, if you make ue of any Antipetilential Plaiter, and add unto it ome Treacle, or nguentum Bailicum, or ele the evering of the Ecar may be very much promoted by this Ointment.
Take Virgins-Honey, Ducks-greee, of each an ounce; Soot, ix drams; Turpentine, an ounce; Yolks of two Eggs, Treacle, three drams; Oyl of Scorpions, as much as ufficeth to make it into an Ointment.
But if the Tumor is not ufficiently abated when the firt Crut is taken off by the Arenical Magnetick Plaiter, it is requiite that you create a econd or third, and then proceed as before.

The Ulcer may be conolidated by a Plaiter of Minium, of White Lead, Diapompholigos, or ome uch Remedy which drieth up the Humor, and bringeth the Ulcer to a Cicatrice: But we mut oberve this by the way, that this
Conolidation is not to be wrought too uddenly, let part of the poyonous Humor which till remains in the Body, hould caue ome new Dieae, which may be fatal to the Patient.

For want of the Magnetick Plaiter, you may make ue of this following, if you take care firt to raie a Bliter, the vertue whereof hath been found to be very great by everal, for the taking away of painful Scrophula's, and the excellent qualities that are in it, have made it famous by the name of

div.head: The Divine Plaiter.
div.p: Take Gum Galbanum, an ounce; Ammoniacum, two drams, Oppoponax, three drams; yellow Wax, twenty ounces; Oyl of Olives, 24 ounces; Litharge of Gold, 17 ounces; Olibanum, two ounces: Mirrhe, Frankincene, of each ten drams; Verdigreece, long Birthwort, Matick, of each an ounce; Bdellium, Loadtone, of each two ounces: Make it according to Art into a Plaiter.

If the Bubo is too protuberant, or cleaves to the Tendon, a Veicatory is too weak; but an actual Cautery is not o neceary: it will be therefore bet to make ue of a potential one, and among thoe everal wherewith I have been acquainted, I know not any one that is more corroive, and yet caueth les pain than this following.
Take unlaked Lime, drachm 1; of black Sope as much as ufficeth: Mix them.

There are few which are not acquainted with uch things as are ueful for drawing of Bliters; among the ret, this Precription
following is to be commended.

Take owre Leaven, half an ounce; Euphorbium, Seeds of Staves-acre, of Mutard, Roots of Pellitory of Spain, of each a cruple and half: Cantharides, a dram and half; tronget Wine-Vinegar, to make for a Blitering Pate.
If the pain be great, the following Poultice may be made ue of, unles neceity require that the Chirurgeon hould make ue of a Cautery.

Take Leaves of a Scordium, Rue, Hemlock, of each a handful; Camomile and Dill-flowers, of each a pugil; tops of Wormwood, two handfuls; Crums of Bread, two ounces; boil them in Milk; adding to it of Eatern Saffron, half a dram; Yolks of two Eggs; Treacle three drams: Make it into a Cataplam.

The uppuration of a Bubo is very rare, the means neceary for it, are uch as Chirurgeons are very well acquainted with, and are not, if Nature inclines to it, to be neglected. The Abceus in this cae is to be opened, firt by a Launcet, and not by the application of any Cautick; but the Ulcer that proceeds from hence, is very lowly healed.

None but uch as are unskilful, make ue of the Plaiter of Frogs and Mercury; for it driveth the Venom inward, and threatneth much danger to the ick peron; wherein we are confirmed both by the Writings of Ancient Authors, and by our own experience.

div.head: The Carbuncle.
div.p:
Called by the Greeks Anthrax (for it is to no purpoe to inert any nice ditinction between
them) hews it elf in everal hapes; but the Symptoms of it are many times very fallible: It is eaie to conclude of it when ever it dicovers it elf by a little Puh of a dark Purple Colour, with an Inflammation round about it; but often appears with a White Puh without any coniderable prominency, which eems to contain a ort of purulent Matter that portends no michief; but if you queeze it, you will find it dry and very hard, and it eats very deep into the Skin underneath it.

Sometimes there appears one ingle Bladder filled with Limpid Matter, which if it be not opened in the pace of 24 hours, it grows black, and upon its diection ends forth two or three drops of black Blood.

Otherwhiles, everal little white Bliters dicover themelves. If thee grow hard underneath, and are accompanied with a Fever and Inflammation, there is no quetion but that they are Malignant; and I know not why they may not be reckoned in the number of Carbuncles, epecially ince they are wont to dipatch a man in as hort a time as the purple ones; and they are to be dealt with after the ame manner, if we expect that our endeavours hould ucceed.

To the Cure of it, it is requiite that the Suppuration hould with all diligence be promoted, and thereby the danger prevented of the Infection dipering it elf. And for this purpoe I have found nothing more effectual than an actual Cautery; which hath alo been approved of by everal Chirurgeons; but there are ome who apprehending it to be too cruel
a Remedy, do upon that account reject it, and chooe rather a Potential Cautick, or ome Medicines whereby Bliters may be raied: Both which I my elf likewie have made ue of, when it hath not been allowed that we hould ue other means, and when I have hoped that thee might be ufficiently efficacious. For a Phyitian is often contrained to comply with the Humor of uch as are converant about the ick Peron, and will pretend to know much, although it be many times to the prejudice of his Patient.
They that approve not of any of the forementioned Remedies, may make ue of the Magnetical Arenick Plaiter, which in this cae we have found to be of great virtue.
For the eparation of the Scar, thoe means which we mentioned in treating of the Bubo, are very neceary: Many have very much commended this following Poultice.

Take Roots of Comfrey the greater dried, two drams; Marhmallow Roots dried, half an ounce; Leaves of Scordium dried, two drams; Meal of Lineed and Wheat, of each half an ounce; make them into fine Powder, poure upon them clean water as much as is ufficient; let them boil a little, that the Mucilages may be diolved, and till it comes to the conitence of a thick Poultice; then add of Honey, Turpentine, and ng. Apotolorum, of each, three drams; Bailicon, Tar, of each two drams; the Yolk of an Egg; Eatern Saffron, a cruple: Mix, and if you pleae, you may add two drams of Treacle.

div.head: Preervatives againt the PLAGUE.
div.p: IT is the Doctrine of the Devil to teach that the ue of all Means is to be neglected; who once pake to our Saviour, and endeavoured to perwade him to cat himelf headlong from the top of the Temple, becaue they need no other ecurity, whom God upporteth by his mighty Hand: but he that hath given us Life and Health, requires that we hould make ue of ome helps for the conervation of both; and therefore if you take my advice, I would wih you to oberve the Rules following.
Amongt which, in the firt place is challenged, and that deervedly, fervent Prayer.

Flight is very allowable to Chritians, if it be conitent with their quality and condition of Life; but let thoe that make ue of this, not depend too much upon it, but remember that it is not poible to fly beyond the reach of the Omnipotent.
And to take thee Directions with them, viz. That they fly early, go far off, and be lack in their return.
When we go out into the Air, either by day or night, we ought to take pecial care that it be clear and free from Vapours.

To which intent it hath been in uch caes very ueful, and found exceding advantageous
to keep good fires both in publick an private, ince the Air is by nothing ooner nor more effectually purified.
It is alo very neceary that the Houes be daily wahed, which if it be done with Vinegar intead of Water, it is much better.

Things of a trong Odour, uch as Amber, Musk, Civet, Benjamin, &c. do not only correct the Malignity, but attract the Venom to them, and have been found hurtful by experience, and are therefore conequently to be concluded o by reaon.
It is ueles and ridiculous to anoint the Notrils with Treacle and Mithredate.

Thoe things which do really purifie the Air, are Amber, Pitch, Mirrhe, Frankincene, the Wood and the Berries of Juniper, Sulphur, Aa Foetida, Horn (but epecially Gunpowder) being either kindled, or put upon a few lighted Coals.
Such as take Tobacco, do very much commend the virtue of that Plant; I do not diapprove the ue of it, though as much as I can, I void the Smoak.

An inordinate Diet is very hurtful at all eaons, but epecially in a Petilential one. There can be nothing precribed in general which may agree with each man in particular; there is very much to be allowed to Cutom, but we mut at all times indutriouly avoid all Meats that are difficult to be concocted, and take great care that the Stomach be not overcharged.

For our Diet (if we can o contrive it) we ought to make choice of Veal, Mutton,
Beef, Pullets, Capons, Peacocks, Larks, Chaffinches, Quails, Hares, Conies, &c. Perch, Pike, Whiting, Sole, Salmon, &c. Eggs, Butter, Green and Parma Cheee, Buttermilk; Cichory, Endive, Sorrel, Lettuce, Chervil, Parley, Roemary, Sharp-Apples, Quinces, Limons, Oranges, Capers, &c.
On the other ide, Fleh and Fih which hath been dried and alted, are very hurtful; as Bacon, and Pork, Haddocks, Eels, Crabs, Shrimps, Green Fruit, and all things that are hard of Digetion.

Walnuts are very much commended, and not without good reaon; for there may be very much ue made of them: The green ones preerved, do much good to thoe that abound with Choler; but uch as are come to their full ripenes, whether you take them freh gathered, or when they are more dried, all that make ue of them, will tell you that they are very pernicious.

The tronget Beer, and Wine of a middle trength, are very ueful at uch times, if moderately taken; but we cannot allow that any, except uch as are very ancient, hould dayly make ue of trong and weet Wines, nor of Spirit of Wine and Brandy.
Go not forth into the Air with an empty Stomach, but always take ome Preervative againt Infection.
Take our Prophylactick Water, 6 ounces; Julep of Roes, 3 ounces: Mix them; take the quantity of a poonful or two each morning.
Or,

Take our Prophylactick Conerve, 3 ounces;
take the quantity of a Chetnut in the morning or as often as you are to go to an infected place.

Vinegar, and all harp things have been commended to us by long experience; but they will not well agree with uch as are troubled with a Cough, weaknes of Stomach, or the Cholick, if they are taken either alone, or in too great a quantity.
I never had any great eteem for outward means, but thoe that can fancy it, may wear about their Neck this Amulet.
Take Arenical Magnet, a dram; Benzoes, as much as is ufficient; make them into great rowls, and ew them up in red Lawn.
We have before decribed the Arenical Magnet when we treated of the Bubo.
Sleep and Watching, exercie of the Body, and the ue of Women, if immoderate, are very hurtful.
Cotivenes is prejudicial, but not o much as a great loones.
Sadnes, Fear and Anger will make very trange alterations in the Blood; he who knows how to moderate thoe Paions, is mot prudent.

div.head: I.
div.p: A Young Man aged twenty two years, being lately returned from the Eat-Indies, on the 21 of July, 1655. in the Evening was uddenly taken with a great pain in his Head, and a hivering through his whole Body, having that day received much injury from the Water and Air; the day following he became exceedingly delirous, o that he could not by four men be kept in his Bed.

The Plague at that time raged very much in the next Town, which was very populous: but there had as yet appeared no Symptoms of it in this of ours: We met with no outward igns of any Malignity, nor did thoe within appear o coniderable, as to forbid the breathing of a Vein, which the Delirium did very much pres us upon: I therefore precribed a Cordial Mixture, which might alo be Sudorifick; whereof 2 poonfuls was to be taken each quarter of an hour, and after the pace of one hour a Vein to be opened in the right Arm, and even ounces of Blood to be taken from thence: I had more than once before made trial of this Mixture in a Pleuriie, which was accompanied with Spots: The Decription of it is as followeth.

Take Waters of Borage, Holy-Thitle, Bawm, of each an ounce; Alexipharmick Water, an
ounce and half; Cinamon-water, half an ounce; Confection of Alkermes without Amber-greece and Musk, a dram and half; Syrup of the juyce of Citrons, an ounce Mix them.

The mixture was taken, and a Vein opened, and uch things as we thought fitting applyed to the Temples, the Neck, and the Soals of the Feet, but all was not ufficient to overcome the Malignity of the Dieae, for he dyed that night.

div.head: II.
div.p:
A Man and his Wife on the 5th of July, were both taken with Buboes in their Groin; She was very drowie, Feverih, and Anxious, but by the ue of Sudorificks and drawing Plaiters, he was by the 10th day following retored to perfect health. He was eized on by a pain in the Head, and a mall Delirium which continued till the 5th day, on which he was taken with a great fit of Bleeding, which with ome intermiion continued for two days, this according to the opinon of all Practical Phyicians was to be judged very dangerous. But when I conidered that his trength was not at all hereby impaired, but on the otheride, the pain in the Head and the Fever abated, nor did the Bubo trike inward; I cat away fear, and concluded that the Judgments of men by time and experience might be much corrected. I therefore thought it not the bet coure to continue here the ue of Sudorificks, but rather to trengthen the Heart, and to incraate the Blood, and thereby to top the Flux of it. To which purpoe I precribed
this which followeth, to be taken by a poonful at a time.

Take Water of Roes and Plantane, of each four ounces; Cinamon-water, ix drams; Dragons-Blood, red Coral prepared, of each a cruple; Confection of Hyacinth, a dram; Spirit of Salt, eight drops; Syrup of Barberies an ounce and half: Mix them.
Upon the taking of this, the Bleeding and the Delirium both ceaed; and thereupon the Patient grew well, the Bubo continuing for ten weeks after.

div.head: III.
div.p: A Maid on the 4th of September, was taken with a Fever, a pain at the Heart, and in the Head, and with a Bubo, which broke out about the inward part of the bending of the left Arm, and eized on the Tendon of the Mucle Biceps; from hence proceeded a very acute pain, not only in that part where the Bubo appeared, but alo about the Armpits by conent of parts, although there was no welling, which thereabouts appeared. I gave her this Sudorifick forthwith.

Take Diacordium of Fracatorius, four cruples; Sal Prunella, a cruple; Alexipharmick-water, an ounce and half; and Holy-Thitle-water, as much as is ufficient; Syrup of Limons, half an ounce: Mix it for a draught.
To the Bubo I applied the Divine Plaiter.
The Sweat came plentifully, but the pain of her Arm, a Delirium, and continual watchings, after the ue of everal other things, forced us to ue this Landanum Opiat.

Take Bawm-water, an ounce; Holy-Thitle-water,
an ounce and half; Alexipharmick-water, an ounce; Confection of Hyacinth, a dram; Julep of Roes, ten drams; Laudanum Opiat, two grains: Mix them.

Of this he took every half hour one or two poonfuls; and although it caued Sweat, yet it procured no Sleep. The Chirurgeon for variety, made ue of his Petilential Plaiter; but neither was the pain hereby remitted: we were therefore forced at length to apply this following to break it.
Take of unlack'd Lime, of Black-Sope, as much as ufficeth.

By the help whereof the Fever very much abated, though the pain continued as before; but yet in the pace of 10 or 12 days it utterly left her; but the Bubo remained open for ix weeks after, for the whole Glandule was conumed by the Ulcer, & ome part of it which was corrupted, was necearily to be eparated from the other. In the mean while, we had great caue to fear that the putrefaction had pierced deeper, becaue the Ulcer was deep, and the ides of it callous, and a erous matter came from it; but by the bleing of God the Cure ucceeded according to our wih.

div.head: IV.
div.p: A Bookeller in May was very much troubled with two Biles, whereof one broke out on his Buttock, the other on the Scrotum. To remove the caue hereof, and to abate the Tumor, I precribed this following Laxative Apozem to be taken two or three days together.

Take Tamarinds, an ounce; Cream of Tartar,
two drams; Senna, 6 drams; Rhubarb 2 drams and an half; Anieeds, a dram and half; boil them in Whey, and to a pint of the trained Liquor, add two ounces of Syrup of Succory with Rhubarb: Make it into an Apozem.
To the Swelling I applied the Plaiter Diachilon with Gums, by the means whereof they were wholly removed.

The ame peron the 26th of Augut (at which time the Plague raged here very much) was taken with a Bubo in his Groin, which, when after inquiition made (that I might atisfie the curioity of him and his Wife) I had declared to be Petilential, it was trange to ee what terrour eized upon them both, but I quickly caued them to chear up again, by letting them know that the Life was not at all in danger; for the Man in all other repects was very well, he eat, drank, and lept well, had no Fever nor pain at his Heart; nevertheles I gave him Sudorificks more than once; and the Chirurgeon drew a Bliter, and afterwards applied Plaiters and drawing Poultices, whereby in the pace of four weeks the Bubo was wholly diipated without any Suppuration.

div.head: V.
div.p: A young Emdener of 26 years old, on the 12th of Aug. fell into a continual Fever, accompanied with drowines, trembling of the Lips, blacknes and drines of the Tongue, all malignant igns; but I retored him again by the 30th of the ame Month: to effect which I precribed him a Sudorifick, Morning and Evening, and for his ordinary Drink, this Julep.
Take Holy-Thitle-water, a pint; Alexipharmick-water, 2 ounces; Julep of Roes, 2 ounces & half; Spirit of Salt, eight drops: Mix them.
On the 3d day there was Spots dicovered all over his Body, nor was his drowines or the trembling of his Lips abated, but he vomited not at all. I gave him this Sudorifick.

Take Salt of Scordium, of Holy-Thitle, of each a cruple; Antimony Diaphoretick, half a cruple; Crabs-Eyes brued, twelve grains; our Prophylactick-water, Mint-water, and Syrup of the juyce of Holy-Thitle, of each an ounce: Mix it for a Draught.
By the ue hereof the Fever abated very much, and on the eight day I found that he had a Thruh; for the eparation whereof, I precribed this Mixture to be taken by poonfuls.
Take the juyce of the greater Houleek, half an ounce; Water of Self-heal, of Purlane, of each an ounce and half; the yolk of one Egg, Syrup of Violets compound, ix drams: Mix them.

This being twice or thrice reiterated, and making ue at the ame time of a Lohoch of the Syrup of Purlane and Violets, by means hereof the Thruh was removed, and the Fever cured without either Purging or letting Blood.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
I was ent for on the 18th of Augut to a Woman great with child, which was taken with a great drowines, and had a Petilential Bubo brake forth in her Groin, but he had carcely any Fever; her Eyes looked well, and her Tongue was moit, and he eemed
very heart-whole, he had now gone even months, & on the night following he was delivered, which I concluded to be a certain ign of Death, and found it true; for on the next day about ten of the Clock he departed.

The Husband of this Woman fell ick the ame day, he was delirous, his Eyes parkled, his Tongue was dry, all which I noted for very ill igns, his Fever was but mall, but the pain at his Heart very great, his Urine like that of men well in health. After having taken two Sudorificks, he began to come to himelf, his Tongue was oberved to be moit, and a Bubo appeared in his Groin, and a Carbuncle on his Back, which on the next day had three or four more joyned to it. Thee Symptoms promied good ucces, but it happened otherwie; for as oon as he aw his Wife dead, he was o altered, that the Bubo triking inward, and the Sweat topping, the 3d day after he died.
An old Woman related to him, had a Carbuncle without a Fever, and by our uual way of proceeding, was cured in nine days.

div.head: VII.
div.p:
A Midwife which went trembling and unteady, gave me occaion from thence to upect ome extraordinary weaknes in her, or a Delirium: nor was I mitaken; for when I came to feel how languidly her Pule beat, I found it evident; but yet I could dicover no outward Symptom: nevertheles the drines of the Tongue, the difficulty of Breathing, and uch other igns did dicover that ome Malignity was concealed within; at length upon
enquiry, he told us that he had a puh upon her right Thigh, which, upon earch, we found to be a Carbuncle of the breadth of a Shilling. She would not grant that he had any Bubo in her Groin (which nevertheles I doubted not of) nor uffer the Chirurgeon to earch. He gave her what was requiite to be applied outwardly, & I precribed her a Sudorifick; after two days he recovered her trength & became of a right mind, & the 3d day eemed to be perfectly well; but on the Evening of that day all was changed, he became retles and almot ditracted, and died that night.

She had taken before I was ent for, Manna with Cream of Tartar, and after that, Tamarinds, all which doing no good, but the Dieae till encreaing upon her, he conjecturing that there was ome Malignity in it, took an ounce of Plague-Water; which, though it were much weaker than the Malignity required, yet he took it for two dayes by my advice; but on the third (whatoever I perwaded to the contrary) he changed all her Linnen, even to her Head-cloaths, and drank Whey in which Tamarinds had been boiled, from whence proceeded her udden change for the wore, and upon that her Death; and thee are the effects of elf-conceitednes.

div.head: VIII.
div.p:
Helena van Wyngaerden, a Servant of mine, on the firt day had ome light Symptoms of the Dieae, the next he was taken with Vomiting, a pain in the Head, and at her Heart, epecially when he endeavoured to rie from
her Bed, her Eyes look'd red, but her Tongue was well enough, and her Fever was but mall; a few dayes before, without my knowledge, he had been at an houe that was viited; I gave her preently a Sudorifick; whereupon, the third day after a Bubo appeared in the left Groin; I continued the ue of Sudorificks, and the Chirurgeon took care of the Bubo, by which means, within a fortnight he perfectly recovered, and went again about her buines.

div.head: IX.
div.p: The Daughter of N. Domer, on the econd of September, complained of a great pain in her head, and at her Heart, and her Tongue grew black and dry. The firt and econd day we put her into a Sweat, and on the third, he told us that he was perfectly well; her Tongue became moit, her Pain, her Fever & Anxiety left her; nevertheles I perwaded her to continue the Sudorificks, but he aroe and ate and drank, went abroad, and after that lept well all night; but in the morning the former Symptoms returned, and in the evening of the ame day there appeared Spots, and the next morning he died.

div.head: X.
div.p:
N. N. had lain very ill for ix dayes, at what time I was ent for to him on the twentieth of Augut, he began to be light-headed, his Tongue became black and dry, and he had a great anxiety at his Heart, his Eyes were fixed, his Hands trembled, and a great Carbuncle dicovered it elf on his Cheek, whoe Tail reached to his very Chin, which was alo hard and
much welled. It eem'd to threaten a much greater increae; for it was very dry, & much inflamed, and not circumcribed within any bounds. To this was added a pain in the Throat (which Symptom I conjectured to be mortal) and a very intene Fever. This deperate cae put us in mind of deperate Remedies; wherefore being guided by my ow Reaon and Experience, and perwaded by the Authority of the mot Eminent Phyitians, both Ancient and Modern, I boldly recommended to him an actual Cautery, which was preently applied by the Chirurgeon, without any great pain to the Patient: This Operation was perform'd in the Morning at ten of the Clock, and between 4 and 5 in the Afternoon it appear ‚Ä¢ d purulent, and the Crut began to be eparated, nor did the Core of it creep any further; all which effects, I know not from what means they could have been expected beides this. In the mean while he weat plentifully, and all things gave his Friends to hope that he would again recover; but I was of another mind, as knowing well the nature of this treacherous Dieae. The ame Evening he took another Sudorifick, and lept quietly enough all night. On the 21 day the Cheek that was affected, dicovered on it ome moiture, the Fever continued as it was: Between his forefinger and his middle one there brake forth a very painful Carbuncle, which affected the whole Arm. To this there was applied another actual Cautery without any great alteration dicerned in the Patient; then we precribed him a Julep which might caue Sweat, & ome food that was nourihing, but no
Sweat appear'd, & the affected places being drier than the ret, fore-boded an ill event. At 9 in the Morning another Chirurgeon was ent for, who approved of whatoever we had done in this cae; at midnight he fell into an high Delirium o that he could not be held in his Bed by thoe which attended; about morning he betook himelf to ret, & in one hour after departed: Some of his Friends accued me of being negligent, which ingratitude I can the better bear; ince I am concious to my elf, and give thanks to God for it, that I omitted nothing which the Rules of Art required to be done.

div.head: XI.
div.p: The Wife of Cornelius Janon being fifty years old, was after he had been ick two dayes troubled with a Bubo in her Groin, and a great anxiety of Heart; but the Fever was but mall: Her Eyes (which I do much oberve in all ick perons (look'd very well; as oon as he weat, he began to confes her elf better, her anxiety was preently removed, and her Fever alo after few days: The Bubo (a Bliter being firt drawn (was dreed by a Chirurgeon with the Magnetical Arenick Plaiter: She fell ick on the eighteenth of September, and her Son on the 23d, who was taken with a pain in his Head, and refuing all Medicines, died within three dayes, but he recovered.

div.head: XII.
div.p:
Everard Tealear, a Vintner, was taken on the 28th of September, with a chilnes all over him, and then with a very great heat, his anxiety was great, and his breathing difficult,
accompanied with naueating, a pain in the Head, a trembling of the Hands, a burning of the Eyes, and an intolerable pain on the right ide of the Groin, yet without an apparent welling. I gave in my Opinion that he was taken with a Petilential Fever, and precribed ome Remedies for that purpoe; after the firt Sudorifick, the pain in the Head and Groin abated, and the Vomiting was topped; after the econd, the pain became tolerable; and by the fourth, it was wholly taken away, and the Feaver cured: Being o uddenly retored, he believed not that there was any Malignity in it, and went abroad forthwith; which I did very much diallow, accuing him of unthankfulnes to God, and foretelling that he was to uffer omewhat more evere, becaue I could eaily perceive his Health and Strength not to be confirmed, and that there was need of a further coure of Phyick to ettle it. He till refued to hearken to me, till on the day following he was attaqued by the ame Enemy, and his Wife alo; he firt complained of a pain in his Groin, and then of a Bubo, which Symptoms confirmed the truth of what I had foretold, and caued him to repent when it was too late: The fear of Death made him now deirous of repeating the Sudorificks, by means whereof, through the Divine aitance, they were both cured in nine dayes, though the Bubo continued on the Woman for a Month after.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
Albert N. on the econd of October, was taken with a great pain at the Heart, his Pule was
not to be dicerned by a gentle touch, his Countenance was like one in an Agony, he was extream prone to Vomit and to Sleep; but he was pretty well in his Senes, his Eyes were not inflamed, his Tongue moit, the Fever but mall, and the Thirt not great: The Vomiting was preently relieved by the ue of thoe things which we have mentioned in their proper place; but the Sweat came but lowly: whereupon I gave him the next day a more powerful Sudorifick, whereof we found very notable effects, but his thirt by that means being increaed, made him drink a great quantity of Beer, whereby the vomiting returned, and becaue he complained of a pain in his Belly, we were afraid of a Diarhaea; wherefore intead of Beer, we gave him this following Mixture by Spoonfuls.
Take Roe-water, two ounces; Holy-Thitle-water, four ounces; Mint-water, an ounce; Cinamon-water, three drams; our Prophylactick-Water, an ounce and half; Syrup of Myrtles, two ounces: Mix them.
And in the Evening he took this Sudorifick.
Take Confection of Hyacinth, a cruple; Treacle, Diacordium, of each two cruples; Salt of Coral, fifteen grains; our Prophylactick-Water, ten drams: Mix it for a draught.

The night after paed quietly, the Vomiting ceaed; the third day after there was a Carbuncle dicovered on the inide of the left Notril: We applied to it our Divine Plaiter, and inwardly we gave Sudorificks, and uch things as
might refrigerate; on the 4th day his Noe was oberved to be cold, and to look of a purple colour, the Carbuncle extending it elf to the Proceus Mammiformis; the Pule beat low and unequal, nevertheles he took another Sudorofick, but without ucces; for about Noon many mortal igns dicovered themelves; and although he was all along of a ound mind, yet after two hours he departed.

div.head: XIV.
div.p: The Wife of John N. Chirurgeon, in September was uddenly taken with a Fever, with drowines and anxiety of heart. I precribed this Sudorifick.

Take Diacordium of Fracatorius; a dram; Confection of Hyacinth, Lapis Prunellae, Salt of Scordium, of each a cruple; our Prophylactick Water, an ounce; Betony Water, as much as ufficeth; Syrup of the juyce of Holy-Thitle, half an ounce: Mix it for a draught.
It produced no Sweat, which was an ill Omen: The next day therefore he took this which is omewhat tronger.
Take Treacle, Diacordium, of each a dram & half; our Prophylactick Water, an ounce and half; Salt of Holy-Thitle, a cruple; Syrup of Limons, ix drams: Mix it for a Potion.
And this alo effected nothing: For variety ake in the Evening I gave her this following.
Take Salt of Wormwood, Scordium, Prunella, Antimony Diaphoretick, of each a cruple; Syrup of the Juice of Holy-Thitle, an ounce; Our Prophylactick Water, two ounces: Mix it for a Draught.
By the help whereof he began to weat, & the Fever to abate, together with the anxiety; but the third day after the Spots appear'd, which carried her off immediately.

Her Husband, after eight days, beginning to viit his Patients again, came about eight in the morning to one that was ick, when itting down on a Stool, he was uddenly o taken, that he could not rie again; about Noon, by the help of his Son and his Man, he went home, where taking his Bed, he was preently eized with a great drowines, which I call'd a Coma; becaue whatever I did or aid to him, I could not get two words from him; I preently precribed him a Clyter, and this Ointment for his Head.
Take Oil of Marjoram, a cruple; Oil of Rue, a dram; of Amber rectified, a cruple; Roemary, half a cruple: Mix them.
I advied alo that they hould endeavour to make him neeze by putting Tobacco to his Noe, and give him inwardly ome of this Mixture.
Take Anti-Epileptick water, of our Porphylactick water, of Betony and Roewater, Syrup of Stoechas, of each an ounce.

The Clyter came from him without any effect, and Tobacco did no good; he took a little of the Mixture; and about evening I precribed him another Clyter, and this Sneezing-Powder following, was blown up his Notrils with a Quill.
Take the flower of Lillies of the Valley, Leaves of Marjoram, of each half a cruple; white Hellebore, three grains: Make them into fine Powder.

By the help hereof he neezed 3 or 4 times, and a purulent Matter came from him at his Mouth, but a greater quantity of it went down his Throat; beides which, there remained a great deal of it in his Mouth, which we could eaily queeze forth by preing his Cheeks. Thee were ufficient igns of an Abceus in the Brain, and conequently of certain Death, epecially when we could not perceive that his Senes returned to him, not that he was any other way reliev'd, but on the contrary, his voice quite failed him, and he began to rattle in the Throat; nor was I deceived in my conjecture; for in a hort pace he died.

Four of his Children, and a Maid-ervant followed him; his Man was cured of a Bubo under his Arm-pit by drawing a Bliter, and by applying ome drawing Medicines. His eldet Daughter and younget Son till urvived: He had a Fever, but was not very ick; but he was handled more everely: She had a Thruh appeared on the eighth day, which took off not only the Fever, but the whole Dieae; and thus of ten in Family, but three ecaped. You have here an account of the true Signs and Effects of Malignity, which none but uch as are poes'd with the Spirit of contradiction, can deny to be Contagious.

div.head: POST-SCRIPT.
div.p: I Intended to have publihed at leat forty of thee Obervations, but being taken up with giving an account of other things which will conduce very much to the illutrating of our Art (which in their due time may be made publick) I could make no further progres in this: Make ue of thee for the benefit of your Friends, and, if you deire to ee them, put us in mind of the other.

div.p: MEDICINA MILITARIS: OR, A BOBY OF MILITARY MEDICINES Experimented.
BY Raymundus Mindererus, Late Chief Phyician of the Electoral Court of Bavaria, and of the Imperial City of Apurg.
Englihed out of High-Dutch.
LONDON, Printed for Charles Shortgrave at the Turk's-Head in St. Paul's Church-Yard. 1686.

CISTA MILITARIS, OR, A Military Chet, Furnihed Either for SEA or LAND, With Convenient MEDICINES and neceary INSTRUMENTS. Amongt which is alo a Decription of Dr. LOWER'S LANCET, for the more afe Bleeding.
Written in Latine By Gulielmus Fabritius Hildanus. Englihed for publick Benefit.
LONDON, Printed for Charles Shortgrave at the Turk's-Head in St. Paul's Church-Yard. 1686.

div.head: A Decription of a LANCET, FOR The more ecure Letting of BLOOD,

argument.p:
FOramuch as it hath been thought convenient by everal good Chirurgeons, to contrive a afe way of Blood-letting, for the benefit of young Beginners in that Profeion; and whereas Dr. LOWER of late, in his Treatie of the Heart, hath dicovered a plain and ecure way of Bleeding, and given a figure of the Lancet, which he commends for that
purpoe, I have been advied, for the publick Good, to tranlate what he hath written, and likewie give the figure of the Lancet, and decription of the Ue of it, as it is printed in the 166 page of the lat and truet Edition of his Book, Printed at Amterdam 1671. in the Author's own words.

div.p: HOw great Ebullition ometimes happens in the Blood, in what veels, and with what wift motion it is cat about every where through the Body, and if an Artery be opened how quickly, and with what force it breaks out, it hath been hitherto treated of in the foregoing Dicoure; by which it appears, how neceary ometimes Blood-letting is, to diminih its Quantity, or to top its Career, and how dangerous the Adminitration of it is, if it be performed by a rude and unskilful hand.

For it often happening, either by want of skill, or common practice of Bleeding, (which makes the Mind fearful, and conequently the Hand trembling and uncertain) that an Artery is opened, or a Nerve or Tendon cut or prick'd, whence follows Swellings, Pains, Inflammations, Gangrenes or Convulions, which put the member in danger of being cut off, or render'd ueles, I thought it might not be beyond the cope of my Treatie, if, by way of Appendix,
I hould hew by what means and Intrument any Vein might be afely and ecurely opened, (if it well upon a Ligature (though it have an Artery, Nerve or Tendon immediately under it.

Foramuch therefore as never any harm happens in Blood-letting, unles a Vein be prick'd through or lipping aide, the Lancet be put too deep into the part, the Fabrick of this Lancet is uch, and ought to be o put into the Vein, as both may be eaily prevented.

For the Lancet is o contrived, that it is not cutting on each ide, unles it be near the point, but is purpoely blunt, and made round on the lower ide, which is to be applied next to the skin, that it may more eaily lide over it, as it appears by the following Table, in which.
a the Lancet.
b the place where the upper edge of the Lancet ends in a plain.

c where the under edge of the Lancet ends, the ret of the under part being polih'd round, and thick, (but not made thicker than the upper plain part) that it may not grate or tear the skin (upon which it mut be applied) by its compreion.
Which figure of the Lancet differs nothing from a common ordinary Lancet, but that the under edge of it is blunted almot to the point.

The way of uing it is only this, that the Member being tied, and the Vein welling, the
Lancet mut be applied as near to it as poible, but o that the Lancet may be depres'd as much as may be; then the Point of it being directed upwards, it mut be gently, and by an oblique tranvere Inciion be put into the Vein: which if o directed, neither can the Vein avoid the point of the Lancet, or the parts underneath be any way offended. Which way of Blooding, as it is mot eaie, o it will never prove unhappy to any one, though but meanly skilful.

And though I do not write this to Phyicians and Chirurgeons, who are expert and frequently exercied in bleeding; yet having een many peoples health and life endangered, either by ill Blood-letting, or becaue a good Chirurgeon could not timely be called in by Phyicians, who mot commonly forbear the Practice of it, therefore I have devied this figure of a Lancet, that they may more ecurely and confidently ue it.

div.head: CISTA MILITARIS, OR, A Military Chet, Furnihed either for Sea or Land, with convenient Medicines and Intruments.
div.p:
WHilt I was in the Low Countries in the year 1612. in the City of
‚Ä¢ orsk, I was entertained with great kindnes by that Noble and Valiant Gentleman, Alexander de Schweichel, Governour of the Place and Works, who amongt the other things worthy eeing, hewed me the Military Chet of the mot Illutrious Heroe, Maurice, Prince of Orange, &c. wherein not onely Medicines and Intruments, but alo Linnen, Rowlers, and other Necearies were prepared, and dipoed all in order in a Room, but not as then put into the Chets, which were fitly contrived for that purpoe, becaue that the Garrion-Souldiers might be
upplied with what they needed for their healths; and alo that the Medicines that were wanting or decayed, might be forthwith renewed: an evident ign, and great demontration of the Piety, Prudence, and Care of this Prince towards his Souldiers. This Chet, as often as neceity required march'd with the Camp, and in the greatet and mot dangerous occaions the Souldiers were for the preent uccoured, and aited from it. Then afterwards they were carried to the next Cities, where they were taken care of by Phyicians and Chirurgeons, appointed and paid by the States: and if by chance any Souldier lot a Limb, or was lame, he was relieved, and had an Annual Penion from the States. This Pious and Chritian Contitution made the Souldiers depie all dangers, and incouraged them to be both valiant and daring.

Therefore that Generals may undertand what things are mot neceary to furnih a Chet with, I thought good to et down both the principal Medicaments, and Intruments, that a Chirurgeon, following the Camp or Sea, ought to be provided with; and if there hould be occaion for any others, he may furnih himelf at the next Shop he comes at.

The Chet ought to be o divided into Partitions and Claes, that all confuion and intermixing of Medicines may be avoided, and the Virtue and Propriety of each preerved. To this purpoe I have divided it into twenty Claes.

The firt contains purging Simples, which mut be put up in Leather-bags, except Manna
and Caia extracted, which may more conveniently be kept in Galli-pots. Thoe Bags again are to be put into other larger, and writ upon in great Characters, Purging Simples.
In the econd Clais are contained Purging Electuaries, which are to be kept in Galli-pots, writ upon, Purging Compounds: and o of the ret.

Syrups, and ditill'd Waters, are to be put into double Glaes, cloe cork'd, and tied down with Bladders. They mut be o plac'd, that they may not move, and o break each other, and their cells lined with Baiz.
Pills are to be wrapt up in white leather, rubb'd firt with oyl of weet Almonds.
Cordial Powders and Electuaries, being put into leather bags, are to be o plac'd in a eparate clais, that they may not mix with the Purgers.
Roots, Herbs, Flowers, and Seeds are likewie to be kept in Bags of Leather or Linnen, and to be o ditributed, that in the firt Clais the Roots, econd Herbs, &c.

Oyls, and common Balams, in Glas-bottles, with crewed Pewter-heads; but the pretious Chymical Oyls, as of Cinnamon, Cloves, Maces, Nutmegs, &c. ought to be preerv'd in double Glaes well topt with Cork, and waxt. The Balams likewie of thee are to be kept in Glaes, or Silver.
nguents, and Fats are bet kept in Galli-pots, or of Pewter, well tied down with Paper and Leather. And Turpentine o likewie.
Plaiters, Gums, Wax, the Sewet of Bears, Cows, Goats, and the like, which are of a olid conitence, are to be put in Bladders wrapt afterwards in Paper.

Metals, and ubterraneous Medicaments, as Vitriol, Allum, Letharge, Bole, &c. as alo Meals, mut be put into Leather-bags: but prepared Tutia, Seif Album, Otiocolla, and the like, which are to be ued in Colliriums, or given inwardly, are to be wrapt up in Paper, and put into Leather-bags, and plac'd amongt the Cordials. Let all the Bags be tied cloe, and written upon in great Letters, to prevent confuion.

Arnick, Orpiment, crude Mercury, ublimate, proecipitate, cautick Minium Troches, Spirit of Vitriol, Aqua fortis, and the like corroive Medicines, are not to be plac'd in the Chet, let the Glas, or what other things they are contained in, break, and o poil and prejudice the other Medicines, and withal endanger the lives of the ick; therefore to prevent this, it is more convenient to keep them in ome Box or Chet apart by themelves.
The Intruments are to be preerv'd in this manner. Thoe that are for cutting, and edged, as Raors, Sciors, Inciion-Knives, &c. are to be kept in Caes, the ret are wrapt in Paper, or rather in Flannel.
Thee being thus prepared and in readines, you mut take a Catalogue of all that you may preently, and without trouble, find them when you have occaion for them.

As your Chet is divided into claes, after the ame manner it is neceary to write your Catalogue; and as often as any Simple & Compound Medicine is wanting, mark it on the Margin of the Catalogue, that you may upply its defect.
All which, kind Reader, I thought good to advie: the Claes following now in order.
