CLASSIS III. Electuaries, and Powders trengthening the Heart, and noble parts.
list.item: Otrocolla, prepared to be given inwardly.

list.head: CLASSIS V. Ditill'd Waters, and the like.

div.head: CLASSIS XIX. Intruments.
div.p: Beides the above recited Medicines, it is alo mot requiite, that a Chirurgeon hould be furnihed with neceary Intruments, without which he cannot perform his duty as he ought. They may be divided into two orts, ome to be fitted for a Box, which he ought continually to carry about him in his Pocket; thee ought to be made mall and little, that they may neither load him, nor afright the Patient: the others are to be kept in the Chet, whilt occaion calls for their aitance. I never viited my Patients without a Box of Intruments in my Pocket, in the which were contained the following:
A Razor.
A pair of Sciors.

p.hi: Two Inciion Knives,

div.p: Four Lancets to bleed withall.
A crooked Knife to open Apotems.
A Flegm, to divide the Gums in the Toothach.
An Extractor, to take out forreign things out of Wounds.
A pair of Forceps for the ame ue.
Needles, to titch up great Wounds, which are to be of different Sizes, ome great, others mall, &c.

A titching Quill, which is ued in titching Wounds: it ought to be of that length, as to contain the Needles within its hollownes. Wounds of the Flehy parts only are to be titcht, nervous parts in no wie. In wounds of the face I never ue Needle, but that which is called the dry titch.
Spatula's, great and little.

p.hi: Probes.

div.p: Speculum oris, one end of which, in affects of the Jaws, and Throat, is to depres the tongue, the other to crape it.

p.hi: vula-poon.

div.p: A Burrus quill, to prinkle Powders upon Wounds or Ulcers.
A Hook, ingle at one end, and two at the other.
A Hone, to et the Inciion-Knives, Lancets, &c.

I had all thee Intruments, and many more, made me by a skilful Artit in Silver, which I ued only within the Town, Patients being les afraid of them than of Iron: but at Sea and at Camps it is not o afe for a Chirurgeon to have them of Silver, therefore they may be very conveniently made of Iron or Steel, except the Probes, which ought to be made of Lead, Copper, or Latin.

Thee Intruments a Chirurgeon ought always to have about him, as alo a Salvatory with ix diviions, which ought to be furnih'd
1. with unguentum Bailicon, 2. with ung. Aureum, 3. Apotolorum, 4. Nutritum, 5. Album Rhais, the 6. with Rubrum Exiccativum, or de Minio: it ought to be made of Horn, or ome olid wood, as Ebony, Guajacum, or Box, for Unguents are better preerved in wood, than in Silver, Copper, &c. It is alo requiite that he hath about him in a Pewter Bottle ome oyl of Roes, to anoint any wounded part, it eaeth pain, &c. as alo another pot with a digetive.
Thus much for the Intruments, which a Chirurgeon ought to wear about him; now follow the others, and firt of thoe that are us'd about the Head.
1. Trepans, by which the Skull is perforated in great Contuions, to give paage to extravaated and concreted blood collected in the head.
2. Levatories, to raie the depreed skull.
3. Scalpra's, to crape the carious skull.
4. A great Speculum oris, by which the Tongue, in great inflammations of the Jaws and Throat, is depres'd.
5. Another peculum oris, to force open the Mouth, which, as I have een ometimes in pamus's, to be o cloe hut, that a drop of Broth could not be poured in.
6. Several Intruments to draw Teeth.

7. And becaue ometimes in eating, a fih-bone or the like is fixt in the Throat, and o would uffocate the peron, therefore it is neceary for a Chirurgeon to have in his Chet uch an Intrument, as I have decribed in the 36 Obervation of the firt Century: but if
he hath it not at hand, let him forthwith make fat a piece of Spunge to the end of a Catheter, and thrut it down the Throat.
8. Intruments to draw forth Bullets from Gunhot-wounds, of which there are divers et down by Authors. I eteem that the mot convenient, whoe Decription you may ee in the 88. Ob. of the firt Century.
9. A great Saw, for amputating great Members.
10. A little Saw for the dimembring Fingers, and Toes; it not becoming a Rational Chirurgeon to eparate them with Chiels, as I have more largely hewn in my Treatie of a Gangrene, &c. chap. 17.
11. Becaue in amputating, the greater part of Chirurgeons ue a Knife, it is convenient to have one well et, and trongly fixt in a Handle.
12. A crooked Knife: its Decription ee in the above named book of a Gangrene.

13. I, in the taking off of Members, intead of a Knife, ue a Cautery, made in fahion of a Knife, well edged, and red hot: its decription is in the above named Treatie. He ought likewie to have ready other Cauteries, ome larger, others leer; ome harp, others round, which may be ued to top the flux of Blood after Amputation, or other great and dangerous Hemorages.

14. And becaue Souldiers, from their debaucheries and impure copulation, are oftentimes troubled with the running of the Reins, Carbuncles, and uppreion of rine, it is neceary a Chirurgeon hould be provided with Catheters and Syrenges.

15. For the reducing of Broken Bones, and Dilocations there are everal Intruments, both by Hippocrates, Orthaius, and other Authors, et down; but I have always found in my practice the Intrument of Ambroe Parey, which is with a Pulley, the mot convenient; epecially if you join to it the Girdle and Remora, as in the 86. Obervation of the fifth Century: it is not only the mot convenient, but mot ueful Intrument for all Fractures and Dilocations, except of the Fingers, Ribs, and Mandibles (which are et by the hand alone; it is alo little, and therefore not troubleome to carry about one.

16. A Chirurgeon ought alo to be provided with Splints of everal bignees, ome little, others big, according to the qualities of the members broken, which ought to be made of thin pieces of Wood, or of Scabbards.
He mut be provided likewie with Mortars, Sives, Skillets to boyl Cataplams in, and alo to mix up Oyntments; and with Glyter-pipes, whoe ue in Angina's, wounds of the Head, Fevers, &c. are very ueful.

The Decription and Cuts of the Intruments are given by Ambroe Parey, Joh. Andreas √† Cruce; but becaue this hould be a compleat Treatie of Chirurgery, there is added to it everal Copper-plates of the mot ueful Intruments for almot all operations, but epecially of all thoe that relate any way to the operations mentioned in this Book.

div.head: CLASSIS XX. Linnen Rowlers, and the like.
div.p: THE Chet cannot be perfectly furnihed, if Linnen, and the benefit received from it, in the application of Medicines, be wanting; for what profit Medicaments, though the mot excellent, without Linnen? epecially in great and dangerous fluxes of Blood, fractures and dilocations of the Bones, and in other accidents, where there is danger in delay; therefore you mut have always in readines Rowlers, both large, narrow, and middle-ized, Linnen cloaths doubled, which we call Compreors, or Boulter-pledgets of Tow.
Lint, which we ue to apply Medicaments upon, and to keep the lips of the Wounds aunder, that they unite not again.

Tents alo of Lint, of prepared Spunges Gentian roots, and the like, which are to be of everal izes, ome big, ome little, &c. they ought to be prepared at leaure hours, that they may be ready when occaion requires.
He mut have alo Spunges, and Oxe-bladders, which are neceary to tye down Pots and Glaes, and alo ued in Amputation.

If a Sea or Land-Chirurgeon be furnihed with the above recited things, and have about him both faithful and expert Servants, he will be able to give aitance to a whole Fleet or Army, and preerve infinites from death.

Candid Reader, I have been omewhat prolix in the etting down the Medicaments, and
other things, by reaon I deigned to decribe a mot perfect, and every way compleat furnihed Chet; but if thou art to furnih one at thy one particular charge, thou mayt elect out of them the mot ueful and neceary Medicaments; but be ure likewie that it be o provided both with Medicaments and Intruments, that out of it, when occaion requires, thou mayt be able to ait and relieve the Sick; for what thou art imployed about here, is neither Beat, nor Pretious Stones, but Man, for whom the Son of God hed his pretious blood upon the Cros: therefore if any thing be neglected, it mut be anwered before the Almighty, to whom an account of all our Actions mut be render'd.

div.head: A BODY OF MILITARY MEDICINES EXPERIMENTED.
CHAP. I. Concerning the Morals of a Souldier.
div.p:
WHereas the Old Philoophers wihed to every one MENTEM SANAM IN CORPORE SANO, a Sound Mind in a Sound Body; conidering how much it conduceth to the Health of the Body to have the Mind free from Vice and Vexation: It will behove a Souldier, as much at leat as any man, to endeavour after that Soundnes and Integrity of concience, which may inpire him with true Fortitude, unditurbed from the troubles and anxieties accompanying Impiety and Injutice. To this end, he ought,
in the firt place, be contant in paying his Duties to Almighty God, by erving Him in publick and private, by imploring the Divine protection and bleing in all his Jut undertakings, and by returning his humble acknowledgments for every good ucces. Next, he ought to erve his Prince faithfully to the bet of his skill and power, to obey his Officers readily, and to do to all others, as he would be done to, if he were in their condition.

div.head: CHAP. II. What care a Souldier is to take of his Body.
div.p:
THe Mind being thus taken care of, thou art to advie with a skilful Phyician concerning thy Body, whether it be not neceary to purge it, the better to ecure thy elf from Agues and Fevers. Then furnih thy elf with ome Mithridate or Treacle, to ue it againt Infection; taking of it in the morning fating, againt the ill Air, the quantity of a Hael-Nut. Take alo with thee a quantity of Zedoary, Angelica, Imperatoria or Materwort, and Carlina; of which thou halt do well, now and then to eat ome for the preervation of thy trength, and againt the corruption of the Air. But epecially keep thy Head and Feet warm, by the neglect of which thou mait cat thy elf into great danger. Take heed of urcharging the tomach, which is to prepare and to convey the nourihment
for the whole body, and retrain as much as thou cant thy appetite, there being nothing more hurtful to health, than when that is irregular and extravagant.
Gird thy elf well, that thy body may be cloe, and o be ecured from receiving michief in leaping, falling, torming, &c. and thy bowels from being put out of their place.

Take alo with thee out of the Apothecary's hop a powder, called Pulvis olutivus de Tribus, which is not dear. Of this, when thou needet purging, take the weight of a ducat or a little more, according to thy contitution, in warm fleh-broath or the like, early in the morning fating; o ordering the matter, that that day thou mait keep thy elf warm in thy quarter. Fat two hours after the taking of it, and then eat warm meat. The ame be done with Pulvis Sena Montagnana, and Pulvis olutivus de Tartaro.

If thou be troubled with Corns on thy feet, apply to them every day freh lard, and continue this, till by the fatnes of the lard they grow oft; and then they will fall off from the very roots without pain.

To free or ecure thy elf from Vermin, take a good quantity of Wormwood, and the inner cuttings of hore-hoofs, cut out by the Farriers when they hooe hores; boyl thee both together in half lye and half water, and o put thy hirt into it, and afterwards dry it in the Air, without wahing it out any other way, and not a Lowe will come into it. This Experiment is found approved amongt the old German Souldiers; and although there
hould be a Lowe in thy hirt, it would not tay there.

If thy feet be moit and weaty, (which is very troubleome not only to thy elf, but to others alo,) take the filings of Bras, which are ometimes ued for dut to dry moit writings with, and put ome of it into thy ocks, and walk upon it. Refreh this every other or third day, and thou halt oon be freed of that inconvenience: Nor be thou troubled, that it makes, as it will do, thy feet look greenih; for there is no hurt at all in that, ince you are not like to put them in your cap.
Take alo with thee ome Stags or Bucks-greae, to make ue of in cae thou houldt be galled any where in riding, or going on foot. Anoint the part therewith at the fire-ide, and it will oon be healed.
To prevent Rut, draw thy Sword through the fat of a Gooe or a Capon, or greae thy Arms therewith.

Take care to have always about thee a hard crut of Rye-bread; for if thou art dry, and detitute of water, wine or beer, to quench thy thirt, chew ome of this dry crut, and it will moiten thy mouth, and coniderably abate thy thirt. The ame may be done with a Leaden-bullet, rolled to and fro in the mouth, Lead being cooling.

It hath been precribed above, to take with thee the Herbs Imperatoria and Carlina. Of this be mindful; for if it hould happen, that thou houldt be obliged to tand ome hours in battel or in the field, take a piece of it in thy mouth for hunger, thirt, and refrehment,
and thou halt find, it will keep thee a good while from faintnes. But woe to thy fellows, if they want it; for they will certainly faint, unles thou be o kind as to give them a hare in thy proviion.

In the bet Apothecary-hops may be found a root, called Cotus, omewhat like Cinnamon; which hath the ame effect. And if others hould eat Onions, others drink Brandy, and I only hold in my mouth of this root the bignes of half a Pea; I hould keep in breath a good while longer than they. But take notice, that this, I peak of, is not the common Cotus, which hitherto hath been old for the true in common hops; but that which comes to us from the Indies.

If thou art a Hore-man, take a good quantity of Bay-alt, a little Brimtone, Clove, and Ginger, and mingle with it ome of the powder of the two above-aid herbs, Imperatoria and Carlina, and give it to thy Hore, or in cae of want of Provender let him have of it upon his bit, or give him ome upon a lice of bread, and it will make him trong and vigorous.

If thou art to ride in a German Saddle, the two hind-knobs whereof are wont only to be tuffed out with traw or hore-hair; get thee made two Tin-flasks with good crews, fitted for thoe places. In one of them carry Brandy, in the other Vinegar. The Brandy will erve thee in cold nights, and freh mornings; and and 'twill be good alo for thy hore, giving him a little of it upon bread. The Vinegar will be of ue to thee for the heat of the day,
wahing thy mouth with it, as alo pirting a little of it into thy hores mouth. Beides mingling it with water, it will afford thee a good cooling drink.

If it he very cold, put ome of that hore-hair, that is wont to be curried out of their mains and tails, into thy Boots. I never received on uch occaions more warmth from any thing, epecially keeping my elf dry. A Hares-skin is alo good for this purpoe, making ocks of it; but if it grow wet, 'tis naught.

Gather of the Wheel-greae that runs out at the nave of the Wheels, and would ele be lot, which hath taken in ome of the ubtance of the Iron that is about the Axel-tree, witnes its blacknes: This is a good Ointment for Hores.

When thou comet into the field, and art to lye abroad, look out for ome riing ground, that the Rain, which may poibly fall, may run away from thee: And avoid as much as is poible. Vallies, Marihes, Ditches, Meadows, and the like low and moit places.

Beides, oberve the Air, and put up thy Tent towards the Eat; which quarter though it be cool, yet 'tis wholom. But let it hould be too cool, order it o, that thou mayt enjoy that wind, which comes from between the Eat and South, as being one of the wholomet of all Airs, and temperate, the South-air qualifying the harpnes of the Eatern. Beware of the Wetern wind, epecially that which blows from between the South and Wet. The Air of Mid-night is wholome
enough and dry, but harp and piercing. Believe it, a Souldier is much concern'd in the Air; nor hath Hippocrates without caue written a whole Book De Aere, Aquis & Locis, to teach, how the Air, Water, and Places are to be dicerned and choen.

Moreover, look about thee for good clear Water, uch as grows warm and cool again ooner than other waters; and oberve this mark for my ake. I know water, that will not boyl Peae, Vetches, Stock-fih, Flounders, &c. In ome Springs Iron is turn'd into Bras, and great care is to be had in the choice of water for drinking.

But if thou cant not have Spring-water, but art neceitated to ue Pit or Ditch-water; have a care not to drink it without training, leat thou houldt wallow Frog or Snake-pawn. For I have known and had in my cure a Countrey-man, who voided, though not at once but at different times, two hundred fifty and five Frogs, and of them many in my own houe, in the preence of divers Eccleiatical and Secular Perons; and ome of the bigget of them, being dried, are till to be een in the Repoitoy of Mantua, as alo in that of Mr. Philip Hainhofer at Aupurg. And there is a Cook in the Hopital of Weenburg or Landsberg, who, (as appeared by the event) had drunk the Spawn of Serpents, out of which were bred divers Serpents in his Body, ome of which he voided by vertue of the Medicine he took, amongt which there was one of the length of a Bavarian Ell. The Man hath been ince in good health, and continues in his ervice to this day.

Wherefore it will behove you to pread your handkerchief over the Ditch-water, and o drink through it; or if you take any of it up untrain'd, quench firt a red-hot Stone or Iron in it, whereby the noxious quality will be detroyed. Or, if you lye till, and can get any Oyl of Vitriol, let ome drops of that fall into it, and you need not then fear any corruption or poyon in uch water. Otherwie, if time will permit, let it boil up and cool again, and put a crut of bread into it, and you may drink of it afely.
Thoe Waters that run out of tony hills and from under rocks, are the bet; to which may be reckon'd thoe Springs, that flow from high places, and purge themelves in clear and and pebles.

If thou meet with Beer or Wine, take heed of exces; and forbear drinking New beer that hath not yet done working, or is not ome days old, becaue new beer caueth the Strangury. And in cae this hould trouble thee, take a handful of Hay-blooms, boyl them in water, and Urine over it, drawing into thy body the warm team thereof, and anointing thy Navel everal times with warm uet.
If thou art hot, and cant not forbear drinking, make water firt; then wah thy mouth, and cool the arteries on both thy temples, and thoe of both thy writs, and then drinking will hurt thee les.

If you chance to drink whilt you are hot, (which is o dangerous a thing that ome have dyed within 24 hours after it; others have fallen into conumptive Coughs, others been
troubled with Pains in their ides and with Impotumes, &c.) then take of the leaves of Bellis or Daiy, which grows in all meadows and pature-grounds, and is green both winter and ummer, and wah them clean, and dres them like a Salad with Oyl, Vinegar and a little Salt, and forthwith eat thereof; and it helps immediately, as I know by much Experience. But this mut be ued preently, the ooner the better. I can ay with truth, that in all my Practice of Phyick for above 20 years I have not met with any Experiment of o quick an Operation from any herb, as from this. But here I mut note, that I have always ued the Red Daiy, and have not tryed the other orts; though I am apt to believe, the others may have the like effect. You mut not eat the Flowers, but only the Leaves. This Experiment hould be put up on all pots every where, for the good of Courriers, Mowers, and other labouring Men, that are wont to drink plentifully when they are hot, and thereby poil themelves in great numbers.

But to proceed; as thou art to beware of exces of drinking at all times, o thou art epecially to forbear when thou art to tand Sentinel, let thou hould fall a leep; whereby thou mayt loe thy life, at leat, thy place and thy preferment for ever.
Neither be fond of Gaming at dice, tables, &c. whence are occaioned quarrels, mitruts, deceit, wearing, and what not?

Avoid alo the company of bae women, let thou houldt be contrained to undergo the Mercurial Salivation, and with it a very lean
Diet, of thin broth, water-gruel, barley-broth, prunes, roated apples, and uch like, without any fleh-meat at all.

div.head: CHAP. III. Concerning the Phyicians and Chirurgeons in an Army.
div.p: EVery Army ought to be well provided with one or more able Phyicians, uch as are not only expert in the cure of inward Dieaes, but alo undertanding in outward Caes, as Wounds, Burnings, Luxations. Dilocations, Eryipelas's or St. Antony's Fires, &c.

Thee Phyicians ought to be no Youngters, that are lately come from Schools and Uniververities, knowing only in Controveries and Diputations, but uch as are expert in the Cure of Dieaes, epecially uch as are mot frequent in Armies. They are alo to be Men of good nature, great honety and condecenion, willing to take pains with the poor as well as the rich. Phyicians thus qualified may o gain the hearts of the Souldiers, that thee will love and honour them as if they were their Parents.

Likewie the Chirurgeons ought to be learn'd, dicreet, and affable, uch as have been long vers'd, and experienc'd, in all the operations of Chirurgery, that can ditinguih well of Dieaes, and with prudence make their judgments thereon: They ought alo to be diligent, and careful of thoe committed to their charge,
and very knowing in all manner of outward applications, as Unguents, Plaiters, Pulments, Lenitives, Stiptiques, Attractives, Digetives, Cauticks, Echarotiques, as alo their Mollifying, Diipating, Repelling, Suppurating and Mundifying, &c. Medicines. They ought to be skilful in dicerning them, and withal in knowing well the caes and times where and when to ue them, They are to be very careful in oberving the beginning, middle and end of Ulcers, Wounds, &c. ince it often may be impertinent and even hurtful too, to ue that in the beginning, that may be pertinent and beneficial in the midt of the cure, and the like.
An able and dextrous Chirurgeon is a great Treaure in an Army, and cannot be enough valued, epecially if he conult in all dangerous caes with an undertanding Phyitian.
Thee two, Phyitians and Chirurgeons, are to be intimate friends together, aiting one another without envy and pride, for the better relief and the greater afety of their Patients.

'Tis very neceary, both thee hould go abroad and travel before they undertake to practie, thereby to acquire experience, and to learn alo to convere with the more dicretion and gentlenes with all orts of humors. And when they come to practie, the Chirurgeons ought to advie with Phyitians, who are but lame Doctors, if they be not skilled in Chirurgery; ince this is the third part of Phyick, from which it can and ought not to
be eparated, being an integral part thereof. It is recorded in hitory, that above 2000 years ince, Podalyrius and Machaon, Sons to Eculapius, went both with Agamemnon in the Expedition for Troja, and there purchaed great honour by their practie not o much of Phyick as Chirurgery.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of Fevers, Hungarian Ditempers, Spotted Fevers, and other Petilential Dieaes, as alo of Hereditary Maladies, together with their Remedies.
div.p: 'TIs known eldom to fail, that in an army there reigneth ome Dieae or other, according to the nature and contitution of the Country, Air, and Diet. The reaons are;

Firt, that amongt o great a number of Men, raied from o many different places, there are to be found Men of very different tempers and contitutions, ound and unound; and amongt the latter, ome that are cabby, others corbutical, others labouring under venereal Dieaes, many inclined to dangerous and infectious Fevers, &c. all which a Phyitian mut have a watchful eye upon, and endeavour to prevent their preading.

Secondly, that Souldiers in an Army want conveniences wherewith to take due care of their health; but are often contrain'd to expoe themelves and leep in the open Air
on moit ground, the vapours whereof penetrate into their bodies; and they are careles or want oppertunities of expelling them out again by weat. Whence is caued an inward putrefaction in the blood and humours, which ometimes proceeds o far, as to aume a venemous nature, and to break out into pots, tumors, bubo's, carbuncles, &c.

Thirdly, that Souldiers commonly keep an irregular diet. Sometimes they have plenty and do upperabound; at other times they have nothing; and then being very hungry, when they come again to a place of plenty, they over-feed and urfeit; whence are bred crudities in the Stomach, and corruption, which caueth malignant Fevers in abundance. Beides, they often feed upon Meat that is unwholom, as tinking Venion, rotten Cheee muty Bread, &c. which cannot but occaion many Dieaes. And when they come to places, where Fruit abounds, as Apples, Pears, Plums, Melons, Cherries, Grapes, &c. they over-eat themelves, and thereby caue Gripings in the Guts, Diarrhaea's, &c.

p.hi: Latly,
p.U: ometimes the Air is corrupted, epecially after a great Battel, and laughter of Men that remain unburied; whereby the Air being tainted infects the living that take it in. Which is often made wore by the exhalations of low and moorih ground, and by thick Fogs.

div.p:
Thee are the general Caues of the common Ditempers reigning in Armies; againt which thou art to arm thy elf accordingly. Firt then be careful in thy Diet; eat not
greedily and indicreetly every thing that comes to hand; and though it be good, yet eat and drink not too plentifully of it, but retrain thy appetite, conidering how detructive every exces may be to thy health.

If thou cant and hat no averion from it, drink every Morning of thy own rine, which prevents corruption in the Stomach, opens obtructions in the Liver, Spleen, Mearaic Veins; which if not removed, there will follow Fevers, the Yellow Jaundice, Swellings, and difficulty of breathing. If thou art avere from doing o, eat ome Bread and Butter with Rue on it; or, if it be not hot weather, take in the morning the quantity of a Hael-nut of Mithridate or Treacle; or infue in Brandy, or rather in Spirit of Juniper-berries, ome Zedoary, Angelica, and a little Citron-peels, and drink a poonful of it in the Morning.

When the Air is corrupted, and there be at hand a Goat, rub thy elf at him, and let not the trong mell keep thee from it. Alo put Quickilver in an empty Hael-nut, cloed up with Spanih Wax, and hang it about thy neck; or the Zenechton prepared of Arenic, (after the manner by and by to be decribed) owed up in thin Leather; for if it hould touch the bare skin, it would caue Bliters and do harm. This Zenechton is a Plaiter, out of which are cut pieces of the bignes of a Dollar, which are carried about the Neck, and hang down near the Heart; keeping good a whole year. And when the infection is pat, this Zenechton being reduced to Powder, will
yet erve to kill Rats and Mice with. It is to be thus prepar'd,

Take of Yellow and White Arenic, of each an ounce, or ¬æ of an ounce; of gummi Tragacanth ¬Ω an ounce; put this gummi in Roe-water or in common water over night, and it will yield a limy Water. Then beat thy Arenic in a Mortar, and put o much of this gummed Water to it, as is neceary to reduce it to a Pate having the conitence of Dough; work it well and round it, and then cut off a lice of the bignes of a Dollar, omewhat thicker; let this lice dry in the Air, and ow it in a piece of thin Leather (well-dreed Dogs-skin is the bet for this purpoe;) carry this about thy Neck o as to let it hang down upon, and to touch the place of thy Heart. Some mix with it a proportion of the Powder of dried Toads, which I have done my elf, it being eteem'd more powerful. Some carry about their Necks dried Spiders; Theophratus commends Celondine, Leaves and Root, carried about the Neck.

Remember alo to burn frequently Juniper-wood before thy Tent; though all ordinary fires cleane the Air: Upon which account Hippocrates advied great fires to be made in Greece at the time of a great Plague, which was thought to have been remov'd by that means. Some burn only a few Chips of Juniper-roots, or ome of the Berries of that hrub, which is as effectual.

If thee means cannot be had, burn ome Gunpowder, ordering it like a Train; this purifieth the Air likewie. And the volleys
of hot made mornings and evenings in a Camp, conduce very much to the dipelling of Mit, and qualifying raw weather.
Frankincene alo, Matick, and uch other Perfumes as dry and clear the Air, may be very uefully burnt; and even a Scholars Perfume made of wate Paper is not to be depied.

If thou cant get Rue, mell often to it: And remember me for this general hint, to take good notice of all Herbs that are green Winter and Summer, and which are not eaten by Hores or Cattel; for they are endow'd with excellent virtues for the good of Man, and therefore made to grow at all eaons of the year.

When the Air is petilential, or breeding any Epidemical Dieae, then wah thy face with Vinegar every morning. If thou cant get Acetum of Rue, Elder-flowers, Lavender, Roes, Marigold-flowers, 'tis the better. Or, if you have the conveniency, prepare the following Acetum: Take Rue, Elder-flowers, Burnet-roots, white Dittany, Carlina, of each equal quantity; a few Orange or Citron-peels, (of which the latter are the better of the two,) and a little Camphire, and ome Walnut-kernels (the freher the better,) leaving the bitter skins upon them; put all thee into common Vinegar, and with this infuion moiten every morning thy Temples, Mouth and Notrils, and the beating Arteries of both thy Writs; taking down a good poonful of it, and thou hat a good preervative.

If it be cold weather, take Angelica-roots, Zedoaria, white Dittany, ome dried Citron-peels,
and a little Camphir, infue them all in Brandy, epecially in uch as is made out of Wormwood or Juniper-berries. Of this Liquor drink in the morning a poonful. But if thou be of a hot contitution, then content thy elf with the former Acetum, in which you may mix a little Treacle.

Some advie to take fating ome of the Juice of Marigold, frehly expres'd out of the Flower and Leaves, as a good preervative againt the Infection. This I have not tried; but I have often in uch caes ued the Acetum of Marigold-flowers, epecially for a Cordial and Sudorifick, and, I think, with very good ucces.

Or make an Electuary of Rue and Juniper-berries, of each equal quantity, adding thereto a double quantity of Walnuts, with their bitter skin on them, ome Figs, a little Treacle, and a little Saffron; beat them together in a Mortar, and pour on them, whilt thou art beating, as much Rue-vinegar as will reduce it to a thick Puls or Electuary: Of this take the bignes of a Hael-Nut or two, fating.

Take the Roots of the greater Burrdock, and thoe of Celondine, both well cleared, and the Bark of Ah; infue them twenty four hours in half White-wine, and half Rue-vinegar; then ditil it, and in the ditilled water mix a little Brimtone-oyl, to render it a little owrih. Of this take two poonfuls in the morning for a preervative. But if any be already infected with the Plague, let him take of the ame ix or eight poonfuls at a time, and weat upon it, it being a very udorifick
Liquor, which, under the name of Aqua Bardana compoita, hath been ued by me and my Collegues in Hopitals and other places with very great ucces. You may mix ome Mithridate with it, if you pleae.

Ele take Carlina, Imperatoria, Serpentaria, Valerian, Saxifrage, Tormentil, Gentian, Angelica and Zedoaria, all cut mall; infue them in Brandy, and drink of it a poonful in the morning for a preervative; but if thou hat the Contagion, take two poonfuls, to weat upon it, in cae the Petilential Poion be not yet broken out, and the Patients Tongue not dry; but if it be, content thy elf with the newly precribed Acetum, as being more afe, and an Inflammation being to be feared from the Brandy.

Hold Zedoar, Angelica, Lovage or Imperatoria, in thy mouth; but if thou be ubject to the Head-ach, then cut it firt mall, and infue it in Vinegar, and let it tand infued for the pace of 24 hours; then take it out again, dry it, and ue it as precribed above.

Amongt the good Preervatives reckon this alo: Take Garden-rue, beat it into a mortar, pour Vinegar on it, and train all through a cloth; mix ome Treacle with it, et it by in a glas, and take of it in the morning half a poonful or a whole. Put a little Camphir to it, if you will have it tronger.
Or put Camphir in Worm-wood-wine, and drink a good draught of it every morning

When I erved in times of great mortality, I infued in Wine Carduus benedictus, Wormwood,
Scordium, Dictamne of Creet, Burnet-roots, and Citron-peels, and after I had taken every morning a good mes of ourih broth, I drank after it a good glas of this infuion. As long as the herbs retain a bitternes, freh wine may be infued upon them.
Infue alo white and well cleaned Garlick in Acetum made of Rue, and take of it a poonful or two in the morning.

In the Apothecary-hops are Pills, call'd Petilential Pills: Among thee caue a little Camphir to be mixt, and of it let Pills be made; of which take at once three or four every week, taking them in a poonful of White-wine, an hour before upper. Thee prevent all inward putrefaction, and keep off all infection, nor do they uffer any collection, of morbifique matter within thee, though they purge not, but only keep the body oluble. They are made up of Aloe Myrrhe and Saffron. Formerly I have printed a whole Book of uch Pills, which I call'd Marocotinas in Latin; where I have decribed their vertues at large.

For the Rich may erve what follows; Take Terra Sigillata, Bolus Armenus, Pulvis Alexipharmacus, or Bezoardicum Nicolai, or the Cordiales Alexandrini Benedicti; item Species de Hyacintho, Aqua Stapediana, Acetum Theriacale, or the Red Hungarian Powder; all thee erving not only to preerve, but alo to recover, by Gods bleing.
Provide out of the Apothecaries-hops Patils of the extract of Angelica or Zedoaria; take one or two of them in thy mouth every morning, and there let them melt down.

Keep thy body clean every way; be chearful; avoid rahnes; nor be affraid, conidering that many have been infected by fear, terrour, and melancholy. Chear thy elf up now and then with a glas of good and incere Wine, but not to exces. Never fating, nor never full. One that is empty will oon be caught with this ditemper, epecially if he live amongt infected people. If he do, let him drink a good draught of Wormwood-wine, Juniper-berry-wine, Roemary, Sage, or Zedoar-wine; which may keep thee from many dangers. But remember, not to drink more of it than will chear thee up and revive thy Spirits. At leat, drink a little Wine with Camphir and Vinegar, kindling the Camphir and letting it burn in the Wine, o as to let it ink into it; for if it burn on the top, it will there remain wimming: And if the Wine be skinned over with it, kindle it again till it be quite burnt out. Take of Camphir for one draught, the quantity of a peae; but if thou be ubject to the Head-ach, then Camphir will not agree with thee.

In cae that any come to be infected, he is forthwith to be eparated from the ound, and to be laid to bed, o as his head and houlders may lye omewhat high; by which means he will be les ubject to faintnes. Then let him preently take ome Sudorifick Medicine, to make him weat; for if the poyon be not peedily driven from the heart, the Patient is lot. You are alo to take great care, that this Ditemper prevail not, and to endeavour to dicover it before the Patient be quite diabled:
For, as oon as any begins to droop, grows melancholy, faint and feeble in his limbs, o as that he is hardly able to hold up his head, drawing his breath with difficulty, letting his head fall to and fro, loing his tomach, growing yellowih about his eyes, with the apples of his eyes tanding out, finding head-ach, interrupted heats and colds; as oon, I ay, as thee ymptoms appear in times of the Plague, Spotted Fevers, Hungarian Dieae, &c. you may then look to it by times; foramuch as uch Patients, that are already infected, go often about until the ixth or eighth day, as I have known my elf, until the lurking poyon of the heart has got the prevalency; and then the poor Patient is quite cat down, and often dyes in very few days, and even in a few hours. Wherefore thou art not to tay, till the wellings and boils appear behind the ears, under the arms, &c. or till the Carbuncles, Bubo's, and the like, break out; but thou art immediately to make ue of the bet Medicines, thou cant be Mater of, to drive out the poyon, if thou wilt ave thy life. I never found any thing, that was coniderable, done in the Plague, by means of Purging and Bleeding; but rather on the contrary, all thoe that had Spots, if they were Purged or let Blood, oon after died. However, I will precribe nothing magiterially to any man; let every one endeavour to do, what he can give a good account of. I have, together with my Collegues, treated many hundreds in our Hopitals infected with the Plague, without ever opening a Vein, and

yet we have by Gods bleing recovered near 600 perons, beides thoe that by the ame mercy we have cured in their everal Houes.

Now to procure weat in the very beginning, take the quantity of two Hael-nuts of Treacle, diolve it in common Vinegar; but if thou cant have a cordial Acetum, made of Roemary, Lavender, Elder-blooms, Rue, Roes, or Elder-berries, ue it much rather, and give it the Patient to weat.

Or take the roots of Celondine, boyl them in Vinegar, and diolve ome Treacle in it: Or take Carduus benedictus, Rue, Petaites or Butter-burr, a little Angelica, Zedoaria, or Saxifrage-roots, boyl them together in half White-wine, and half Vinegar, or only Water, diolve a little Treacle or Mithridate in it, and let the Patient take it warm, to make him weat.
Mithridate hath the like virtue with Treacle, yet neither of them are afe to take for Women with Child, old Perons and young Children.
You may alo make ue to good purpoe of the Saxon-powder, taking of it the weight of a Ducat in Caduus benedictus, Scabius, or Sorrel-water; which Powder is thus to be prepared:

Take Valerian half an ounce; Celondine, or Nettel-roots, of each one ounce; Polypody, Althaea, (or Marchmallow,) wild Angelica, of each two ounces; of garden Angelica, four ounces; of the rind of Laureola, (or Lowry,) an ounce and an half: Thee roots are to be dug up in their bet trength, viz. between the middle of Augut and the middle of September, and being
cleaned, they are to be cut mall, and then put in a glazed pot, pouring a harp Vinegar upon it, o as to cover it two inches high. Then lute on the cover with a lute made of whites of Eggs and Flower; let all be boiled upon a gentle fire; then pour off the liquor, and dry the roots, and reduce them to powder, mixing with it ome 26 berries of Herbe Paris, (or One-Berrie (which look like Pepper-corns, very good againt poion; and thus the powder is made. This herb grows in hadowed and moderately moit places; I have found of it everal times in Kohinger-wood near Ingoltad: It hath four leaves on one talk, and one berry on the top. An herb belonging to the family of Solanum's or Night hades; whence the leaves of it do very much cool Inflammations, epecially thoe of the Eyes, when laid upon them.

Take notice of Sorrel, bruie ome of it and pour Vinegar on't, (the Rue acetum is the bet,) and train the juice through a cloth; put into it a little powder of Angelica, about the weight of half a Ducat; or of the root of Dictam, or of Butter-burr, or a little Treacle or Mithridate, and give it to weat.

On this occaion of mentioning Dictam, I mut add, that in our Countrey there grows only the white Dictam, which is, among others, an excellent Antidote, but you mut take of it the double quantity and weight to that of Creta. You may boil of the root of half an ounce in half White-wine and half Vinegar, or, intead of the Wine, in Carduus benedictus water; and drink of the Decoction warm, and
put your elf to weat; or take of the powder of it a drachm and an half in warm broth with a little Vinegar, for the ame purpoe.

The Dictam of Creta hath hairy leaves and purpureous blooms, and is ued in the prepation of Treacle. This herb by its odour drives away Serpents. The wild Goats being hurt by any Arrows eat this herb, and 'tis aid, that by this means the Arrows fall out of the wound. This perhaps hath no other ground than that of the Poet Virgil, affirming that Venus with this herb healed her Son Aeneas when wounded in the War. His words are Aeneid. 12.
Hic Venus indigno nati concua dolore;
Dictamnum genitrix Cretaea carpit ab Ida,
Puberibus caulem foliis & flore comantem
Purpureo, non illa feris incognita Capris
Gramina, cum tergo volucres haeere agittae.

About this time came in the Hungarian Infection, which was a Dieae that bred uch a a putrefaction in the bodies of Men, that even when they were near death, they fell a vomiting but that with uch a tench, that no body could endure it. Here thoe Medicines do well, that preerve the body from putrefaction; for the Plague, Spotted Fevers, and the Hungarian Ditemper, proceed all from inward corruption. And of them, the Plague attacks the Spirits reiding in the Heart, and o killeth very quickly; whereas Spotted Fevers have their eat in
the Blood, and therefore do lat twelve, fourteen, and ometimes twenty days before they kill. But the Hungarian Dieae is eated chiefly in the putrified Phlegm of the Head and Brains; whence thoe that labour under it, are tormented with great and maniacal head-ach.

But though thee three Dieaes have their rie from one and the ame caue (Putrefaction,) and are to be cured by the ame remedies; yet is therein required the dicretion of a prudent Phyitian, for the ordering and precribing of Medicines according to circumtances.

Take a drachm of Zedoary, give it pulveried to the Patient in Acetum of Rue, or Elder, or Marrigold flowers, or even in common Vinegar: Let him weat upon it. 'Tis good againt all orts of venom, and caueth a weet breath, as reiting inward corruption.

In the Apothecary Shops you find an Electuary, called Diacordium, found by that famous Phyician Hieronymus Fracatorius. It is like to Treacle and Mithridate; only 'tis red from ome Ingredients giving it that colour. This may be ued with afety by Women with Child, young Children and all orts of Perons, whereas, as was aid above, Treacle and Mithridate may not. It is made chiefly of Scordium or Water-Germander, which hath the mell of Leek when bruied.
Galen in his firt Book De Antidotis, Chap. 12. writeth, that when in a great Battel ome lain Bodies chanced to fall upon this Herb, they rotted not as far as they were touched by this Herb.
The aid Fracatorius did compound this his Diacordium out of this Herb Scordium, Tormentil, Serpentaria, Gentian, Bole Armeniac and Terra Sigillata, and uch like Ingredients.

It is chiefly to be ued in the hot Dieaes of the Head; which I have done many a hundred times. Take of it the weight of about two ducats in common Vinegar, or in Elder-water, or rather in the expreed Juyce of freh Sorrel, and weat upon it. 'Tis very good epecially in the Hungarian Sicknes and other venomous and infectious Dieaes. To young People you may give a leer quantity, and proportionably you are to leen the Doe for Women with Child or in Child bed, and little Children.
Beides take notice of the Powder of Doctor Heius, which hath been ued with great benefit, and is thus prepared.

Take a drachm of Sugar-candy, a quarter of an ounce of pulveried Ginger, and a drachm of Camphir; reduce all to a fine Powder; give of it to the infected Patient the weight of a drachm in Vinegar mingled with the Water of Marigold flowers, Scabious or Sorrel, and weat upon it. If you have none of thee Waters, then look that the Vinegar be not too harp, and to that end dilute it with ome Wine and Water. Mean time, though in this cae I highly value Camphir, yet in tead of Ginger I would ue Zedoary, Saxifrage, Carlina or Imperatoria, or the true Petaites or Butter-burr.

Again, Brimtone is none of the meanet Remedies in thee infectious caes; for it preerves
the Body from Putrefaction. Wherefore take of the noble Flowers of Sulphur a quarter of an ounce, being ublimed from Colcothar; add to it one cruple of Camphir, an ounce of the Spirit or Oyl of Cyprian or Venetian Turpentine. Put all this into a Glashead, lute it well and put it upon hot Sand or Ahes, whereby the Oyl of Turpentine will come to open the Brimtone, and produce a red colour like a Ruby, or at leat as yellow as a high-colour'd Hyacinth. Of this give ome to the Patient three or four times, mingled with a little Treacle, or in Sorrel, Cardobenedictus, or Scabious-water. This Balom is excellent alo in ore Breats that are growing purulent, taken in warm broth, or in a good Wound-drink. But this mut be in caes of no great heat or inflammation, in which it would be dangerous.

Amongt all the Remedies, which erve againt Infectious Dieaes, that of Henricus Stapedius, to be found in my Book de Petilentia, is an excellent one, and perhaps the bet for curing as well as preerving; of which half a poonful being taken fating, is able to keep a Man well for twelve hours or more: But if any be already infected, he mut take of it at any time immediately, to the quantity of a poonful and an half, or two poonfuls, for weating. Which is to be repeated every eighteen or twenty four hours, to make the Patient weat, till he recover, or till the Petilential Boyls and Carbuncles break out behind the Ears, under the Arms, or elewhere. This Water, though it be omewhat
dear, yet its vertue countervails its price. The older it grows the more vertue it hath.

Many have acribed great efficacy to the Blood of Animals: Thus old Democritus, (witnes Galen,) prepared an Electuary of uch Blood, called Diathaemat√¥n. Some eteem much the Blood of Storks, becaue they eat Toads and Snakes; others value the Blood of Hens, becaue they eat Spiders and other venomous Inects. I hould eteem mot the Fleh or Blood of Badgers; which is to be dried in the hade, and that done, you mut mix with it Saffron, Camphir, and ome or other of the Anti-petilential Roots, as of Angelica, Zedoaria, or the like, together with a little live Brimtone to the quantity of a ducat; which is to be taken in Acetuni of Rue, or Marigold-flowers, or Walnuts, and in cae of want of thee, in common Vinegar: Upon which the Patient is to weat. If thou art a good Huband, have ready a good Acetum of Rue, Walnut-kernels and Marigold-flowers, taking the greater quantity of Rue; and as you ue it, fill it up again with Acetum of Elder-berries.

The Rich do ue for their Phyick in the time of the Plague, the red Hungarian, as alo the Imperial red and gray Powder, Bezoar, Harts-horn, Antidotum Matthioli, Terra Sigillata, Bole Armeniack, Scorzonera and Contrayerva, Species de Gemmis, Diamargariton de Hyacintho, and other high Medicines, of which I have largely dicoured in my above-cited Book De Potilentia. But I, though I have ued uch Remedies among the Rich, yet I content my elf commonly with the plainer
and mot common Medicines, of which I have more knowledge and experience.
The Pickle of Ebulus or Walwort, (alias Dane-wort, or Dwarf-elder,) which is of kin to Elder; as alo the Pickle of Juniper-berries, are alo of great ue in this cae.
The Phyicians of Ausburg made great ue, in the year 1572. of the red Imperial Powder; the compoition of which is in the Augutan Dipenatory at large, as alo in my Book de Pete.

Thee are the everal means to provoke weat, which I eteem to be of great efficacy for that purpoe upon a udden. And though Souldiers have not the conveniency of a Bed for weating, when they are in a march, and often cannot put off their Cloaths for many nights together; yet let them ue uch udorifick means: for, though they cannot weat outright, yet they may fall into a dampih moiture, which if it trike not in again, may prove as good as a weat. Yet in this cae he mut turn his Shirt: Quod non facit udor, praetat id tenuis udor.

But here is to be noted, that 'tis not enough, once only to give a udorifick Medicine to an infected Body; conidering that the venom, like a raging Sea, is toed to and fro every way. And though it hould eem to thee, as if by thy approved Antidote thou hadt overcome the Dieae, the ymptoms of it excepted, yet thou art not to trut in this cae; for I my elf have been ometimes deceived, and hard put to it to make good what by confidence I had omitted. Wherefore you mut not trut
to the once taking a udorifick Potion or Powder, becaue uch malign and lurking Dieaes, that keep no titch, do indeed fly the firt time from thy Medicament, and hide themelves under it, but they are wont uddenly to re-appear. Wherefore you mut repeat the Antidotes, that were firt adminitred to you, for the time of 16, 18, 20, or 24 hours, according to circumtances, and o long and often, till you judge your ick Brothers or Friends Heart ecured from the infectious Venom.

When the weating is over, thou mut then refreh thy Patient, firt by drying him well, and next by giving him a little Vinegar to tate in a poon. The Rich may afford ome lices of Citron, of which Theopompus Chius writeth, that the Tyrant Clearchus Heracleota, who lived in Pontus, having poioned many People, the vertue of Citron was at length found out, of which a lice being eaten proved an effectual Antidote againt it. The ame vertue may be found in a lice of a common Apple; and the Syrupus de Pomis is one of the Cordials of our hops.

But the thirt, that ues to follow upon weating, will not be quenched with o mall a matter; wherefore take three parts of water, one part of Vinegar, and, if the Patient be not too hot, one part of Wine, mixing ome Sugar therewith, and of this let him drink a good draught, and it will cool and refreh him.

Beides, take ome of the guts of Hens, and ome lices of Radih, prinkle them with
Vinegar and Salt, and bind them to the oles of his feet; this will draw away the heat. But let not the Radih lye too long upon them, becaue it will give a tink that may increae the head-ach, wherewith the People that have the Plague are commonly troubled enough without provoking it. Moreover you will do well to tye about his writs ome Rue beaten with Vinegar. Anoint his Loyns and Back-bone with the Unguent of Roes, or with freh Butter; but if there appear any Spots, forbear to anoint him, let they hould be driven in.

You will do well to have Epithemata of good things about you, as of Roe water and Elder-vinegar, to lay over the Heart; with which mix ome Camphir. But if you find any thing of Specks, &c. broke out, you mut ue no wet thing.

Anoint his Heart with Oyl of Scorpions, take the Oyl of Sea-blooms and of thoe Earth-worms that appear after rain, of each ix ounces, of St Johns-wort Oyl two ounces, of freh Elder-blooms and Rue, each a handful and an half, of the Acetum, of Marigold-flowers and Roes, each about three ounces, of live Spiders forty five: Boil all thee together, till the Vinegar be o qualified, that when 'tis thrown into the fire, it caue no cracking there. Then train it, and in this trained Oyl put a matter of five and twenty Spiders more, of the bigget ort, and add to it of Camphir diolved in the Spirit of Roes half a drachm; let it tand in Balneo Mariae or upon hot embers for twelve hours, and then
put to it of Treacle and Mithridate, of each half an ounce, and let them work together. With this Oyl anoint the eight Pules, viz. both Temples, behind both Ears, both Hands, and both Knees, as alo the Heart. And this is an excellent Succedaneum to Scorpion-oyl, much ued by the Germans.

Beides, you mut refreh and trengthen the Patient with convenient Meat and Drink; I mean with good Fleh or Barley-broath, with a little Vinegar in it to make it avoury to him who will have appetite to little ele, till he have haken off this venomous Ditemper; which when he hath done, his tomach will be o keen, that you will find work enough to keep him from urfeiting.

Be alo careful to keep thy Patients Body open; if he be obtructed, ue a Cliter, or take Butter or Hogs-greae, mixing a little Salt with it, or, if it be to be gotten, a little Micetrickles, and put it into his bowels. Phyick at the mouth for this purpoe is not always afe: When the Patient is dicharged of the venom, a little liquor of tew'd Prunes with ome Senna-leaves in it will do well for opening the body. Some freh Butter eaten in the morning, or melted in warm Broath, and taken down, is wont alo to keep the body oluble.

The Drink of thee Patients may be, Water with ome Bread oaked in it; or take of uch Water, wherein Bread hath been oaked, one quart, and a little Vinegar, with two or three poonfuls of Kitchin-ugar, mingling it well together. If you have no Sugar, ue uch Water
with Vinegar alone: This affords good Drink in malignant Fevers. Among the Romans it was drunk by the Souldiers, under the name of Poca.

You may alo take a handful of well cleaned Plantain-roots, and boil them up in three quarts of Water, and then decant the Water, which though it be omewhat bitter, yet 'tis very good in Fevers, and a good Drink in hot Ditempers.

If you have Oyl of Vitriol, let a few drops of it fall into clear Water, mingling it well; and you will have a factitious Sawer-brun or Acidula. But ue no Metalline Veel for this purpoe. With this kind of Water many People have been erved in all orts of Fevers; the Oyl of Vitriol, in uch Ditempers, if rightly ued, being very beneficial.

But if a Man hould have with it any Pulmonick Dieae, in that cae he mut forbear acid things, and ue Liquorice, and content himelf with Ptiane. Nor is it at all good to ue acids in Petilential Pleuriies.

And ince on this occaion we mention this cae, and we having above given warning, not eaily to blood in Petilential Dieaes; yet may Venae-ection be ometimes, upon good conideration, ued in that Pleuriie, provided it be done in the very beginning, and the Patient be trong and full of Blood. Yet this is not to leen the blood, but only to give it vent; but before bleeding the Patient is to weat by taking ome of the above pecified Antidotes.

If the Patient have violent Head-ach, lay on his head Vine-leaves or freh Cabbage-leaves;
and, if you have no Alablater-alve, take two parts of Vinegar, and one part of Oyl of Olives (the Sea-blooms Oyl, and Elder-Vinegar were better;) dip long rags of linnen therein, and having well queez'd them again, lay them lukewarm over the face and temples. Even Vinegar alone is good. Of uch Applications you may make many, of Acetum of Roes, Elder-blooms, and the like, with a little Camphir. The expreed Milk of Peaches is alo very effectual in this cae.

If at the going off of this Ditemper, a hot defluxion hould fall into the Eyes, take Camphir and infue it in water, and often moiten the Eyes therewith; and if it hould be cold and windy weather, you will do well to keep your elf out of the open Air, and not to let this water dry up in your Eyes in the cold wind.

In cae of having lot thy hearing, take of thy own Urine, and with it wah thy Ears within, but withal dry them very well, becaue that moiture is very noxious to the Ears: And it often happens, that after the Hungarian Sicknes People grow deaf or hard of hearing. Others put the water of Carduus-benedictus ditilled with Wine into the Ears, or the Oyl of bitter Almonds.

If thy Throat well, or the Palate of thy Mouth be fallen down, gargarize thy Throat with warm Milk, wherein Figgs have been boil'd, or weetned with Sugar. The Flowers of Phyllirea or Mock-privet, which grows in the Hedges, boiled, and ued for a gargarim, heals alo a ore Throat. The ame doth the
middle rind of Oxyacantha or Haw-thorn, if boiled, with a little Allom diolved in the Decoction. If you have the Juice of Mulberries, mix a little Honey of Roes with it, and often take a little thereof. The Roots of Sloes boiled in red Wine, and the Mouth often wahed therewith, is alo very good.
If thou hat the Squinancy, boil Scabious in Meath, and drink thereof warm, when train'd. Beat Turnips and fry them in Butter or Oyl, and clap them in a cloth round about thy Neck.
If thou cat up blood, take Moue-ear, Ground-Ivy, Cumfrey; boil them in half Wine and half Water, or in Meat, and Drink often of it. But if the Plague reign not, open firt a Vein.

For a violent Cough, boil white Turnips, well cleaned in common water; throw away this firt water, pour on other water, and in it let the Turnips boil till they grow oft. Strain this water, weeten it with Sugar, or infue in it Liquorice cut mall; and drink of it mornings and evenings warm. Or make a Decoction of St. Johns bread, and drink it, abtaining from all four and alt things.

The bleeding at the Noe is alo incident to perons infected; which is no good ign, though in ound perons it often frees from the Headach and cools the Liver. If this bleeding be too violent, clap Ice-cold water about the Patients Neck, or let him put his Pudenda in cold Vinegar.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Inflammation of the Tongue, its rie, and concomitants, together with the Remedies.
div.p: WHen the Tongue is inflamed, the whole Oeophagus or Weaand is inflamed alo, and this from beneath upward, becaue the inward fire ends up its moak all along, as it were, that chimney, which like oot ticks to it, drying and blackning the ame.

But there is another Inflammation, much more dangerous, which taking its rie about the Heart, and therefore is call'd the Inflammation of the Heart, which proceeds from the great inflammation of the orifice of the Stomach, ituate near the heart, in which is inerted the ixth pair of Nerves, which maketh the aid orifice very enible of any pain. This part being eized by o great an inflammation, which is venomous withal, it mut in a manner harden, and hrink; and this heat is of that extent that, the inner Membrane of the Stomach & that of the Tongue being one and the ame, what befalls the Stomach, the Tongue mut needs be enible of it. Whence it comes to pas, that if the Gall overflows and paeth into the Stomach, the Tongue preently finds the bitternes of it: or if the Stomach be full of lime or foul, or the like, the Tongue is oon affected therewith.

There is another kind of Inflammation, by the Latins called Prunella alba. This is of the ame kind with the ret, but not of the ame degree; for 'tis not of o dry a nature, as the others are, but commonly is moit, yet overlays all the Gums, the Throat, and the Weaand with uch a tough white lime, like a kind of Leather, and o covers the Almonds with the ame, that ometimes it can hardly be removed even with Intruments. The Tongue is as if it were cruted over with dough, the Gums like an Oven that by the heat of fire is burnt white, the Almonds cover'd as 'twere with white leather, and the Palate of the Mouth likewie. And in this cae if the Patient will peak, he lalls and tutters, his Tongue being burthen'd with a load of lime; or, if he make his Tongue wagg, the lime pins out like a thred, and o invades the Teeth as if they were laid over with varnih. And when this varnih on the Teeth grows black (as I have often oberv'd it to do) and drieth on them, 'tis a mortal ign; of which Hyppocrates aith, Quibus in febribus livores circumdentes nacuntur, his fortes fiunt febres, 4. Aph. 53.

Thee are the three orts of Inflammation; for which let us now eek out the Remedies, beginning from the lat, the White. This is not to be mater'd by gargariins alone, but the hand mut be employed alo. Take therefore Cotton-wooll, or Flax, and wind it about a tick or rod, and dip this in Vinegar, and rake his Throat and Gums therewith, yet taking care not to make it raw; let him gargarie between, and wah well his Mouth
with Water and Vinegar, or Mul-berry-juyce. Privet that grows in the hedges, or the middle rind of Haw-thorn, boiled in Water and a little Vinegar, then trained, with a little Sal-armoniack put into it, is in this cae an excellent gargarim; but if there be bliters upon the Tongue, or elewhere, then take intead of Sal-armoniack a little unburnt Allom, and mix it therewith. If you can have the Juyce of Turnips, or the Juyce of freh Houe-leek, diolve therein alo a little Sal-armoniack, and ue it to wet the tick, wherewith thou cleanet the Throat of the Patient; dipping it often therein, and carrying it about the
vula or Palate of the Mouth; and you will ee lumps come away as big as Peae. The skin is under this Prunella alba fair and red, but tender. Whilt thou art cleaning the Patients Mouth, let him often gargarie with the Waters above-pecified, and he will clear his Mouth of the looen'd lumps. If thou cant get Mulberry-juyce mixt with Honey of Roes, the Mouth will heal the better; for upon this ort of Inflammation there uually follows a Putrefaction of the Mouth; and in cae thou perceivet any uch thing, take Wood-orrel, and the above aid rind of Haw-thorn, make a Decoction of it, and put in it a little Allom, and often gargarie with it. Clean thy Teeth from the lime with Water well harpned with Vitriol.

The common Inflammation of the Mouth may be cured with frequent wahing of the Mouth, taking a gargarim made of Houe-leek, Lettice, Night-hade, or Self-heal Water,
mixing a little Honey of Roes and Mulberry-juyce with it. Of this gargarim the Patient is alo to wallow a little, thereby to moiten the Throat.

Some take Houe-leek, and beat it, and put to a pound of it half an ounce of Sal-armoniack, mixing it well together. And o they put it for ome days in an earthen pot glaed under ground; then they ditill of it a Water in Balneo or in Sand: Which is excellent both to drink and to gargarie, though the Sal-armoniack make it a little unpleaant.

But there is nothing better to allay this Inflammation than Niter; which is o well known amongt Souldiers, that they are wont to give one another Gunpowder to drink, which Powder performs this effect not upon the account of the Coals or Brimtone, but the Saltpeter.
For this caue Experienced Phyitians and Chirurgeons endeavour to purifie Niter for this ue, that it may have the greater effect; and this they do in manner following:

They take of the puret Niter they can get, as much as they think fit; they beat it to a fine powder, and melt it in a large Crucible, & whilt it boils up and foameth, they pour into it a little powdered Sulphur, and o let it boil together, till the blew Sulphur-flame ceaeth; then they cat in more freh Sulphur: Which they repeat often, and then pour out the Niter into an earthen veel glaed, making Lozenges of it, of which they put one pulveried into a quart of limpid water, and o give the Patient to drink of it as much as he
needs to quench his thirt. Or they give of this purified Niter to their Patients, labouring under this Inflammation, the quantity of a ducat or half a ducat weight in Broath, or in Ptian, till they find the Tongue cleared of its lime.

The ue of Salt-petre thus prepared removeth alo the Inflammation of the Heart, epecially if it be melted upon Lead, and then proceeded with as before. For Lead is a coniderable cooler, of which cooling quality the Niter, whilt it is melting upon it, taketh in not a little. Let then your Lead melt, and when 'tis melted, diolve the Niter upon it, and then, to purifie it, cat ome Brimtone into it, as was aid above, till it be cleaned from all impurity; and then give of it to thy Patient two or three times a day, according as need hall require.

Otherwie, take live Crafihes and freh Houleek, beat them together in a Mortar, queeze out the Juyce, with it mix a little Sal-Armoniack, or a pretty deal of thy prepared Niter; make a Potion of it, and give of it even cold to thy Patient, repeating this everal times, every eight or ten hours once, according as you hall ee occaion.

Or, take freh Lard, (if it be alted, draw it through hot Water to unalt it,) and cut a lice of it two fingers large, and of the thicknes of a knives back; put this into the Mouth of thy Patient, it is an excellent Remedy againt this Inflammation; of which I hall give the reaon hereafter. I have een wonders done with it. But if thy Patient do rave, then faten this lice of Lard with a Thred and Needle to his
Shirt or Doublet, let he wallow it. Or take freh Butter, and put it in cold Water, and of it give thy Patient at a time the quantity of a Hael-nut to hold it upon his Tongue, and let it melt there; which will keep the Tongue always moit. And if thou work among this Butter ome of thy prepared Niter, it hath a wonderful effect, though the tate be not pleaant.

I promied above to explain the Reaon of the Cure of thee Inflammations. When you take a Gargarim of the Waters of Night-hade, Wood-orrel, Knot-gras, Endive, Houleek, and the like, mingled with Vinegar, you do well, but this is not enough; the reaon is: If you wet a piece of Leather, you make it indeed limber, but when it comes to be dry, it grows hard and hrinks, except you greae it over with ome fatty matter, and then it will remain mooth. So it is with the Tongue; though it be made clean with Gargarims, yet will it become again rough and untoward, unles ome fatnes be ued: For which caue I have directed to ue Lard, or Butter mixt with Niter.

If the Almonds be welled, thou mut abtain from all owre things, and prepare a Gargarim of Figgs, St. Johns Bread, Mallows-flowers, Liquorice, Elder-canes, mixing with it ome Roe-honey, or Juyce of Walnuts, or the Rob Diamorom, gargling often with it, eeing that this ymptom is a dangerous thing; for when the Throat wells of it, few Patients do ecape death, epecially if it be a Petilential Squinancy. And in cae there appear any Tumor
outwardly, take fine Flower, Milk and Saffron, making a Pule of it; and, to keep it from growing hard, mix with it Althea-alve, or Hounds-tongue-alve, the Oyl of blew Violets, Mullein, white Lillies, Camomile, or the like, adding a little Oyl of Scorpions to it, and applying this outwardly.

Make alo a Scraper of Alder-wood, if it may be had; if not, other wood will erve, though Alder be bet. Throw it into cold Water, and let it lye there, uing it as often as there is need; yet take heed of making thy Tongue ore or raw.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of Fevers, Belly-aches, Tumors of the Belly, Yellow-Jaundie, and Ditempers of the Liver.
div.p: IN Camps there is nothing more frequent than Fevers of the Stomach, ariing from ill Dyet, which Souldiers are often put to for want of better, eating what they can get, Cheee, Herbs, Fleh half boiled, tale and muty Bread, and the like. Hence is gather'd a morbifick matter in the Stomach, which caueth putrefaction, and conequently Stomach-fevers.

In this cae thou art firt to purge: And for that purpoe make ue of the Pulvis olutivus de tribus, recommended above, taking the weight of a Ducat, or a Ducat and an half, in warm
Broath, and fating two or three hours after it. Or fetch from the Apothecary of the Tabulatum Diaturbith cum Rhubarbaro, or the Diaphoenicon in tabulis, taking half an ounce at a time, and keeping thy Chamber. Or, infue Sena-leaves in Wormwood-wine, and drink a mall glas-ful of it an hour before thy breakfat: This will alo erve very well, epecially if ome Carduus benedictus have alo been fermented in the Wormwood-wine.

If thou art troubled with Gripings or Inflation of the Belly, take of Zedoar, or Angelica-roots, or Orange-peels, cut them mall, and take at a time the weight of a Ducat in hot Broath. If the Inflation be much, take in the morning the quantity of a Hael-nut of Mithridate, fating an hour after it; and if the pains of thy Belly prevail, make a Decoction of Wormwood in Wine, and drink of it as hot as thou cant; this will allay the pains, and give thee ome tools. Mean time abtain from raw Fruit, and Beer, Milk, Herbs, and uch like.

If thou art wollen, take half a drachm of Rubarb, and about the ame quantity or a little les of Mechocan; reduce it to powder, and take it in Wormwood-wine, or warm Broath, in the morning fating, and eat nothing within an hour or two after. Be careful to take down ome Treacle in the morning fating; but you are firt to be purged. Otherwie make a Decoction of the Roots of Elecampane and Pimpernel, or Swallow-wort, in Wine, and drink a warm draught of it mornings; it will provoke Urine. If thou cant bear amongt it
Wormwood, Carduus benedictus, or Centory, add them in the Decoction, and it is a good potion for the Liver.

An Herb, call'd by the Latins Euphatorium Avicennae, in Englih (I think) Common Hemp-Agrimony, hath a great operation in welled People, drinking of the Decoction thereof, made in Wine. Beides, ue in this cae Parley and Smallage-roots in thy meat. Boil Hore-radih, and drink of the Decoction warm in the morning. Thy ordinary drink is to be a water, in which hath been boiled a good quantity of Cummin, Annis or Fennel. You may alo now and then drink a little Wine, welled people having no great heat in them.

From thee obtructions of the Liver and Mearaic Veins comes difficulty of Breathing and a dry Cough, which occaions the Inflation of the Belly, and helps to entertain the crudities and indigetions: Mean time there ueth to follow upon this the Yellow Jaundie. For this, take the Roots of Cyclamen or Sow-bread, reduce them to powder, and take the weight of half a ducat in Meath, or Wine mixt with a little Honey, weating upon it; and you hall find your heets dicoloured of a yellowih colour. In the ame manner make ue of the eed of Aquileja, or Columbine. I have reduced thee three to powder, and mixt them together, and given of it the weight of a ducat to weat; which hath proved very uccesful. Orange-peels ued in like manner, do alo much good in this cae. The bitter Centory boiled in Meath, and a good draught drank of it warm in the morning, is alo very good. Likewie a Decoction
of the white Hore-hound and Chicory-roots is alo ued to good purpoe in this cae. Thee things expel alo Worms, if any do lodge within thee; for which may alo be ued the Souldiers Pills of Aloe, called Marocotinae. In this cae Vinegar of Squills is alo an excellent remedy, taking of it in the morning early a poonful, two or three, and exerciing after it. It will open the Breat, and make you expectorate phlegm and lime in abundance.

If you be troubled with Wind and Gripings of the Guts, be careful to have your Body oluble. Boil Calamus, cut mall, in Broath, drink of it hot, putting a little Angelica, or Materwort. Do this mornings and evenings, and beware of drinking cold, and abtain from all Milk, keeping your elf very warm, epecially about the Feet, which you will do well to bathe with a Decoction made of Aarabacca, Camomile, wild Trefoil, wild Marjerom, wild Thyme, putting a little Salt into it. For your drink, boil Cummin, Annis or Fennel in Water, and now and then a glas of Wine may do well.

Thee Gripings may alo be cured with drinking very bitter Wormwood-wine, as hot as you can endure it. This is alo opening. If you boil Elecampane and Orange-peels with the Wormwood, it will have the greater effect. And if you add to it Allium Sylvetre (Crow-Garlick) you have an excellent Medicine for this purpoe. This I have ued my elf, and found preent relief from it, when in a very hard Winter upon a Journey I was taken with thee Gripings. 'Tis indeed a very unpleaant potion, exceeding bitter, epecially being to be drunk
hot; but the good effects will make amends for that. If the pains hould not ceae after all this, mix with it the quantity of a Hael-nut of Treacle or Mithridate, and o drink it off together.

If you can get Malvay, mix a little Oyl of Olives with it, and drink of it warm. Oyl of weet Almonds would be better, one half of that and the other of Malvay; though thee things perhaps will not o eaily be had in a Camp. Freh Butter may erve intead of Oyl.

Ele make a Decoction of Juniper-berries, or Laurel-berries, and Elecampane in trong Wine, and drink a good draught of it mornings and evenings. Or reduce the Herb Carduus benedictus to powder, and drink its weight of a ducat in warm Malvay or other trong Wine; it will remove the Gripings, epecially if you mix with it a little Zedoary pulveried.
For your Meat, take Larks, if they chance to be in eaon, draw them, and fill their bellies with Garlick, and o rot and eat them.
Make a Decoction of Burnet, or of Materwort, and Laurel berries, in Beer, train it, and melt a little Butter in it, adding a little Pepper, and o drink of it hot.

For an outward Application, take the Oyl of Rue and Wormwood, dip Cotton into it, and put it warm to thy Navil. Or beat Onions, and fry them in Dill or Camomile-Oyl, wrap it up in a linnen Cloth, and apply it to thy Belly, where the pain is mot violent, refrehing it often.

The Oyl of Laurel-berries, mixing a little Juniper-berry-oyl or Nutmeg-oyl with it, may be ued with great benefit, anointing the Navil therewith, and afterwards put to the Navil a warm dry bag filled with Bran and Camomile-blooms. Or fry Cow-dung in the Oyl of Dill, or of Camomile, or of white Lillies, and apply it thus to thy Navil, keeping thy elf, and epecially thy Leggs, very warm.

If you perceive any Hydropical Ditemper in you, make a Decoction of Wormwood and Juniper-berries in Wine, drink every morning a warm draught of it fating. You may alo to very good purpoe boil with it Swallow-wort, Burnet, or Succory-roots, adding alo to it ome Annis or Fenneleed. But it will be requiite firt of all to purge with Mechoacan and Rhubarb; and now and then to repeat this purgation. Abtain from Milk, Beer, Fruit, and all raw and obtructing food. If you knew how to ue Elder, you would have an excellent Purge to free your Body from the Hydropical water, becaue the Juyce of the Roots of Elder purgeth Hydropical Perons exceedingly: But 'tis not o afe to ue it, unles you do it with great caution, becaue a very little of it taken inwardly purgeth both by tool and vomit, like Antimony. Half a nuthel full may uffice. The like effect you'l find in Elder-buds boiled, and then dreed with Oyl and Vinegar like a Salad, eating a very little of it. But I advie you not to ue too much of it; ele it will cat you into great faintnes. The juyce of the Roots of blew Lillies hath the like vertue, but is likewie to be ued with great dicretion.

Otherwie take Earth-worms, and having wah'd them clean in Wine, reduce them to powder, and take of it for ome mornings the weight of half a drachm in warm Broath or Wine, mixing a little Rhubarb with it.

The Swelling of your Leggs may be removed by heating ome Tiles and prinkling them with Wine, and clapping them about your Leggs to make them weat. For a welled Groin, take warm Milk, wherein Calamus Aromaticus hath been boiled, and weeten it well with Sugar, and apply it.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of all orts of Fluxes; as alo the Tenamus, or vain endeavour of going to tool; and the Haemorrhoid or Piles, and Marica's or ore Fundaments.
div.p: IN Wars and Camps, Bloody and other Fluxes are very frequent, caued by an irregular and ill dyet; and thee Ditempers, epecially the Bloody Flux, carry away abundance of Men. Where it is to be noted, that the Bloody Flux is infectious, and very catching.

Commmon Fluxes and Looenees may eaily be cured. Amongt other Remedies, take burnt Harts-horn, and take it often in Broath; or pulverie Medlar-kernels, and take of the powder in Broath likewie. Alo an Electuary made of Quinces and Sloes will cure them. The ame does Nutmeg, and the
Roots of Tormentil, Snakeweed, or the Roots of Cinquefoil, baked in Eggs, and eaten. Likewie the Seed of Dock, broad Plantain; item Terra Sigillata, or Bolus Armenus, and Wheaten-bread coming hot out of the oven, and dipt in red Wine, and eaten. Again, Matick pulveried, and put into Almon-milk, red Wine, or Broath, the weight of a drachm, is good for uch a Looenes epecially as comes from indigetion; adding a little Nutmeg or Galingal to it. Oaken-leaves alo, or the Rinds of Pear-trees, with a little Mace boiled in Wine, and drunk, cureth common Fluxes. Again, Bura Patoris (Shepherds-Pure) boiled in Steel-water with a little Coriander, and drunk, is alo very good; and o are Crafihes boiled in Vinegar, and the cales beaten to powder, taking a drachm of it mornings and evenings, either in red Wine or in Broath wherein in red-hot Steel hath been everal times quenched. Hawes alo boiled, and made into a thick Electuary, and trained, is beneficial, if taken in the morning fating, and an hour or o before upper, the quantity of a Walnut.

Beides, take new Milk with its Cream on it, quench therein divers times red-hot Pebble-tones, o that the Milk may grow hot of it; then mix with it two or three well-beaten Yolks of Eggs, two ounces of Sugar, melting in it an ounce and an half of the Suet of a Deer or Stagg, and about half an ounce of Albumgraecum, uing it for a Clyter, which cleaneth and healeth the Guts, and allays the harpnes of the Blood and other corroive humors, that annoy the Bowels.

But take heed of not topping too uddenly the Bloody Flux, or any other Laske; for if you do, the annoyance will remain in the Body, and caue Impotumes, Difficulty of breathing, and other dangerous Ditempers. Wherefore conult with thy trength, and if that be coniderable, make not too much hat; yet keep a bridle upon it, o as to be able to top it when there is need. Mean time, if it be without a Fever or heat, you may do much with new Milk, drinking it alo mornings and evenings warm, ome red-hot Stones having been quenched therein, and ome Sugar mixed with it, to prevent curdling in your Stomach. This Medicine was known to the famous Grecian Phyicians, Aetius, Alexander Trallianus, and Galenus himelf, l. 10. de Simpl. Med. facult. If you add a little Albumgraecum to it, 'twill be the better. I have my elf done much good with thus prepared Milk, but then there mut be no Fever; which if there be, you'l eaily perceive it by a great thirt, quick pule, hot hands, and little leep &c. For bloody Fluxes are not wont to be accompanied with haking Fevers, but only with hot fits, which pend more of the Patients trength in an hour, than haking Agues in everal days; which is to be well heeded.
Eggs boiled hard in Vinegar, and given to the Patient, that is troubled either with the Bloody or any other Flux, it will be topped.

The Roots of Tormentil, or of Snake-weed pulveried, and this powder drunk in a convenient vehicle, the weight of a drachm, is
one of the mot approved remedies againt thee Fluxes; Tormentil-roots being very powerful not only to top them, but alo to take away their catching malignity.
The Mos that grows on wild Roe-hrubs, reduced to powder, and taken in Wine, wherein have been boiled the husks of Acrons, is an approved remedy in this cae.
Scrape red Lead or Rudle, uch as Carpenters mark their lines with, put it into Wine or Broath, wherein hath been boil'd the broader kind of Plantain and Tormentil-roots; or take it in an Egg.

Hares-blood dried, and taken inwardly, is alo a tried Medicine in this Ditemper. Item, open a new-laid Egg, take out the white, and fill it up with Nutmeg, or the pulveried root of Tormentil, or of Snake-weed, and give it the Patient to eat; or put into it ome pulveried Blood-tone, and it will do good.
I have ued with good ucces the Seed of the broader Plantain, groly beaten, and roted in an Egg, againt the Flux; and I know it alo to have been beneficially ued againt the Bloody Flux.
Take of Mummy, a little Matick, Bol-Armeniack, Sanguis Dracon ‚Ä¢ , mix them together, and make a powder of them, and take of it in a convenient Liquor, the weight of a dram, once or twice a day.
