Take Rye-bicuit, and boil it in Water with Coriander, and the roots of Tormentil or of Cranes-bill; quench ome Steel in it once or twice, and give of it to the Patient to drink.
Make a Decoction of Shepherds-pure and Meadow-weet, in Water and Wine, and now and then drink of it.
Burn live Crafihes in an earthen Pipkin well-cloed, until they be o burnt as to be reduced to powder; of which give to the Patient mornings and evenings a Thimble-full or two in a convenient Liquor.

A dried Liver of a ucking Lamb, or of any other uch Animal, is very good in this cae, provided uch a Liver, before 'tis dried, be boiled in Vinegar. Let the Patient take a drachm of it twice a day. Alo the Blood of a Lamb, or of a Hind, both dried, will have here a good effect.

Take a Pigeon, Wood-cock, or Patridge, and having drawn any of them, fill them with Matick and a little Nutmeg, and o rot them on a Spit, and whilt they are roting, bate them with red Wine, and o let them rot till they grow o hard as will make them pulverable; then reduce them or any of them to powder, and take a poonful of it at a time in warm Broath.

The highet Experiment in this cae is Crocus Martis, taken in the Juyce of the broader kind of Plantain, or in a Pule of red Beans, or Rice-broath; the doe is half a dram. But when the pain is very great, you may then add to it ome opiat Medicine, as of the Trochiques de Garabe, or one only grain of Laudanum Opiatum. And give the Patient now and then a little new-made Treacle, or mix with it a few grains of the Confection of Archigenes; for of uch Medicaments a Field-Apotheque is not wont to be detitute.

For the Patients ordinary drink, boil water, and in it Coriander, dried Sloes, dried lices of Quinces, burnt Harts-horn, Matick, Nutmeg, or any one of thee; putting to it ome of the roots of Snake-weed, Tormentil, or uch like adtringent roots. Of this water the Patient may drink according as his neceity hall require.
The red Juyce of Quinces, boiled up without Sugar, is alo much to be commended in this cae, for trengthening the bowels, two or three poonfuls of it being taken at a time, and that twice a day.

In many places a drink is made of Sloes, Piloella or Moue-ear, and Juniper-berries, infuing them all in common water, and letting them ferment together. This yields a pleaant acid drink, allaying the violence of the Flux, and quenching thirt withal.
The Rich may make Granat or Quince-wine. But I have here undertaken to deliver uch things, as are parable and cheap for the poor common Souldier.

I am orry, that in the Field there is no conveniency of adminitring Clyters: For, though I precribe none without great neceity; yet Clyters being of great benefit in Dieaes of the bowels; they being to them like Plaiters, I cannot but recommend in this Ditemper Clyters of Milk, wherein Pebble-tones have been everal times quenched, mixing a little of the melted Suet of a Stag or Hind, without any Oyl or other fat. I remember, I had once a Patient of quality, that had about an hundred tools within twenty four hours, who by the ue of uch Clyters, once or twice applied,
was fully retored. The caue whereof is, that the Milk wahes the bowels, and clears them of the harp humors that annoy them; moreover, it is healing and repairing, by reaon of the Pebbles quenched therein. The Sugar is abterive, and helps to clean the injured places. The Fat ticks to the parts annoyed, to defend them from being further hurt by the ubequent humors, which running down over it, can find no tay there, and conequently caue no more hurt to thoe parts.

Yet mut you not put in any greaie Fat, or any Oyl of Olives, becaue they hinder healing; and all Oyl, except that of Lineed, Poppies, Hemp and Almonds, is very harp; and you will find, that if any drop of Oyl of Olives hould chance to fall into your Eye, no Juyce of Oranges or Limons is o trong as to exceed the acrimony of that Oyl. But of this Oyl more will be aid in the next Chapter, to which I therefore refer you. If you would have your Clyter yet milder and more anative, you may beat a yolk or two of new-laid Eggs, and mix them with it; though I have contented my elf with the Ingredients before mention'd, and found great benefit thereby. Ele you may in this cae ue for a Clyter the Cremor hordei, mixt with yolks of Eggs beaten in it; which is alo very good to wah out the bowels.

Here is no conveniency of making much ue of Apothecary-hops; ele many things might be precribed to lay upon the belly and the navil, as alo divers fermentations, and tomachical Unguents. You may therefore content
your elf with thoe plain and eaily parable means, already deliver'd, and be thankful to God for them.

But then you are alo to think upon means to obviate Symptoms of this Ditemper, and particularly Drought, which is wont very much to torment people in this Dieae. 'Tis true, Acid things do quench thirt, but they cannot be ued boldly, and therefore you mut ue them with great dicretion and warines. And as for weet things, they uually increae thirt, and do eaily corrupt, and turn into gall. Wherefore give to the Patient preerved Currans; or if freh ones be in eaon, mix a quantity of them with Honey or Sugar, and give him of it to eat upon white-Bread and Butter. Or plump dried Black-cherries, or dried Damacene-prunes in half Wine and half Water, and let him hold & queeze them in his mouth. Or, if you can, mingle ome Almond-milk with Chalybeat-water, and let him drink thereof; and this is both meat and drink. Or let him drink water, wherein Coriander and roots of Tormentil have been boiled. Or boil in water dried lices of Quinces, roots of Bitorta or Snake-weed, and burnt Harts-horn, put into it a toted crut of Rye-bread rubb'd with Nutmeg, but let it not lye in it above a quarter of an hour, let the water hould thicken and become vicous. Marmelat alo of Quinces, Black-cherries, and Sloes is proper in this cae, giving the Patient a lice of it to hold upon his tongue, and o to wallow it down.

Further, you mut learn how to remedy a Tenamus, which is more irkome to the Patient,
and, occaions more trouble to the Phyitian, than the Bloody-flux it elf, ince it night and day painfully provokes the poor Patient to go to tool, and yet to no purpoe. For this I have ued many remedies, but found almot nothing more beneficial, than Fomentations of this nature following: Take Potentilla (wild Tanie Silver-weed) Knot-gras, Mullein, and Oak-leaves, of each as much as you pleae, put them into two linnen bags, and let them boil in Smiths-water, wherein much Iron hath been quenched: Squeeze out thee bags between two boards, and let them be held alternately to the anus, as hot as can be endured. Black Pitch, uch as is found on Larch and Fir-trees, put upon a heated fire-hovel, and the fundament held over it, is alo a good remedy; & o is Turpentine, ued after the ame manner.

Again, take a black well-burnt Brick out of the hearth, heat it thoroughly, and wet it with harp Vinegar, and wrap it about with a linnen cloth, and let the Patient it on it as hot as he can endure it. This was the Experiment and Remedy of old Aetius; but he reduced the Brick to powder, and by boiling it in Vinegar, reduced it to a pule, and o put it into a linnen rag, and applied it to the fundament. You may chue which you pleae of the two.

Milk-Clyters, uch as above precribed, would alo be good, but that 'tis not afe with Clyter-pipes to vex the anus, which is already ore enough. Yet you may give a Suppoitory of Deers-uet mixt with ome Oyl of Mullein. And the grey Diapompholox, or the white Camphire-unguent,
or the like, mixt with it, would not be improper in this cae.

If there be a Falling down of the fundament, then let it often take in the fumes of the above-mention'd Herbs, adding to them the beaten talks of Sloe-hrubs, and thoe of red Roes, as alo Moue-ear, and Mug-wort. The outer bark of Elder, and of Shepherds-pure, doth alo well with it. But above all things keep the Patient warm, and let by no means any of the aboveaid teams grow cold on the ore part.

Make alo a Decoction of Garlick, and pour it hot into your cloe-tool, let the Patient it upon it, to receive the hot teams. Beides, put ome burnt Harts-horn in a linnen cloth, and o trew it upon the fundament, by little and little to drew it up. Or heat an Oaken-board very well, and cover it over with Stags-uet, and let the Patient it upon it whilt 'tis hot. Put Colophonium or the Roin of Pinetree upon a heated Iron, and let the Patient by holding his fundament over it take in the teams thereof, Anoint alo the part with Butter, in which Onions have been boiled; and trew upon it Album-graecum very finely pulveried. You may alo make a Salve of Cerue, Bol-Armeniack, Dragons-blood, Stags-uet, Blood-tone, Oyl of Myrrh, or Butter in which firt hath been boiled broad Plantain, Mullein, or wild Tanie Silver-weed; and with this anoint the fundament.

As for the Marica's, which do torment Men epecially, they may be cured with Oyl of Eggs, Salve of red Hounds-tongue, as alo with
the nguentum Populeum, or with Butter tirr'd up and down in a Leaden Mortar, till it turn grey or blackih, Let the Patient drink alo of Scrophularia or Fig-wort, infued in his drink, this being a pecifick for that evil. Alo the Oyl of Mullein, Elder-blooms, Water-lilly, and White-lillies, is an excellent remedy for it, a rag dipped therein being laid upon the part affected. To ue carifying on the lower part of the back-bone, is alo very good, though it be very painful.

If the Hoemorrhoid-vein bleed in a convenient time, and do not overbleed, it is an exceeding good thing, and preerves from many Dieaes, as the Inflammation of the Lungs, Stitches of the ides, the Leproie, Melancholly, Quartans, and the like. If the ame vein hould bleed in one that is mad, or diturbed in his mind, or in one that is troubled with the Inflammation of the Kindneys, thee Ditempers would thereby be allayed. But if it hould bleed too often & too violently, it weakens much, caueth a pale colour and the Dropie. My Collegues and I have often open'd it by Leeches, and thereby found great benefit. But in cae it hould exceed in bleeding, you mut deal with it as you do with the Bloody Flux, and give to the Patient Terra Sigillata, Bol-Armeniack, burnt Harts-horn, and the like adtringent things. If you can get ome teeth of the Hippo-potamus, rap it into powder, and drink ome of it in red or white wine; it tops all bleeding, of the noe, mouth, guts, fundament, hoemorrhoids, the matrix, epecially the bleeding of Women after delivery.
Here is alo very ueful the expres'd Juyce of Plantain, Shepherds-pure, and of the tender leaves of Ra-berries, or Brambles, infued in wine and drunk.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Petilential Boyls, lcers, Carbuncles and other venomous Sores.
div.p: ABove I have precribed ome, both Preervative and Curative, Medicines againt the Plague, reerving for this place the Chirurgical means, to be ued againt that Ditemper, thinking it bet to dicoure of them together in a place apart.

Concerning then the Petilential Bubo's and Sores, that rie behind the Ears, under the Arms, and about the Groin, the Cure of them conits chiefly in this, that they be ripen'd with peed; for which end are to be employed meer emollient and uppurating things. Yet are you to know to ditinguih between Boyls, there being ome of them that are not venomous, epecially in young people; and they may be hereby dicerned, that at the touch they caue no pain, whereas the Petilential ones are very painful; which are alo dicover'd by the accompanying venomous Fever, and other pernicious Symptoms. And of thee latter great care mut be had to bring them out, and to a peedy maturation, becaue thoe that lye deep are very dangerous.

Some there have been, that have ued Scarification, and even Veicatories, thereby thinking to fetch out the venom. Others have pierced the Sores through, about a hands breadth beneath the Sores, putting the root of black Helebore into them, thereby to draw out the venomous matter. But uch means have rather irritated the evil, caued great pains, and put the Patient to greater danger.

Wherefore I judge nothing afer and better, than, as I was intimating, to ue Emollients. Take then of the common Diachylon, and lay it upon the invenom'd Boyls; and beides make a pule of thee herbs, viz. of Camomile, Mallows, Melilot, Dill, Line-eed, Fenu-greek, Althaea, the roots of White Lillies, as alo alve of Althaea, Oyl of Camomile and Lillies, mixing a little Saffron with it, and ome Oyl of Scorpions. Of this pule make ome warm and lay it over the Diachylon upon the Sore.

Or, boil Wheaten-bread in the broath of Mallows and Camomile, till it grow oft, then affron it over, and mix March-mallows-alve with it, and lay it on. Or make a Plaiter of Figgs and roted Onions; or, make a pule of Bread-leaven, Honey, yolks of Eggs, and the juyce of Onions, adding a little Turpentine to it, and o lay it on.

If the meer common Diachylon be not ufficient, ue the Plaiter Diachylon cum gummis or de Mucilaginibus, or mix a Melilot-plaiter with the common Diachylon, make a pule of it with Oyl of Lillies, mixing a little Oyl of Scorpions with it, and o lay it on.

In laying on of Treacle, I have this conideration, that Treacle, hinders putrefaction, which is the thing here mot of all deired, becaue all maturation, which here is a reducing the Sore to uppuration, is a kind of putrefaction.

Here alo the Plaiter call'd Bailicon is of good ue; likewie the Ceratum Oeipum Philagrii and Meuae, which Cerata are made of Gummi Ammoniac, Bdellium, Turpentine, liquid Styrax, Gooe-greae, Marrow of Cows-bones and Oeipum, and a little Saffron. Some take a dried Toad, and lay it upon the boyl, to draw out the venom.

Now when the Sores are oftned and ripe, and yet break not of themelves, they are to be opened with a lancet; and if you have to do with Perons o delicate that they cannot endure a lancet, you may make ue of the Lapis Septicus or Corroive-tone, which opens without pain, but is more low. Mean time beware of opening the Sores too oon; for then they will turn to a hard welling, which the Patient will not wear off whilt he liveth.

There are alo ome Plague-ores that never break, but wear away by weat. Yet if they hould leave behind ome hardnes, you may, when the danger is pat and the icknes overcome, make ue of ome fomentations of Melilot, Camomile, March-mallows, Mullein and uch like: You may alo take of the Gum, call'd Tacamahaca, and mix with it a Plaiter of Melilot or Diachylon, and lay it on.

The Sores being open'd; they mut be kept open with mall pellets, (called by the Germans,
Quellmaieln,) dipt in a Salve made for this purpoe out of freh Butter, Yolks of Eggs, and Turpentine, well mixt together cold.

But it happens ometimes, that uch Bubo's, by reaon of the venomous matter, do eat in, or grow fitulous, or make matter-baggs, in which the matter ettles. In this cae you mut ue the nguentum fucum, Apotolicum, or the Aegyptiacum: Or make the following water, to be quirted into uch Sores; namely of Celondine, Scordium or Water-germander, Carduus-benedictus, Centory, or the like Herbs, together with Tormentil and Whitlow-gras; all boiled in wine. If the Sores be very ill, you may boil with it ome quick Brimtone, and Myrrh, and if need be, mix with it a little fine Verdigreae. Or, take Honey four ounces and an half, a quarter of an ounce of Aloes Epatica, a dram of Salt, an ounce and a half of Scordium, mix all well together, and keep it for ue; and when you have occaion for any of it, then diolve it in wine, and fpirt it in. Mean time, enlarge the opening of the Boyls with the aforeaid Pellets, that o the matter may have vent enough, and come away without any impediment.

The Unguent of lyes Aldrovandus is alo very good, for the clearing of uch Sores; and 'tis made of Oyl of Roes, the Juyce of broad Plantain, harp-pointed Dock, Centory, and Night-hade, with a little Litharge, burnt Lead, and prepared Camphir. Intead of the Juyce of Night-hade, you may take that of Cumfry.

As for the Sores call'd Anthraces, and thoe they call Carbuncles, great care mut be taken to break them oon, and to heal them lowly, that o the poyonous matter may all come away. They ripen and break oonet by fatty (but not hot) Plaiters and Unguents; epecially uch as are made of Butter, Leaven, Yolks of Eggs, and Honey; or if you mix together Turpentine, nguentum Populeum, or Roe-alve mixt with Yolks of Eggs, or the nguentum Anodynum mixt with the Ointment of Hounds-tongue, and laid on it. It mut be often refrehed, becaue uch hot Sores and Ulcers, before they break, do o draw, wate, and, as 'twere, lick up thoe fatnees, that ometimes of the Plaiters, that have lain on them, there remains nothing but the bare ragg. The Emplatrum Bailicon, or the common yellow drawing Plaiter, is here the mot ueful.

You mut alo urround the Anthrax with good defenives; for if it invade the neighbouring part never o little, it will oon make a large halo or circle, which will at length eparate from the ound, and fall away like an Ecarre. For uch defenives make ue of Album Camphoratum, or the nguentum de Liquiritia, known by our people under the name of Dr. Mindererus his Licorih ointment. Item the nguentum de Lithargyro; or the nguentum Jovis, prepared of freh Butter, with Thlapi minus, or Bowyers Mutard, (otherwie narrow-leav'd wild Crees,) Cranes-bill, Elder, Poppy, Vervain, and ome haved Licorih. Some take nothing but Vervain
and the freh leaves of Henbane, beaten together, and the Juyce trained, and o ued. Of this Ointment you may make much with confidence; for it will do you very good ervice in Inflammations, epecially in the cae of the welling of the Groins.

Amongt the approved Medicines for this purpoe, may deervedly be reckoned the Plaiter made of Soot; which is thus to be prepared: Take of the finet Chimney-oot one ounce and a quarter; of Leaven, Turpentine and freh Butter, ana one ounce; of Venetian Soap an ounce and a half; two Yolks of Eggs; of Treacle and Mithridate, ana a quarter of an ounce: Beat all thee together in a Mortar, and o reduce it to a pate, and then ue it Plaiter-wie.

When the Anthrax or the Carbuncle is broken, you mut then handle it very gently and dicreetly, uing only the above-decribed Egg-alve, putting it into the opening, and covering the Sore only with the common yellow drawing Plaiter, or the Plaiter prepared of Oyl, Wax and Roin, or Turpentine. Let the matter work out well, and when you are ure that 'tis very clean, and have a mind to conolidate it, make only ue of Triapharmacon, vulgarly call'd the brown Diachylon; you may beides put into it ome of the nguentum de Tutia, and that of the Diapompholox, and one of the Plaiters of them upon it. The lme-plaiter alo, made of Oyl and Cerue, heals alo very well. But be very careful, let any of the matter remain lurking in the Ulcer. If here and there any hould be found yet remaining,
as often happens, then make ue of the Emplatrum Apotolorum. But if you can prepare the Diapalma, otherwie called Diacalcithros, make ue of that. I am wont to call it the Fitula-plaiter, becaue it doth not eaily uffer Fitula's to tink, but keeps them clean and weet. Such a Plaiter is alo that, which is called Iis, to be found in Galen, and performing the ame thing. They are both to be found in the Augutan Dipenatory, together with the way of preparing them.

Now what concerns Old Sores, which many are troubled with, in their Leggs epecially, becaue the humors of the body uually ettle there; you mut above all things be careful to keep them clean, and to that end wah them, at leat once a day, with your own Urine: Or boil Carduus benedictus, Egrimony, Plantain, and Roots of Tormentil, in half mall Meath and half Wine, and wah the Ulcer with it, as often as you dres it. Among the common Plaiters for uch evils is the brawn Diachylum one of the bet. Ele you may prepare this Ointment which follows: Take the middle rind of Elder, and St. Johns-wort, boil them in Oyl, putting a little Wine to it, and o let it boil up till the Wine be boiled away; then take it off from the fire, and let it cool; this done, tir a little Turpentine amongt it, and a Yolk or two of Eggs, according as you make a greater or leer quantity; mixing with it a little Allum and Vitriol, (the white is the bet,) tir all well together, and apply it to the Ulcer, and make a bandage, and cover it as uually. For a good Drawing-plaiter,
take Roin, Bees-wax and Oyl-Olive; the quantity of the Roin mut be but the half of the Wax: Let them melt together, and tir amongt it ome Tartar exquiitely powder'd. Ue not much of fatty things to uch Ulcers. I have had under my care uch Ulcers, that were to be healed with only dry things, as with trewing in of Crocus Martis, and the red Earth of Vitriol, of which hereafter.

For this reaon the antient Phyicians and Chirurgeons invented a dry Stone, which they kept o ecret, that they called it Lapis Philoophorum; which is eaily made, as followeth: Take Allum, Hungarian Vitriol, of each one pound, beat them to powder, and mix them well together; then put all into a glaed earthen pot, and pour upon it two quarts of Water, boil them together, and tir them continually with a Spatula, taking off the cum: When 'tis boiled in, put to it an ounce of Bolus Armenus, an ounce and a half of Cerue, a quarter of an ounce of Camphir, all finely powder'd, tirring it well about; latly, put it to a quart of harp Vinegar, and boil all together to a tony conitence; which reduce to powder, and of it trew a little into the Ulcer, or let ome of it diolve in a convenient Liquor, and wah the Ulcer therewith, or dip ome Linnen raggs in it, and lay it over the place.

'Tis alo prepared this way: Take green and white Vitriol, of each a drachm; of Lapis Calaminaris, Cerue, Bol-Armeniack, of each two ounces and a half; of Sal-Armoniack an ounce. Beat them all to powder, put them in an earthen pot, mingle and tir them together
in Vinegar, to be a thick pule; then put your pot upon a hot Charcoal-fire, to let it grow red hot, o as that the matter be reduced to a tony conitence; of which diolve about half an ounce in half a pint of Water, dip Linnen raggs into it, and put it twice a day upon the Ulcer. 'Tis alo very good for purulent Breats.

I was peaking above of Lavements: Thee you may prepare of all orts of Wound-herbs, by boiling Conound, Bugle; Fluellin, Ground-Ivy, Yarrow, Snake-weed, Avens, Armart; you may alo, againt putrefaction and the ettling of purulent matter, mix ometimes a little Myrrh, or Aloes Epatica, Frankincene, Matick, quick Brimtone, Camphir, Niter, Allum, Vitriol, or the like. Nor is it needful to bind your elf to this or that preciely, but you may take uch of them as you can get.

I have a peculiar Ulcer-alve, which I call nguentum Decameron, being made of ten orts of Juices. Of thee the principal is the Juice of Pericaria, (Armart;) to which are added the Juices of Groundel, Tobacco, Yarrow, harp-pointed Dock, Cranes-bill, broad and pointed Plantain, Centory, St. Johns-wort, and Celondine. Thee Juices mut be well trained, and then kept for ome days in glaes or glaed Veels to ettle, and then very gently pour off the clear from the ediment. Which done, boil them with freh Butter, and ome good Licorih newly craped, as alo ome Tormentil and Cumfrey, adding a little red Hounds-tongue Salve and Oyl of Myrrh, and
Deer-uet: Let all be boiled together, till the cracking ceae, and the Juice be boiled in. Then train it through a Linnen Cloth; and add to it ome Venice-Turpentine, Gum Elemi and a little Bees-wax, both the latter melted each a part. Of the Wax there needs no more than to bring the Salve to a due conitence. Then is this Unguent prepared, to which may be added a little refined Verdigreae, which will make it perfect. It is of great efficacy in foul Wounds, for both cleaning and healing; as experience will hew.

A Chirurgeon, in meeting with Ulcers, is to oberve well the purulent matter that iues, ince he may from thence learn the condition of the evil, whether it proceed from foul Blood, Gall, corrupt Phlegm, or Adut Melancholy. If the evil grow wore, and the Humors of the Body force their way copiouly thorow, then beware, and withal exhort the Patient to purge, or to weat with taking ome Saafras, or the like.

The Sanies or matter that is thick, white, and well digeted, is the bet; but when there runs but a harp water out of the Ulcer, this is not good, and is withal painful. Which to obviate, you mut ue Litharge, Cerue, and the like; putting alo beaten Lead upon the place, and cleaning the fitulat holes with Lead-oyl, qualifying its harpnes with Oyl of Eggs. This Lead-oyl is made two ways, the the one out of Cerue, which is green; the other out of Litharge, which is yellow or reddih Both are prepared with Vinegar.

Boil Celondine in wine, and with this wine
you may alo cleane the Ulcer with good effect. Mix afterwards a drachm of Verdigreae with about four ounces of the Juyce of Ground-Ivy; ue it with wiecks or raggs dipt therein for the foul Ulcer-holes.

Burn Oyter-hells to powder, and ue it for old Ulcers that need cleaning, which this powder will well perform by reaon of the Salt that is in thoe hells. You may ometimes have occaion alo of the Mercurius praecipitatus, or the Mercurius dulcis Cometicus. If you can prepare this you have a good Remedy.

As for hard Knobs and Boyls, they commonly owing their rie to the Venereal Dieae are not o proper for this place. However you may make a plaiter againt uch Knobs of the phlegm of Althaea or Marh-mallows, Gummi Ammoniac, Galbanum, Turpentine, Myrrh, Miel-toe of the oak, mixing a little Bee-wax therewith and ome Oyl of Earthworms. If you will have it tronger, mix with it Gumm Elemi, Tacamahaca or Carana. But this can only be compaed by the rich men; the poor mut be content with the Melilot-plaiter, mixt with Saffron and the Oyl of Mullain or Dill. You may alo prepare for uch Patients a Salve of Fox-oyl, Dill-oyl, Turpentine, Man-greae, and the like, mixing therewith ome Oyl of Earth-worms and the Oyl of Mullain-flowers, Camomil and white Lillies.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of the Chirurgical means of taunching blood, of Wound-baloms and plaiters, of Wound-drinks, and remedies for Burnings.
div.p: THis is the mot neceary Chapter of this whole Tract. For, although in every Camp, yea in every Regiment, and even in every Company there ought to be one or more Chirurgeons; yet becaue in a battle, or the torming of a trong-hold, there may be wounded a very great number of men, who, by reaon of the multitude, cannot all be dreed by the Chirurgeons, every common Souldier, that is ound and unhurt, is obliged to ait his fellow, conidering it may oon be his own cae.

In the firt place then, refreh thy fellow that is wounded, with wine, cold water, vinegar, or the like; then place him in a right poture. For, if the wounds be in the head or about the breat, you ought to lay him high with his head and houlders, that o the blood may ink down from the places wounded. If his legg be hurt, put it o that it may not hang downwards, and thereby the afflux from the body be prevented, which otherwie might caue a tumour. If the wounds be in the middle of the body, then place him
o, that, if poible, he may lye omewhat hollow with his back.

This done, wah the wound very gently, (o as not to anger it,) with meer wine, or even with pure common water, only with a very little alt cat into it: or with the Patients own urine; and then dry it with lint of long-worn linnen, without much tirring in the wound, for fear of making the veins bleed again.

If any one do bleed o copiouly, that it is not eaily topp'd, and the Patient is in danger then receive of his blood in an Iron pan, and letting it run about therein, hold it over the fire till it be dry and between your fingers friable to powder; of which trew ome into the bleeding wound, and it will top it. But of this cae more hereafter.

The wound being cleaned, and the bleeding tayed, take fine linnen-raggs, burn them as you are wont to do for tinder, and quench it in Oyl of Olives; and put ome of it into the wound, If you have no plaiter at hand take a lice of unalted lard and lay it on. If that be alo wanting, dip a pledget of linnen-raggs in warm wine, and being wrung out very dry, lay it upon the wound, and a dry bandage over it, that o the moit pledget may long keep warm. Though in uch wounds, as are apt to bleed much, warm bandages are often to be avoided, and ometimes (but with ingular care and dicretion) cold bandages to be ued, if the hurt be not in the brain, breat or bowels. Whence old Hippocrates hath this Aphorim: Frigido ver√≤ in iis locis utendum, unde
anguis aut fluit aut fluxurus et. Yet this mut be done with great caution, let in the place affected there hould follow a Gangrene.

After this, take Oyl of Olives and Wine, beat them well together, and warm the mixture; dip it in Linnen pledgets, wring them dry, and lay them on warm with a dry bandage over it. This mut de done once every hour, or every two hours, nor let this care and labour eem irkom to you, for it will have a good effect.

This Dres is almot the only thing, which the Knights of Maltha make ue of at Sea to heal their wounds; for the Oyl allays the pain and the welling, as the Wine cleaneth, and thee two together caue healing. Whence the Samaritan in the Gopel is aid to have poured only Oyl and Wine into the wounds of him, that was fallen among Thieves. You may therefore make out of thee two a Wound-alve that may be equivalent to almot every common Wound-balom, preparing it thus:

Take one part of Oyl-olive, and two parts of Wine, boil them together till the Wine be boiled in, and the Oyl, when any is thrown into the fire, cracks no more; and you have a Wound-oyl according to wih: Put of it with fine Linnen havings into the wound, and it will, for a plain Remedy, do marvels.

You may alo melt Lard unalted, mix it with Honey and Rye-flower, and o make it into a Salve, which, though plain and imple, may when put upon the Wound, have as good an
effect, as many Plaiters that are in great eteem.

Otherwie, for a very good Wound-alve, take of the bet Aloes cleanly pulveried the weight of a ducat, mingle and tir it with half an ounce of fine Honey; melt afterwards by it elf half an ounce of Deer-uet, and tir it among the other Ingredients: Thus you have a good Salve againt the putrefaction of wounds, and for the awaging of their pains, as alo for healing them, if you duly apply it to the wound: If you'l add to it a little Cyprus-Turpentine with the Yolk of an Egg, you may.
The black Wheel-greae in a time of need is alo a good Wound-alve, and is only depied becaue of its plainnes. When you ue it, lay only over it the leaves of Snake-weed, or of pointed Plantain.

But by all means keep the wound clean, and let not many look into it, for fear they hould by their breath annoy it; ome being fating, others having eaten one thing, others another. But epecially admit not many Women, when you open the wound for cleaning and dreing it. But above all things take care to exclude the Air as much as is poible from the open'd wound, epecially if any Artery or Nerve be hurt. Take notice, that Carpenters and Joyners, when they have hurt themelves, do almot by this only means of well cloing their wounds, and keeping out the Air, heal themelves. They take a very thin chip, and lay upon it ome of the Glue, wherewith they joyn together the Boards of
their work, and this they apply to the wound, firt well cleaned, and let it lye on, till it fall off of it elf, and the wound is healed. But this will not do in cae any Bones be hurt.
Item, take Honey and the Dut-flower of the Mills, freh Butter and Bol-armeniack, and knead it well together, without any fire, until it be as thick as a Plaiter, and this laid on is very good.

Item, take Cumphrey well cleaned, cut it mall, add to it one or two of the Vulnerary Herbs, uch as you may meet with in the field, as Pyrola or Winter-green, Yarrow, Plantain, Fluellin, Orpin, Conound, Sanicle, Bugle, &c. Boil this in Lineed-oyl and a little Wine, until the Wine is boiled away; and this being trained, put to it ome raw Honey and one or two well beaten yolks of Eggs, (according to the quantity you make) and a little Turpentine, and o thrut it, with ome Hemp or Flax dip in it, into the wound.

Lime-water is one of the implet or plainet Remedies, but healeth admirably well. Take only ome unlaked Lime, pour on it clear Water, and let it tand upon it till the Lime be fallen to the bottom: Wah the wound with it, epecially uch as are old running Sores, and you'l find a wonderful effect.

Thee plain means may be ued, in cae you want a Chyrurgeon, taking the aitance of your Fellow-ouldier in the application; though thoe very Remedies may challenge a place among the mot chargeable ones, precribed and applied by Maters. And provided the Chyrurgeon do not under-value thee my
plain and cheap Remedies, but receive them thankfully, I am ready here to teach him ome ways, hitherto concealed by me, which I cruple to keep any longer from publick knowledge.

Know then firt, that to a Phyician belongs alo the knowledge of Chirurgery, as a third part of the Art of Medicine, the other two being the Pharmaceutica, precribing Medicines for inward Dieaes, and the Diatetica, ordering the Patients Diet and other necearies. I have my elf, whilt I practied Phyick, dreed in Camps many wounds with my own hands and cured them, carrying always my Chirurgical apparatus about me, without any diparagement to my Profeion; imitating herein the Examples above-alledged, of Podalyrius and Machaon, two of the chief Phyicians of the Antients in the Army before Troy, who were not at all ahamed to practie Chirurgery, and to attend the cure of wounded Souldiers.

Firt of all then, conider well, whether the wound be mortal or no. Next, what limb or part it is that hath received the wound: The wounds in the Head are commonly the mot dangerous, by reaon of the Symptoms incident to them, as the Apoplexy, Falling-Sicknes or other Convulions, the Paley and Laming of the Limbs by reaon of the hurt Nerves, as alo Phreny, los of Hearing and Speech, &c. which are wont to be conequent, according as the repective Nerves have been truck or wounded. If the Breat be any where wounded, great care alo is to be had, and the means mut be directed to prevent purulency,
(which that place, by reaon of the heat there, is ubject to,) and to heal the Pleura or the inner Membrane of the Ribbs; the like is to be done concerning the Diaphragme, &c.

You ought alo to oberve, what kind of wound it is you have to do with, whether any Bone, any Nerve or Artery be hurt; whether it be a meer fleh-wound, and the like. If it be a gaping wound, you mut, if it hath taken cold from the Air, bathe it with warm Wine, and keep it very cloe; and make ue of the trong atringent Plaiter, prepared of Roin, Gumm Elemi, Turpentine, Pitch, with ome Matick, Frankincene, Sarcocolla, as alo ome Blood-tone, Mummy, and Crocus Martis mixt therewith, and keep all on carefully with a good bandage, which is a great matter in all wounds. For, ome months ince, I had a Patient under my cure, whoe Skull in the place of one of its futures was ever'd, o as that I found a coniderable pace between the two parts eparated. I order'd a Chirurgeon of my particular acquaintance to draw thoe parts forcibly together with good bandages; which being well done, I caued his Hair to be horn away, and an atringent Plaiter to be applied, which was almot like a Rupture-plaiter: whereby in three or four weeks, to the admiration of many, my Patient was perfectly healed. This plaiter was the Ceratum ex pelle arietina, mixt wit Gumm Elemi, and with a little Ceratum de Betonica.

You mut alo be provided with good Blood-taunching remedies. The common ones are, Bol-armeniac, Sheep-trickles, Blood-tone, Tragacanth,
Terra Sigillata, Mill-dut, Hares-hair, Peacocks-dung, &c. Avoid by all means Cauticks, epecially Sublimat Arenic, Colcothar; with which you anger a wound, and cat the Patient into very dangerous ymptoms: For, though they may by their corroivenes at firt atringe the wound, yet they do afterwards o fret and eat it, that you would think, hell-fire were in it. Beware alo of a hot Iron, which many have a refuge to as to a Mater-piece and the lat remedy.

Among the chief Atringents, is Frog-pawn; which therefore you are, when 'tis in eaon, to make good proviion of, for the whole year. Take therefore in the Spring a lump of raggs, and dip it into Smiths-water, in which firt ome crude Allum hath been diolved. Let this lump be dried again, and then draw it thorough the Spawn of Frogs, o as that the Spawn may every where hang on it, and expoe it to the Air to dry; and afterwards draw the ame again thorough Frog-pawn: Which repeat as often as you can, during the eaon of Frog-pawn; for the oftner you dip the raggs into it, the more vertue they will receive. This Spawn tauncheth bleeding, with a good bandage. I have often ued with good ucces the ditilled water of Frog-pawn in the bleeding of the Noe, firt mixt with crude Allum, and then drawn up into the Notrils. Take a green Frog, burn him in a pipkin, not to ahes, but o as to be reducible to powder: This powder put into a mall Taffaty-bagg, and hang it about the neck of a woman that floods exceively; and he will find great help from it.

Having often made mention of Allum, which is one of the chief remedies for topping of blood, I will make publick the Magitery of Allum, which I have hitherto kept ecret. Take then of the bet and clearet Allum as much as you pleae; pulverie it, and put the powder into an Oxe-or Swines-bladder, tying it very cloe; Then throw it into a kettle of hot water, and the Allum will be diolved; this Solution bring over the helm out of a low retort, until the Allum get a caput mortuum; then ceae to urge the fire any more, let you force corroive pirits from it, which are noxious to our preent purpoe. This caput mortuum put again into a bladder, and diolve it as before; and do this o long, until the whole body of your Allum be brought over the helm. But you mut filter the firt olution for fear of any dut or other heterogeneous matter mixt with it.

This is the Magitery of Allum, able to draw the veins together without corroion. Apply this to wounds, or any other bleeding part. You may mix with it Tragacanth, Gummi Arabick, Sanguis Draconis, and well-beaten Whites of Eggs.

Take good notice, whether the wounded Patient have heated himelf in torming a place, or by any other military execution, or whether he be yet ditemper'd by paion; for as long as this lats, the blood is in a rage, and can hardly be topped. In this cae top the wound with Peacocks dung; and take Vineger and Whites of Eggs well beaten together, a little Allum, and refined Salt-peter put to
it as much Frog-pawn, Shepherds-pure, broad Plantain, or other convenient water, as is neceary; o that there may be three parts of water and one part of vinegar; dip pledgets into it, and clap them cold to the wound, and the bleeding will ceae,

Crocus Martis alo is an excellent tauncher of blood, to be ued both inwardly and outwardly. For inwardly it cureth the Bloody Flux and other Fluxes; and outwardly applied to wounds and trewed into them, it cloeth the veins. But it mut not be prepared with Aqua-fortis, or ditilled Vineger, or any corroive thing, but only by the heat of a reverberating furnace; and afterwards ditil often from it ome proper water, as of Roes, Speed-well, Self-heal or broad Plantain, after which preparation it is divers times to pas again through a reverberating furnace, until it grow as light as a down-feather: And then 'tis fit for our purpoe; for as long as it is trong and heavy, the body of it is not throughly opened.

Among other things, you may make ue of the Red earth of Vitriol; which is to be thus prepared: Take Vitriol, as much as you pleae, put it in a new unglaed pipkin, into a Potters oven, to deprive it of its moiture, and to reduce it to a Colcothar: Then pulverie this calcined Vitriol, and in a large glaed earthen dih pour hot water on it, letting it tand o for four or five hours; then decant the water, and pour other hot water upon it, as before, repeating this three, four, or five times, until all the alt be got out of the aid Colcothar;
which whether it be done, may eaily be found by the tate. Then dry this red dulcified Earth, and it will prove a very good blood-taunching medicine; which may alo in other caes be variouly ued; as you'l find it hereafter of great ue in my plaiter for wounds made by thruting.

The water you had poured on this Colcothar, you ought not to throw away as ueles, but to put it by; and, for other occaions, you may boil it away, and it will leave a Salt behind, as white as now, with which you may do wonders in foul Sores. I have ued it with good ucces in uch caes; in which it cleaneth and maketh a firm ground for new and good fleh to grow upon. For, though there be many things, that cleane Sores, yet they leave the fleh looe and pungy; but this is both atringent, and withal maketh uch a ound and firm bottom, that you may trut to it: Whence alo it is to be ued in fitulous Sores.

But to return to the topping of Blood; take the blood of a Lamb or Sheep, let it tand in a clean earthen veel, until the erum be ever'd from it; pour this off, and dry the blood well in a new glaed pipkin, upon hot embers: Then pulverie it, and mix with it a fourth part of clean pulveried Tragacanth, and trew this into the wound. If the iue of the blood be o impetuous, that it wahes away the firt application, then wipe the wound again, and trew into it of the ame powder the econd time. Putting amongt it Allum, Crocus Martis or the red Earth of Vitriol, you will do
well: Bind the wound with the Emplatrum Santalinum, (which is called Incognitum by our Chirurgeons,) or with the Ceratum ex pelle arietina, due to Arnoldus de Villa nova.

The blood being topt, and the wound cleaned, you mut then apply good vulnerary Oyls or Wound-baloms. Oyls are all, as I mention'd above, fatty; whence it is, that they do not eaily conolidate wounds, unles you put to them ome refined Matic, Sarco-colla, Sanguis Draconis, Sandarach, or the like.
But to open unto you the good affection of my heart, I hall decribe here my Wound-balom, wherewith I have, by Gods aitance, done much good, viz.

Take as much as you pleae of Turpentine of Cyprus, which comes from Venice, and is taken inwardly; and the ame quantity of the red Oyl of St. Johns-wort, diolve them together: Then take Gumm Elemy, diolve it apart, and pour it among the other; and o let all cool, and when 'tis half cold, pour amongt it a little Oyl of Bees-wax, and your Balom is prepared. I cannot tell you the precie weight of each ingredient, becaue as often as I have prepared it, I have done it by the Eye, and as it eemed good unto me; only note, that there mut be o much of the Gumm Elemy as to give it a due conitence; which you may try, by cating a drop or two of it into cold water; this Balom being to be thinner than an Unguent, and yet thicker than Oyl.

This Balom heals very peedily, epecially
when ued in wounds frehly inflicted, on fine pledgets, and only with a yellow Tractif bound over it.

Be alo provided with good Plaiter for wounds made by Thruting, uch as are the Opodeldoch of Theophratus, or the good black Thrut-plaiter thus to be prepared: Take of Oyl of Roes even ounces; of Colophonium, black Pitch, white Wax, Roman Vitriol, Cerue, Frankincene, Myrrh, ana eight ounces; of Matic, one ounce of the Oyl of Eggs, two ounces; of Spike-oyl, one ounce; of the Oyl of Juniper-berries, three ounces; of Mumia, two ounces; of white Vitriol and red Corals, ana two ounces; of Heron-uet, one ounce; of Magnet, two ounces; of well cleaned Earth-worms pulveried and of Camphir, ana one ounce: Of all this make a powder ecundum artem.

My Opodeldoch, that I make ue of, is almot like this, but that I mix with it the red Earth of the Oyl of Vitriol, above poken of in the matter of Blood-taunching; and add alo to it Turpentine and Gumm Elemi, with ome Tutia, Aloes epatica, well prepared Lapis Calaminaris, and Crocus Martis: And thus the Plaiter becomes red and hard, like Spanih Sealing-wax. I take alo Gummi Ammoniac, Galbanum and Opoponax, the Oyl of St. Johnswort and Myrrh. This Plaiter draws from the bottom, and reaches deep. A Souldier, having this about him, and, upon occaion, working it only to ome flatnes, there being no need of laying it on a cloth, may thus put it on the wound, taking it off mornings and
evenings to wipe it clean; and then working it through again, lay it on as before: And o he may heal himelf; which when done, let him clean the Plaiter, and role it up in a bladder, for another occaion.
I have een coniderable opperations of Gumm Elemi ued alone, laid on leather, and put upon the thrut; but this wound is then to be kept from falling together.

To prevent incidental heat and inflammation of the wounds, make ue of the Oyl of Roes, Bol Armeniac, Whites of Eggs and Camphir. But to avoid trouble, you may find ready, in the Apothecary-hops, the nguentum album, nguentum de Minlo, Camphoratum de Liguiritia, de Lithargyro, Santilinum, and the like; to be put about the wound when dreed.

You may with great benefit, and you ought alo, epecially in the wounds of the Head, provided there be no danger of bleeding, lay over the bandage ome fine raggs moiten'd in wine, and well dried again. This allays the pain, and withall prevents welling.

And in cae the wound be welled, you may alo to good purpoe make ue of Fomentations made of the herb and flowers of Mullein, Betony, Egrimony, Cowlips, Camomil, Melilot, Ground-Ivy, red Roes, Bugle, and the like: But beware of all hot things, whatever they be. Boil the aforeaid herbs or the like in half wine and water; but if the wound be not inflamed, take two parts of wine and one of water. With uch fomentations I have done much good; among others upon a Fencing-Mater
of Nurenberg, called Cameyen, who in the publick Fencing-chool received thruts in both his Eyes, inomuch that by reaon of the great welling that enued thereupon he lot all his ight; but by the ue of uch fomentations, God bleing the means, I recover'd his ight.

A Bone being broken, et it carefully, and bind it up trongly, having laid upon it Oxycroceum or Emplatrum de pelle Arietina. You may alo comfort uch wounds with the like fomentations, as before decribed.

On the bank of the Rhine is found a Stone in the gravel, call'd Lapis abulous, which is eaily reducible to powder: Of this, if you can get it, give to the Patient, whoe bone is broken, a drachm to be taken in broath, mornings; of which he will find a very good effect.

In the cae of a Limb wrenched, clap to it Bran boiled in wine, ometimes, according to occaion, mixing with it a little Salt, and Marhmallows or red Hounds-tongue-alve. If it have happened long ago, then make a pule of Wheaten-flower, Milk, and the Oyl of Camomil or Mullein; mixing a little Saffron with it, and clap it on hot. If there be any collection or coagulation of blood, the Unguent of Hounds-tongue will do well, together with a linnen compres moitened in warm wine.

You mut alo be provided with good Wound-drinks; but they mut be prepared diverly, according to the everal places wounded. Thus in the wounds of the Head, Betony challenges the pre-eminence and the
greatet quantity of all the Vulnerary Herbs; In the wounds of the Sides, Carduus Benedictus, claims that right; in the wounds of the Breat, Veronica (or Speedwell) ought to have it; in thoe about the Kidneys, the Herb Strawberry mut be preferred; in thoe near the Liver, Agrimony will have the precedency, and o forth. Mean time, the Vulnerary Herbs to be ued in uch occaions, are thee; Sanicle, Winter-green, Ladies-mantle, Speedwell, Orpine, Mugwort, Ground-Ivy, Straw-berry-leaves, Agrimony, St. Johns-wort, Cinquefoil, Bugle, Tormentil, Snakeweed, Avens, Woodrooff, &c.

You may make an excellent Wound-drink of thee four Ingredients, viz. Winter-green, Orpine, Mugwort and Snakeweed, boiled in half Wine and Water; but in cae there be an Inflammation, Wine is to be forborn, or very little of it to be employed.

If any Bone be broken into plinters, do not pull them out with any violence, but looen them with a good Ointment of Eggs, keeping the wound open the longer. Nature her elf will not uffer any plinter to remain behind.

Now you mut be ready with ome good thing for Blood coagulated, in cae any peron hould have been flung down, queezed, beaten, or fallen from a high place. The right powder for this purpoe is thus made: Take of Terra Sagillata, or Bol-Armeniack, Sanguis Draconis and Mumia, ana half an ounce, of Sperma Ceti and Rhubarb ana half a drachm, reduce it to a powder; of which give the Patient
the weight of about a ducat in Wine, or Chervil-water. Or take a good quantity of Chervil, boil it in Meath or Fleh-broath, and let the Patient drink a good draught of it warm, three times a day. Or let him drink a Thimble-full of Sperma Ceti in Beer, adding a little Butter to it. Or take of Mumia half an ounce, or Sperma Ceti two drachms, of Oculi Cancrorum (of which the blew ones, which ometimes fall from Crafihes whilt alive, are the bet,) three drachms, adding to it a little Licorih and Cinnamon, and ome Tormentil Roots: Of this pulveried give every day to the Patient, mornings and evenings, the weight of about half a ducat, and by this means you will expel purulent matter and blood, and bony plinters, and ometimes even bullets lurking in the fleh; not omitting other good Wound-drinks, and vulnerary Baloms, Plaiters, Ointments and Fomentations. Again, take of the red Hounds-tongue Ointment, of the bignes of a great Walnut, diolve it in warm Broath; it expels all coagulated blood, epecially if you mix ome Sperma Ceti with it.

If you have any Thorns, Thitles, Bullets, Small-hot, or the like, to draw out, where perhaps you cannot reach them with Intruments, then burn live Crafihes in a new Pipkin, until they be reducible to powder, but burn them not to Ahes. This powder mix with Hares-uet, and lay it on, and you will find a good effect. Alo take the Roots of the big Reed that grows in Marihes, dry them to be pulveried, and mix Virgin-honey with it,
and lay it upon the part; and of the ame powder give the Patient to drink, twice a day, the weight of half a ducat in Wine, or in Broath, or in a vulnerary potion, if you have at hand. The firt of this I learned of the Excellent Doctor Schleer of Contance.

The Excrement of a Gander, being applied, is alo powerful in drawing out Iron. Again, Quince-wine mingled with Vinegar, and putting ome Saffron and Gun-powder amongt it, if you give it to one that hath been hot, it will do him good. Otherwie, they make a plaiter of the Roots of Cumfrey, Aron, Polypody, Juniper, and dried Radihes, all reduced to powder, and mix it with Hares-uet and grey Diachylum, making a thick Ointment of it, and preading it over a piece of Hare-skin, and o laying it on. This is greatly praied, epecially when econded with good Wound-drinks, of which Mater-wort is one of the Ingredients: But if you have not this at hand, take a Beet and boil it in Wine, and lay it warm on the wound. Likewie young Swallows, not yet fledge, burnt to powder, and this powder made by Acetum of Roes into a pule, and laid on, does the ame.

You ought alo to be provided for the Synovia: And if you proceed aright with my Wound-balom above decribed, and keep the wound warm, you may therewith do much good. Mix with it, ex abundanti, the red Earth of Vitriol, above dicoured of. This Synova is a dangerous thing, and often caueth almot intollerable pain, if it be not well handled; the Herb of Straw-berries and its
Juyce have great vertue in this cae. Some make ue of the White of Eggs, Bol-Armeniack, and the like. The Magitery of Allum alo belongs hither; for, Allum mixed with Vinegar, and clapp'd on very warm, allays it alo. Elder-blooms likewie, ued every way, are effectual in the ame cae. Employ alo diligently uch Defenive-plaiters, as are not fatty, becaue fat lays no hold on water.

To proceed to Burnings, I know almot no better Salve for burning than this; Take a Tench, or any common-Pond-fih; fry one or more of them with good Butter, pour the fatnes upon cold Water in a broad earthen Pan, and you have an excellent Ointment againt Burnings. When, ome years ince, a Powder-Mill was blown up, and the Attendants upon the work o mierably burnt, that they looked as if they had been roted, they were healed with this Ointment, only a little finely powder'd Sage being mixt with it.

Cream and Lineed-oyl mingled together, and raggs moiten'd therein, put upon the burnt part, healeth, though the burning were made with Aqua-fortis; for, to my knowledge, a certain Chymit that had thus burnt all his Arm, was thereby retored. Or, take Oyl of Elder, or tale Oyl that hath been long in a burning Lamp; beat half as much, as you take of that, of the Whites of Eggs amongt it, and anoint the burnt part therewith. If you can get no Oyl of Elder, take any other cooling Oyl, as of Nymphaea, (Water-lillies) Poppy-eeds, Violets or Roes, or the Oyl of Poplar-buds, or of Marh-Marigold Flowers.

If you can have Quince-wine, it marvellouly extinguihes the burning of any hot, dipping a Linnen pledget in it, and drawing it through the wound, or left in it, repeating this every twelfth hour. The Juyce or Wine of Quinces mut be ued as it comes from the fruit, without any mixture of Sugar. This I learn'd from a Nobleman, a great Souldier, of long experience in the Wars of France, the Low-Countries, and Hungary.

The nguentum Jovis, made of Henbane, Vervain and Butter, is alo very ueful for this purpoe. Likewie the Ointment of Calx viva, which is firt ix or even times to be laked and dulcified with pure water, pouring every twelve or ixteen hours freh water upon it, and decanting the former, o as to leave always the Calx at the bottom; which is then to be mixed with Oyl of Roes, or ome other cooling Oyl, for an Ointment.

If you be well acquainted with Elder, and know how to ue it, you may obtain out of it one of the bet Cures of Burnings, epecially out of its middle rinds. Again, Yolks of Eggs and Lineed-oyl, equal quantities, mixt together, and pread over the burning, is alo very good. Egg-oyl likewie ued by it elf, and Vernice employed by Joyners, do well alo; but the latter of thee two, if it be mixed with Oyl of Spicanard or Petroleum, is to be mingled amongt Lineed-oyl.

Spread freh Butter upon Cabbage-leaves, having firt fryed the Butter with ome blooms or the middle rind of Elder; and o lay them to the burning; Elder being a great reiter
of Inflammations, and therefore very good to allay St. Antonies fire; if you pull its mild green rinds from the tem, and lay them on, without moitening them. Ele they ue againt the aid Fire, Flower mixed with the powder of Licorice, to be clapt on with a ragg done over with red Saunders. My way is, to take the havings of ome freh and juycy Licorice, and to fry them in new Butter; then to train the Butter from it, and to fry the like freh Licorice therein, and to train the Butter from that again; repeating this five or ix times. Among this trained Butter I tir ome pure and fine Cerue, Whites of Eggs and a little Camphire. And with this Ointment I have, by the aitance of God, done much good in the aid inflammation of St. Antonies fire; and the common people do to this very day call this Ointment by no other name than that of Doctor Minderer's Licorice-Ointment. But to return to the quenching of Burnings.

If you can have Milk-cream, mingle it with Cow-dung frehly made, and o clap it on; though freh Cow-dung alone allays burning. Crafihes pounded alive, and fryed in freh Butter or in common Suet, the Butter trained here from, is alo a good Ointment againt burnings. Unalted Lard, melted by a Wax-candle, or an hot Iron, and dropp'd upon freh cold water, and then gather'd up from the water, and carefully rubbed from the ame, hath the like operation. Take one of the cooling Oyls above-named, and freh Butter, boil the middle rind of Elder in it, and with a
ufficient quantity of Wax make of it a Salve, and this alo will cure burning.

You ought alo to be provided with a fit apparatus, Lints, Swathing-clouts, &c. and to take Deer-uet, Oyl of Roes or Elder, and white Wax, and melt them over the fire, yet o as that you melt the Wax, by it elf, and add of it no more to the ret than to make it a thin plaiter. Into this compound you mut dip ome fine lint, and you'l find it very ueful for any angry part; as alo when one limb prees or otherwie incommodes another, as happens in hydropical and other wollen people, whoe belly o inks down, that the thighs uffer by it; in which cae uch lints are to be put between the parts, to keep them from immediately touching and preing one another.
A grangrene is cured with Sal-armoniac boiled in Urine, epecially in that of the Patient, and clapping uch Urine upon the part affected:
The quantity of the Sal-armoniac may be ix drachms.

For frozen Feet, take Gander-uet and Deer-uet; diolve them together, and pour them into a white excavated Turnip, and expoe this for a while to the Air, Rain, Wind, Hoar-frot, Snow, according as the eaon hall be: Then mince the Turnip, and fry it in the ame Suet which you had poured into it; that done, queeze it out, and let the fat fall upon cold water; and being there brought to conitence, take it off, and bring it over the helm from burned Wine, and decant this carefully from it again, and 'tis duely prepared. You
may alo recover frozen Feet with white rotten Turnips, beaten with Butter or Tallow, and o clapt on.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of everal promicuous Medical Practices, for the Service of the honet Souldier.
div.p: THis Chapter I have annexed to the former as an Appendix, for the eae and good of Souldiers; wherein ome things will occurr, not inferiour to thoe that have preceded. But herein I have kept no order, but et them down promicuouly, yet faithfully, to upply what may have been omitted before.

If you be troubled with the Tooth-ach, coming from the cold in winter, take the root of Pyrethrum (Pellitory of Spain) and boil it in Vinegar, and hold this Vinegar warm in your mouth, and it will draw out the phlegm that caues the pain. Or, take the root of Elder, boil it in half Wine and half Water, and hold it warm upon the Teeth. But what you take of this Decoction mut be often pit out, and other freh taken into you mouth; of which I have found wonderful Effects.
The root of Heath boiled together with the ame herb in wine, and laid on is eteem'd to be powerful in drawing out thorns and plinters.
You may make a good Ointment againt the Itch and Scabs, of Savin, tale Fat, Brimtone and Juniper-berries Oyl.

If your Limbs after long icknes be weak, boil Valerian-roots in Camomil-oyl, and anoint uch Limbs therewith. Alo the Oyl of Lillies in the valley, and that of yellow Violets, is good for the ame purpoe.
For worms in the Fingers, bruie Paricaria (Armart,) and lay it on; or take of a Piggs Bladder of Gall, and put it on the affected Finger like a Thimble.

If you have any coagulated or congealed blood in your Breat, make a Decoction of Scabious, Chervil, and Germander, in two parts of wine, one part of water; and train it, and drink of it mornings and evenings.

Againt the putrefaction of the Mouth, make a Decoction of Privet in water, adding afterwards a little Allum to it, and ue it for a gargarim. Alo a Decoction of the middle rind of Hawthorn, with a little Allum, is of great effect in the ame cae.

Cabbage and Colewort-leaves burnt to ahes and a Lixivium made of it, and clapp'd on, cureth a Gangrene, and the wild Fire, epecially if you mingle a little Oyl of Elder therewith. If you can have no Elder-blooms for this Oyl, take the green middle rind of Elder, and boil it in Oyl Olive, and then train the Oyl; which done, take freh rind of Elder, and proceed with it as before, repeating it three or four times to make the Oyl the tronger. You may add a little wine to it whilt 'tis boiling, but that mut all boil away, and
o long till the Oyl cracks no more in the fire.

p.hi: Southern-wood
p.U: tamped with greae and laid on, draweth out plinters.

div.p: If you have the Itch or are cabby, and can light upon ome water tanding in the hollownes of a Beech-tree, wah your elf with it. Or make a Decoction of the brown rind of Alder, (which is under the gray,) in Butter, and anoint your elf with it; mixing, if you will a little Brimtone therewith.

If you be troubled with the Ring-worm, or any running Scab, infue Litharge in Vinegar, and let it tand a night infued, or make a Decoction of the ame in Vinegar. But your pain or veel mut be of bras. This Vinegar mingle with Oyl of Elder, or of Roes, or the like, and it will become a fine gray Salve, curing uch running Scabs as aforeaid, and cooling alo Inflammations.

If your Body be bound, take Sage pulveried and mix it with greae, and anoint your Navil with the quantity of a hael-nut of it. This I have with very good ucces advied to women in child-bed, that were thus bound and obtructed. If you will have it tronger, mix with it the Gall of a Fih or of any Animal whatoever; but then you mut not give it to a woman in child-bed.

Gromel (by the Latins call'd Milium Solis) pulveried, and the weight of half a ducat of it taken in wine or broath, provoketh urine; yet mut the belly be open'd firt. The ame doth Linaria or Toad-flax, boiled in wine
or broath. Likewie ditilled water of Radihes, repeating the ditillation everal times from other freh Radihes. Which will have the better effect, if the Patient bath his lower parts in a bath made of Marh-mallows, Melilot, and the like.

Gromel, above-mention'd, taken in warm broath, expels the birth: And o do the blooms or buds of Walnut-trees; Crabs-eyes alo, pulveried and taken in warm broath; likewie Iop boiled in wine, and drank warm. This I have inerted for the ake of poor Souldiers-wives, who amongt us often follow the Camp. If they have any great After-pains, let them bath their lower parts in a Bath made of Dill, and Camomil-flowers. And the yolks of hard Eggs, beaten together with ome convenient Oyl (Nut-oyl is the bet,) and a Plaiter made of it, and laid to the belly, is alo very good. If they have too great a profuion of blood, let them take a drachm of burnt Harts-horn, and burnt Ivory, in a convenient Vehicle.

In cae of a mortal wound, take of pure Turpentine four ounces, wah it with freh limpid water, and then diolve it over a mild fire; which done, mix with it two ounces or two ounces and an half of white Wax, diolved apart: To this add about three ounces of Womans milk, which is ucked by a Boy. The Turpentine and Wax being omewhat cooled together, mut be well tirr'd, and then poured on cold Vinegar; whence, when 'tis brought to a conitence, it is to be taken off, and made into a Plaiter, and o laid on.
Hore-tail (in Latin, Equietum) heals the wounds in the urinary parts, the powder of it being taken in broath or Speedwel-water, or the Decoction thereof being drank.
Gummi Ammoniac is a good dicutient of hard Tumors and Knobs: Tacamahaca appeaeth pain proceeding from cold, being laid on the part affected.

To make the pellets ued to be put in wounds that are to be kept open, (which here in Germany we call Quellmaiel,) take a Spunge of the finet ort, put it in Whites of Eggs well beaten and mixed with Roe-water, to make the aid Spunge imbibe this moiture. Which done, bind it cloe together with thred, and let it well dry in the Air, and o convey of it into the wound that is to be kept open: where it will well again, and o ditend the wound.

If you be troubled with the Gonorrhaea, take Houe-leek growing on old walls (call'd by the Latins, Semper vi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ninus,) put it into your hoes, and go bare-foot upon it; anoint your loyns and privy parts with Henbane-oyl; and take mornings the quantity of two big hael-nuts of well wahed Turpentine, for ome days together, avoiding all aromatic, hard, and alt meat.

An old Experimenter hath noted, That whooever hall wah his head twice a week with a Lixivium made of Juniper-ahes, his ight hall never fail him, but remain good to his end; nor hall that peron be troubled with any vermin upon his head, nor with any headach, nor uffer any change of his hair. For my
part, I never tryed it; but it being a very plain and afe thing, I thought good here to inert it.
Againt the biting of a Mad-dog, lay Aa foetida with Garlick upon the bite; it will draw out the venom.

To free your elf from the Gravel, make a Decoction of Ah-wood in wine, and drink of it warm once or twice a day upon an empty tomach; uing withal good baths. Vervin alo the leaves and roots, beaten together, and drank, is very good in this cae.

If you have a trong breath, proceeding from a foul tomach, infue Wormwood and Carduus benedictus, together with ome Citron-peels in in wine, and let them boil a little therein, and then drink a good draught of it mornings. Chew alo and wallow ometimes a little Myrrh, and take now and then three or four Aloes-pills.

I could add many other things, if my leiure would permit: Thee which I have et down, you will take in good part; and though I have not tryed them all my elf, yet you may ret aured, that uch as have not been experimented by my elf, have been tryed by my honoured Collegues and other honet perons, and approv'd.
